narrative: On December 11, 2020 at 3:00pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emelyn Sanchez P. made an announced visit to The House of Bethesda for the purpose of conducting a Case Management- Licensee Initiated (Pre-Licensing) inspection visit. LPA Sanchez P. met with Dr. Aline Smith, Facility Administrator and Robert Smith, Facility Director who granted access to the facility and a toured was conducted. The facility will be licensed to provide care and supervision to six (6) children ages 13 through 17. Ambulatory only. There are no bodies of water on the premises. The census today is zero (0). The home is set up as follows: This is a one story house with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room, family room, staff office, dining area, kitchen/laundry area, and outdoor space. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition there is one sofa, a desk with a operating computer and a locked file cabinet. Family Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition there is one love seat and one sofa, a desk with a operating computer, center table, a covered fire place, and an operating sliding door that exits out into the left side of the home. Staff Office: Located to the right of the family room. There is a desk with a operating computer, fax machine, and closet space. All medication will be kept double locked in the staff office inside a locked box. Dining Area: One table with six (6) chairs. Kitchen/Laundry Area: There is a stove/oven with four (4) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave and two refrigerators/freezers. The food service in the home will be adequate with perishable/nonperishable food supplies. There is a fire extinguisher located to the right once entering the kitchen. Trash can has a tight lid on. All cleaning supplies are kept locked in cabinets above the washer and dryer. The knives are kept locked in the kitchen cabinet and will be made accessible only to employees. Bedroom #1: Is vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #2: Is vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Bedroom #3: Is vacant. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. One (1) bathroom is located inside the staff office and the other bathroom is located next to Bedroom #3. The bathroom located inside the staff office will only be used by the facility staff. All bathrooms were checked and were in operating conditions. The faucets that are used by the children were tested and delivered hot water at a safe temperature range. There are security bars on the windows in Bedroom #1 and #3. The emergency release handle is in working conditions. Outdoor Space: LPA Sanchez P. observed the entrance area and backyard to be free of debris and hazardous materials. Garage: The detached garage will be kept locked and will only be used for storage space. LPA Sanchez P. also observed a freezer that will be used to store extra food. The home was inspected and the following was observed: The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are inaccessible to children in care. No more than two (2) children will share a bedroom. Children have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. Outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives are stored in a locked cabinet and inaccessible to children. Staff will conduct a sharps count to ensure all sharp objects are returned and locked in the lock box. Adequate supervision will be provided for children in care. Staff will ensure three nutritious meals and snacks. Food supply will be ample in the home. Children will be accorded personal rights. Children in care will be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care will be able to contact the licensing agency or Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. All posting requirements were met. Children in care will not be restricted in telephone use except by court order. There is a working telephone line available for clients to use. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable and meet statutory requirements. The home will operate within capacity and limitations of license. LPA Sanchez P. observed age appropriate First Aid supplies. However, LPA Sanchez P. encouraged Licensee to obtain a regular thermometer to have instead of the disposable thermometers located inside the first aid kit. Also, fire extinguishers require service. There was no deficiencies cited at this time of the visit. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be mailed or e-mailed to the facility for signature due to COVID-19 restrictions.

On December 17, 2021 at 9:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Daphne Edison made an announced visit to The House of Bethesda for the purpose of conducting a Case Management (Post Licensing) inspection visit. This was a follow-up visit which took place on November 12, 2021 at the above location in which no one was at the home. LPA Edison met with Robert Smith, Licensing Executive Director who granted access to the facility and a tour was conducted. The home is licensed to provide care and supervision to six (6) children, ages 13 -17 years old, ambulatory only. There is a provisional license with an expiration date of May 4, 2022. There is no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The census today is zero (0). The home is set up as follows: This is a one story house with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room, two (2) staff offices, dining area, kitchen/laundry area, and outdoor space. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a sofa and desk with an operable computer. Staff Office #1: Located off of the living room. There is a desk with an operable computer, fax machine, and closet space. All medications kept will be double locked in the staff office inside of a locked box. Staff Office #2: Located to the right of Staff Office #1. There is a desk with an operable computer, fax machine, and closet space. Dining Area: There is one table with six (6) chairs. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C. Kitchen/Laundry Area: There is a working stove/oven with four (4) gas burners, and two refrigerators/freezers. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher located to the right once entering the kitchen. The kitchen trash can have a tight lid on it. All cleaning supplies will be kept locked in cabinets above the washer and dryer. The knives will be kept locked in the kitchen cabinet and will only be accessible to employees. Hot water is delivered at a safe temperature range. Bedroom #1: Is vacant and furnished with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. The beds have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. The windows have security bars with a working emergency release handle. Bedroom #2: Is vacant and furnished with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. The beds have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. Bedroom #3: Is vacant and furnished with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and lighting in this room. The beds have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows which are all in good repair. The windows have security bars with a working emergency release handle. Bathroom #1: (Located in Staff office #2) Clean and operable at the time of visit. Hot water is delivered at a safe temperature range. Bathroom #2: (Located next to Bedroom #3). Clean and operable at the time of visit. Hot water is delivered at a safe temperature range. Outdoor Space: LPA Edison observed the entrance area and backyard to be free of debris and hazardous materials. Garage: The detached garage is kept locked and is only used for storage space. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There are storage cabinets in the hallway where extra linens will be kept. Medicines, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions will be inaccessible to children in care. No more than two (2) children will share one bedroom. There are no weapons in the facility. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked cabinet and inaccessible to children. Staff will ensure all sharp objects are returned and locked in the lock sharps box. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable and meet statutory requirements. All fire extinguishers are fully charged. LPA Edison observed age appropriate First Aid supplies which also contains tweezers and a thermometer. The home is expected to operate within the capacity and limitations of the license. Currently, there are no clients or staff at the facility. Facility is still waiting to receive CARF accreditation and mental health certification and does not expect to have staff or clients return until July 2022. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at the site visit Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the facility.

Bathroom #1: (Located in Staff Office #2) Equipped with a toilet, bathtub/shower combination. Safe and sanitary operating condition. Bathroom #2: Equipped with a toilet, bathtub/shower combination. Safe and sanitary operating condition. Outdoor Space: Entrance area is free of debris and hazardous materials. Backyard: Free of debris and hazardous materials. Garage: The detached garage is kept locked and is only used for storage space. The facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There are storage cabinets in the hallway where extra linens will be kept. Disinfectants, and cleaning solutions will be kept in the laundry area in locked cabinets inaccessible to children in care. There are no weapons in the facility. All medications kept will be double locked in the staff office inside of a locked box. investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Jessica Ford. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients which revealed that staff left youth unsupervised and an uncleared adult was supervising youths. On April 4, 2020, a client (see 811 for confidential names) was taken to the hospital for an assessment. While at the hospital, the staff (S1) accompanying the client became concerned of a potential COVID-19 exposure. As a result of this concern, S1 left the client unsupervised at the hospital and contacted the facility for someone to replace her. According to interviews, there was only one staff on shift back at the house. Due to the facility being short staffed, S2 left the home to cover S1 but asked her boyfriend to cover S2's shift at the house. S2's boyfriend did not have a background check record clearance or exemption with the Department on this date but was approved to cover the shift by the Administrator under the presumption of the statewide waivers due to COVID-19. S2's boyfriend stayed with residents alone for a few hours until S2 returned with the client. Although the Department did issue statewide waivers for background check requirements due to COVID-19 (PIN 20-04), Administrator did not follow the terms and conditions set forth in PINs 20-04 and 20-09. The boyfriend's presence at the facility on April 4, 2020 was not approved by the Department because there no written waiver submitted as required by PINs 20-04 and 20-09. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email due to COVID restrictions. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced Case Management visit, via telephone as a result of Covid-19 related restrictions and spoke with Administrator Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the phone call was to discuss the facility's Needs and Services Plan (NSP) LPA obtained several NSP from current and previous clients placed in the home. Based on record review, the NSP are not in compliance with the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards. LPA observed the NSP lacked written approval from the child or authorized representative; lacked information regarding services necessary to meet the clients' needs. Additionally, the NSP modifications did not include the facility's recommendation regarding the feasibility of the child's return to a less restrictive family-like setting; the need for modification in services and the progress of the child toward a transfer goal. All the NSP reviewed by LPA contained the same information with no changes in the language. Based on the information obtained, the facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six regulations 87068.2 and 87068.3. A copy of this report and appeal rights were sent via email to Administrator for signature.

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients as well as reviewed documents which revealed that staff failed to protect youth from being harmed by other residents. On 09/16/2020, staff were not supervising clients when a fight broke out between two clients in the home. The tension between the clients continued and escalated to another fight outside the home involving four clients which again, staff did not prevent or intervene. The documentation obtained does not demonstrate the efforts made by the facility staff to de-escalate the first fight in the home; prevent clients from leaving the home; or what was done to prevent any further incidents between the clients. Based on the information obtained, staff failed to protect youth. Based on LPA's observations, interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced Case Management visit, via telephone as a result of Covid-19 related restrictions and spoke with Administrator Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the phone call was to discuss a few concerns on the facility. LPA discussed the following with Administrator: Runaway Plan, Emergency Intervention Plan (EIP), staff training, admission determination and procedures, reporting requirements and supervision concerns. LPA conducted a thorough review of the facility's staff training records, incident reports and the facility's plan of operation and program statement as well as interviewed staff and Administrator. Based on record review, staff training records do not include training received on physical and psychosocial needs of children, including behavior management, de-escalation techniques and trauma-informed crisis management planning as required by regulation 87065.1 (c)(3)(X). Training records do not demonstrate how much time is spent on this required topic. According to training records, staff receive ongoing training from Managing Aggressive Behavior (MAB) however the Program Statement states training is to be provided by Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI). The MAB training is not in compliance with the regulations as it was not approved by the Department prior to implementation as required by regulation 87095.22(c). next page... Additionally, facility is not following the Plan of Operation and Program Statement in the following sections as required by regulation 87022(f): Staff training plan- facility does not provide some of the training listed in Section D, page 4-12. Admission process and procedures- facility is not completing pre-screening triage and assessments to determine the appropriateness of placement as stated in Section F, page 2. EIP- facility does not utilize manual restraints as an emergency intervention when a resident is in imminent danger of self-harm or harm to others in the home as stated in the Program Statement Section 22, page 6. After a review of the facility's Law Enforcement contact reports and service calls from the local police department, it was revealed the facility is under reporting incidents and late reporting to the Department as required by regulation 87061(k)(1). Late reporting has been addressed with facility on several occasions. LPA discussed with Administrator concerns over staff's supervision on youth due to a few incidents that occurred in the home. An incident report emailed to the Department where staff provided youth with a cleaning product to complete chores. Staff did not supervise youth who later drank some of the disinfectant spray in attempt to self-harm. Youth was taken to the ER for ingestion of a toxin. On another occasion, a youth obtained access to a facility phone in the middle of the night and made unapproved and unsupervised phone calls. Based on incident reports and interviews, staff did not supervise youth on these occasions as part of their duties and required by regulation 87065.2(b)(1). The facility is being cited for the deficiencies listed above. The plan of correction discussed with Administrator will also include a submission of an updated Plan of Operation and Program Statement to the Department for approval. A copy of this report and appeal rights were sent via email to Administrator for signature.

The Department has investigated the complaint alleging staff do not ensure that minors in care participate in school and facility is not meeting minor's mental health needs. As far as mental health needs, the STRTP was recently approved for in-home mental heatlh services but is contracted with the county to provide mental health services. C1 was attending therapy sessions regularly although is it unclear if there was a delay in the services. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to provide the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cynthia Galindo, and Vanessa Galvan traveled to Inspiring Pathways in Hanford, California. LPAs met with Administrator Shannon Blanchard and inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 72 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. There is no pool and no pets at the facility. LPAs reviewed client and staff files. LPAs interviewed two clients and two staff. Deficiencies were cited on todays visit, see LIC809-D. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection

Deficiencies were cited on todays visit, see LIC809-D. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection.

narrative: On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with direct care staff Zelisa Gayton. The purpose of the inspection was to clear a POC and discuss a few concerns observed during a previous an unannounced visit. LPA spoke with one client who was in the kitchen. LPA observed the menu to be in the office but staff explained that she was working on today's menu but it's usually placed in the kitchen. LPA asked staff if there were any recent hires. Staff said yes, Administrator hired two new staff, one has started working at the home and the other person is pending background check. There are no deficiencies to be cited on todays visit. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection.

2. Staff driving foster children with suspended license: A staff member admitted that her license had been suspended. She stated that she had notified the Administrator that she was not allowed to drive but stated she could not provide dates of when the suspension was in effect. Staff member has since provided valid license and plan of correction will be cleared at today's visit. This is a TYPE A violation 3. Facility staff did not safeguard a foster child's funds. In this particular case while the client's regular allowance and clothing allowance were accounted for, her personal funds that had been stored in the locked box came up short. Staff stated that tracking the client's personal funds has been an issue in the past. The Administrator replaced the missing funds. This is a TYPE B violation. TYPE A violations pose an immediate risk to the health and safety of the clients in care while TYPE B violations pose a potential risk to the health and safety of the clients in care. Based on the LPA's observations, interviews and records review which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the above allegations are found to be substantiated. A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to Zelisa Gayton

narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo traveled to Inspiring Pathways in Hanford, California. LPA met with Administrator Shannon Blanchard and facility manager Natalia Yado inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 72 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed. Accreditation is valid until July 31, 2022. STRTP was approved on May 2, 2019. The MHPA was approved since May 7, 2022. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. There is no pool and no pets at the facility. LPAs reviewed client and staff files. LPAs interviewed one client and four staff. Deficiencies were cited on todays visit, see LIC809-D. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection

On this date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cynthia Galindo, Reyna Martinez and Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at the Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to issue deficiencies. LPA conducted a file review of a youth who was discharged from the STRTP due to injuring another youth during a fight. The file did not contain a Crisis Management Assessment that is required to be done either prior or immediately after placement. Also missing from the file was the removal notice given by the STRTP to the county requesting the youth be placed elsewhere as required by ILS 87068(e)(2)(A)(1)-(6). Based on LPA's observations, California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached 809D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients as well as obtained relevant documents. Interviews and documents reveal that youth accessed a sharp object that was used to injure another youth during a fight. On April 16, 2022, staff provided the youth with an eyebrow razor and when the eyebrow razor was returned later that day, the blade was missing. Interviews confirm that staff was aware that the blade was missing but yet no attempts were made to locate the blade. Staff did not provide the proper care and supervision by locating the missing blade after becoming aware that it was missing. The next day, the same youth who returned the eyebrow razor with the missing blade, got into that fight with another youth and staff did not intervene. The youth sustained injuries during the fight. Staff failed to protect the youth by not stopping the fight. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Additional citations are being issued on a Case Management. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 90

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients as well as obtained relevant documents. Confidential interviews and documents reveal that facility staff did not notify responsible parties of the minor's day pass. On July 11, 2022, minor was authorized by the court a day pass with bio family. Interviews confirm that facility staff allowed minor to leave the home however, staff did not notify the county social worker or probation officer. Additionally, on June 24, 2022, minor was granted a day pass by the facility without notifying responsible parties. According to the facility's Program Statement, section 13, Family Visitation, "all off-site passes, including overnights, must be approved by the authorized representative/placement agency and IP treatment staff". As a result, facility is in violation of their Program Statement. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 90

13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Shannon Blanchard. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and clients as well as obtained relevant documents. Confidential interviews and documents reveal that facility was not aware of minor's whereabouts and staff did not check ID when minor was picked up for a day pass. On July 11, 2022, minor was authorized a day pass with bio family. When the minor was picked up, staff did not ensure minor was picked up by only authorized individuals according to the minor's Needs and Services Plan as they did not verify identification. Facility staff assumed minor was picked up by bio family and would spend the time with bio family. However, interviews reveal minor was not picked up by bio family and did not spend the time with bio family. As a result, facility staff did not know minor's true whereabouts and allowed minor to leave the facility with an unauthorized individual. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 90

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a complaint inspection at Inspiring Pathways and met with Natalia Yado. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff and obtained relevant documents which revealed that facility staff mismanaged youth's medications while in care. Confidential interviews confirm that staff gave youth the medication she arrived with and was provided by the county social worker. Youth was placed in the home on August 17, 2022 and was discharged from the home on September 13, 2022. The facility received a copy the JV223 that was granted on July 19, 2022 after youth was placed in the home. A copy of the JV223 was obtained from the facility but only consisted of two pages with no list of the medication prescribed. Medication records are consistent with the medication the youth received during her stay at the home. However, the youth's Needs and Service Plan for August lists a different set of medication which does not match the medication records. According to the JV220 an JV220 attachment provided by the CSW, the medication listed on the NSP was the correct medication that was prescribed and should have been given to the youth. The facility staff did not confirm with the county social worker the medication the youth was to take according to the JV223 that was granted on July 2022. Based on LPA's observations and interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 90

On this date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cynthia Galindo and Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Inspiring Pathways. LPAs met with Shannon Blanchard and Natalia Yado. The visit is part of the Non-compliance meeting agreement that took place on 08/24/2021. LPAs reviewed seven staff files, focusing on new hire training, ongoing training and Emergency Intervention training as well as minium personnel qualifications. LPA Galindo inquired about the biannual review that was due last month. Administrator stated she was unaware of the due date and vaguely remembers having a conversation with LPA Galindo about it's submission to the Department every six months. Administrator stated she will get it done within the next week and will submit to the Department every six months. The facility's Plan of Operation and Program Statement updates are currently being reviewed by SOC and CCL. A technical violation is being issued for the biannual review and citations are being issued for the discrepancies found in today's staff file review. Note, the review of staff files is not complete and LPAs will return at a later date to finish reviewing the remaining staff files. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

Licensee stated that as the Plan of Correction, the training would be completed and proof will be provided by 02/16/2023. Licensee did not submit their proof by the deadline. On this date, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cynthia Galindo and Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management (CM) inspection at Inspiring Pathways. LPAs met with Shannon Blanchard and Natalia Yado. The visit is a continuation from the last CM on 02/02/2023. LPAs finished reviewing all staff files. LPAs found that all files did not have the 7 day or 30 day training assessment for new hires. The new staff files did not have the required education and experience requirement in the file. The files lacked documentation of successful completion of job shadowing. Adminstrator is currently updating the Plan of Operation and Program Statement. LPA Galindo discussed with Administrator the following: -proper documentation for new staff training including the training assessments - STRTP ILS version 4 - documenting the job shadowing in the staff files - the requirement to have at least one facility manager to be present at all times -updating the training chart - support staff vs direct care staff - documenting staff's qualifications in their file Based on the information obtained, the facility is being cited. A copy of the report is being emailed to the Administrator as well as the appeal rights.

narrative: Identified within the special incident report (SIR) submitted on 7/11/2020 by facility; C1 was taken on a personal outing to the dollar store to buy a notebook. At the time of leaving the store C1 got upset with staff and started walking away from staff disappearing into the store. Staff paid for items and walked outside of the store and C1 was not present. Before leaving the store staff notified local law enforcement and overseeing agencies. Staff left the store but returned to the store to pick up C1 after receiving a call from C1's family identifying C1's whereabouts. Interviews conducted with staff state that C1 hid from staff and staff was unable to be located at the time of the incident. Staff denied leaving C1 stranded or locking C1 out of the facility or vehicle. Based on interviews with C1, C1 stated she did not want to talk about the incident or anything pertaining to time in facility. Documents provided by facility show staff receiving required training in reasonable prudent parenting, trauma care and medications. Interviews conducted with other children in facility identify home and staff as being attentive, present and available to assist children with their needs. Statements made during confidential interviews and documents reviewed do not corroborate with complaint allegations. LPA was unable to ascertain whether or not child was stranded at store or if child ran away. Additionally, LPA was unable to identify an incident or occurrence where C1 or any child was locked out of the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or may be true there is not a preponderance of evidence to identify that the allegations did or did not happen; therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator for signature and review.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/4/2020 at 2: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha telephoned the James Penny House Inc. for the purpose of concluding the above complaint investigation. LPA spoke with Administrator Robert Carter and discussed the following complaint findings. Investigation consisted of the following: On 7/23/ LPA conducted initial 10-day investigation and interviewed manager and two (2) children (see confidential names LIC811 dated, 7/23/2020). LPA attempted to interview other children however, children declined interview with LPA. On 7/31/2020 and 8/12/ LPA received documents requested from facility. On 8/22/ LPA reviewed documents received. LPA attempted to contact social worker to identified child. LPA was unable to contact social worker and was declined interview with child #1. Investigation revealed the following: Based on interviews conducted and information provided it is not clear that staff stranded child #1 (C1) or that C1 was locked out of the facility. Interviews conducted with staff and management identify an incident occurring where C1 was left for a brief time at the local dollar tree store. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: One client who was allegedly hit and yelled at moved to a lockdown facility and LPA was not granted permission by client's guardian to conduct an interview. LPA attempted to interview additional clients who were allegedly yelled at and threatened but attempts were unsuccessful. LPA's calls to the guardian of one client were not returned while another client is AWOL and whereabouts are unknown. One client interviewed refused to address the allegations but stated that client had no issues with staff and other clients during placement, and that there was no issue with food. Staff denied hitting and yelling at clients. Staff reported that clients were questioned by law enforcement during AWOL and then brought back to the facility by staff. Clients were upset and threatened to call licensing. Staff reported that one client made the call. Staff stated they were redirecting clients prior to AWOL but clients were non complaint. Another staff denied yelling and making threats towards clients. Staff reported engaging positively with clients and redirects clients when they exhibit negative behavior. Statements obtained from other clients interviewed did not support the allegations. Clients reported not being aware of the allegations and claimed no maltreatment by staff and no issues with food. LPA observed adequate perishable and non-perishable food supply during the unannounced inspection. Photos were taken by LPA for proof of facility meeting regulatory requirements. Staff informed LPA that meals are prepared based on the menu and that there are options available to clients who refuse any meal served. Clients are encouraged to participate in menu preparation. Staff follow the posted menu but are open to accommodating requests during meal preparation, with concurrence from all clients. LPA did not find evidence to support the allegations in interviews with other parties and during the records review. Based on information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations was not met, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were emailed to the facility representative. LPA requested for the licensing report to be reviewed, signed and emailed back to LPA. There was no deficiency citation issued.

investigation_findings: 13On March 5, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, emailed the complaint findings to Administrator, Calissa Walker. On October 5, 2020, the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Office (RO) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: one staff, Danyelle Jones, Unit Coordinator, via telephone on March 5, 2021; one Client (see Confidential Names, LIC Ref. #1 dated March 5, 2021) via telephone on February 26, 2021; and one County Social Worker (CSW) via telephone on February 24, 2021. The LPA reviewed the special incident reports, the needs and services plan and the Client Personal Property and Valuables forms. The investigation revealed that the facility policy includes the gathering of a client's belongings from their bedroom and storing them in the office when the client runs away so that the client's roommate will not go through and take things from the client's items. It revealed that when the client returns to the facility, the items are returned to the client. The investigation revealed that Ref. #1 received their belongings from the staff when Ref. #1 returned from being awol. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Clients became hostile and threatened first responders. One client attempted to vandalize first responders' vehicles. One of the staff went to the hospital only after the situation at the facility calmed down. No other staff reported for duty to assist. In addition, the facility plan of operation show that staff is to either accompany a client or follow the ambulance when a client has to be transported to an emergency facility. Based on information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard was met, therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Deficiencies are being cited under STRTP General Regulations Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87065.5 (g) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. It was revealed that alcohol and drugs are not allowed at the facility and these are confiscated if found by staff. Based on information obtained, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there was no preponderance of evidence found to support it. A copy of this signed report, the LIC 811 (Confidential Names dated 7/23/21) and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of the inspection.

On August 9, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Herring, Juliet Robles and Raymond Wu conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 10: AM. LPAs met with Danielle Bell, Facility Manager (FM). The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP's Mental Health Program Application is pending approval. The STRTP has not submitted an application for National Accreditation. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 11-17 years of age. The facility also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are four (4) ambulatory minors and one(1) ambulatory non-minor dependent currently in placement. This facility is a one-story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, one (1) office, kitchen, dining, formal living rooms, and family room. Physical Plant The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are locked in a walk-in closet located in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in the office. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 115 degrees F. All toilets, handwashing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. Operations Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. The board of directors regularly conducts meeting to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. Cash resources are kept on the facility premises in a locked and secure location. Client Records All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. LPAs interviewed two(2) clients during the inspection. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. One(1) Type A Deficiency cited during this inspection. LPAs provided three (3) Advisory Notes-Technical Violation (LIC9102TV) and one (1) Advisory Notes-Technical Assistance (LIC 9102TA). Appeal rights provided. An Annual/Required Continuation inspection is required. An exit interview was completed and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

On August 10, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Herring and Raymond Wu conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility at 9: AM. LPAs met with Danyelle Jones, Unit Coordinator and Robert Carter, STRTP Director. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a Case Management - Annual Continuation inspection of the facility. During this inspection, LPAs reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan, Emergency and Disaster Preparedness Plan, and Staff Records. Emergency Intervention Plan Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPAs observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. The drills are documented and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Staff Records LPAs reviewed seven(7) personnel records. All individuals subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and signed a Criminal Record Statement. Personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. Personnel records contain documentation of 24-hour initial training, and 40-hour annual training in addition to CPR and First Aid. This inspection reveals that seven (7) out of 7 personnel records reviewed by LPAs, do not contain health screening and TB test documents. There are two(2) Type B deficiencies cited and two (2) Advisory Notes-Technical Violation (LIC9102TV) provided during this inspection. Appeal rights provided. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

On 9/09/21 at 4: PM PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Herring arrived at the facility named above for the purpose of interviewing two clients in order to complete the SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection initiated on 8/17/21. C1 and C2 were not available for interview during the previous inspection. (See Confidential Name/s list (LIC811) provided on 8/17/21.) LPA met with Raeanna Howard, Unit Coordinator. LPA completed SB 484 client interviews. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative.

It was alleged that at least one staff member (S1; See LIC Confidential Names Form) at the facility failed to meet the needs of one client (C1) in care. More specifically, it was alleged that the staff member failed to take C1's comments seriously during an incident in which they were in a mental crisis. No injuries were sustained although C1 was taken to the hospital as a precaution. In interviews conducted with clients in the home, the clients all stated that they felt safe in the home and felt that the staff were able to meet their needs. The clients all denied feeling dismissed by the staff members in the facility and any time issues were brought up were addressed in a timely manner. In an interview conducted with C1, C1 stated that S1 was their favorite staff member in the facility and denied ever feeling dismissed by S1. S1 was always helpful and took their comments seriously. In interviews conducted with staff, the above comments were corroborated. S1 stated that on the date of the incident, they stayed with C1 the whole time that they were in a state of crisis and played games with them to try and redirect them per their individualized safety plan. S1 denied being dismissive of C1's feelings and stated that the facility had procedures in place to try and redirect clients in crisis prior to calling emergency services. An interview conducted with the facility social worker confirmed these statements. The social worker stated that they had never seen or heard of any staff members in the home being dismissive of clients and they had no concerns about it. Comments made by clients during times of crisis were always taken seriously. A review of C1's Needs and Services Plan and Admissions Agreement confirmed that C1 was known to have episodes of mental crisis and that attempts to redirect them prior to calling emergency services was standard. Based on interviews, redirection procedures for C1 involved constant supervision, board games, car rides, and more. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the above allegation occurred. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met. Therefore, the allegations are deemed UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report, along with the Licensee's Appeal Rights (LIC 9058 01/16) was provided to the Licensee.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection 08/09/22 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 08/09/2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara and LPM Angela King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Calissa Walker, Administrator.

narrative: It was alleged that staff members (S1, S3) made inappropriate comments while minors were present and encouraged the client (C1) to fight another client residing in the home. Staff (S1, S2, S3) denied the alleged allegations further indicating that all staff members are trauma-informed and understand the importance for each client to complete their individualized program. Staff further indicated that they have not heard nor have clients reported to them any incidents regarding staff using inappropriate language. All staff members denied encouraging anyone to fight, however, further disclosed that an incident occurred involving two clients (C1, C5) who were involved in a physical altercation outside of the facility. S1 further indicated that they were transporting C1 in the vehicle and received a call from another staff member (S2) informing them that C5 had just gone AWOL. S1 indicated that on the way back to the facility they observed C5 less than a block away from the facility, so they (S1) stopped to verbally redirect C5, and in doing so, C1 jumped out of the vehicle and started an altercation with C5. S1 indicated that she attempted to verbally redirect the clients but was not having any luck, so S1 called another staff member (S2) who assisted in separating the clients and taking them back to the facility without any further disruption. An incident report was completed, and all supporting agencies were notified in a timely manner. Information obtained from the above clients denied the alleged allegations further indicating the clients are the ones who threaten and use foul language toward staff when upset. Clients indicated that the staff does a good job of avoiding shouting matches and de-escalating situations that may arise in the facility between clients. Clients further stated that they feel safe and supported by the staff members at the facility. Clients denied that staff encourage them to fight each other. C1 further disclosed that she did get into an altercation outside the facility with a former client (C5). C1 indicated that they were being transported by S1 back to the facility and they had stopped to pick up C5 who had just gone AWOL. C1 stated that she got out of the car and started a verbal altercation with C5 which turned physical and was separated by S1 and S2. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Facility Administrator.

narrative: Page The investigation of the above allegation was conducted by LPA Winston Moroney, and it consisted of but was not limited to a review of records, including the client's needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with three staff members (S1, S2, S3) on 10/21/22, four clients (C1, C2, C3, C4) on 10/28/22, and the CSW on 11/2/22. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated February 10, 2023). It was alleged that the facility staff handled a client (C4) in a rough manner while trying to redirect them resulting in staff pushing the client into a wall and hitting said client with an object. Information obtained from staff members (S1, S2, S3) denied the alleged allegations further indicating that all staff members are trauma informed and understand the importance of maintaining a healthy relationship with all clients and supporting them in successfully completing their individual programs. Facility staff further indicated that the facility is a hands-off facility and will only place hands on a client to prevent self-harm or bodily harm to others. Staff further disclosed that an incident involving (S3) and C4 occurred on 9/23/22 where (C4) had taken the cell phone into their room knowing that their CSW had informed staff that (C4) was not allowed to use their cellphone unless being supervised by a staff member. S4 indicated that supervision was required due to (C4) sending and receiving inappropriate messages from an unknown male. S3 indicated that when they attempted to retrieve the cell phone C4 ran into the room and began punching a hole in the wall, S4 attempted to verbally redirect and de-escalate the situation from the bedroom doorway when C4 ran and nudged S3 out of the way. S3 further disclosed that after two minutes of using verbal redirection C4 calmed down and proceeded to the living room where staff gave C4's phone back without further incident. Staff indicated that the incident was documented and sent to the appropriate agencies. Information obtained from CSW indicated that they were aware of the incident and when they spoke with C4, they didn't disclose any information indicating that everything was good and that they felt safe. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Facility Administrator.

narrative: It was alleged that the staff did not report incidents to appropriate agency, staff did not accept the client back into the facility and facility did not follow the minor's treatment plan. The Ref. #1 (see Confidential Names, LIC Ref. #1 dated February 15, 2023) was placed at the facility on 6/30/22. CCL received Special Incident Report (SIR) dated 7/1/22 stating Ref. #1 attempted to AWOL on 7/1/22 at 5: PM and brought back to the facility by Law Enforcement (LE) on 7/2/22 at 12: AM. Ref. #1 became agitated and walked out of the facility stating they were leaving the facility. Ref. #1 picked up rocks from the flower bed and began throwing rocks at staff and facility's vehicles breaking windows. LE was called and when the Officer arrived, the Officer transported the Ref. #1 to Mark K Shell for 5150 hold. At 6: AM, the Officer called and informed a staff that Ref. #1 made threats to others in the facility so the LE Officer recommended that Ref. #1 not return to the facility. The facility received a call from the hospital requesting to pick Ref. #1 up as they will be discharged. The facility did not pick Ref. #1 up from the hospital because the Ref. #1's bed was closed. The facility contacted the placement county, Fresno Social Worker, regards to discharge of the client; due to immediate danger to staff and clients in the facility, the Ref. #1's bed was closed. The Ref. #1 was placed in the facility without the medication. The facility was informed the Ref. #1's medication will be brought to the facility next day, but the medication never came. Ref. #1's CSW stated that the emergency refill was requested. Staff stated the incidents are reported to appropriate agencies and CCL. Clients interviewed stated incidents are reported to their CSWs as they knew of the incidents. Based on the information gathered, although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative via electronic mail.

narrative: On November 30, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Dawn Mahecha and Tommy Davis conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 12:45PM. LPAs met with Administrator Raeanna Howard (Admin). The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 11-17 years of age. The facility also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are three (3) ambulatory minors currently in placement. This facility is a one-story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, one (1) office, kitchen, dining, formal living rooms, and family room. Physical Plant The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are locked in a walk-in closet located in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in the office. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 126.0 degrees F warning signs were posted of temperature being over 120 degrees F. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. During this inspection LPA Davis reviewed three (3) staff files including Administrator and STRTP Director and three (3) client files. . Exit interview was conducted, no deficiencies cited and a signed copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

narrative: On 9/5/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the James Penny Short term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) for the purpose of a case management incident inspection. LPA met with Mental health coordinator and discussed the following incident: - Client communicating with elder brother 2/13/ Coordinator stated the following: Client doesn't have a phone currently and staff monitor calls. Staff ensure whoever is being called is on the line and if staff hear anything inappropriate, staff will stop the call. Social worker is aware of situation and information is documented in clients call log file. Brother was not identified originally as having restrictions with client. After client disclosed interactions with brother to Administrator, Administrator notified social workers and CPS which received no further action. However, facility conducted prudent parenting in ensuring client did not have interactions with brother who was making inappropriate contact with client. Client had biological mother, grandma and another brother identified as supervised and approved visits. LPA requested that facility provide approved visitation log and updated CFT notes regarding clients visitations and calls. Exit interview conducted and no deficiencies were observed or cited during inspection and a copy of this report was provided to representative.

On 9/5/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the James Penny Short term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) for the purpose of a case management incident inspection. LPA met with Mental health coordinator and discussed the following incident: - client being sexually and physically abused 7/31/ Coordinator stated the following: Client doesn't get approved or denied visits with girl friend. Incident occurred in Las Vegas in May but client reported to Administrator in July. Administrator at that time called local law enforcement out and they took a report. On August 3,2024 client AWOLed from Camarillo outlets during outing and met up with girlfriend. Client returned two days later and I observed client with black eyes and client disclosed being physically abused by girlfriend. I did a scar report when client disclosed and I called local police and they stated they could not take a report due to incident occurring in Vegas. I did a SCAR report and notified social worker of incidents. Have had multiple CFTs regarding girl friend and client and client still makes contacts. LPA obtained copy of CFT notes showing that client was aware to not contact girl friend. Exit interview conducted and no deficiencies were observed or cited during inspection and a copy of this report was provided to representative.

On 9/5/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the James Penny Short term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) for the purpose of a case management incident inspection. LPA met with facility manager and discussed the following incident: -Restraint leading to bruising and bite marks on child: Facility manager stated the following: Client was hitting her head on the ground and was self inflicting injuries. Me and my coworker were holding clients arms. Me and the other staff were holding her on her arms and then we did a restraint by holding her on the ground with her arms out. Holds were approximately 20 seconds. Client wasn't getting what she wanted so she started grabbing random things to try and hurt herself so staff were trying to grab the things away from her. Client wanted to do a bunch of things and became agitated because we wouldn't let her. Client got picked up by police that night and police took her to the hospital. Client was trying to run in traffic when she noticed police. I didn't receive any medical attention for my injuries but I have received training on how to properly conduct restraints. Client was biting staff but staff were not biting client. Client is currently at behavioral hospital and will be discharged on Saturday. Three incidents occurred with client regarding client being aggressive towards staff. Staff called local police each time to address clients behavior first time police responded and found client in street, second time police didn't respond to call and third time client was taken 5150. LPA requested medical paperwork, police reports and plan moving forward for client and use of restraints. LPA requested manual restraint log of documented uses of restraints. Exit interview conducted and no deficiencies were observed or cited during inspection and a copy of this report was provided to representative.

On September 19, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brent Lockhart and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 09:45am. LPA met with Administrator Raeanna Howard (Admin). The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 11-17 years of age. The facility also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are four (4) ambulatory minors currently in placement. This facility is a one-story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, one (1) office, kitchen, dining, formal living rooms, and family room. Physical Plant The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions are locked in a cabinet located in the garage and sharps are locked in a cabinet located in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in the office. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 73 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe sanitary and in good repair. Client Records LPA and LPM reviewed four (4) client records. Client records reviewed include, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, appraisal/needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. On today's inspection, there are two (2) Type B citations issued, see LIC809D. LPA and LPM also provided (5) five Advisory Notes/Technical Violation (LIC9102TV). An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC811 and appeal rights were provided to the facility administrator.

On 3/25/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brent Lockhart conducted an unannounced visit to James Penny Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of a case management inspection. IRFU - 0001639-FN On April 11, 2025 at 10:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brent Lockhart conducted an unannounced inspection at James Penny House, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management concerning a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on April 6, 2025. During their conversation C1 disclosed she was sexually assaulted while running away. C1 didn't provide any details of the perpetrator. C1 arrived at the facility on 4/1/25, FA provided a safety plan for C1 to LPA, the plan in the process and consist of C1 participating in programs like mental health services, individual rehab and therapy so she can become more acclimated. Exit interview conducted and no deficiencies were observed or cited during inspection and a copy of this report was provided to representative.

IRFU - 0001640-FN On April 11, 2025 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brent Lockhart conducted an announced Case Management inspection regarding a death incident of a client in care from James Penny Inc. Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA met with Facility Administrator (FA) Raeanna Howard. narrative: Page The Department received a complaint alleging a client (C1) (See Confidential Names list LIC811 dated 6/5/25) sustained injuries as a result form and altercation with a staff (S1). LPA Larios was unable to obtain a statement from S1 due to expired contact information. However, record review revealed S1 denied physically abusing C1 to another agency's investigator. The victim maintained she was hit on the face and scratched on her neck by S1 resulting in injuries. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted did not support the allegation. Witnesses reported C1's behavior prompted two staff to initiate multiple restraints during the afternoon of 1/5/25. However, none of the facility clients or other staff present reported observing S1 physically abuse or hit C1. Furthermore, witnesses reported observing an altercation between C1 and another youth during the incident, where the other youth was observed hitting C1 on her head. In addition, a social worker met with C1 on 1/8/25 and described the reported eye injury as "not fresh" and a scratch on C1's neck as "closing and healing". The social worker reported the injuries could have occurred prior to the reported incident. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and record review the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. A copy of this report and LIC811 dated 6/9/25 were given to the above-mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Larios on 6/9/25, at 9: AM. During the inspection LPA Larios met with Administrator, Raeanna Howard. Information obtained from record review and interviews conducted revealed that on the afternoon of 1/5/25 incidents occurred at the facility requiring staff to restrain a client multiple times over a three-hour period. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted indicate that during this time a staff (S1) (See Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 6/9/25) obtained a water hose and sprayed a client (C1) with water due to the client's confrontational behavior. In addition, multiple witnesses reported observing S1 exchange profanities with C1 while addressing the behavior. A review of the incident report generated by the facility revealed the absence of information required by the Department including a description of the restraints used. The facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards STRTP 87072(c)(16) Personal Rights due to the client being sprayed with water and 87061(i)(7)(C) Reporting Requirements due to the absence of required information in the incident report. Refer to LIC809D for deficiency. A copy of this report, LIC811, LIC809D and appeals rights were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative.

On June 19, 2025, at 1:15 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla conducted an unannounced Case Management - Other inspection at James Penny House Inc, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to deliver an amendment to a LIC9099 originally delivered on 06/17/2025. LPA met with Raeanna Howard, Administrator. No deficiencies cited during this inspection. A signed copy of this report as well as amended report were provided to Raeanna Howard, Administrator. Exit interview conducted. No further action required.

It was alleged staff transported minors in care without providing proper accommodation. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated that when clients are transported, there are at least two staff in the car. On the day of incident, there were staff with two clients in transit. Client 1 (C1) became upset when the staff did not open the van window enough to stick their head out the window. C1 then removed their seat belt off and refused to put it back on. C1 then stood up and tried to reach for steering wheel. A staff intervened and moved to the back seat of the van and staff provided multiple redirections. C1 continued to stand up inside the van trying to reach for the steering wheel. Staff pulled over on the side of the road and that is when C1 climbed into the front seat and left the van. C1 ran into the middle of the road and staff followed and provided redirections. However, C1 refused and sat in the middle of the street and refused to get up. Law enforcement was contacted and C1 was transported to the hospital. The LPA was unable to obtain any statements from clients as they declined to be interviewed. The statements obtained from the confidential interviews did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violation occurred, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights explained and a copy of this report, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

narrative: On August 12, 2025, at 12:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles, Timika Martin and Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection at James Penny House INC, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on behalf of LPA Brent Lockhart. The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on May 21, 2025. LPAs met with Raeanna Howard, Administrator. The SIR dated May 20, 2025, indicated that C1 (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 08/12/25) was on an unauthorized absence from the STRTP. The SIR indicated that C1 was sexually assaulted by an unknown male. The SIR indicated Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) came to the facility to speak with C1 and requested she go to the hospital to take a Sexual Response Assault Team (SART) exam, as well as turn over the clothing she wore for evidence but C1 refused . S1 stated the client didn't want to cooperate because she feared the evidence would implicate another boy C1 says she had consensual sex with and she didn't want to get him in trouble. Based on document review, interviews with staff, and the Officer who came out to the facility, the STRTP offered C1 medical attention after returning from her unauthorized absence but she refused services. No deficiencies were cited against the STRTP but LPA encouraged the facility to stress preventative measures to clients and the danger of leaving the facility unsupervised. Signed copies of Licensing Reports were provided to STRTP representative.
