On August 12, 2025, at 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection at James Penny House INC, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on behalf of LPA Brent Lockhart. The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on June 16, 2025. LPA met with Raeanna Howard, Facility Manager. The SIR dated June 12, 2025, S1 noticed C1 (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 08/11/25) wanting to leave the facility and expressed to C1 the dangers of leaving the facility on an unauthorized absence from the STRTP. C1 rejected all offers by staff and left the facility on 6/12/25. Staff followed procedure by following C1 out the home and down the street before they lost sight of her. C1 never returned to the facility, when facility tried to contact C1 and encourage her to come back, C1 told the facility to stop calling her and she is fine. C1 was in communication with C2 and disclosed different locations to C2, who then disclosed that information with the facility, but couldn't confirm if the locations were valid. In addition, C1 was in contact with her CSW and expressed she was safe. According to CSW, C1 was placed with a friend of the mother on 6/20/25, and as of today is still with the family friend. C1 was discharged from the facility on 6/22/25. Based on document review, interviews with staff, and the County Social Worker, the STRTP followed proper protocols when clients leave the facility on unauthorized leave. Continued on 809-C In addition, the facility inform parents, social worker and Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) of any updates they receive regarding C1's location. No deficiencies were cited against the STRTP. Signed copies the LIC809, LIC809-C, LIC811 and Appeal Rights were provided to STRTP representative. Appeal rights explained.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on 08/26/25 at 10: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 08/26/25). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and youth safety plans, and crisis prevention intervention plan and client intake information sheet, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA, Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Raeanna Howard.

On September 11, 2025, at 10:30 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brent Lockhart conducted an unannounced Case Management - Incident inspection at James Penny House INC, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on July 30, 2025. LPA met with Glorious Maclin, Facility Manager. The SIR dated July 29, 2025, indicated that C1 (See LIC Confidential Names list dated 09/11/25) while on an unauthorized absence from the STRTP indicated that she was touched inappropriately. C1 couldn't give a day or time the incident took place. The facility encouraged C1 to talk to Bakersfield Police Department (BPD) as well as seeking medical services, but she declined both options. S1 completed a Suspected Child Abuse Report (SCAR) and submitted to C1s County Social Worker (CSW). Actions taken by the facility included increasing therapy and counseling sessions to three times a week, and other incentives thru Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings and treatment plans to cope with C1s experiences. Based on the information gathered,. No deficiencies were cited against the STRTP at this time. However, LPA encouraged the facility to stress preventative measures to clients, and the danger of leaving the facility unsupervised. Signed copies of LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to STRTP representative

Special Incident Reports (SIRs). LPA also reviewed Department databases, and reports from other agencies. On June 11, 2025, the Department received a complaint alleging that lack of staff supervision resulted in a minor engaging in inappropriate activity. It was also alleged that staff did not prevent minor from AWOLing. And lastly, it was alleged that staff did not report incident. Interviews with facility staff resulted in denials of all allegations. Staff stated that they conducted their room checks as per protocol, and that the door to the minors' rooms are usually ajar unless someone is changing in the room, allowing for extra visibility. Staff denied seeing any inappropriate activity being done by clients. Staff stated that they could not control what happened while minors were on unauthorized leave away from the facility, but that they did caution all minors against leaving for that same reason. Staff stated that redirection is used when minors attempt to leave unauthorized, but that they cannot forcibly stop any client from leaving, so they do what they can and then report accordingly to law enforcement, the client's authorized representatives and community care licensing (CCL). Staff stated that they did report what the client revealed to them upon the client's return from an unauthorized absence to appropriate authorities. Confidential interviews conducted by LPA revealed contradicting statements regarding the allegations, including whether client revealed to staff what happened during their unauthorized leave and also statements that staff do try to discourage clients from leaving through redirection, and that staff cannot place hands on clients to prevent them from leaving. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be Unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Raeanna Howard, Administrator. Appeal rights provided.

narrative: Children denied that staff allowed them to participate in illegal activities or that staff did not provide adequate supervision. Staff also deny participating or allowing illegal activities or not providing adequate supervision. Staff specified that some children take part in a drug program but that children's social workers provide drug testing weekly. Additionally, children are allowed unsupervised walks. Facility staff notify social workers when children leave facility unsupervised, however, children usually comeback within the time allotted. Staff only conduct searches if they have probable cause but do consistently conduct room searches. Staff stated that if they see children smoking or doing something illegal they immediately take action and confiscate the contraband. Administrator stated that staff are drug screened and fingerprinted and have worked in the facility for a long time. LPA did not review or receive any documents or reports that identify staff taking part in any illegal activities. Documents reviewed and information received show continued training of staff members in caring for children and all staff members currently being cleared and associated to facility. LPA was unable to corroborate complaint allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or may be true there is not a preponderance of evidence to conclude that the allegations did or did not happen. Therefore, this complaint is being closed Unsubstantiated. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was emailed to Executive Director.
investigation_findings: 13On 11/5/2020 at 4:00PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha telephoned the John and Dorothy Almklov House for the purpose of concluding complaint investigation. LPA spoke with Executive Director Robert Carter and discussed the findings to the above identified complaint investigation. Investigation consisted of the following: On 8/26/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha conducted initial inspection and interviewed Administrator, staff and five (5) children (C1-C5) (see confidential names LIC811, dated, August 27, 2020 . Additionally, LPA Jean Herring conducted on site inspection to facility. On 11/5/ LPA reviewed documents received. Investigation revealed the following: Based on interviews conducted with children, staff and other confidential entities it is unclear if staff are allowing minors to engage in illegal activities or not providing adequate supervision to minors while in care. Interviews conducted with C1-C5 identify staff being present and attentive to them in providing care and supervision. Stated in interviews with C1-C5 children identify either smoking or seeing others smoking cigarettes. Children stated if they smoke cigarettes they walk outside or down the street. On occasion they stated they tried to smoke at the facility but staff would confiscate items and immediately redirect them. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Tele-Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Herring and Gilbert Gutierrez on March 4, 2021 at 1: PM via Microsoft Teams Meeting. Remote "tele-inspection" of facilities is a part of Community Care Licensing Division's emergency response to the spread of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19). During the tele-inspection, LPAs Herring and Gutierrez spoke with Trina Smith, Facility Administrator. All pertinent staff and client records were scanned and emailed to the LPAs prior to the tele-inspection upon request. LPAs conducted a facility tour with Ms. Smith at 1: PM. Two records of clients taking psychotropic medications were reviewed at 1: PM. LPAs observed that the Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMARs) for C1 and C2 for December 2020 indicates that all AM psychotropic medications (M1, M2, M3, M4, M5, M6) were not administered on 12/13/20. S1 put her initial on the appropriate box for each PMAR and circled her initial to indicate that the medication was not given. However, S1 stated that S3 was the staff scheduled to pass medications on 12/13/20 for the AM shift and that S1 only put her initial on each PMAR form because she was the one who discovered the medication error. There was no documentation or special incident report explaining actions taken and reasons why all psychotropic medications were not administered on 12/13/20 (AM shift). LPAs inspected C2's psychotropic medications at approximately 1: PM. The administrator informed LPAs that C1 has been on a home pass since 2/14/21. C1's medications have been released to his parents, therefore, LPAs were unable to inspect C1's medications. (continued...) LPAs reviewed 2 staff files at approximately 2: PM. LPAs interviewed 1 client at approximately 2: PM. LPAs were unable to interview C1, who was on a home pass at the time of tele-inspection. LPAs interviewed 2 staff members at approximately 2: PM. LPAs reviewed the facility's Plan of Operation prior to the tele-inspection. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Trina Smith, Facility Administrator at approximately 2: PM. LPAs provided Advisory Note -Technical Violation (LIC 9102TV) and Advisory Note - Technical Assistance (LIC 9102TA). One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and cited from the California Code of Regulations, Title 22. A copy of this licensing report was provided to the licensee via email. Appeal Rights provided.

narrative: The Department received a complaint alleging Client (C1) was restrained by Staff (S1). S1 denied the allegation. The investigation revealed S1 conducted a walk through of the facility grounds and observed a window open. S1 asked C1 to close the window. C1 became escalated, grabbed S1 and pulled S1 through the window. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff indicated a hold was used due to C1's aggressive behavior. The local police department was dispatched to the facility due to the incident and S1 declined to press charges. Information reported to the Department indicated C1 was not harmed during the incident. Based on information obtained from interviews conducted and record review the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and Confidential Names List LIC811 dated 09/08/22 were given to the above mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: On October 19, 2023, at 12:27 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived at the John & Dorothy Almklov House, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management inspection. LPA met with Henry Trochez. The Department obtained knowledge on September 26, 2023, of an incident that occurred involving clients of the STRTP. The report states that during a supervised walk in the neighborhood, an altercation occurred at a nearby park between clients of the home with staff present. Upon review of records at STRTP, it was discovered that an incident report had been created for the event but was never reported to Community Care Licensing. Mr. Trochez provided a copy of the report for LPA. During today's inspection, the STRTP was cited for being in violation of Reporting Requirements. Please refer to LIC809D (citation page) A signed copy of this report and LIC809D were provided to Mr. Trochez. Exit interview conducted. Appeal Rights provided.

Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged facility staff are not appropriately supervising minor in care. Interview conducted with staff were similar and denied the allegation. Staff stated that they have adequate staff throughout each shift to monitor the children in care. Staff stated that children get passes to walk or be in the community but that when children do not return on time or if they aren't allowed to be gone proper agencies are notified and local law enforcement is called, and reports are filed. Staff stated they typically are unaware of what transpires when children run away from facility. However, one staff stated that they were made aware of one incident occurring while one child was on runaway status due to local law enforcement telling them what happened, but staff stated they were not given specifics only questioned about potential locations of child's whereabouts. Children had similar statements and denied the allegation. Children stated that there are adequate staff and that there is adequate staff to meet their needs. Two children had contradictory statements. Children stated that there was adequate staff to supervise them in the home, but that staff don't always answer the phones when children are on outings or wanting to get picked up. Additionally, one child stated that staff don't intervene when children are fighting. However, the information provided for staff was unclear as to if incident occurred in the home or while children were outside on runaway or outing. Child in which this investigation was generated denied speaking with LPA. Documents reviewed identified proper notifications were made pertaining to incident referenced within this investigation and all incidents leading up to and after child returned were documented. Licensing Program Analyst attempted to reach county social worker but was unable to speak with county worker regarding incident but documents reviewed identified no issues or concerns with facility or children being placed in facility. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On 9/13/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the John and Dorothy Almklov House for the purpose of concluding the above complaint investigation. LPA met with Lead Facility Manager and discussed the above identified findings. Investigation consisted of the following: On 6/7/ LPA interviewed Administrator and Direct Care staff (see confidential names, LIC 811, dated June 7, 2023). LPA received the following copies: Current staff/ client roster, staff training log, six (6) children's most recent needs and service plans, law enforcement special incident reports (SIRs) for the past two months and any associated complaints or documents associated to the care and supervision of children. On 6/21/ LPA met with and interviewed children (see confidential names LIC811 dated 6/21/2023). UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: LPA also reviewed pertinent STRTP records, Department databases, and reports from other agencies. Investigation revealed that STRTP staff took three (3) clients on a supervised walk around the neighborhood, satisfying the staff to client ratio for being outside of the facility. On the walk, the group came upon two additional STRTP clients at a local park who were out of the STRTP on permitted community pass. The two groups interacted and an argument ensued. STRTP staff attempted to de-escalate the argument throughout, getting between participants for separation, only for another to engage from a different angle. By all accounts of the clients involved, STRTP staff did actively supervise the youths and de-escalate to the best of his ability. Based on information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit Interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Henry Trochez, Administrator. Appeal rights provided.
investigation_findings: 13On November 13, 2023, at 11:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived unannounced at the John & Dorothy Almklov House, a Short-term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), and met with Henry Trochez, STRTP Administrator, for the purpose of delivering findings on the above complaint investigation. On September 26, 2023, the Department received a complaint alleging that the STRTP staff did not adequately supervise youths while in care. LPA's investigation consisted of the following: On 09/29/ LPA interviewed Reporting Party. On 10/05/ LPA interviewed two STRTP clients (see LIC Confidential Names list dated 10/5/23). LPA received the following copies: Current staff/ client roster, staff training log, clients' most recent Needs and Service Plans (NSPs), and relevant special incident reports (SIRs). On 10/19/ LPA interviewed two clients at their respective high school (see confidential names LIC811 dated 10/5/23). (Cont'd) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA)s T. Davis and Dawn Mahecha went to John and Dorothy Almklov House on November 30, 2023 at 09:10am for the purposes of a joint unannounced Random Annual inspection. LPAs met with Crisol Jimenez, Head of Service and Robert Carter, Executive Vice President and discussed the purpose of today's inspection. The STRTP is located in a residential neighborhood and currently has six youth in placement. LPAs observed the facility's kitchen to be clean and well stocked with several food items (perishable and nonperishable). Sharp knives, chemicals, cleaning supplies, and medications are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. Each bedroom contained twin beds, dressers, and closet space. There is adequate seating in the dining area and the living room. LPAs also observed the bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. There is no swimming pool or other bodies of water on the premises. The Executive Vice President stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons on the premises. The last fire drill occurred on October 27, 2023 at 9:05am. There is adequate space for indoor and outdoor activities. Smoke alarms were operable throughout the facility. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. LPAs reviewed five client and three staff files and found the reviewed files to be in order. LPAs conducted staff Interviews. Clients were either sleeping, sick, or refused to speak with LPAs. LPAs obtained an updated LIC500 (Personnel Report) and a client roster. LPAs also obtained Board of Director's meeting minutes dated August 08, 2013 and September 12, 2023, respectively. The facility will be undergoing renovations in the foreseeable future. Licensee will email LPAs a copy of the facility's plans going forward as it relates to the renovations. LPAs obtained sketches regarding the future project. LPAs found no Title 22/ILS deficiencies on this date. Exit interview done LPAs discussed the cold weather conditions and precautions with licensee and provided licensee with the department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov).

LPA also reviewed pertinent STRTP records, Department databases, and reports from other agencies. The STRTP has three bedrooms for clients. Two are along the left side of the home with the third bedroom, the master bedroom, being across a hallway that bisects the home. The facility has three restrooms in total. One is located within the master bedroom, one located in the hallway, and a third in the rear of the home, near staff offices. According to S1, The rear restroom is for staff only. Staff restroom has a toilet and sink and is used for multi-purpose storage. The hallway restroom is designated for use by the clients whose bedroom is on the left side of the home. The remaining restroom, in the master bedroom, is for the occupants of that bedroom. Interviews with S1, C1, C2, C4, and C5 were consistent in revealing that the restroom located in the master bedroom was being used by all clients as an auxiliary restroom if the hallway restroom was occupied. Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards Article 7 are being cited on the attached LIC9099-D. Exit Interview conducted. Plans of Correction discussed. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, LIC9099-D, and LIC811 were provided to Henry Trochez, Administrator. Appeal rights provided. This is an amended finding delivered on 12/15/23. LPA also reviewed pertinent STRTP records, Department databases, and reports from other agencies. Interviews with clients (C1, C2, C4, C5) and staff (S1) returned answers inconsistent with the allegation of staff allowing youths to smoke in the facility. The STRTP has signs prominently posted stating that smoking/vaping is not allowed in the facility. Clients denied having seen anyone smoking or smelling smoke. Clients stated everyone was pretty much sober. Staff said they did not allow anyone to smoke in the home, and denied having smelled anything either. Staff did indicate that vape pens are seen on the client's person occasionally, but when seen, staff asks for the client to turn it in. In cases where a client did not surrender, then staff would allow them to go on, but wait for the client to leave the pen lying in plain sight or inside their laundry on laundry day to confiscate it. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit Interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Henry Trochez, Administrator. Appeal rights provided.

investigation_findings: 13On November 13, 2023, at 12:00 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived unannounced at the John & Dorothy Almklov House, a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), and met with Henry Trochez, STRTP Administrator, for the purpose of delivering findings on the above complaint investigation. LPA's investigation consisted of the following: On 10/19/ LPA interviewed Reporting Party. On 10/30/ LPA interviewed three STRTP clients (C2, C4, C5) and one facility staff (S1) (see LIC Confidential Names list dated 11/13/23). LPA received the following copies: Current staff/ client roster and facility floor plans. On 11/06/ LPA interviewed one client (C1), but was unable to meet with another (C3) at their respective high schools. (Cont'd) SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: LPA also reviewed pertinent STRTP records, Department databases, and reports from other agencies. The STRTP has two facility vehicles. LPA observed a small sedan, and a white Toyota minivan. LPA was shown the inside of both vehicles. Of note, the white Toyota minivan has capability for seating eight (8) passengers, with the first row consisting of two (2) bucket seats, the rear row consisting of a bench seat for three (3) passengers, and the middle row consisting of two (2) dedicated bucket seats and a fold down seat with seat belt attached to the bucket seats allowing for a third passenger. LPA observed the fold down seat to be cocked in an unusual way, and asked Administrator (A1) about it. A1 said seat was working and attempted to put the seat in place, but being unable to, actually pulled the seat off the hinges and told LPA, "Oh, I guess it 's broken." Interviews with clients (C1, C2, C4, C5) and staff (S1, A1) reveal knowledge of the seat being in disrepair, however LPA is unable to determine whether facility staff allowed clients to use broken seat during transport due to conflicting statements. Further investigation revealed that the facility van was taken to an auto shop on April 20, 2023, for a seat repair. However, the seat is a special order from the dealer and the part is on back order as stated in the work order. The work order was not provided to the LPA during the investigation. The STRTP also states that the facility has another vehicle which can be used to transport clients if additional seats are needed. Although one of the facility van seats is not in good repair, the facility took the van to the repair shop to obtain a work order. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit Interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC9099-C, and LIC811 were provided to Shaderian Williams. Appeal rights provided.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles and Timika Martin on 02/15/24 at 9: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Robles and Martin met with Ronnie Wofford, Facility Manager, Robert R. Carter, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. There are no children currently that take psychotropic medications. LPAs reviewed two (2) staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs interviewed two (2) staffs on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Ronnie Wofford, Facility Manager and provided a copy of this licensing report.

It was alleged that minor had access to illegal drugs while in care and staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in minor consuming hand sanitizer. The investigation revealed that the minor returned to the facility from being AWOL and appeared to be under the influence. The minor exhibited unusual behavior and later on asked staff to contact 911 after the minor started vomiting. The minor disclosed drinking hand sanitizer during AWOL. The minor was transported by emergency personnel to the hospital where the minor reported drinking hand sanitizer and using methamphetamines. It was discovered during confidential interviews that the minor obtained hand sanitizer from school and drank it inside the bedroom, after returning to the facility. There was no witness to the incident. The minor engaged in substance abuse while away from the facility and no one from the facility provided the minor with methamphetamines. Staff on duty responded appropriately by monitoring the minor's behavior after returning from AWOL and by immediately seeking medical attention for the minor. Based on the information gathered, the allegation of neglect/lack of supervision is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met. An exit interview was conducted, and copies of the following licensing reports were provided: LIC 9099, LIC 9099-C, LIC Confidential Names and Appeal Rights. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: The Department received a complaint with the following allegations: Staff hit minor resulting in injury, Staff did not allow minor to eat/Staff confiscated minor's personal belongings. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 and S2 denied hitting the minor, restricting access to food or taking personal items.S1 stated that all youth have access to food as needed, with a monthly menu posted and request for late-night meals. S1 reported that there is no policy or practice of food denial. S1 denied any allegations of physical abuse or inappropriate conduct towards the youth. S1 indicated searches of youth are conducted to maintain safety.According to S2, each youth is provided a personal locker with a key, ensuring security for personal items. S2 clarified that the facility maintains an open access policy to food, with a monthly menu available on the refrigerator. The interview with RP2 revealed that RP2 could not provide any specific details or confirm the allegations. RP2 disclosed no knowledge of the circumstances around the alleged confiscation of the youth's personal belongings. The youth placed in the home declined to give a statement as part of the investigation. Record review revealed that an incident report was generated on 12/28/23 by the STRTP and submitted to the department. The incident report indicated that law enforcement was called to the facility by C6 and C6 admitted to fabricating the story that S1 had hit C5. The incident report stated that law enforcement interviewed C5, S1, and S2. After the interviews, law enforcement left the facility. Based on the confidential interviews and records reviewed, the complaint against the the facility is unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated determination means the allegation lacks a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and LPA Martinez provided a signed LIC 9099 to the representative.

However, C1 refused to provide any details regarding the incident. C1 indicated the incident was reported to staff. C2 denied nor confirmed the allegation. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. The statements obtained from the confidential interviews did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. investigation_findings: 13On August 7, 2024, at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karen Suh conducted a follow-up complaint inspection to deliver the finding of an investigation concerning to the allegation above. The LPA met Raymond Brown, Unit Coordinator, and discussed the finding. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of but were not limited to: the Administrator, two staff and three clients (see Confidential Names, LIC 811, dated August 7, 2024) on March 15, 2024. The LPA was unable to contact County Social Worker (CSW) after several attempts. The LPA obtained and reviewed clients (Needs and Services Plan. It was alleged that staff did not ensure sharp objects were inaccessible to clients in care. It was allegedly a client, C2, held a knife on another client, C1's, face. Staff denied the allegation. Staff stated all sharp objects, including knives are locked. Clients do not have access to the knives. Staff stated there was no incident between clients C1 and C2 on March 4, 2024. (Cont.) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: The staff members (S1, S2, and S3) refuted the accusations, asserting that they have no knowledge of, and C1 has not disclosed any information about being associated with adult females. They emphasized their active involvement with the clients, staying informed about each client's daily activities. The staff also assured that they would intervene when necessary to guide clients in adhering to and completing their program. Both the staff and support team stressed the significance of educating clients on condom availability and safe sex practices. They consistently remind clients about the dangers of unprotected sex and the risks of contracting sexually transmitted diseases. Regarding the drug use allegation, the staff explained that the facility implements measures to prevent contraband from entering, including conducting self-searches on clients and inspecting all bags. Despite these precautions, clients have succeeded in smuggling contraband by hiding items in areas not easily accessible to staff. If contraband is found, the staff will confiscate, document, and dispose of it appropriately. Information provided by C1 corroborated the aforementioned details, expressing a sense of security while residing at the facility and acknowledging the staff's assistance in achieving their individualized plan. C1 denied involvement with adult females or mistreatment of animals, stating that the only substances used were marijuana and alcohol during AWOL. C1 admitted to fabricating the claims to provoke a reaction from their teacher. Additionally, C1 mentioned that the facility staff are vigilant, conducting visual searches of items brought back to the facility and confiscating any contraband discovered. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Facility Manager. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Facility Manager.

investigation_findings: 13On September 6, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney made an unannounced visit to the John and Dorothy Almklov home on behalf of LPA Dawn Mahecha for the purpose of closing the above complaint investigation. LPA met with representative and discussed the following findings. Investigation consisted of the following: On 2/15/ LPA Christopher Larios conducted initial 10-day and on 3/14/ LPA Mahecha met with and interviewed Administrator and two staff (see confidential names list LIC811, dated, 9/6/2024). LPA requested the following documents: Staff/ client roster, three (3) children's needs and service plans, daily logs of incidents of fights with staff and amongst peers. Additionally, LPA requested incident reports for AWOLs for three children and any recent medical visits. Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged staff encourage minor(s) to physically abuse other minor in care. Staff had similar statements and denied the allegation. Staff stated that children are not encouraged to hit, physically abuse or be in each other's rooms when staff are not monitoring. Staff stated that children will sometimes go into each other's rooms and staff will redirect children to leave or if children refuse staff sit and monitor children while in the room. Staff stated one child had accidents and was accused of peeing on themselves and in a roommate's bed. Staff stated that the child would initiate fights with other children in the home, but if children reported incidents or incidents were observed staff would redirect children and children would be moved to ensure children didn't fight with each other. Interviews conducted with children had similar statements and children denied seeing or witnessing any staff encouraging children to physically abuse anyone. Children stated facility have enough staff to monitor them and are actively present within the facility. LPA attempted to interview child in which investigation was about, but LPA was unsuccessful. Documents reviewed identified that one child did identify staff encouraging children physically abusing one another but child did not identify which staff encouraged children or who else was present to observe incidents. Documents identified that child was consistently on run-away status and that incidents documented child's behaviors and documented interactions with children. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Timika Martin, Pamela Silva, Amber Hunter and Joe Martinez on 08/07/25 at 9: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Administrator, Abraham Nesheiwat and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed two (2) of children's records and three (3) of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed two (2) of children's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed three (3) staff on site to discuss the facility's policies and procedures of operation. LPAs interviewed one (1) child currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the inspection, the LPAs observed deficiencies (see attached 809-D). Plan of corrections were discussed, and appeal rights were provided. LPAs conducted exit interview and provided a copy of this licensing report to Administrator, Abraham Nesheiwat.

On 08/27/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez initiated an annual/random inspection at the Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with the facility representative listed above. During the inspection, LPA Martinez interviewed 3 staff. and observed the following: The interior of the facility was observed clean, sanitary, and in good repair Indoor temperatures were maintained within the required range of 68-85 degrees. All hallways and stairways were free of obstruction. Smoke detectors were tested and found operational. Carbon monoxide detectors were present and functional. At least one fully charged fire extinguisher was available At the time of the inspection, there were no clients present. Construction was going on in the facility and water was shut off. LPA Martinez was not able to inspect water temperature. Water will be turned back on prior to youth returning to the facility. The kitchen and food preparation areas were sanitary and well organized. Cleaning supplies and toxic substances were locked and inaccessible. Food storage areas were clean and sufficient supplies of perishable and nonperishable food were available. Sharps are locked in the facility office and inaccessible to youth placed in the home. The facility has readily accessible first aid supplies maintained in a central location in the facility. Three bedrooms were observed during the inspection. All individual beds were clean, safe, and comfortable, with pillows, mattresses, and linens provided. Each child have their own bed and adequate supply of linens (sheets, blankets/coverings, towels, and washcloths) available to allow for weekly changes or more frequent changes. Adequate storage space for each child's clothing and personal belongings were observed. The facility also has a separate, lockable locker for each youth to store their personal belongings. Due to time constraints, the annual review will need to be completed at a later time. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA Martinez conducted an exit interview and provided the STRTP Representative with a signed copy of the LIC 809 and LIC809C.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an annual Inspection with Johnnie's House. LPA met with Robert Oliver Administrator. Johnnie's House converted to Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on June 30, 2020. STRTP is licensed to serve 6 clients ages 6-17. At 11: AM, LPA Rollins conducted a file review with Administrator. LPA reviewed 2 clients files and Staff files were reviewed. LPA observed two client files and found no deficiencies. The documentation in the clients file are complete. LPA observed all staff files to be complete, all correct documentation and all staff were up to date with there 40 hours of training for the year. LPA spoke with Administrator about the upcoming facility move to Oakhill Circle Oakland, California 94605. Administrator states that the move happen on June 10, 2021. LPA explain the documentation that the facility needs to turn in. LPA request an updated LIC 200, Fire Clearance, submit relocation checks to San Bruno Office and updated program statement with new address on it. Administrator states that currently the facility doesn't have any clients in the facility. LPA states that LPA will conduct a facility inspection when it is ready. LPA spoke with Administrator about facility getting there Mental Health Certification. Administrator states that facility is working with the county to get there Medi-Cal certification. LPA advised Administrator that LPA will extend the facility for another 6 months. During inspection, LPA requested a updated copy of the LIC Personnel Report to maintain their file current. A review of Licensing Information System on June 30, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

The house is one story and has 3 client bedrooms. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Facility will add appropriate supply of required foods and emergency foods upon placement of youth in the home. 10. Sample menu posted. 11. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 12. A full report is to be remitted within 7 days and may also be made to the incident reporting email. After licensure, you will receive a letter notifying you of your assigned LPA, from the San Bruno office. The application will be given to Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Carolyn Flynn, for review. I will notify you once the SOC analyst has finished the review of your Plan of Operation/Program Statement, ILS, v5, submitted via email on November 30, 2023. Actionable items are in bold print. A copy of this report was provided to George Jordan.

On 4/24/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit. LPA met with Administrator George Jordan and Executive Assistant Betheny Jordan and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA became aware of deficiencies and areas in which technical support may be beneficial. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, the licensee revised the plan of operation without providing to the licensing agency for review and approval prior to implementation. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Plan of Operation. Additionally, the licensee indicated in the revised plan of operation that per county, state, and team recommendations, the facility "holds sole responsibility" for visitation procedure changes. LPA advises that per the above cited ILS section, the facility must submit revised plan of operation procedures to the licensing agency for approval. LPA discussed that approval should be obtained prior to implementation. LPA also advised that individual visitation, transportation, and other service plans, and any modifications, be documented in the resident's needs and services plan and that, per ILS Section 87068. Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan, the facility ensure written approval of such modifications is obtained from the authorized representative(s) prior to implementation. Lastly, a transportation arrangement to a resident's medical appointment was made and when the assigned staff member could not provide transportation that day, an on-call staff member or other staff was not made available to ensure transportation. LPA advised that, per ILS Section Transportation, the facility is to ensure transportation to health related services, so to avoid missing future appointments, utilization of on-call staff is encouraged. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Executive Assistant Betheny Jordan.

investigation_findings: 13On 4/24/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit. LPA met with Executive Assistant Betheny Jordan and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, the investigation found that the facility agreed to provide transportation to a medical appointment scheduled by the authorized representative, who holds medical rights. The facility was not provided sufficient notice of the initial appointment to arrange transportation. The day of the rescheduled appointment, the assigned staff member had a personal emergency and could not provide transportation. The appointment was rescheduled, and the resident has since been assessed. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Executive Assistant. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

13On 4/24/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit. LPA met with Executive Assistant Betheny Jordan and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential observations, interviews, and record review, the investigation found that the facility restricted family visitation and phone calls without the support of the full care team. Upon learning that an authorized representative did not agree with the new plan, the facility did not revise the plan. The plan of operation was then revised to support the revised visitation/call plan, including a statement that the licensee has deciding power to make such changes. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Executive Assistant Betheny Jordan. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 06/10/24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Celeste Aparicio and Kristin Pierotti conducted a facility evaluation visit for a case management regarding an observed deficiency from a complaint investigation; control number 14-CR-20240506113008. LPA met with Facility Manager and informed on the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, confidential interviews and records review were conducted. Based on interviews, record review, and observation the following deficiency was discovered regarding background clearance for staff member S1. (See LIC811) LPA observed S1 to be working at the facility on 05/08/24. Upon LPA's arrival at the facility on 05/08/24, LPA observed S1 exiting the facility vehicle from the driver's seat. During records review conducted on 06/04/24, LPA observed the initials of an unknown staff member on the facility transportation log starting from 03/25/24 to 05/20/24. LPA also did not observe S1 on be on the LIC500. During a confidential interview, LPA learned S1 was still in training. Upon further review, LPA observed that S1's criminal background clearance with facility is in pending status. Therefore, S1 has been working at the facility since 03/25/24 without a criminal background clearance associated to the facility. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 3, Section Criminal Record Clearance, Subsection (e). Additionally, pursuant to Subsection (g) of this regulatory section, LPA is assessing an immediate civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100) per violation (1) for a maximum of 5 days, for a total of five hundred dollars ($500). See attached LIC 809-D and LIC 421. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 08/16/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a case management visit to follow-up on a submitted incident report. LPA met with Facility Youth Mentor and informed the Youth Mentor on the purpose of the visit. Based on the submitted incident report, a resident was searched by having staff check the resident's pockets after returning to the facility from a runaway. Facility Youth Mentor explained that staff conduct searches because of the resident potentially bringing contraband into the facility. LPA discussed the youths' personal rights regarding unreasonable searches and informed Youth Mentor that searches cannot be conducted as a part of facility policy. LPA provided technical support in the form of an advisory regarding the processes around case-by-case searches for residents in care. See LIC Technical Assistance. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Youth Mentor, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Staff were ensuring they had the inhaler during afternoon activities but not during morning transport to school, which is located about 40 minutes away from the facility. 2 deficiency citations were issued at today's visit. On 08/28/2025 at 11:15 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brenda Rodriguez conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection and met with Anjelle Skates, Administrator. LPA Rodriguez disclosed the purpose of the inspection and was granted entry into the facility by the Administrator. LPA Rodriguez used the CARE Inspection Tool. The facility currently has a census of two (2) clients. LPA Rodriguez reviewed five (5) staff files, two (2) client files, and the emergency disaster plan binder. LPA Rodriguez conducted two (2) confidential staff interviews and two (2) attempted confidential client interviews. The clients did not want to get interviewed. During physical plant inspection, no deficiencies were found. LPA Rodriguez toured the facility inside and out. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and full-sized beds. Each bedroom has drawers for extra storage space. The client's bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. Extra linens are in a closet in the hallway. The facility is clean, safe, and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. The weekly menu was posted. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. At this time, the inspection is not complete. LPA Rodriguez will be back at a later day to complete the required annual inspection. Control Number - 2197-FN On September 23, 2025, at 4: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on a submitted Incident Report (IR). LPA met with Maria Castaneda, Youth Advocate and communicated with Administrator Anjelle Skates over the phone. At the time of the visit, two staff members and three clients were present. The IR was submitted regarding an incident that occurred on September 16, 2025. The Administrator stated that the 24-hour notification was reported to LPA Brenda Rodriguez in person during a prior visit. According to the report, Client C1 was found unresponsive, slumped over, and smelled of alcohol. Paramedics were contacted, but when C1 regained consciousness and was informed that emergency services had been called, C1 became upset and AWOLed from the facility. Paramedics and a clinician searched for C1, who was located on the same block returning to the facility. C1 was evaluated by paramedics, vitals were checked, and C1 was cleared to return to the facility. During the visit, LPA interviewed the Administrator to obtain additional information regarding the facility's plan to ensure C1 follows the safety plan discussed in the Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting and updated needs and services plan to address alcohol consumption. The Administrator stated: "We do bed checks routinely every hour. We can't control what she does off-site. She is working daily with her clinician but continues to decline all medication. We requested that she be placed in a higher level of care." Additionally, LPA discussed with the Administrator the proper procedure for documenting incidents involving law enforcement contact. LPA provided the Administrator with the LIC 624-LE form for reference, as well as PIN 23-02-CRP and PIN 17-04-CRP. No deficiencies were observed or cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Maria Castaneda, Youth Advocate.

Control Number - 2196-FN On September 23, 2025, at 4: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the above-referenced facility to follow up on submitted Incident Reports (IRs). LPA met with Maria Castaneda, Youth Advocate and communicated with Administrator Anjelle Skates over the phone. At the time of the visit, two staff members and three clients were present. Several IRs were submitted between September 13 and September 17, 2025, involving law enforcement contact. Upon review, LPA observed that the reports were missing required components related to law enforcement involvement. During the visit, LPA interviewed the Administrator, Anjelle Skates over the phone to obtain additional information. LPA also discussed with the Administrator the proper procedures for documenting incidents involving law enforcement contact. LPA provided the Administrator with the LIC 624-LE form for reference, along with PIN 23-02-CRP and PIN 17-04-CRP. LPA explained that while the facility is not required to use the LIC 624-LE, any form used must include the same required information. No deficiencies were observed or cited during this inspection. However, as an area of improvement, LPA issued a technical violation under Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87061(j) - Reporting Requirements. Please refer to LIC 9102 for additional details. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Maria Castaneda, Youth Advocate.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Monica Pavia and Jasmine Cardeno made an announced site inspection, for the purpose of preparing for a prelicensing inspection, at a later date. LPAs met with Facility Manager, Anjelle Skates, who provided a tour of all buildings on the campus. LPAs observed the following items that need to be addressed prior to a prelicensing inspection to be scheduled. 1. Capacity request for Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) application must not exceed bedroom space available for children in placement. No more than 2 children shall share a bedroom. 87087(b)(1) 2. Program shall not have more beds for children's use than required for the maximum capacity approved by the licensing agency. 87088(c)(1)(A) 3. LPA will check camera policy with CCL policy department. Cameras are never allowed to be used in lieu of staff supervision. 87078(b) 4. Bunk beds are not allowed for this population. 87088(c)(1)(C) 4. Hot water temperature shall be maintained between 105 and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. 80088(e)(1) 6. All sharps and poisonous cleaning supplies must be kept locked. 80087(g)(1) 7. Dining room must provide necessary space for licensed capacity. 87087.3(a) 8. Extra linens to be made available in children's living quarters. 80088(g) 9. All food must be covered in the refrigerator/freezer. 10. Display Personal Rights, Menus and Complaint Policy/Grievance Forms in each building on campus, accessed by children in placement.

On 6/16/2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield initiated an annual /required inspection at the above facility. Upon entering the facility LPA Belfield was greeted by administrator Tangie Jackson and Jamie Richard who assisted with the inspection. Present during this inspection were three staff and two clients. A tour of the facility was conducted, observed during the time of the inspection were the following; posted forms: all forms required to be posted such as license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and activity calendar, were all posted. Smoke detectors were located and are in working condition. The facility was observed to be clean and in good repair. Food supply was sufficient for non-perishable food and perishable food for one week. LPA interviewed C1 and C2 ( see LIC 811 dated 6/16/2021). The water temperature was below 120 degrees which is within the requirements of the regulations. During this inspection LPA Belfield reviewed staff files and client files. During a file review it was observed in the Licensing information System that they were no active fingerprints for S2 ( see Lic 811 dated 6/16/2021) however, LPA Belfield observed paper work showing an approved exemption status from the department. At this time it is unclear what happened to cause a conflict of information in the system. LPA discussed with administrator Jackson, that S2 needed to stop working until the issue with their finger prints were resolved. LPA observed all client and staff records to be up to date and complete. LPA Belfield discussed medication logs with administrator Jackson and reminded administrator that Psychotropic medications must be documented separately. All medication logs are current and complete. LPA observed medications remaining. Also discussed were the use of medication forms. LPA informed administrator Jackson that the program could create their own forms to log medication as long as it has all of the required information according to the regulations. Advisory issued for section, 80070(a) client records. During a client file review it was observed by this LPA that C4 did not have an immunization record. This was due to the client being recently placed and files were being obtained by the county worker as stated by administrator Jackson. LPA Belfield conducted interviews with C4 and C5 who were present in the facility. Advisory issued for of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, section 80070(a) Client Records. There were no violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six or Interim Licensing Standards, cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with administrator Jackson and a copy of this report will be sent to Licensee Jamie Richard and administrator Jackson.

On Friday May 13, 2022 at 11: AM Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers (LPM's) Carolyn Flynn, Helga Wong and Isabel Mendoza conducted an office meeting virtually via Microsoft Teams. Community Care Licensing (CCL) met JR Northstar I Administrator, Rachel McCormick and Consultant, Tricca Leverenz. Tandreya Jackson was unable to attend. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the Mental Health Program Approval (MHPA) and the required items for permanent licensure for JR Northstar I & II. The facility's 24 month STRTP provisional expires on June 30, 2022. The facility submitted their MHPA to DHCS on April 12, 2022. DHCS cannot move forward with the application until the facility finds a qualified Head of Service and the facility is contracted by Contra Costa County Behavioral Health. At this time, the county is expected to finish their review by August of 2022. During this meeting the following options were discussed; withdrawal of STRTP application by the program, this would prevent CCL (Community Care Licensing) from taking legal action against the program. The facility was informed that if the program is not able to obtain their Mental Health approval by the date of June 30, 2022 the department will have to take legal action. The facility was also informed that they could withdraw their STRTP application and submit a plan of closure. The facility will have an internal discussion, and the Administrator, Rachel McCormick will contact LPM Mendoza on when they will submit their closure plan to CCL, or notify LPM if there are any immediate changes with DHCS or their county contract. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility for signature.

On 8/22/22 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng conducted an unannounced Annual/Random at listed facility. LPA's met with Jamie Richard, Executive Director(ED) and toured the facility inside and out. The group home is currently licensed to serve 6 clients, currently there are four clients. Present during the inspection were three staff and three clients. At 10:50am, LPA's toured the facility. LPA saw three bedrooms and three bathrooms. Two bathrooms were for clients and one was for staff. LPA's observed the facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, facility rules, and other forms posted[ on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis interviewed one client and two staff. LPA Karkazis and Ng reviewed staff and client files. The needs and services plans were not up to date. The facility menu was not posted in the kitchen. LPA's advised ED to have the facility menu posted. All staff were fingerprinted and had child abuse index check clearances. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 114 degrees, which is in within range. Thermostat read 68 degrees, within range. At 11:00am LPA's walked through the backyard. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell made an unannounced inspection to the Kids to Kids- Faith House on 04/29/2022 at 10:50am for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required Inspection. LPA O'Connell met with the Facility Manager (FM), Lina Severino, who granted access to the facility. The entire physical plant was inspected, inside and out. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) female clients, ages 13-17 years, ambulatory only (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 04/29/2022). This is a three-bedroom, two-bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry area and a carport. Annual fee is current. LPA inspected the facility with the the FM and observed the following: Bedroom #1: Is occupied by Client#1 (C1) and it has two full size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by Client#2 (C2) and it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by Client#3 and Client #4 (C3 and C4) and it has two twin size beds, adequate closet and drawer space. There is no bodies of water on the premises. The smoke detector was tested and is functional. The passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. The menu with date is posted in the kitchen. Documents posted in the main hallway: client's personal rights, grievance procedure, emergency exit plan, referral number for licensing agency, and facility license. The outdoor space is clean, clear and free of debris. Knives are locked in the staff office, and clients do not have access to them. Chemicals are kept in a locked closet where clients do not have access. Continued on LIC809C Medication is locked and accessible only to the facility manager and staff that are on shift. LPA observed a fully charged fire extinguisher in the staff main office. Refrigerator was inspected and perishable food was available for at least 2 days, and non-perishable food items were stocked in pantry. Fruit was available on kitchen counter. Facility truck was inspected and in good working condition with current registration and insurance. At the time of inspection, LPA O'Connell reviewed the LIC 500 and obtained information that a staff SI, S2 and S3 has been scheduled for work and does not have clearance in Guardian to provide services. LPA discussed matter with the Facility Manager and Facility Administrator, and all agreed that an immediate civil penalty would be assessed, and staff would not be allowed to return to the facility until clearance can be obtained. LPA discussed outcome of visit with the facility administrator and left a copy of this report on site.

Although there is evidence indicating implementation of established AWOL policy and staff intervention, neglectful behavior and/or lack of resident oversight cannot be confirmed with C1 due to unknown whereabouts and lack of impartial witnesses. Therefore, it must be concluded that an allegation of neglect/lack of supervision cannot be substantiated at this time. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On 03/08/2021 at approximately 6:00, Client#1 (C1) runway way (AWOL) from the facility. Facility staff attempted to redirect C1 and was offered to go on a walk, do activities, and have a one-on-one with staff. Facility had the Crisis Team on call with C1. C1 hang up on the Crisis Team but at approximately at 7:30pm, C AWOL from the facility. Facility contacted Ventura County Police Department to report missing person report. C1 was gone for approximately two hours. At around 9:45pm, C1 reached out to Facility Staff to report that she left to the Vons shopping center near the facility and that she was in a car on unknown man. Facility staff and Law Enforcement arrived the Vons shopping center to pick up C1. Facility reported that C1 was outside of the man's car and was trying to get back in. C1 and unknown man reported a different description of the incident. C1 was offer medical assistance and was given counsel that was not able to determine if the incident did happen. Results from the Department's investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Neglect and Lack of Supervision are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: continued from page 1 (LIC 9099) On November 11th, AGPA Woodard conducted a subsequent inspection to the facility for the purpose of gathering additional supporting documentation. Confidential interviews and a review of supportive documentation revealed that Law Enforcement responded to calls at the above facility 22 times for assaults, missing persons, suspicious circumstances, and follow-up investigations. Staff did follow the runaway procedures by contacting the non-emergency number to place a missing person report, provided important information regarding the minor and photo identification, and when the client returned the facility staff contacted the police department to close the missing persons' report. The habitual runaways did receive citations from law enforcement, and when a client was gone longer than 24 hours, a child and family team meeting was held to implement prevention interventions. Based on confidential interviews and review of supportive documentation, AGPA Woodard determined the lack of supervision allegation that staff do not provide adequate supervision to minors, the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred, therefore the findings are unsubstantiated. A copy of this report was left at the facility.

met_with: Shannon Walling, Facility Manager; Andrea Espinosa,Senior Manager
narrative: On May 6, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a Case - Management Incident inspection to deliver and discuss findings from the Department's Investigation on self- reported incident received July 21, 2020. LPA met with Facility Representatives, Shannon Walling, Facility Manager and Andrea Espinosa Senior Facility Manager and together discussed investigation details. On July 21, 2020, Community Care Licensing received an incident report from facility representatives reporting that Staff member #1 (S1) contributed marijuana to minors. The incident was referred and assigned to Investigations Bureau, Investigator, Dennis Douglas. The investigation revealed, according to gathered information from independent interviews and review of corresponding records including incident reports and reports from the Ventura County Police Department, S1 provided and smoked marijuana with several of the clients at the facility. The marijuana was provided by S1 to the clients in the form of a "wax pen" and a "pipe". Sources revealed the encounters would occur outside of the facility during "walks" or while S1 was in the facility vehicle with the clients. S1 admitted to Investigator Douglas that she provided and smoked marijuana with the minor clients. Confidential independent interviews with clients residing in the facility at the time, further corroborate claims as some residents admitted to smoking marijuana out of S1's "wax pen" with S1 on several occasions and S1's "pipe" on at least one occasion. Upon discovery of said incident, S1 was terminated from her position at the facility. Facility representatives notified all required parties and conducted an internal investigation pertaining to the incident. (Continued on pg. Lic809d) Corrections concerning facility policy and procedures pertaining to this incident were reviewed and updated as necessary. Based on gathered information there is corroborating evidence to support reports of S1 contributing marijuana to minors. S1's actions towards clients poses an immediate health, safety and personal rights risk to children placed in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with Health and Safety code HSC 1558 (a)(2) Conduct inimical. See page 809D for deficiency. Exit interview conducted; Appeal Rights issued. A copy of this report was emailed to Facility Representatives.

narrative: On 03/08/2021 at approximately 12:00pm, Client#1 (C1) and Client#2 (C2) informed facility staff they wanted to runway (AWOL) from the facility. Around 4:50pm, C1 and C2 packed their belongings and walked out from the front door. Staff was able to obtain the vehicle plates, make and model of the vehicle that picked up C1 and C2. Facility contacted Ventura County Police Department to report missing person report. At 7:15pm Ventura County Police officer arrived at the facility to take the report. Interviews with facility and clients reported the facilities policies and procedures in what facility does when clients runway. met_with: Facility Representatives, Xiomara Lopez, Assistant Manager Danny Bakst, Head of Service
narrative: The investigation revealed C1 was first placed August 18, 2021 with a history of anxiety, depression and prior suicide ideation without a plan. Confidential interviews and review of records indicates C1 was planning to graduate from facility's program and high school. On November 12, 2021, C1 appeared to be in a good mood and was last seen alive approximately 15 to 20 minutes before being found unresponsive. On November 12, 2021 at approximately 1: PM, Staff member found C1's bedroom door barricaded with a dresser. The door was pushed open and C1 was found partially suspended by a black cable cord secured to dresser drawers. Resuscitative efforts were begun, 911 emergency was called, and C1 was transported to a hospital where C1 was subsequently pronounced dead. Witness statements obtained indicate C1 appeared to be in a positive mood on the morning of the incident and showed no obvious signs of distress, plans to harm self or plans to commit suicide. Ventura County Police Department responded to the incident and found there was no crime committed. Ventura County Medical Examiner Investigator determined no suspicions of foul play regarding the incident. Based on gathered information obtained, there is not enough evidence to prove C1's untimely passing resulted from questionable death, but rather by suicide by hanging self from a closet drawer in their room. The findings are deemed Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of regulations at this time. Exit Interview conducted. A copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights are provided to Facility Representative.

narrative: LPA Rosas and AGPA Barnes-Woodard conducted interviews with clients and facility staff that provided information that on 05/14/2021, Client#1 (C1) was video recorded by personal cell phone by Staff#2 (S2). Staff#3 (S3) confirmed that outdoor ring camera was removed after the incident. Results from the Department's investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Based on interviews on 05/14/2021, Staff#2 (S2) did recorded Client#1 (C1) with personal cell phone which infringes on C Personal Rights and poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Version 4, Article 6. Continuing Requirements: Personal Rights 87072 (11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, *exploitation,* infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.
