narrative: On September 4, 2025, at 10: AM, via Microsoft Teams, Community Care Licensing (CCL) and Systems of Care (SOC) conducted a Technical Assistance Call (TA) with the applicants of Kinfolks Helping Hands, Inc. The meeting was attended by Ansar Muhammad, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA), Marjana Jackson, Staff Services Manager I (SSM I), Cynthia Velasquez, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Dawn Segura, Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Demetri Roberts, Applicant, and Naja Roberts, Applicant. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Application and Plan of Operation/Program Statement submitted to CCL on 03/28/2025. Applicants noted that the incorrect version of form LIC 9106 was initially submitted. Subsequently, applicants completed the correct version of the LIC 9106A form. During the call, the following topics were discussed: Application 1. Bacterial Analysis - Not Applicable. Applicants will not be using a private water source. Plan of Operation and Program Statement 2. Staff Plan - In addition to staff, applicants plan to utilize house parents who will incorporate prudent parenting standards to facilitate a home-like environment. 3. Population To Be Served • Facility will serve children 8 through 17 years of age; facility will not serve nonminor dependents • Children with Special Health Care Needs - Applicants will review ILS section 87001 and additional regulations to determine if children with special health care needs will be served. 4. Personal Rights - Applicants plan to utilize video surveillance outside of the facility. Applicants were provided the Provider Information Notice (PIN 24-09-CRP) that provides guidance on the use of video cameras in children's residential congregate care facilities. 5. Emergency Intervention Plan - Applicants indicated that CPI and Ukeru System will be utilized if other efforts have been exhausted. Applicants were provided information related to available resources provided by the state and county that can be used when outside intervention is needed. Applicants were advised to utilize 911 as a last resort. Applicants stated that required documents and revisions will be provided to CCL by 09/12/2025. A copy of this report was sent to Naja Roberts, Applicant, for signature. The signed report will be maintained in the facility file in the Riverside Regional Office.

met_with: Dave Bacchi Program Coordiantor & Alex Mankarios, Administrator
narrative: The facility provided copies of their camera surveillance, Nightly Bed Checks and 32 pages of Daily Observation. Additional evidence obtained include Rocklin Police Department Incident Reports #2006250163 and #2006250164 and 10 facility photos. The complaint alleges that the facility staff did not provide adequate supervision, resulting in inappropriate interaction between clients. The facility's policy does not allow youth in each other's bedrooms; it also requires bed checks completed every 30 minutes to ensure youth safety which starts at 11: PM. Y1 admitted to going inside Y4's room and kissing Y4. Details from the video footage confirmed Y1 was inside Y4's room for at least 70 minutes: · at 11: PM, Y1 opened Y4's bedroom door · at 11: PM, Y1 entered Y4's room and remained until 12: AM (32 minutes) · at 12: AM, Y1 went back to Y4's room and remained until 12: AM (37 minutes) · at 12: AM, Y1 opens Y4's door and stands in doorway until 12: AM (1 minute) S1 was responsible for bed checks on June 22-23, 2020 and stated bed checks began at 11: PM. S1 also stated Y1 and Y4 were "laying on the floor in their bedroom doorways." Yet the footage confirms Y4 door was not open, therefore S1 would not have been able to see F4. S1 statements contradicts the video surveillance. Further details from the footage also confirm: · S1 was inside the staff office from 11: PM- 12: AM- missing 11: PM bed checks · At 12: AM, S1 only checked the hallway and did not enter any youth bedrooms. · Bed check at 12: AM, S1 is unable to locate Y1 for 3 minutes. S1 stated she would "look up" at the surveillance video "if" she heard things, but S1 did not hear any bedroom doors open or close. S1 did not notice Y1 going in and out of her room. Yet, S1 remembered Y1 coming to the office multiple times. The supervision provided by S1 did not comply with the facilities policies of appropriate supervision and inappropriate contact occurred between youth. Based on the facility's video footage, interviews conducted, and photos taken, the complaint allegation is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for Personnel Duties 87065.2 (b)(1) which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marla Horne conducted a case management via telephone with the facility social worker. The case management was to follow up on incident reports dated 9-13-20 and 9-15-20. It was reported on 9-13-20 that a youth (C1) had gotten into the medicine safe as well as the sharp knives drawer. C1 was able to get into the safe because she had seen the PIN number as a staff person opened the safe while C1 was in the staff office. C1 was able to access a sharp knife when the drawer was unlocked during a meal preparation. C1 threatened to harm herself and was transported to a hospital to be assessed for a 5150 hold. C1 was released later that evening (9-13-20) and returned to the facility. To ensure the safety of staff and youth the facility social worker and facility administrator developed a plan of correction. The staff were retrained on Koinonia procedures and C1 is not to be in the staff office. Staff are to keep the sharp knives drawer locked during meal preparation. The medication safe will not be opened while youth are in the office or when the office door is open. A second incident report submitted on 9-15-20 noted that C1 had taken money from the house budget wallet during a transport from school to the facility. C1 was able to get the money because the staff's purse was in between the van seats. Staff have been instructed to keep their purses in the van safe while transporting youths. End.

Youth also made statements that staff disrespected her and she did not want to go back to the facility. The youth's whereabouts are unknown therefore no statement was obtained from youth. Staff stated having no knowledge of escalation prior to youth leaving nor did staff know youth was disrespected. Based on the information obtained the allegations, that minor was mistreated while in care and staff are not properly supervising the minor, are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may or may not have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and the LIC811 were discussed and left with Bill Ryland.
investigation_findings: 13On 6/28/21 at 9:17 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Robin Sullivan contacted Bill Ryland (S1), to deliver the finding for the allegation that minor was mistreated while in care and staff are not properly supervising a minor in care. LPA Marla Horne opened the initial investigation with the facility on 3/25/21 and received a client roster and a staff duty roster. LPA Robin Sullivan interviewed an Auburn Police Sergeant on 6/23/21, two facility employees and the Merced Probation Officer on 6/22/21. LPA Sullivan received one youth's Needs and Services Plan, Treatment plan, incident reports, and discharge summary from the facility and a police report from the Auburn police department. The investigation revealed that the youth has a history of leaving facilities without permission. The youth left the facility without permission on the evening of 3/13/21 after watching a movie. Staff contacted Law Enforcement (LE) to report the youth missing. LE located youth but youth refused to return to the facility. Youth was held in protective custody for safety until an agreement to return was hesitantly made. Youth made statements to LE that she wanted to be back in her hometown. narrative: On 2/9/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor, LPA Tana Kinder, and Program Manager Rosa Rodriguez met with Director to discuss concerns for Koinonia House #5 and #3. The list of concerns include: -Unreasonable consequences for the youth -Staff used of profanity at the facility -Staff usage of personal phone during supervised visit -Denial of phone call to youth to make confidential phone call to the Foster Care Ombudsman. -Youth not allowed to have private phone call conversations with their Social Workers and other professional staff. -Broken washer appliance. Director reported that the staff have been trained on Foster Youth Rights and explained the phone policy for staff and youth. Director will email LPA Lor a revised program statement of the policy. Director will address the concerns with the facility and will follow up with LPA Lor on 2/11/22.

Multiple professional staff confirmed that while having private conversations with the youth on the phone, staff from Koinonia #5 were presented and answered the professional staff's questions for the youth. Based on additional interviews, staff are supervising youth while youth make personal phone calls. It was confirmed that no youth had court order in place with or without restricted/monitored phone calls. Therefore, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met and the above allegation is determined to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited on the attached 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of the report, and appeal rights will be emailed to Facility Administrator. Based on the interviews with the youth and staff, they confirmed that the searches and bathroom privacy were appropriate, and none felt violated. Although youth stated that they were not provided condiments for food, there is inconsistency based on the interviews. Staff denied the allegation of inappropriately disciplining the youth and provided LPA a list of chores in the STRTP. In addition, the Program Statement was reviewed and confirmed their disciplinary policy. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the above allegations; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights will be emailed to Facility Administrator.

narrative: The facility sent incidents reports, involving C1, to the Probation Officer (PO) and Community Care Licensing (CCL) by electronic submissions. A facility communication log indicates phone messages were left and emails sent to the PO communicating visitations, an out-of-state move by father, notification of client instability, C1's positive actions, notice of psychological evaluations, and a 14-day notice. Probation states they did not receive a needs and services plan or a treatment plan for C1. The facility uses consequences, referred to as therapeutic assignments (TA), for negative behaviors. Four staff and three youths describe, in separate interviews, the process of receiving TA. The interviews confirm staff and residents have a similar understanding of the consequence system. The therapeutic assignment and the corresponding consequences are not included in the facility program statement. The Parole officer was not informed C1 had accumulated an abundance of TA until the accumulation seemed unachievable for C1. C1 was not available to interview. Based on the evidence and interviews conducted the allegations that reporting requirements were not met and the discipline system is not trauma informed are UNSUBTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights and the LIC811 were discussed and emailed to Bill Ryland.

On 2/24/23 at 3:30pm, Community Care Licensing Division (CCL) conducted an in-person meeting with Koinonia to discuss some concerns regarding blanket policies in the Program Statement. The meeting was held at Natomas Drive Park, Sacramento, CA 95834. The attendees were as followed: Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD): Regional Manager (RM) Margo Castaneda, Licensed Program Manager (LPM) Rosa Rodriguez, Licensed Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor Koinonia: Executive Director Tiffany Sickler, Administrator Canaan Sampson, Compliance Manager Laura Richardson, Board Member Krystal Edwards Ombudsman Foster Care Office (OFCO): Manager Brittany Newton, Ombudsman staff Larry Fluharty Child Trafficking Program Unit (CTPU): Associate Government Program Analyst Darrin Holt, Staff Manager Ashley Bray System of Care Branch (SOCB): Manager Marjana Jackson, Help Program Specialist Shamika Payne, Provider Policy Manager Alicia Bernstein During the meeting, the following sections were discussed with Koinonia attendees; Section Transportation, Section Trauma Interventions, Section Complaints and Grievances, Section House rules, Section Nursing and Section Emergency Intervention. Due to the lack of time, not all sections were discussed thoroughly. However, it was agreed upon that there cannot be blanket statements in the Program Statement. () The next step is Koinonia will edit their program statement to reflect the changes and will email it to Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephanie Lor for review by March 24th, 2023. Koinonia attendees were provided with resources for guidance with the Program Statement by all the departments during the meeting. The following email was provided to Koinonia for guidance: csecprogram@dss.ca.gov Exit interview was conducted and a report will be emailed to the facility for signature.

met_with: Linda Wagner, Facility Administrator in Training
narrative: On April 16, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez and Orlando Areizaga arrived at the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a Case Management inspection. LPAs' observations are as follows: Upon arrival to the facility, LPAs' observed a natural pond that was not there at the last visit to the facility. LPA was able to observe that the pond was deep enough for large geese and ducks to swim in. -LPA addressed the pond with FA in training who informed that it was a natural, non man-made, pond that occurs throughout heavy rain in the area. LPA brought up the drowning risks. FA in training specified the alarms on the doors and windows alert staff to the unauthorized exit of a youth and they follow to maintain line of sight. Some youths do play in the pond, catching fish and frogs, with supervision. The grass was over grown in part of the front, side, and rear yard where LPA could not see their feet through the overgrowth. - LPA addressed the overgrowth as an issue and reminded that it is a safety hazard. FA in training showed that Lawn care is scheduled to come out to the facility on Fridays'. Also a youth in care volunteers to mow the lawn as it calms them down. Maintenance also stated that they would address this issue. LPA observed at three (3) windows had no screens installed at the time of the visit. - Screens are not damaged, The youth in care remove them and staff 'pop them back in'. LPAs observed expired food in the fridge as well as one (1) damaged can in the pantry area. - FA in training threw way the expired/damaged items. A LIC TV was issued for the CCR, Title 22 80087 (a) Buildings and Grounds. Appeal Rights were discussed and an exit interview was conducted with FA in training. Copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left at the facility.

C2 was observed to have extreme behaviors, including acting out in a harassing manner towards other youths in the facility as well as staff. Staff notated that they did reach out to the management regarding assistance with C2 and their supervision needs as well as concerns with C2's sexually aggressive behaviors towards another youth placed in the facility. As issues were arising, the facility was unable to address these in a timely fashion which allowed the client to continue the negative behaviors towards staff and other youth. Also, staff suspected that a wax pen was sneaked into the facility by client in care. Staff witnessed C2 showing signs of being high and random puffs of smoke exiting the bathroom area while youths utilized the restroom. Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards (LIS) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Exit interview conducted, and Appeal Rights were discussed with Linda Wagner, Facility Administrator. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were left at the facility. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did occur therefore the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Marla Horne and Cindy Johnson made an unannounced annual/required inspection of the facility on 10-26-21 at 9: AM. LPA's met with facility administrator Jordan Barbour and conducted an inspection of the inside and outside of the facility. LPA's observed required postings of facility license, foster youth rights, emergency evacuation plan as well as evacuation maps. LPAs observed operable smoke/carbon monoxide detectors and fire extinguishers. LPAs observed the kitchen refrigerator, freezer and pantry to have adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable food items. LPAs observed the bathrooms to have warm running water which is required. Bedrooms were observed to have required bedding and furniture. LPAs observed an adequate supply of bedding and linen. The outdoor area was clear of debris. The facility van was observed to have operable brake lights, headlights, turn signals and working seat belts. LPAs observed medications, sharps and cleaning supplies/chemicals to be in a locked cabinet. LPAs reviewed staff and youth files and all required documents were observed in the files. No citations issued during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Jordan Barbour. *

Staff used an inappropriate form of discipline. Based on confidential interviews, youth are completing excessive amount of Therapeutic Assignment (TA). Some interviews reported that the 16/20 exercises could be doubled up, which causes the youth to be very tired out. It was noted in the facility program statement that 16/20s are a form of discipline in the program. Staff enforced an unreasonable dress code for minors Based on confidential interviews. there were conflicting statements about the dress code. Some interviews reported that the dress code is for the safety of the youth, however, other interviews were reported that the dress code was too strict. The dress code policy was noted in the facility program statement of what is allowed and what is not allowed. Staff forcing minors to be drug tested. Based on all the confidential interviews, it was reported that youth are required to take random drug tests after awols, home passes, or any outings that were without a staff supervision. It was noted on the program statement that random drug test could be required when appropriate. Staff not allowing minors to have private phone calls. Based on the confidential interviews, there were conflicting statements on private phone calls. Some interviews reported that private phone calls are allowed, while other interviews stated that staff are supervising during phone calls. Staff require minors to complete an excessive amount of chores. Based on the confidential interviews, there were conflicting statements on youth are completing excessive amount of chores. Some interviews reported that the chores are too much while others reported that they did not have an issue with the chores in the home. It was noted on the facility program statement on chores provided in the home. Minors are required to cook meals. Based on the confidential interviews, there were conflicting statements on youth requiring to cook meals. Some interviews reported that youth are not required to cook meals, but can switch chores if the youth did not want to cook. Some interviews reported that cook is part of the chores and youth can get consequences (Cont on 3rd page) if chores were not completed. It was noted in the facility program statement that cooking is part of the chores in the home. Facility program statement is unreasonable. The program statement is currently being edited. The program statement has been updated to ensure that it allies with the the updated version of Title STRTP Regulations. Facility withheld minor's personal item. Based on the confidential interviews, there were conflicting statements on withheld of personal items. Some interviews reported that the youth are given their personal items upon request, while some interviews reported that youth cannot have access to their personal items. Staff force minors to attend religious services Based on confidential interviews, there were conflicting statements on force of attending religious services. Only 1 out of the 4 clients, reported that youth have to participate in the living room while completing work assignments. It was reported that the services were optional and youth are not forced to participate. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur; therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with the Administrator Assistant. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights will be emailed to the agency.

narrative: All parties involved confirmed that a staff member made the clients feel disrespected and uncomfortable when a staff member wore inappropriate clothing at the facility and on one occasion lifted their own shirt, exposing their undergarments to the clients in care. It was also confirmed that the same staff member made inappropriate comments to one of the clients which made the client felt extremely uncomfortable and called their DPO. Per Law Enforcement Officers, the comments made by the staff member could be considered a form of grooming. In addition, other witness has also observed the staff member made comments about the client's appearances, weights, and food choices which made clients uncomfortable as well. Lastly, the facility has placed the staff in question in a 90- day trial, staff was moved to another facility, and was written up due to these allegations. Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the Preponderance of evidence standard has been met; therefore, the above allegation(s) are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Interim Licensing Standards, Article 06, 87072 (c)(15)(16)- Personal Rights are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. out of the 9 interviews conducted confirmed a client was touched during a movie night on November 9, 2024, but it was also confirmed that staff were supervising the clients during movie night. One of the clients touched another client in care around the waist, hip, and thigh. Staff members were seated by the desk area overlooking the living room where the movie night was taking place. The incident happened so quickly that staff were not able to prevent the interaction between the clients in care. Staff members did not witness the incident taking place but it was confirmed and reported by other clients in care. During the investigation LPA Turner was informed one of the clients in care has been having inappropriate conversations and a lack of boundaries between other clients and staff. LPA Turner was informed that other clients keep their distance from this client. LPA Turner was notified by staff that the clients in care were separated and placed in different bedrooms. One of the clients in care is no longer able to have roommates due to their behaviors. Therapy and therapeutic assignments are taking place to encourage healthy boundaries between staff and clients in care, and to aid in navigating potentially harmful emotions and actions. Even though the incident took place, there was no lack of supervision during the incident. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegations is UNSUBSTANTIATED. narrative: On July 22, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at the above facility to conduct a Case Management regarding an incident that was reported to the Department. LPA was greeted by Jazmyn Brown, Facility Administrator and was granted entry into the facility. On July 15, 2025, it was observed by facility staff that there was a medication error with a youth in care, during a routine audit of the chart. The facility observed the youth for any side effects and began a comprehensive re-education and reinforcement initiative with the staff involved in medication disbursement. During today's visit, LPA reviewed the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) & Medication Administration Record (MAR) for 1 youth as well as current medication counts for the month of July 2025. LPA obtained the training that is being provided as a result of the error and logs of who has taken the training as of today's date. During the inspection of the above documentation, LPA observed multiple errors, dated from 7.11-7.19, and regarding the forms and medications. LPA conducted 2 of interviews with Staff. Facility Administrator (FA) took the staff who issued the incorrect medication off of the roster for issuing medications until further monitoring of their progress can be completed along with additional training. Additionally, they contacted the psychiatrist to verify that there were adverse side effects. Based on interviews conducted and records review, it was confirmed that the error reported along with other errors did occur. This is an immediate Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to clients in care. A citation is being issued on the attached LIC 809D. An exit interview was conducted and appeal rights were left at the facility.

On September 25, 2025, at approximately 11: A.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez arrived at the above Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a Random Annual Inspection. LPA met with Facility Administrator, Jazmyn Brown who granted LPA entry into the facility. No youths were present at the beginning of the inspection but they arrived later. LPA inspected physical plant of the facility. LPA observed 3 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms and the rear structure. All documentation including Personal Rights, Grievance Policies, and Facility Sketch are posted at the entry area of the house. Carbon Monoxide and Smoke Detectors were tested. Fire Extinguishers were observed fully charged. Water was tested at 108 degrees. First Aid kit was observed to be fully stocked. Cleaning chemicals and Disinfectants were observed to be locked up. There are multiple common rooms available for the youths to occupy. Medications are stored in the staff office behind a locked door and in a locked cabinet. Toilets, wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks. Soap and Paper towels were observed in the bathroom area. Laundry Facilities are in the hallway with a schedule of which days which youth and do their laundry. Bedrooms had appropriate furnishings and clean linen. Extra linens were stored in the hall. Facility Motor Vehicle properly maintained with lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts. Facility is free of vermin. Locked Facilities in the rear yard include the counseling office and 2 garden sheds, all met requirements. Complaint Procedures for Youth were reviewed. The previous quarter's of board minutes were also reviewed by LPA. Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available at the front of the facility. Quarterly Drills conducted and documented in the staff office. Disaster preparedness supplies verified Number of Staff files reviewed 5. Criminal record clearances were verified along with First Aid and CPR. Job Titles and qualifications were verified along with Training Hours. Number of Clients files reviewed 2. Centrally Stored Medication log and Medication Administration log was reviewed and verified. Trauma Informed Practices are implemented as needed and other modes of therapy are used such as Equine Therapy and Healthy Relationships counseling. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: · Annual fees · Administrator Certificate for: Jazmyn Brown · Emergency Disaster Plan (per H&S Code 1565) · Accreditation Name and Expiration Date: October 2025 · Mental Health Program Certificate Expires: October 2025 · Annual Emergency Intervention Log · Personnel Roster, Facility Sketch, LIC 500, LIC 610C and LIC 308 · Waivers and Exceptions An exit interview was conducted with Jazmyn Brown, Facility Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left at the facility.

During the pre-licensing visit, LPA and LPM conducted a Health and Safety inspection using the CARE tool. LPA observed the facility was clean inside and safe. The outside of the facility has a canal that runs through the front and back yard. LPA Soliman observed the facility is a one story house. LPA observed three bedrooms and one staff office equipped with appropriate furniture, bedding, and supplies for clients. Sufficient storage space for client's personal belongings was observed in each room. The facility is requesting to be licensed for six youths ranging in age from 13 to 20 years old. LPA Soliman observed a medication Lock box in the staff office, which was empty, but locked, and accessible only to designated staff. Facility will verify required food on hand at time of client placement. On 10/20/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a case management inspection. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. The Licensing agency was informed that the facility caught a staff member on camera footage smoking marijuana on facility grounds. Based on record review and interview with Administrator, the staff member continued to work their shift after smoking marijuana, there were three residents present at this time, and one staff lead working with the staff. The facility had faced some challenges with the staff prior, provided the staff member additional training, and when other staff reported a concern that the staff member had smelled like marijuana one day when they were on shift, the Administrator spoke to the staff member about this less than a month prior and sent a follow-up email. Once the facility became aware of the incident, by seeing the facility camera footage, the staff member was directed to not come to their shift and instead report to the office. The staff member was to be terminated. However, the staff member resigned before showing to the office. LPA reviewed and obtained copies of staff records, including the follow-up email and staff training documentation. Per Administrator, the smoking policy is to not smoke on the premises, inside or outside, and this covers all substances. Staff are not to be intoxicated in any way on their shifts. Apart from onboarding training that all staff receive, no training or reminder about smoking and intoxication has been provided to the staff yet following this incident, but a staff meeting is planned for today, and Administrator agreed to include this as a topic. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Buildings and Grounds and a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Sonam Prasad, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 2/17/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a facility evaluation visit for a case management regarding observed deficiencies. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA conducted confidential interviews with staff, residents, and witnesses and review of facility records. Through this, the following was learned and/or observed. The facility does not have a facility manager designated for each shift. Per the plan of operation (POO), "At least one staff member each shift shall be designated as Facility Manager. When the House Manager is working a shift, he is considered the Facility Manager for that shift." Per applicable licensing requirements, there shall be a facility manager present whenever the administrator is absent and children are present, including the night shift. Currently, the facility has one designated facility manager, who is also not fully qualified, and who does not work the night shift. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personnel Requirements. The facility admitted a youth without consulting with the full team as indicated in the POO, and only provided 1-2 days of notice of the intake. Per the POO, "When possible, the intake interview will include the La Cheim STRTP psychiatric nurse as well as the La Cheim STRTP Program Administrator... Emergency Placements are discussed with our Program Director who will then consider the case and consult with our Psychiatric Team before giving a decision on intake." A recently admitted youth was admitted without consultation with the CCL approved administrator and without the psychiatric team. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section Plan of Operation. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Sonam Prasad, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Head of Services Dae'Jah Foster; Administrator Sonam Prasad
narrative: On 3/9/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to review and discuss plans of corrections (POCs). LPA met with Head of Services Dae'Jah Foster and Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. The POCs were developed and agreed upon on 2/17/23 for five citations issued on that day, under an LIC 809 and a LIC 9099, both dated 2/17/23. The due date for all POCs was 3/3/23. Submissions were received for 3, and 2 were missing. After the due date, licensee made a request for an extension but did not specify for what or until when. On 3/8/23, a complete request was received. Due to being past the initial due date, the extension is not being granted. At visit, LPA confirmed that the 2 missing POCs were incomplete. These were Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87022(f), due to not following intake procedures outlined in the plan of operation, and Section 87065(f) due to not having facility manager coverage during administrator absence. LPA is assessing two civil penalties for failure to correct, each of $100 per day beginning 3/4/23 and continuing until complete, for a total of $600 each as of today. LPA emphasizes that POCs should be submitted by tomorrow to avoid continuing fees. Additionally, during review of the LIC POC requiring training on consequences, LPA observed that the submitted training slides included discussion of a 10-day consequence for returning after curfew where home visits would be prohibited for 6-9 days. LPA confirmed this has been implemented as a consequence, although it has only recently been implemented for curfew violations. However, the plan of operation (Section 17 of the program statement) states that "discipline will not be used to deny home visits." LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section Plan of Operation as well as assessing a civil penalty for repeat violation of $250, as this section was previously cited on 2/17/23. LPA also advises that per STRTP ILS Section 87072, denying home visits without a court order is personal rights violation, so this policy would not be approved. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Head of Services.

The hired Head of Service does not have a master's degree nor any of the listed licenses. Further, the hired Head of Service has identified themself by multiple titles, including "Residential Director" in their email signature, which is not a listed job title in the approved POO. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the allegation "Head of Service not qualified" is found to be substantiated. Lastly, per applicable licensing requirements and the POO, the facility manager shall have either a bachelor's degree or two years of experience working with the population to be served or equivalent. When hired in October 2022, the facility manager had five months of experience as a direct care staff at the facility. The facility manager had multiple years of experience working with populations outside of the age range and care needs / behavioral backgrounds of the facility population. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the allegation "Facility Manager not qualified" is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing one citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personal Rights, one citation of STRTP ILS Section Personnel Requirements, and one citation of STRTP ILS Section Plan of Operation. See attached deficiency pages. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Sonam Prasad, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 2/17/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a complaint investigation visit to deliver findings. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. The investigation consisted of confidential interviews with staff, residents, and witnesses and review of relevant facility records. Based on LPA's investigation, there have been multiple observations among staff and residents of inappropriateness from staff member(s), including wearing inappropriate clothing, inappropriate interactions with clients, and bias/favoritism. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the allegation "Staff being inappropriate with clients" is found to be substantiated. Additionally, based on LPA's investigation, both the Head of Service and Facility Manager are not qualified. The Head of Service may be filling the role as listed in the facility plan of operation (POO), based on review of applicable requirements and the POO, of the Social Worker/Clinical Coordinator or the Program Director. The former requires a master's degree and the latter a LSCW, MFT, or LPCC license. [] SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 4/7/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit regarding an incident report. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. The incident report in question indicated that on 3/10/23 a resident was administered three pills, instead of the prescribed dosage of one pill, of the medication Benztropine. The incident report was sent to the Licensing agency on 3/24/23. The staff were retrained the next day and all staff were retrained on medication administration. The facility submitted evidence of this upon request. The written incident report was submitted past 7 days following the incident, as were other reports submitted on 3/24/23, including reports for incidents that occurred on 3/13/23, 3/14/23, 3/15/23, and 3/16/23. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, sections Health Related Services and Reporting Requirements. See LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sonam Prasad, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/7/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility and observed deficiencies for which this case management report was generated. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. During the visit, LPA observed a lighter with lighter fluid in it in the side yard. LPA removed the item and handed to Administrator for disposal. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, section Buildings and Grounds. Additionally, LPA measured the hot water at both resident bathrooms and observed the temperature to reach 143. F downstairs and F upstairs. LPA is issuing a citation of Title 22, Section Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Sonam Prasad; CEO Carizma Chapman
narrative: Based on confidential interviews, the food supply was less than the required amount to meet the needs of the residents in care, including an empty refrigerator in the kitchen. Additionally, at least one resident has purchased their own food and keeps their own food supply in their room and has done so after requesting staff purchase preferred foods and those foods not being obtained and/or prepared. LPA observed the facility to require cleaning and multiple repairs. Outside, LPA observed trash and contraband in the side yard, including an empty water jug, two empty cigarette packs, and one lighter with lighter fluid. LPA removed the cigarette packs and lighter and handed to Administrator for disposal. LPA observed a broken support beam under the back deck that had swung to the ground. Downstairs, LPA observed the bathroom toilet roll holder to be missing with a large screw exposed. The bathroom light switch cover was loose with a loose nail. The dressers in both downstairs bedrooms had missing drawer knobs and sharp screws exposed where the knobs would screw on. In one of the downstairs bedrooms, there is a heavily stained mattress with a hole in it, which Administrator stated would be replaced. The window screens were torn, and the curtain rod was pulled from the wall fixture. Upstairs, LPA observed a dresser with no drawer knobs, resulting in difficulty opening the drawers. There were two large holes in the wall of one of the bedrooms, graffiti on a ceiling beam, on the window, on the dresser, and on the front and back of the door. The graffiti on the door included gang-related symbols/lettering and profanity that speaks negatively of the facility and specific staff members. The door frame is also broken. There is currently a resident in this room, and Administrator stated the graffiti and holes were caused by a former resident and that the current resident moved into the room with this damage present. Administrator stated that the resident cannot be moved to one of the vacant bedrooms downstairs due to a runaway risk. When LPA arrived, there were two residents and one staff, Administrator. One of the residents is a known runaway risk. Staffing should be increased to provide extra supervision and meet this resident's needs. Administrator provided evidence of their correspondence with licensee on getting these issues addressed. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, sections 80087 and 80088 and Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards sections 87076 and 87065.5. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Sonam Prasad, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 4/7/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an initial complaint inspection. LPA met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and informed of the purpose of the visit. CEO Carizma Chapman entered the facility at around 1:45PM. During the visit, LPA conducted a tour of the facility and grounds with Administrator and obtained photos. LPA observed the kitchen trash can to be placed on top of the lid, meaning it was being used without a lid. LPA observed expired food in the upstairs cabinets and refrigerator and in the downstairs emergency food supply, including rotten bell pepper, expired cans of soup and sausages, and old cereal in open bags with no boxes. The emergency food supply log was last updated on 2/19/21 and includes more food than was available in the cabinets, and much of the food was expired. Administrator confirmed more food would be purchased but also confirmed that there was a lot less food last week. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 5/24/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a case management visit to request documents. LPA met with Facility Manager Tatiana Good and informed of the purpose of the visit. During a visit to the facility, LPA requested the below documentation for review, but these were not provided during the visit. LPA advised that these should be readily available at the facility site for review by the licensing agency. LPA requested that the below items be sent to LPA by Monday 5/29/23 5PM: 1) Pro-Act Certificates valid during the month of September 2022 for all staff working in August-September 2022. 2) Consequences Logs for 2022 to current. 3) Manual Restraint Logs for 2022 to current 4) Needs and Services Plans for current residents for January 2023 through May 2023. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Tatiana Good, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Additionally, facility records reveal that a 14-day notice was issued for a resident with a stipulation that the resident would not be authorized to return to the facility following another psychiatric hold or law enforcement contact. After an incident in September 2022, the resident was released from a hold, and the facility did not pick up the youth. The facility did not follow proper procedures in developing a transition plan for the resident and ensuring trauma-informed care of the resident. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87061 and Section 87068.4. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Tatiana Good, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts Michelle P. Kyane conducted a case management inspection on 7/27/2023 at 11: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 2 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 2 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 7/27/2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. The minutes of meetings of the board of directors related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth's safety plans, crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Kyane observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Sonam Prasad , Facility Administrator.

On 8/3/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins met with Administrator Sonam Prasad and Facility Manager Lenora Bass. LPA informed Administrator over the phone of the purpose of the visit. Administrator is out on leave and confirmed that S1, who granted LPA entry to the facility and was the only staff on site with one resident present, is not a facility manager. S1 called the Head of Services, who informed that a facility manager was being called in. Facility Manager Lenora Bass arrived at 1:10PM. LPA used the CARE inspection tool to complete this inspection. LPA conducted a tour, file review, and interviews with two staff and one resident. One resident was not present and not available for interview. LPA observed the facility to be clean and organized, kitchen and bathrooms were in sanitary condition, food supply was in quantity and quality to meet residents' needs. The outside space is maintained in safe condition. Personal rights, house rules, grievance procedures, license, and facility sketch are posted where visible to residents and visitors. LPA observed that two employees listed on the LIC 500 and who are required to have a background clearance associated to the facility are not listed as eligible on the clearance roster printed today. See LIC Confidential Names. These staff cannot work on site until a clearance is obtained. LPA observed that personnel files were not available at the facility for review. A continuation visit is required to complete the review of personnel files, including emergency intervention training, first aid/CPR training, and all training certificates. LPA observed, as stated above, that upon entry, there was one staff, who is not a facility manager, and one resident present. There were no other staff present, and LPA requested a facility manager be called. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Criminal Record Clearance, Section Personnel Records, and Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personnel Requirements. See LIC 809-D pages. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility.

narrative: On 08/06/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an announced collateral visit to the facility to conduct a confidential interview. LPA met with Sonam Prasad, Administrator and informed the Administrator on the purpose of the visit. During the inspection, LPA attempted one client confidential interview related to an outside investigation. The facility Administrator informed LPA that the client is not at the facility due to being on a runaway. LPA was unable to speak with the client. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the facility.

On 12/22/ Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jean Stidman and Maignacia Villapudua-Soto conducted a Pre-Licensing Inspection via FaceTime with Yolanda Johnson, Executive Director, and Reverend Randolph Johnson, Sr, .Administrator. LPA's observed the home is a two story five bedroom and three bathroom home. Three bedrooms are used for the clients and two for staff offices. The clients rooms have two beds in each room and two dressers. Two bedrooms have one desk and one bedroom has two desks for the clients. One bathroom downstairs is for staff and two bathrooms upstairs are for clients. All three bathrooms did not have paper towels. LPA observed staff put paper towels in all three bathrooms. The facility has a visitor sign-in sheet, hand sanitizer, temperature check log inside the front entrance. The medications are kept locked in the downstairs office inside a locked file cabinet. The facility has one 'no touch' thermometer that is in the downstairs office. The kitchen sink has paper towels and a bottle of dish soap available for hand-washing. The facility has at least two days supply of perishable and seven days of non-perishable food. The facility has two refrigerators and four freezers full of food. The laundry room, staff offices, staff bathroom, and downstairs closet were locked. The garage has extra cleaning supplies in a cabinet and the hall closet upstairs has extra hygiene supplies that are locked. The backyard has chairs and a punching bag for the clients. The facility has three fire extinguishers that have been serviced within the last 12 months. The facility has two vans. The main van has gloves, hand sanitizer, a mileage log and both vehicles started. The vehicles only have one first aid kit that must be moved between vehicle use. The facility has three clients in placement and three staff were at the facility. LPA's recommended the bedrooms with one desk be sanitized between client use, paper towels be available for use in all the bathrooms, a soap dispenser is available for use at the kitchen sink, the facility obtain an additional first aid kit for the backup van and the facility place extra face masks in the vehicles. The facility will be a granted provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license effective 12/22/2020 with conditions.

An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 3/8/21 at 7:45am. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA Stidman prior to the inspection. An announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Stidman and Maignacia.Villapudua-Soto on 3/9/21 at 7:45am. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. All files and medication documents were sent to LPA Stidman prior to the inspection. LPA's interviewed one staff on site at 7:45pm. Facility cited for violation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87065.1(c)(3)(M) Training Requirements . New direct care staff shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training within 90 days of hire. Training shall include oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications. The file review for staff S1, S2, S3, S4 shows the only time staff were trained on psychotropic medication was on 2/2/21. All four staff have been employed more than 90 days. Facility cited for violation of STRTP ILS 87068. Modifications to Needs and Services Plan. The needs and services plan (NSP) shall be updated at least every 30 days and the licensee shall ensure that the child and his/her authorized representative(s) is offered the opportunity to participate in such modifications. record review of children's records for clients C1, C2 and C3 show the NSP were not updated every 30 days and the licensee did not obtain the authorized representative's signature on the NSP. Facility cited for violation of STRTP ILS 87070(b)(12) Children's Records. A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following: (B) The date of the prescription, (C) The quantity of medication and number of refills initially prescribed, (D) When applicable, any additional refills prescribed, (G) Documentation of each refusal shall include the reason for the refusal. Record review of the Medication Dispensing Logs (MAR) for clients C1, C2 and C3 are missing the date of prescription and number of refills. C MAR shows the client refused a medication but the reason for refusal was not documented. LPA provided this report to Randolph Johnson Sr, Administrator by email with a request for signature and to scan this back to the LPA Stidman on this date.

facility_name: LIFT UP YOUR HEAD THERAPEUTIC HOMES, INC.
narrative: The allegation that facility staff did not ensure that C1 participates in school is related to C1 not attending schooling since October 2020. While the facility staff interviewed stated that they witnessed C1 logging in virtually and engaging in school, regularly. Staff reported that they witnessed C1 completing school work and engaging with teachers while logged on. Facility staff states that C1 was in attendance almost daily and states that despite being in attendance, the facility would get calls daily about not attending school. Staff states that they even called the school office in hopes to rectify the situation but the daily calls continued to be received. CSW states that C1 missing that many days and not being in school is not true. CSW states that C1's school was in direct contact with CSW and had CSW's email but CSW was not notified of any concerns about this prolonged absence(s) from school. LPA sent emails to C1's school requesting information related to C1's attendance 4/9/21 and 8/24/21 and no information was received. LPA was also informed when attempting to contact the school that LPA is not authorized to receive this information without written consent or court order. The allegation that S1 utilized an improper restraint is a result of C1 reporting that C1 was not allowed to leave the staff office when C1 wanted to and that S1 placed themselves between C1 and the exit door. C1 reported that S1 blocked C1 in the staff office and denied C1 the ability to leave the office when C1 wanted to exit. C1 could not recall when this happened. There are no witnesses found and no incident reported that would indicate when this allegation happened or if it happened. S1 denied that C1 was ever blocked in the staff office and prevented to leave at any time. As a result of the investigation and interviews conducted, LPA Hill finds that the allegations that facility staff did not provide minor adequate supervision, facility staff did not ensure that minor participates in school and facility staff utilized an improper restraint are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Johnson and documents were provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced tele inspection on 8/27/21 at 10: AM and met with Yoldanda Johnson, Administrator to discuss findings of the complaint allegations as stated. Ms. Johnson was informed that the investigation included an initial virtual inspection at the facility on 4/9/21, a subsequent in-person inspection conducted on 7/16/21, interviews with C1, C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6 (see LIC811 dated 8/25/21) as well as interviews with four staff, complainant and county social worker (CSW). LPA was also provided with C1's Needs and Services Plan and staff contact information. The allegation that facility staff did not provide adequate supervision is related to C1 leaving on an unauthorized absence and staff not shadowing or looking for C1. Incident report received 4/3/21 indicates that C1 did go on an unauthorized absence 3/27/21. After C1 did not return on their own "after giving C1 time", and C1 could not be located in the area, law enforcement was contacted and a missing persons report was filed. CSW stated that they were aware that the facility would give C1 time to calm down and did sometimes follow but not always due to the availability of staff to do this. CSW stated that C1 would usually return on their own after calming down. CSW stated that there was no formal plan related to this time away in the Needs and Services Plan. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto, and LPA Jean Stidman arrived at the facility for the purpose of conducting unannounced ANNUAL/RANDOM inspection. LPAs met with Administrator, Rev Randolph Johnson and Administrator Yolanda Johnson on 12/21/21 at 10: AM. The home is a three (3) bedrooms, two staff office with three (3) bathrooms, one of the bathrooms is used by staff. LPAs toured the facility inside and outside. LPA inspected the entire facility. All bedrooms are equipped with drawers and closet space and smoke detectors. At today's inspection four clients and three staff were present during the inspection. LPAs reviewed five client files. The following conditions were observed: The home is clean, safe and sanitary throughout. The kitchen has adequate food, fruit, snacks and supplies. The backyard is clean and has adequate space for clients to play and take space. Cleaning supplies and hazardous materials are locked in the laundry room and inaccessible to clients. The extinguishers (2) and first aid kits. The Facility Van was inspected and is in good repair. All bedrooms of the home are equipped with adequate linens, drawers for each client. All required Licensing forms are posted and were observed during inspection. LPA observed a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods in the kitchen. The food menu is posted on the refrigerator along with personal rights. The home has games, and movies for the clients. LPA's were not able to complete the inspection due to technical issues and will return at another date to complete the inspection. LPA's discussed deficiency concerns with the licensee.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto arrived at the above STRTP to conduct a Case Management inspection on 1/20/22 at 3: PM. LPA Villapudua-Soto met with Janae Moore, Direct Care staff, Administrative Assistant. Community Care Licensing received an incident report dated 1/10/22 pertaining to C1 being picked up at school. C1 entered the van and tried to change the channel on the radio. Staff reminded client that he was listening to his music and changed the radio station. C1 stated that music was a coping skill and needed to listen to his music. C1 attempted to change the music station and staff then placed his hand on C1's hand and asked not to change the radio station. This activity went back and forth 2 or 3 times. The client exited the van upset and returned to the school. The staff left client at the school. LPA interviewed C1; LPA will return to the facility for further interviews. No deficiencies were cited at this time. Further investigation is needed.

narrative: An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ignacia Villapudua-Soto on 01/24/2022 at 2: PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Administrator Yolanda Johnson. An initial inspection was conducted on 1/20/22. LPA discussed an incident report submitted to Community Care Licensing on January 10, 2022, concerning client 1 regarding an incident (Refer to confidential name's list, LIC 811) where C1 was picked up from school upon entering the vehicle, C1 turned off the music that was listening to. S1 reminded client that he was listening to music and turned his music. C1 was angry due to being picked up from school and not participating in school track. C1 changed the radio station to his music and staff placed his hands on C1 hand and squeezed it. C1 became angry and stated that this was his coping therapy to listen to music and asked the staff not to touch him. This activity went back and forth 2 or 3 times. C1 was angry and was yelling at the staff never to touch him again and C1 exited the van and walked back to school LPA interviewed C1, S2 and Administrator regarding this incident. LPA obtained additional information to support the incident that Staff did squeeze C1's hand. The facility will be cited 87072(d)(11)To be free of physical........ emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions ....withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning. Refer to LIC 809 for Title 22 deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted. **Confidential names list provided** **Appeal rights given***

met_with: Yolanda Johnson Executive Director, Reverend Johson Administrator
narrative: On November 28, 2022, at PM an In- Office informal Conference was held with the Lift Up Your Head STRTP (LUYH). The following people were in attendance: Regional Manager Margo Castaneda (RM), Licensing Program Manager Dara Campos (LPM), Licensing Program Analyst Jean Stidman (LPA), Yolanda Johnson Executive Director (ED), Reverend Johson Administrator (AD), Mia Washington facility board member, Marjana Jackson Manager with Systems of Care (SOC), Michael Ford SSM Foster Care Rates SOC branch, Craig Pedrucci Division Chief with San Joaquin County, Kim Pawlowicz Licensing Program Analyst (LPA2) attended in person. Cynthia Poulos, Melissa Guerrero and Donna Bickham with San Joaquin County Behavioral Health Services attended via Microsoft Teams. The following information was discussed: · Failure to meet condition of the facilities Provisional License · Denial Letter for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) - Closure Plan · Appeal Rights for the denial of the applications LPA Jean Stidman and LPM Dara Campos reviewed and discussed the report with Reverend and Yolanda Johnson. narrative: On Tuesday 9/21/21 at 9:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to conduct the required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and Facility Manager Ike Davis. LPA made a pre-visit screening call and safety precautions were taken, including hand hygiene and mask-wearing. LPA used the Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. LPA inspected facility site, conducted interviews with all present staff and residents, and reviewed all current staff and client files, including files for recently discharged resident and staff who recently left facility. At 4:45PM, LPA had completed the inspection. An annual continuation will need to be completed in order to finalize the report and any citations or advisories. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On Friday 9/24/21, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for an annual continuation inspection. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. There were no children present during today's visit. The inspection was initiated on Tuesday 9/21/21. Refer to LIC Facility Evaluation Report, dated 9/21/21. LPA used the Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. LPA inspected the facility site, conducted interviews with all present staff and residents, and reviewed current staff and client files, including files for recently discharged resident and staff who recently left facility. The facility was observed to be safe and free of immediate hazards. There are no firearms on the premises, per Administrator. Chemicals and medications are properly stored and inaccessible to residents. Medication administration is logged correctly and, based on staff interviews, medication administration procedures are thorough and followed correctly. Facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature. Residents report that the program provides a supportive environment. The facility is operating in accordance with their license. Staff have background clearances and are associated to the facility. The following concerns were observed: LPA observed the following: Sliding door handle broken; curtain rod over sliding door needs to be drilled back into the wall; large tear in living room sofa with stuffing spilling out; broken microwave door and handle; 3 bedroom doors are broken and/or have large holes, and 1 of those doors does not close due to damage; 4 holes in walls upstairs that have not been repaired; lights in the large bedroom's en-suite bathroom were non-functioning, including the toilet room light. Some items are pre-existing, and LPA was advised they would be fixed soon, so the repairs are still in-progress. Damages at site are not determined to cause an immediate risk to residents. LPA issued a citation of Title 22, Section Buildings and Grounds. LPA observed that the needs and services plans for resident R1, R2, and R3 (Refer to LIC Confidential Names, dated 9/24/21) were not available on site for review. LPA was informed by clinician that a needs and services had not been updated for resident R1 since the pre-placement. R1 was placed on 7/2/21. LPA issued a citation of STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87068. Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. Needs and services plans should be updated every 30 days, noting any progress in the youth's case plan and can provide an opportunity to document what, if any, information from outside agencies is still being obtained. LPA observed that documentation of successful completion of training was not maintained in the personnel record for each staff. LPA is unable to verify training and that all hours of initial training and the 40 hours of annual training have been completed if not properly documented/logged. Current records do not reflect that all training was met, including for staff S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, and S6. LPA issued a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87065. Training Requirements. LPA observed that the facility has developed and is using a clearly organized chart for initial training that could be adapted for documenting annual training. LPA observed that the hot water in the upstairs hallway bathroom measured at a high of 154. F, which exceeds the permitted ranged. A hot water warning notice was posted at the sink, complying with Title 22, Section Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies. LPA advises that the facility continue to monitor the hot water temperature at vanity sinks and adjust hot water settings as necessary to ensure temperatures do not go above F. Three citations and one advisory were issued at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Britanee Windom conducted a case management inspection on 03/15/22 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 4 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, March 15, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Davis.

On 4/20/22 at 3PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility regarding deficiencies that were discovered during an investigation at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and screening call. The investigation was conducted by the Investigations Branch. During investigation, confidential interviews were conducted with residents, staff, and authorized representative, and police report was reviewed. Based on interviews and record review, the following deficiencies were found. Staff S1 (See LIC Confidential Names, dated 4/20/22) used a disallowed restraint technique, by placing resident R1 in a prone restraint, per the program statement emergency intervention plan, which states, "Interventions Never to Be Used... Prone restraint, unless written authorization has been provided by the youth's physician, based upon their prior physical examination of the youth." Based on file review, the facility did not obtain such written authorization documentation, as R1 was not in placement long enough to get a medical and physical assessment. Additionally, the file contains a Health & Education Passport, dated 12/28/21, that lists asthma as one of R1's conditions, which is listed as a risk factor in prone restraints in the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87095. Emergency Intervention Prohibitions. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87022(f) Plan of Operation. During the prone restraint, R1 placed R1's own hands behind their back, and S1 held R1's hands down to keep R1 down in the restraint, as witnessed by S2, and by doing so held R1 in a prohibited restraint. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section Section 87095.01(a)(5) Emergency Interventions Prohibition, which specifically prohibits the use at any time of any restraint that places a child in a prone position with their hands behind their back. LPA also advises, per STRTP ILS Section 87095.66(c) that any restraint requiring two staff, such as prone restraints, must be performed with two staff. Additionally, at visit LPA inspected the personnel record for S1 and found there was no intervention training certificate. The program statement indicates the facility will use Pro-Act, but Administrator stated the facility does not perform restraints. The personnel record does not reflect that S1 was properly trained and certified prior to using the restraint technique, and S1 and Administrator confirmed that S1 has not been trained since working with licensee's facilities. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87095.65(a) Emergency Intervention Staff Training. It was also learned during the investigation, based on S1's statements, that S1 made statements to R1 such as, "This is the best home you'll ever be in, don't mess it up." This statement does not align with supported trauma-informed care practices and is emotionally abusive in nature. Staff statement that R1 is "bad for business" also indicates an inappropriate attitude toward R1. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87072(c)(11) Personal Rights. Lastly, the incident report submitted by licensee and written by staff S1 for the incident during which S1 performed the prone restraint does not include information about the restraint. As such, Administrator stated she was unaware that a restraint had been performed. The incident report is also lacking detail of the events, does not indicate when staff notified law enforcement or what items were damaged, and includes language (i.e. "verbal judo") that Administrator is unfamiliar with and cannot verify as part of the progam's intervention plan. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87095.61(a) Documentation and Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli on the above date. During the inspection, LPA Bertoli met with Administrator Nina Davis and Facility Manager Keylai Boughton and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 2 child records on site at the facility starting at 11:30 am. LPA reviewed 5 staff personnel files on site at the facility at 1:30pm. LPA reviewed 2 child psychotropic medications and medication records at 1:15pm. LPA interviewed 2 staff on site starting at 11:00am. LPA interviewed 2 children currently taking psychotropic medication starting at 10:30am. LPA provided the Summary Report to facility upon completion. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. An Advisory note was given on ILS section 87068. Needs and Services Plan. LPA conducted exit interview with Nina Davis and Keylai Boughton at 2:45pm

The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) is/are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072(c)(10) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. It was reported that staff S1 made threatening statements to R1 and threatened to hit R1, but staff denied and no witnesses confirmed statements. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents, staff, and witness, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
