narrative: On 10/6/22 at 11:18AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for an inspection. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and Facility Manager Keylai Boughton and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool to conduct this inspection. Two staff and four residents were present. No residents were interviewed due to not agreeing to be interviewed. The facility grounds were inspected, and LPA will return to complete the inspection. Medications, chemicals, and sharps are stored where inaccessible to residents. Personal rights, Licensing contact information, and grievance procedures are posted in the facility. License and facility sketch are posted. There are no firearms on the premises, per Administrator, and no dangerous items were observed by LPA. Residents were observed to be clean in well-fitting clothes, engaged in activity together and with staff, and comfortable with staff and other residents. Facility has a large supply of food of good quality and within date, and staff confirmed that food out of date is never served and staff check at least bi-weekly and when preparing meals to ensure food quality. During visit, LPA observed that the facility van, which staff confirmed is in use, has a large crack across the front of the windshield. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title Section 80074. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report sent to Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 12/14/22 at 2PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and Facility Manager Keylai Boughton and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the noncompliance conference (NCC) held on August 8th, 2022, the facility will be subject to increased inspections, will submit a LIC 500 on a quarterly basis, will provide updates on pursuing designating different administrators for all facilities under licensee, and will provide staff training and reminders, documenting everything, on all required topics, including supervision, facility policies and procedures, communication, personal rights, and emergency intervention. During visit, LPA inspected facility, resident, and personnel files. LPA received the submitted LIC 500. The facility has not yet been able to designate a separate administrator for each house but will continue to provide updates. The second house that Administrator Nina oversees is temporarily closed, so for the time being, Administrator is only overseeing one facility. Staff training is well documented, but some issues were observed. LPA observed that one staff member was designated a facility manager, but their file did not reflect they were fully qualified for the role. Additionally, another staff file reflected that the staff member had not received emergency intervention training since April 2021 and had 27 hours of training to complete by February 2023. LPA issued citations and advisories for these during a post-licensing inspection completed on this same day. As such, additional citations/advisories are not included as part of this report. No other deficiencies were found. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility. Administrator Nina Davis's signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On 12/28/22 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a complaint inspection at The Lighthouse Mentoring Center 2 located at Buckeye Way, Antioch, CA 94509 and spoke with Geramani Martin, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA Ng reviewed documents and conducted interviews with client and staff. All interviewed parties stated there is sufficient staffing to meet minors needs. In addition to the confidential interviews, LPA also reviewed their staff schedule and found that there is enough staff to ensure proper supervision. Although, the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that there is insufficient staffing to meet minors needs. Therefore, the above allegation are unsubstantiated. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with Geramani Martin, Facility Manager. narrative: On 3/10/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. Per the noncompliance conference (NCC) held on August 8th, 2022, the facility will be subject to increased inspections, will submit a LIC 500 on a quarterly basis, will provide updates on pursuing designating different administrators for all facilities under licensee, and will provide staff training and reminders, documenting everything, on all required topics, including supervision, facility policies and procedures, communication, personal rights, and emergency intervention. During visit, LPA inspected facility, resident, and personnel files. LPA received the current LIC 500. The facility has not yet been able to designate a separate administrator for each house but will continue to provide updates. An ad has been running, but the licensee has received few applicants and no applicants have met minimum qualifications. Staff training is well documented, and staff are receiving training on the required topics. However, not all staff have received the required 40 hours of annual training. Facility Manager S1's (see LIC Confidential Names List) record reflects that only 13 hours of training was received between February 2022 and February 2023, which is 27 hours short. LPA also notes that Facility Managers S2 and S3 need 23 hours and 16 hours respectively by June 2023. Licensee provided letters sent to staff in December 2022 informing staff of the missing hours and the need to have 40 hours. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.1 (see attached LIC 809-D). An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility. Administrator's signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 8/28/2023 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an announced visit to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this visit is to conduct the Psychotropic Medications inspection. LPA met with administrator Nina Davis who assisted with the inspection. At the time of the inspection, there were two staff, and the administrator. The facility currently has five clients, three were at school, one was on a home visit, and one client was in the facility after an appointment. LPA reviewed the files of two staff however, training's were located in a separate binder observed by LPA Belfield. During a review of the training's LPA Belfield did not observe training specific to psychotropic medication. Administrator states that the person in charge of the training files will send the training to this LPA via email. LPA agreed to this. LPA Belfield interviewed two staff members. The facility's current census is five clients, three of whom are currently prescribed psychotropic medications. Three client files were reviewed. LPA also reviewed the centrally stored and medication logs as well as Psychotropic Medication Administration Record for each client. Based on record review, LPA Belfield observed that one of the psychotropic medications for C2 ( see LIC 811 dated 8/28/23), are being documented incorrectly and it is the wrong dosage is being administered to the client. Facility will be cited for violation of Interim Licensing standards, section 87075(c) Health related services. LPA Belfield observed staff conduct a pill count of the psychotropic medications for each client. There were missing pills for C2's medication was noted during the medication log review. Facility will be cited for violation of 87075(c) Health related services. During a review of the Psychotropic Medication Record, it was observed that the medications required information was present, however it was incorrect such as refill information. This is a violation of California Code of Regulations (CCR) 84070(b)(13)(c). Technical Violation Advisory issued. During a review of the client file LPA Belfield observed that the needs and service plans do not have clients signatures and there is no documentation to prove that clients are offered the opportunity to participate in the development of the needs and service plan. Technical Advisory issued for Interim Licensing Standards, section 87068. Needs and Services Plan. All citations and advisories described on the following page D, during the completion of this inspection at a later date. Due to time restraints and needed documentation, this inspection is incomplete and will be completed at a later date.

On 9/26/2023 at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced inspection to the above licensed facility. The purpose of this inspection is to conduct the continuation of the Psychotropic Medications inspection. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis who assisted with the inspection. At the time of the inspection, there was one staff present S1 (see LIC 811 dated 8/28/2023). The facility currently has four clients, all who were at school during the time of this inspection. During the first part of this inspection conducted on 8/28/2023, due to time restraints and needed documentation that was being sent to the department, the inspection was not able to be completed. The training documentation was sent to this LPA within the following week. Based on review of the training information received and the observations of LPA Belfield during the previous inspection and today 9/26/2023, and confidential interviews conducted, the following citations and advisory will be issued to the facility today and will be described on the following page LIC D. During a review of the staff training received for the staff, Two of four staff did not have training on psychotropic medication S2 and S3 (see LIC 811 dated 8/28/23), facility cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards Section 87065.1(d)(3)(M) Supervision, Evaluation, and Training Requirements. Administrator did not have required minimum number of hours for psychotropic medication training however, there was two hours of training earned, technical violation advisory issued for of section 87064(a)(1)(B) of the Interim Licensing standards. The facility's current census is four clients, three of whom are currently prescribed psychotropic medications. Three client files were reviewed on 8/28/20203 and one client file was reviewed for follow up today 9/26/20203. LPA also reviewed the centrally stored and medication logs as well as Psychotropic Medication Administration Record for each client. Based on this record review, confidential interviews, and LPA Belfield observed that one of the psychotropic medications for C2 ( see LIC 811 dated 8/28/23), is being documented incorrectly and the documentation is observed having the wrong dosage being administered to the client. It was confirmed that client was receiving double the amount of medication they were supposed to be receiving. Facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing standards, section 87075(c) Health related services. A civil penalty is being assessed. LPA Belfield observed staff conduct a pill count of the psychotropic medications for each client on 8/28/2023. There were missing pills for C2's medication during the pill count conducted by the staff on 8/28/2023. Another pill count was conducted for C2 during this inspection today 9/26/2023 the medication count was not correct. Facility is cited for violation of 87075(c) Health related services. LPA observed missing information and incorrect information from the centrally stored medication form and the PMAR form for C2. It was also observed by this LPA that medications listed on the JV220 for C2 are not all listed and administered to the client at the facility. Documented communication between prescribing physician was observed by this LPA. This Medication inspection was conducted on 8/28/2023, 9/26/2023 and concluded on 9/27/2023. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be sent to Administrator Nina Davis and Licensee Jay Lightener.

narrative: However, the youth did report feeling uncomfortable with the discussion afterwards. Because no one else witnessed the incident, and because the reports contradict, it cannot be confirmed what specific topics/questions were discussed and in how much detail. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with resident and staff, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. LPA advises that the facility be sure to inform and train all staff on each youth's care plan prior to staff providing care. Staff should all receive CSEC/CSEY training but should have been informed of and trained on how to provide care to the specific youths in the facility, including being aware of the youth's needs and behaviors, in order to know how best to communicate and check in with the youth. LPA is issuing an advisory per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. NOTE: This complaint came in when the facility was a group home, so the group home regulation is provided. The facility has since transitioned to STRTP, so please be advised of the corresponding STRTP regulation, STRTP ILS Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report left with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Rashell Conner, who agreed to sign the copy of this report emailed by LPA and return a signed copy to LPA.
investigation_findings: 13On Wednesday 10/07/2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to close the complaint and provide findings. Due to COVID-19 safety orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. LPA met with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Rashell Conner. During investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews with involved resident and staff. Based on confidential interviews, the staff member did not realize the youth felt uncomfortable due to the youth answering questions and offering up additional information. The staff was attempting to check in on the youth and had not been aware of the youth's CSEC activity. In the youth's needs and services, it states that the youth "has history of AWOLs... truancy, argumentative, including cutting school... and [youth] is high risk for CSEY." The staff was unaware that the conversation may lead to potentially inappropriate topics. The staff member works at another house under the licensee and only filled in a few times at this facility site. The staff reported that they did not ask specific questions about the youth's activities or how much the youth charges during these activities. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

met_with: Assistant Director La Tanya Harper, Interim Administrator Rashell Conner
narrative: A replacement was found after calling multiple care staff. Based on the interviews with residents, staff did night checks but possibly not after a certain hour. It is unclear what time resident R1 left the facility. R1 reported R1 left out the bedroom window at 11:30PM and that there weren't any room checks after 8PM. R1's roommate reported R1 left at 9:30PM and that staff were doing regular checks. S1 reported the last check in was at 11PM. It is possible that S1 called the advice nurse about the chest pain around the same time that S1 went upstairs and did the check ins, but it is also possible that due to their chest pain, S1 may not have been able to make it upstairs to check on youth. It is possible that a lack of supervision from either a lack of check ins or the delay in finding a replacement staff due to not having an on-call staff allowed for R1 to AWOL and travel to another city. R1 has a known history of being an AWOL risk and having relationships with older men. The issue with invading the youths' privacy is an understandable concern. However, if a youth is asleep, the only way to check on them is to have sight of them so you do not disturb their sleep. Morning staff reported a teddy bear was in the bed when they tapped the "body" and pulled the covers, so even if night staff had done a check in by sight, they still may not have realized the youth had left. It was reported that the reason there was no on-call staff designated in the absence of a facility manager was because staff were unwilling to for concerns of not being properly paid. LPA was not able to determine if this was the case. The only staff designated facility responsibility and on-call status at that time was S2. Further, the Director and Assistant Director could not be reached. However, S2 was responsive and did assist in finding a staff to take over the night shift. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. LPA is issuing an advisory per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 84065. Staff/Child Ratios. Additionally, LPA is issuing an advisory per Health and Safety Code Sections 1522.4(a). The facility has since been licensed as STRTP, but this incident occurred when facility was still a group home. LPA advises the facility review STRTP ILS Section 87065. Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios, as there are additional requirements regarding on-call staff for STRTPs. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Rashell Conner, who agreed to sign the report emailed by LPA Hawkins and return a signed copy to LPA.
investigation_findings: 13On Thursday 11/05/20 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver findings of a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Rashell Conner. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with staff and residents. Based on interviews and record review, staff said they did room checks, but resident said staff did not. Staff stated that they do not go in the female residents' room because they sleep in their underwear and they do not want to invade their privacy. On this night, Saturday 6/13/20, staff S1 was the overnight staff. Around 11PM, S1 had a medical emergency related to a heart condition and needed to find a staff replacement. S1 called an advice nurse, who advised S1 go to the emergency room. Staff S1 notified supervisor S2, who stated S2 couldn't leave S2's young children home alone late at night. Both S1 and S2 reached out to the Director and Assistant Director but were not able to get ahold of either. There was no on-call staff other than S2, as there was no facility manager and, per staff, the facility manager usually filled the role of on-call staff. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: ... stated they drove into the youth to get the youth to move but later denied this in interview with LPA. Based on LPA's review of video footage, R1 placed self on the hood and windshield of the vehicle and was directed by staff to get off of the vehicle. The vehicle appears to be stopped at this time. R1 removes self from the vehicle, and as R1 steps off and away from the vehicle, the vehicle is propelled forward about a foot at approximately 5- MPH. The speed is low but is high enough to indicate the gas was pressed rather than just the brake being lifted. R1's body is very close to the vehicle, and R1's hand is either still on the vehicle or had just been removed. From the driver's side, from where the video is shot, it is not clear that R1 would not be hit by the vehicle. However, R1 does not show signs of being hit. The vehicle's horn is then honked 6 times in succession. There is no apparent purpose for the honking other than perhaps to warn R1 from walking in front of the vehicle as it is now moving. Based on this footage, LPA determines that the staff operating the vehicle did not act appropriately, and their actions put the health and safety of R1 at risk. Individuals should not jump onto vehicles, and individuals should demonstrate extra caution when operating vehicles around others, especially if others are making attempts to place themselves on top of the vehicle. Additionally, during this incident, staff S1 confirmed to police that S1 stated to youth R2 when R2 pulled out a knife, "You're bringing a knife to a gun fight," though S1 later denied this in interview with LPA. Police found an illegally concealed firearm during a search of S1's vehicle. S1 stated to police that S1 did not know at the time that S1's coworker (S2) had put S2's gun in S1's vehicle after extensive damage was caused to S2's vehicle earlier that day. S1 denied brandishing the weapon. Based on involved resident interview, S1 made a statement about not we're fighting but we're shooting. Based on record review and confidential interviews, S1 made a statement to R2 of a threatening nature that was a highly inappropriate thing to say to a child in care at a STRTP facility, as the statement could reasonably be interpreted by the youth as a threat. Multiple charges were filed against S1 by police, including assault with a deadly weapon, criminal threats, and cruelty to a child. The charges were ultimately dropped, but there is no evidence in supplemental reports that contradicts the findings mentioned above. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation per California Code of Regulations, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights and a copy of this report were provided to Asst. Director La Tanya Harper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. ... stated they drove into the youth to get the youth to move but later denied this. R1 removes self from the vehicle, and as R1 steps off and away from the vehicle, the vehicle is propelled forward about a foot at approximately 5- MPH. The speed is low but is high enough to indicate the gas was pressed rather than just the brake being lifted. R1's body is very close to the vehicle, and R1's hand is either still on the vehicle or had just been removed. From the driver's side, from where the video is shot, it is not clear that R1 would not be hit by the vehicle. However, R1 does not show signs of being hit. The vehicle's horn is then honked 6 times in succession. There is no apparent purpose for the honking other than perhaps to warn R1 from walking in front of the vehicle as it is now moving. Based on this footage, LPA determines that the staff operating the vehicle did not act appropriately, and their actions put the health and safety of R1 at risk. narrative: On Tuesday, September 14, 2021 at 9:54AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the Inspection Tool to complete the annual inspection. LPA toured the facility site and observed the facility to be clean and sanitary. Administrator informed LPA that the facility plans to get a new dusting rod to remove a hanging web/dust web in the entry way and to haul the old mattresses currently stored in the garage to the dump. Commonly touched services are sanitized regularly. Pool in backyard has a pool cover. Per Administrator, there are no firearms on the premises. Sharps and medications are stored in the locked closet in the entryway. First aid kit is stored centrally. Scissors and tweezers are missing from the first aid kit. Bedrooms are tidy, residents have individual beds, and beds have clean linens. The room temperature and hot water temperature measured within permitted ranges, at F and 114. F, respectively. The kitchen was in sanitary condition with functioning equipment and dishware, cookware, and utensils to meet the needs of residents in care. Food storage was sanitary, food was fresh and in date, and there was food storage to meet the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate. LPA reviewed all client files and staff files. Staff files were complete, and training record shows that the facility has been conducting trainings in 2021. Per Administrator, who is new in this position, the 2020 training record has not been found yet. 2019 training was complete for staff who were working at the facility that year. 1 file had a first aid certificate that was expired by just under a month, but the refresher training had been conducted, and the certificate needed to be placed in the file. 1 file for new hire was missing health screening, but the doctor visit to complete this was scheduled and evidence of the appt being scheduled was in file. [] Client files were mostly complete. See LIC Confidential Names for the following: - The file for R1 was missing or had incomplete: Identification/Emergency Info (LIC 601); Personal Rights (LIC 613B); Cash resources (LIC 405); and Physician's Report w/ TB Test (LIC 602). NOTE: R1 was placed a few days ago on 9/10/21. - The files for R2, R3, and R4 were missing: Personal Rights (LIC 613B). LPA issued 2 advisories per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Health Related Services and STRTP Interim Licensing Standards Personal Rights. No citations were issued. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On Thursday 2/3/22 at 9:16AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to review training records, per the agreement established at the Noncompliance Conference on 9/23/21. The agreed upon terms were that the licensee would be subject to increased monitoring for at least 12 months and the licensee is to conduct monthly trainings on any of these topics: trauma-informed care practices, safe vehicle operation, proper de-escalation procedures when following residents in a vehicle, and firearm storage and safety. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA also spoke to Assistant Director La Tanya Harper over the phone to discuss the report. Safety precautions were taken, including LPA wearing an N95 mask, hand hygiene and gloves, and screening call. LPA reviewed the training binder, training logs, and training certificates and obtained copies of the training logs. LPA observed the following: 1) Staff S1, S2, and S3 (See LIC Confidential Names) have not attended a training on firearms, per the logs. LPA advises that a make-up training be held for these staff members. 2) The AWOL Procedures training covered safe vehicle operation, based on the training materials previously provided to LPA, but the training log does not clearly reflect this, and the materials were not available in the binder due to being stored at the administrative office location. LPA advises that, since the requirement to have trainings on safe vehicle operation is in response to a staff member's unsafe operation of a vehicle during an AWOL incident, the materials be available for review at the facility site to verify for anyone reviewing the logs that it covered safe vehicle operation and/or that another all-staff training be conducted that specifically covers safe vehicle operation and is titled to reflect that. The training log is otherwise complete, and the licensee is in compliance. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Nina Davis and Assistant Director La Tanya Harper over the phone. There are no citations. A copy of this report was provided to Administrator Nina Davis, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst Britanee Windom conducted a case management inspection on 05/12/22 at 9: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 1 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, May 12, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, monthly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Nina Davis.

On 6/30/22 at 2:55PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to review training records, per the agreement established at the Noncompliance Conference on 9/23/21. The agreed upon terms were that the licensee would be subject to increased monitoring for at least 12 months and the licensee is to conduct monthly training on any of these topics: trauma-informed care practices, safe vehicle operation, proper de-escalation procedures when following residents in a vehicle, and firearm storage and safety. LPA met with Direct Care Staff Keisha Ward and Direct Care Counselor Imani Richardson and informed of the purpose of the visit. Pre-visit contact was made in the morning of the day of visit. LPA reviewed the training binder, training logs, and training certificates and obtained copies/scans of the training logs. LPA observed the following: 1) At the last visit, on 2/3/22, it was observed that not all staff had attended a training on firearm safety. At today's visit, it was observed that the staff missing the training have since attended. 2) All except for one staff have been trained on safe operation of vehicles. 3) The facility is conducting trainings on listed, and related, topics about every 30 days / monthly, per the agreement. However, per the training logs, not all staff have attended trainings. Two staff training logs do not reflect any trainings have been completed since 3/29/22, and one staff training log does not reflect any training since 3/9/22. Staff logs reflect that staff have completed as much as 20 hours and as little as 8 hours of training in the past 12 months and do not reflect that the 40hr requirement has been met. 4) Lastly, LPA observed that staff on site, who is the only staff present while two residents are present, is not trained to the level of a facility manager. The 4PM shift's staff were also not facility managers. LPA is issuing two citations, per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Personnel Requirements and Section 87065. Supervision, Evaluation and Training Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Direct Care Counselor Imani Richardson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Nina Davis, Facility Manager Imani Richardson
narrative: On 9/16/22 at 3:55PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Nina Davis and Facility Manager Imani Richardson and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. Two staff interviews were conducted. No resident interviews were conducted due to resident being unavailable for interview. The facility was observed to be clean, sanitary, and tidy. There is food to meet the needs of resident in care, and the majority of food was within date. There is a pool with a locked cover. Medications and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to residents. A menu is posted in the kitchen. Facility license, facility sketch, emergency disaster plan, grievance procedures, and personal rights are all posted in the facility where visible to residents and visitors. COVID-19 symptoms, hygiene routines, and screening procedures are posted around the facility. Room temperature was maintained within permitted range, at F. Hot water at bathrooms measured 123. F, and all sinks had hot water caution signs posted. Despite the sign, the hot water still needs to be within the permitted range. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80088. See attached LIC 809-D. LPA observed a bowl of fruit with a molded melon, which Facility Manager stated had been recently purchased. LPA observed that the bowl was placed on the kitchen table under the skylight. Facility Manager immediately threw out the fruit and cleared and cleaned the bowl. LPA advises that the facility ensure all spoiled food is thrown out promptly and advises that fruit be stored where it will remain fresh and out of direct sunlight. An annual continuation visit will be conducted to complete this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Facility Manager Imani Richardson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

...school schedule. Per the facility's program statement, "Transportation is provided to all youth/NMDs to school unless the youth/NMD prefers to walk to school in which in that case it is right for their age, developmental level, maturity and it's in their Needs and Service Treatment Plan," which was not followed. Further, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section Transportation provides that facilities shall ensure transportation is provided to residents with any special arrangements agreed upon with the care team and documented in the needs and services. Based on confidential interviews and record review, staff perform room searches with two staff and the resident(s) present during the search. This policy/procedure is not listed in the facility program statement. Additionally, based on confidential interviews, multiple reports indicated that staff have made inappropriate comments and spoken inappropriately of or with residents, including referring to resident as nasty for making a mess and discussing a resident and their personal matters around or with other residents. One of these staff is no longer employed by the licensee. Based on confidential interviews, staff did open a resident's expected mailed ID in order to make a copy of it and has done this before. However, it is not a policy or a trend that staff will open residents' mail, and no mail is withheld from residents. Staff do request that residents open packages in front of staff in order to log it on residents' inventory list and to ensure the item is not dangerous or contraband. Resident reports indicate this has not been an issue for residents. However, this is not listed in the facility program statement, and residents have a right to confidentiality in the mail they receive. Lastly, based on confidential interviews, a resident requested to be taken to the emergency room for pain, but staff did not agree to transport resident. Resident and a peer called 911, and when the ambulance arrived, staff spoke to the medics, who then left. Later that night, the resident again expressed their concern of their pain, and staff called the advice nurse, who advised the resident be taken to the emergency room, and the resident was transported by ambulance due to the late hour. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections Plan of Operation and Health Related Services and STRTP ILS Sections Transportation and Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Assistant Administrator La Tanya Harper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. Based on confidential interviews, staff do provide transportation to the hospital, but if an incident occurs in the middle of the night, when the ratio only requires one staff on shift and on-call staff cannot arrive quickly enough, staff will allow a resident to be transported by ambulance. LPA advises that per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065. Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios, facilities with a capacity of 6 or fewer residents, when one or more residents are present, shall have at least one direct care staff on call and capable of arriving to the facility within 30 minutes. Based on confidential interviews and record review, a resident had a medical visit on 11/14/21, and the visit summary advised a follow-up appointment be made for one (1) week later, which would be around 11/21/21. Medical records reflect that multiple visits were made, but no visit summary for a visit around this time was observed. Based on interviews and record review, some appointments were cancelled or could not be scheduled within the physician's requested time frame, and some health appointments the resident elected to not go to. Resident records do not reflect a trend of not scheduling doctor appointments. There is insufficient information to determine that appointments are not made for residents. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is/are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation(s) is/are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Staff did not call the police immediately for each time the resident left due to the resident following a pattern of returning within 15 to 60 minutes. Additionally, the resident was a known risk for unauthorized leaves, which the facility expressed concerns with to the resident's authorized representative, but the facility found 1:1 supervision inaffective for the resident due to the resident becoming agitated by increased staff monitoring and being near staff, resulting in 1:1 supervision being terminated for the resident. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be substantiated. Due to the known risk for unauthorized leaves and not reporting the leave(s) immediately to the police, per facility protocol, LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Plan of Operation. See attached LIC 9099-D. LPA also advises that per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.5, the facility shall increase the number of direct care staff when a resident requires special care and supervision due to behavior. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Assistant Administrator La Tanya Harper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. Additionally, the resident was a known risk for unauthorized leaves, which the facility expressed concerns with to the resident's authorized representative, but the facility found 1:1 supervision ineffective for the resident due to the resident becoming agitated by increased staff monitoring and being near staff, resulting in 1:1 supervision being terminated for the youth. There is not sufficient information to determine if a violation led to the incident occurring. Additionally, based on confidential interviews and record review, drug use is not allowed in the facility, and it has either not been witnessed by some parties or staff have been observed to confiscate contraband when they become aware of it. The facility is reported to have a menu residents enjoy, staff make quality meals and accommodate residents' dietary needs and preferences, residents are able to make their own meals if they prefer, and the facility was observed to have a large store of healthy food. However, at multiple visits, LPA observed food out of date or expired, including significantly moldy fruit that was exposed and accessible to residents. There is not sufficient information to prove that food service is overall inadequate. Further, based on confidential interviews, most residents report that staff do not bully and are not aggressive with residents. Staff use verbal intervention during altercations, but do not use physical intervention and are hands-off. Lastly, it was reported that medical documentation for a resident could not be located in order to provide to a paramedic who responded to the facility. The specific documentation could not be clarified, and LPA was able to have access to medical documentation. However, LPA advises that the facility ensure medical documentation is accessible to care staff in case of an emergency so that medical information can be provided to authorized parties. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is/are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation(s) is/are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Assistant Administrator La Tanya Harper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13On Thursday 11/05/20 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a visit to deliver findings of a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Assistant Director La Tanya Harper and Interim Administrator Tracy McWoodson. Due to COVID-19 social distancing orders, this visit was scheduled as a tele-visit. During the investigation, LPA Hawkins conducted confidential interviews with staff, social worker, and probation officer. Based on interviews and record review, following an incidence of aggression that resulted in an altercation involving each youth in placement at the time, the police were called for assistance and resident R1 (See LIC Confidential Names) was 5150'd and taken to the hospital. R1's social worker reported that the facility told the social worker that they refused to pick up R1 and bring back into care, because they felt that R1 was not fit for congregate care. narrative: On Friday 10/1/21 at 10:22AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for a required annual inspection. LPA was granted entry by Facility Manager Cheryl Scott, and Interim Administrator Tracy McWoodson arrived at 11:25AM. LPA used the Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. LPA obtained copies of the following: Current LIC Personnel Report, LIC Emergency Disaster Plan. At 4:30PM, the inspection was not completed. Additional time is needed in order to finish the inspection and the report pages. LPA advised that an annual continuation inspection will be conducted at a later date. LPA inspection today included: 10:35AM Tour: The facility is clean and in good repair. There are some minor wear and tear damages that do not affect functionality and are being addressed with work orders, so repairs are pending. License is visibly posted in staff office. Personal rights and foster youth bill of rights are posted in the living room. First aid kit was observed to be complete. Chemicals and detergents are stored in locked cabinets in the laundry room and garage. Medications and sharps are stored in a locked closet in the living room. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature, and hot water in the upstairs hallway bathroom measured within permitted range, at 112. F. 1PM File Review: Files are well organized. Medication Administration Records (MARs) are orderly, and psychotropic medications are logged on the appropriate form. File review will continue during the annual continuation visit. During visit, LPA observed that staff S1 (See LIC Confidential Names) is not showing as associated to the facility but appears on the schedule (LIC 500). At 3:35PM, Assistant Director La Tanya Harper made the clearance transfer via Guardian so S1 appeared on the roster. S1 does not need to be removed from the schedule, but a citation of California Code of Regulations, Section 80019 was issued with a mandated civil penalty of $500. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

The needs and services plan dated 10/21/21 includes the following: "Transition Plan: [R1]'s current plan is to graduate high school and move back with her grandmother or transition to a county connected independent living program. The staff and counselors at Lighthouse Mentoring Center are supporting [R1]'s connection with her grandmother and guiding and educating her on the resources available through the Independent Living Program. Additionally, [R1] is working on developing other independent living skills, such as securing, and retaining employment, budgeting and managing her own transportation." The complaint report was filed on 10/20/21 in response to an incident that day. The transition plan was updated after the incident. Administrator informed LPA that the plan was not updated before because the plan to manage own transportation had been verbally discussed and agreed upon at a CFT. This was, though, before R1 changed schools. Additionally, the facility did not have a record of bus routes that R1 was to utilize to make their way home, and Administrator was unaware of what bus route R1 would need to take to get home to the facility, which is a safety concern. Based on LPA's review of local bus routes, the 9-minute car ride home would have taken R1 an average of 2 hours to get home by bus. The only route that would be quicker (but still 90 minutes) costs more than the amount of money R1 is provided to self-transport. Multiple routes require multiple transfers, and R1 is a known AWOL risk, per interview and record review. Staff are able to transport youth to work after school on days R1 works, but the facility does not have a schedule for R1's job, because the employer does not provide these to R1. However, staff availability indicates that staff are available to pick up the youth after school. Further, the route home from R1's previous school was about 37 to 44 minutes by bus. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. There is one citation. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 6/17/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a case management visit. LPA met with facility staff Danielle Rosenbaum and Administrator Tracy McWoodson, who arrived at 11:55AM. met_with: Administrator Tracy McWoodson, Clinical Director Phyllis Ritter
narrative: S1 did not engage with R1 as part of planned ignoring and did not realize that P1 was overhearing R1's statements. By staff taking a personal call while at the facility, confidential information and/or identifying information such as names, voices, and private conversations of residents can be heard by individuals not affiliated with the facility or youths' care teams, which is a privacy and personal rights risk. Immediately prior to the incident, S1 had gone to use to the downstairs bathroom, and S2 was downstairs, and staff were not able to prevent P1 from entering the facility and going upstairs. The front door, which is typically locked, per staff, was unlocked. P1 went upstairs trying to identify who it was who was disrespectful to S1 earlier. R1 was in another resident's room, which is the door nearest the top of the stairs. P1 entered, and the altercation began. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) is/are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.2(a)(2) Personnel Duties and Section 87072(c)(10) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Administrator Tracy McWoodson, Clinical Director Phyllis Ritter
narrative: Residents upstairs call for staff, both of whom are downstairs. S1, who was upstairs with the residents, had gone downstairs prior to the incident to use the restroom. S1 reported that S2 was made aware of this and was nearby downstairs with another resident but may not have been able to see the residents upstairs. S2 reported that S2 was not made aware that S1 was using the restroom and that S2 was in the kitchen area with the fifth resident in care. S2 responded when called by the residents. The lighter, and per staff statements, multiple lighters on multiple occasions, were confiscated from R3. However, due to lack of supervision, the lighter could not be confiscated at the time of the incident, the incident of R3 using a dangerous item could not be prevented or intervened, and R3's injury could not be prevented. Further, resident and staff statements indicate that staff interactions with youth are not always trauma-informed and that multiple staff members at times use an inappropriate and disrespectful tone with residents when delivering information or explaining consequences. When staff share information with residents, the tone, word choice, and body language are important in delivery of that information. Additionally, if a resident responds negatively to a staff statement, staff are responsible for ensuring they use trauma-informed care, per policy procedures, to calm the resident, communicate their intentions, and to maintain the relationship between staff and residents and the health and safety of the resident. Staff tone and attitude contribute significantly to the environment in the facility. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) is/are found to be Substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7, Section 80087(g) Buildings and Grounds and Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties and Section 87072(c) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 9-15-22 at 10: AM, , Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) George Karkazis and Licensing Program Manager (LPM),Isabel Mendoza , conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Daniel Rosenbaum Facility Manager and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Short Term Therapeutic Program is licensed to serve six clients.Present during the inspection were two staff and one client, however client left during inspection. Client appeared in good spirit and was watching TV in the living room and greeted LPA and LPM. At 10: AM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed four bedrooms and three bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility.LPA's observed outdated personal rights form. Lpa's printed updated copy and Facility Manager posted them. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 120 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked.. The facility is in good repair and clean. However, during the inspection LPA and LPM observed the upstairs bathrooms having several markings/stains on the bathroom walls and cabinets. Also, observed stains and debris in several kitchen cabinets. However, during inspection staff members cleaned the kitchen cabinets. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff. During the tour, the client left, therefore no client interviews. At 1:00PM, LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At 1: PM LPA Karkazis reviewed staff files and during file review several staff files did not have their degrees in the personnel files. LPA reminded the facility to ensure they keep each staff members education experience/degree in each file due to it being difficult for LPA to confirm education. Please refer to 809c form for continuation Also, during review LPA reminded the facility to keep all training material in the facility staff training binder, due to several training materials missing. At 2PM LPA Karkazis reviewed clients files and files were complete and all clients had updated personal rights LIC 613 and required forms. At this time there were deficiencies however the facility received two Technical Violations, Title 22 regulations, Building and Grounds, and 87065(g)(1)(A)(1) Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

Additionally, based on record review, a resident was alleged to have been denied medication, but records reflect prescribed medications were administered and logged. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation may have no reasonable basis. However, during record review, LPA observed that some medications were not administered for a few days due to needing to be filled, and one medication was potentially administered incorrectly or logged incorrectly. A medication, Aripiprazole, was prescribed at 1 1/2 tablets at bedtime for 15 days and filled on 2/18/22 with 1 refill, administered for 15 days, and then filled on 3/18/22 with 0 refills. The facility continued administering daily until they ran out after 4/10/22. If the medication was only to be administered for 15 days, administration should have stopped after 4/1/22, and at 1 1/2 (1+1/2) dosage, the facility would be out of the medication after 4/1/22. However, after filling the 3/18/22 prescription, the records reflect that staff notated the medication was not administered due to needing to be filled. The resident is no longer in care, so a medication count cannot be conducted. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is/are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation(s) is/are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst Britanee Windom conducted a case management inspection on 03/14/23 at 10: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed.(See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, March 14, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, monthly assessment, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Windom observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Tracy McWoodson.

During another incident, one resident was downstairs in the front living room on a phone call monitored by the staff on duty. Another resident was upstairs, unsupervised. The front living room is visible from the upstairs landing and hallway, but the main kitchen/dining/family room area is not visible from the front living room. The resident upstairs came downstairs, entered the main kitchen/dining/family room, and exited the facility through the back sliding door. This resident then returned about 5 minutes later with contraband not visible to staff, and returned upstairs. The investigation found that the call the resident was on was not a required supervised call but that staff observe the resident on the phone to ensure the resident does not make unapproved calls afterward, as the resident does have a list of calls that need to be approved and/or supervised. Later, both residents were in one of their bedrooms and shared the contraband, which was learned to be a can of alcohol and a nicotine vaporizer pen obtained by the resident who exited the facility from an adult not affiliated with the facility. Additionally, multiple reports obtained described supervision at the facility as relaxed or that staff are disengaged or distracted on their phones. The incident report submitted for this incident also did not reflect that engagement or redirection was done. Lastly, the staff could have been stationed upstairs and had sight of the resident on the phone or could have engaged with the resident who exited the facility and continued listening for a break in the phone discussion or for redialing, or the facility could have increased staffing to meet the extra supervision needs of the resident with required monitored phone use. Regarding the third allegation above, the reports obtained indicate that due to a lack of supervision allowing residents to enter other residents' rooms, multiple residents have had their personal belongings stolen by other residents, and sometimes those items have been destroyed, including clothing, a journal, and a family photo. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), section Plan of Operation and 87065. Personnel Duties. See attached LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Personal inventory records reflect that the resident in question had a collection of clothes, and interviews with individuals who observed the resident did not support that the youth did not have enough clothes. Some reports obtained indicated that residents exchanged clothes and that this practice has continuously been discouraged by facility staff. Similarly, some reports obtained indicated that residents shared electronic devices, but that, since not all residents are permitted by their authorized representative to have certain devices, such as a cell phone or other other electronic communication device, that this practice is also discouraged by facility staff. Additionally, it was reported that the resident in question had their electronic device taken away by the facility. However, interview with the authorized representative and staff indicated that the resident did not have an electronic device while in the program, so no device could have been taken away. Lastly, the allowance records reflected regular allowance dispersal, and residents interviewed support that allowance procedures are followed. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. narrative: The email chain does not reflect clear communication in responding to the request to confirm the correct details, but staff picking up the resident on Monday indicates agreement with the plan. There was mention that the resident was not picked up on Tuesday due to the facility not having enough gas in the van, which was not supported by all involved staff member(s) but which was supported by the email chain correspondence. The correspondence indicated that there was no issue with gas because the facility had only intended to pick up the resident from school on Monday and from the local BART station on Tuesday. Additionally, during that week, the care team noted that the resident had a wrapped ankle and had expressed that it had been hurting for a while. The care team asked the facility management about this, and management staff stated that there was no communication to staff about an ankle injury. However, review of the facility shift notes reveal that there was an entry on January 21, 2023 about the resident having leg pain, and the staff member requested that the facility schedule an appointment for the resident to make sure the resident did not sustain a sprain. However, the resident was not taken to see a physician, and the facility could not supply evidence of a medical visit for the resident regarding the matter. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing citations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87074 and Section 87072 and California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80075. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/13/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to follow-up on a submitted incident report (IR). LPA met with Administrator Tracy McWoodson and informed of the purpose of the visit. An IR was submitted for an incident that occurred on 08/14/23. Per the IR, staff confiscated a resident's birth control medication (a plan b pill and condoms). During a visit to the facility on 9/12/23, Administrator confirmed that the medication had not been returned to the resident. During today's visit, Administrator further explained that the medication was a single pill not in any packaging, so staff were not sure if the medication was actually birth control. Administrator stated the resident has not asked for the medication and that if the resident were to ask, the facility would take the resident to the doctor to get the requested medication. The condoms had been returned to the resident the day of the incident. LPA advises that since one of residents' personal rights is to have access to birth control medication, if staff confiscated the pill due to not being sure it was birth control, and if the condoms were returned to the resident, these details should be included in the incident report. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 10/19/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit and met with Administrator Tracy McWoodson. LPA informed that the purpose of the visit was to conduct a quarterly inspection, per the agreed upon terms of the noncompliance conference (NCC). On 2/1/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit and met with Administrator Tracy McWoodson. LPA informed that the purpose of the visit was to conduct a quarterly inspection, per the agreed upon terms of the noncompliance conference (NCC). LPA conducted confidential resident and staff interviews and reviewed resident and staff files. LPA observed resident and staff files to be complete, except for the items discussed below. During review of incident reports, LPA observed an incident in which staff handling of a situation may have contributed to two residents running away from placement. LPA discussed the incident and planned follow-up with the staff members with the Administrator. LPA reviewed the involved staff members' files. LPA observed that staff S1's (See LIC Confidential Names dated 2/1/24) personnel file did not include the staff member's initial training record. Therefore, LPA was unable to verify that S1 had completed the necessary initial training in order to be left alone with residents and to be counted toward the staff to child ratio. The documents were requested, and the licensee was unable to supply on this day, so LPA was not able to verify the documents reflected the necessary hours. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.1(d)(5). See attached LIC 809-D. Additionally, LPA observed that staff S1's personnel file and LIC Personnel Record did not reflect the necessary qualifications, such as a degree, specific certifications, transcripts reflecting completion of specific courses, or other evidence of relevant experience, as specified in the STRTP ILS. LPA requested the documents, and the licensee was unable to supply on this day. LPA is issuing a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87065(g)(1). See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Tracy McWoodson, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On May 21, 2024 at 10: AM, An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and Celeste Aparicio, pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Belfield and LPA Aparicio met with Executive Director Assistant LaTonya Harper who assisted with the inspection. During this inspection a file review was conducted and interviews were conducted with staff and clients. There were two staff and three clients present during this inspection. LPA reviewed 3 of child's records and 3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed 3 of child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed 1 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA's observed incomplete documentation regarding medication and client files and a full medication count could not be completed. At this time, due to more information needed to complete the inspection, the inspection could not be completed. LPA interviewed 2 of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication and the third client refused to be interviewed. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Executive Director Assistant LaTonya Harper . No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Executive Director Assistant LaTonya Harper

On May 31, 2024 at 10: AM, an unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield and Celeste Aparicio, pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). This inspection is a continuation of the inspection that began on May 21, 2024, at 10: AM. LPA Belfield and Aparicio met with Administrator Tracy McWoodson who assisted with the inspection. During the previous inspection, LPA Belfield and LPA Aparicio met with Executive Director Assistant LaTonya Harper. Staff and client file reviews and interviews were conducted. During the client file review of the initial inspection, LPAs observed no documentation indicating the child has been participating or offered the opportunity to participate in the development of their Needs and Services Plan (NSP), and NSP not being updated every 30 days from the date the child was placed in the facility in three of the three client files. Additionally, LPAs observed no child and authorized representative signatures available on the NSP in three of the three client files. During today's inspection LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility, photos were taken during the walkthrough, reviewed client Psychotropic Administration Records (PMAR), reviewed Centrally Stored Medication Log (LIC622), and LPA's observed administrator conduct a pill count for each client. Based on observations made during the pill count and psychotropic medication documentation review, LPAs determined the following: the centrally stored medication log for each psychotropic medication is not properly documented to include the correct pill counts and number of refills prescribed; the document prescription numbers on the PMAR's and centrally stored log were incorrect for one of three clients files; Psychotropic medication was logged on a PRN form instead of the PMAR. LPAs are issuing citations for violations of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) sections 87068.2(d) Children's Record, 87068.3(a) Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan, and 87070(b)(14) Children's Records, as described on the following page LIC809-D. Regarding LPAs observations made, the NSP's did not have child and authorized representative signature. The licensee is being issued a Technical Violation Advisory Note: STRTP ILS, Section 87068.2(g) Needs and Services Plans. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was sent to with Administrator Tracy McWoods, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

After the review of documentation and interviews with relevant parties, it was found that the allegations could not be corroborated due to inconsistent statements obtained. narrative: On 09/06/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a case management inspection regarding Personal Rights and Reporting Requirements related to a complaint investigation; control number 14-CR-20240625121741. LPA met with facility Administrator and facility Head of Service and informed on the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, confidential interviews and records review were conducted. Based on interviews and record review, LPA observed some incidents that needed to be discussed regarding residents right to participate in extracurricular activities and reporting requirements for unusual incidents which may threaten the physical or emotional health of a resident in care. LPA determined that the facility acted appropriately in addressing residents inability to participate in their preferred extracurricular activity by offering the youth alternatives. Facility staff regularly encourage residents to participate in extracurricular activities and community based programs. LPA discussed general regulation reporting requirements and identified an area in which a technical support may be beneficial. LPA is issuing an assistance for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80061(B)(E)(1) Reporting requirements. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to facility Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 09/10/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with facility Administrator and informed the Administrator on the purpose of the visit. During the inspection, one resident was present at the facility. Resident declined to speak with LPA. The two other residents were not present at the facility due to being on an unauthorized absence since 09/07/24. During inspection, LPA toured the facility and inspected facility records. LPA observed staff and client files to be complete containing all the necessary documentation specified in the CARE Inspection Tool. LPA reviewed training binder and observed staff training logs to be well documented. All staff have background clearances and updated CPR certification. LPA conducted two staff interviews and attempted to interview one resident. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA found no deficiencies. The facility is maintained in safe condition, and maintained at 75 degrees Fahrenheit. No hazards were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 09/10/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made a visit to the facility to conduct the facility's final quarterly inspection, per the agreement established at the Noncompliance Conference (NCC) held on 8/11/22. LPA met with facility Administrator and informed Administrator on the purpose of the visit. The agreed upon terms were that the licensee would be subject to increased monitoring, and the licensee is to conduct training on any of these topics: trauma-informed care practices, safe vehicle operation, proper de-escalation procedures, and firearm storage and safety. Additionally, licensee would submit current LIC500 on a quarterly basis and facility will provide staff reminders during staff meetings about facility policies. LPA reviewed staff training records and personnel files. LPA observed complete training records reflecting the required hours being met and the required topics being covered, including trauma-informed care practices and verbal intervention/de-escalation. During the inspection, the facility provided an updated LIC500 to reflect new hires. Based on LPA's observations, record review, and confidential interviews, the facility was observed to be operating in compliance with applicable regulations/licensing standards and the NCC terms. No deficiencies were observed during today's visit, and there are no outstanding plans of correction (POCs). The facility has met the conditions of the 8/11/ NCC and will no longer be subject to noncompliance inspections. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 09/24/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted an unannounced case management visit at the facility to provide technical advisory support related to a complaint investigation; control number 14-CR-20240701094516. LPA met with facility Administrator and informed the facility Administrator on the purpose of the visit. During the investigation, confidential interviews were conducted and an area in which technical support may be beneficial was identified. Based on interviews it was learned that S1 may have used language that suggested the residents to engage in physical altercation to resolve their issues after S1 exhausted all other verbal de-escalation tactics and redirection prompts. (See LIC Confidential Names List). LPA provided technical support in the form of an advisory for staff to set limits for behavior that are consistent with trauma - informed care standards. See LIC Technical Assistance. During the discussion, Facility Administrator indicated that staff regularly receive training around trauma informed care and staff are encouraged to swap places when handling an escalated resident. Facility Administrator added that they have checked in with S1 regarding trauma informed practices while identifying areas of improvement. LPA advised that Facility Administrator maintains this type of conversation and training with their staff. LPA obtained documentation of supervision check in between facility administrator and S1. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to facility Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. 3. Facility will add appropriate supply of required foods and emergency foods upon placement of youth in the home. 8. Sample menu posted. 9. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 10. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 11. Facility has 3 restrooms for client use, all are operable. 12. Client files will be kept in a locked filing cabinet, locked in the staff office. 13. Staff files will be kept locked at the facility main office, and will be available for review at facility, within a reasonable time frame of request by LPA. Applicant is associated through Guardian and has been fingerprint cleared. Prior to accepting placement's, all staff must be fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Discussed Guardian process with the facility. Based on this inspection, the facility will be ready for licensure. A copy of this report was provided to Executive Director Assistant, La Tanya Harper.
