narrative: On 9/30/21 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask-wearing. The Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. There are two residents in care. LPA interviewed present residents and staff. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature, and hot water in the upstairs resident bathroom measured within permitted range, at 111. F. At 3:45PM, LPA completed the inspection. Additional time is needed in order to draft and finalize the report pages. An annual continuation will be required. LPA advised of return visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left with Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/30/21 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask-wearing. The Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. There are two residents in care. LPA interviewed present residents and staff. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature, and hot water at the upstairs resident bathroom measured within permitted range, at 111. F. The facility, per the tool, was in compliance in all areas other than those listed below, for which citations or advisories were issued. 1. Staff Ratios. During visit, two residents returned home, and there was only one staff (Administrator), and no additional staff showed at their arrival. LPA issued an advisory of STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.5(b)(1). 2. Staff Ratios. The current LIC Personnel Report indicates there is one overnight staff who works 12AM-8AM Monday through Friday and one overnight staff who works 12AM-8AM Saturday and Sunday. LPA issued a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87065.5(b)(2). 3. Needs and Services. Residents records contained needs and services plans that were not being updated every 30 days. R1's (See LIC Confidential Names, dated 10/7/21) plan was dated 5/28/21 and had a "re-evaluate" date of 7/21/21, and R2's plan was dated 8/22/21 and had a "re-evaluate" date of 11/22/21. LPA issued a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87068.3(a). 4. Smoking on Site. During tour of facility, LPA observed 10+ cigarette butts in the back and side yards. Per Administrator, staff are aware that residents are smoking in their rooms and throwing the cigarette butts out of the window. Staff are doing contraband checks, but cigarette butts have not been removed from grounds. LPA issued a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87087(c). 5. First Aid Certificates. LPA observed that 5 of 10 staff files reviewed [Refer to LIC Confidential Names for staff names] did not include a valid/current first aid certificate. LPA issued a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87065.1(c)(6)(A). 6. Staff Training. LPA observed that 9 of 10 staff files [Refer to LIC Confidential Names for staff names] did not contain training documentation. Some staff were missing all staff training and had no training record in the training binder. Some staff had the initial training log completely signed off. Staff work at multiple facilities, and LPA has prior knowledge that some staff have completed initial training based on copies of their files at other locations. However, the training records in the staff files at this site would indicate that less than 15 hours of training were completed in 2020. Additionally, there is a training record in staff files that indicates 20 hours were completed in 2021, completed over two days, with 10 hours done each day. The dates are 1/12/21 and 3/30/21. Per Asst. Director La Tanya Harper, these dates are the completion dates for mulitple days long training courses. There is no training material for this training in the record, breakdown of time spent on each topic or how the hours were calculated, nor a certificate. LPA issued a citation of STRTP ILS Section 87066(b)(4). 7. Bedroom Sharing Arrangement. LPA observed that the resident records do not contain documentation of the bedroom sharing arrangements. LPA issued an advisory per STRTP ILS Section 87087(e). 8. Condition of Site & Grounds. LPA observed minor damages, including a cracked microwave door, two fist sized holes (one in bedroom, one in upstairs hall), and cracked/punched doors to two bedrooms. Damages do not appear to cause an immediate risk, and all items are functioning. Administrator showed LPA a list of items, including these damages, that have been sent to the director for repairs but have not yet been repaired. Per Administrator, the licensee is taking steps to address these damages. The facility is otherwise in good condition. Additionally, LPA observed two bent and broken window screens in the side yard. Per Administrator, residents break these off of the windows in order to throw cigarette butts out. LPA observed the screens had not been removed from the side yard. The screens are made of metal, which can be bent and worked into a dangerous item. The screens also are in the walkway, and while light in weight, they are large and could obstruct the passageway in an emergency. LPA issued an advisory per STRTP ILS Section 80087(a). 9. Health Screenings. Two staff files were missing health screening with TB test. LPA issued an advisory of STRTP ILS Section 80066(a)(10). One staff does not work on site at this location. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On Friday 4/22/22 at 1:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility regarding an incident report submitted to the Licensing agency. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones "MJ" and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. LPA interviewed 1 staff and 2 residents, reviewed staff binder and staff training, and obtained copies of the residents' treatment plans/pre-placement assessment, staff contacts, staff termination letter and initial training for staff S1 (See LIC Confidential Names). Based on the submitted incident report, on 4/12/22 staff S1 came to work intoxicated. Second staff on shift observed S1's state, evidenced by S1's appearance, behavior, and throwing up, and notified management. Second staff removed present resident so resident would not be around S1. Interviews with Administrator and residents indicate that there were no prior incidences of this nor any indication that S1 would do this. S1 was directed to leave the facility that day, and did so, and S1 was terminated the following day. There are no deficiencies found at this time and no citations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report left with Administrator MJ, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensing Program Analyst(LPA) Shikya Belfield and Lisa Schlembach made an unannounced inspection at the above facility on 6/29/2022 at 4: PM. These beds are prohibited. Facility issued a Technical advisory for violation of Interim Licensing Standards, version four, section 87088(c)(C) Fixtures Furniture and Equipment and Supplies. On 9/9/22 at 10:45AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA's) George Karkazis and Alyssa Ng conducted an annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask-wearing. The Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) is licensed to serve six clients, ages 10 -17 years. Currently in placement are 5 clients. The Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. At 11:00AM LPA Karkazis toured the facility, inside and out. LPA's Ng and Karkazis observed at the time of this visit, the facility to be clean, safe and sanitary. The facility is maintained at a comfortable temperature, and hot water in the upstairs resident bathroom measured within permitted range, at 107. F. There a were total of five bedrooms and three bathrooms. One bathroom was designated for staff. All client bedrooms were observed to have ample storage space and adequate bedding. At 1:15PM LPA's Karkazis and NG reviewed the staff and clients files and they had the necessary forms. LPA Karkazis observed that one staff file did not contain training records. A citation was issued. LPA Karkazis interviewed one client. The following documents are posted in the facility: facility license, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, menu, chores, activity calendar and personal rights. A review of Guardian on September 09, 2022 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. A citation was issued ILS 87076(c)(1), two days of perishable food not present. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility. The inspection is not complete at this time and a continuation of this inspection is necessary.

narrative: On 12/22/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit. LPA met with Assistant Clinical Director Jason Braden and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review conducted during an investigation at the facility, on 09/15/2022 around 7PM, a police officer made a visit to the facility and observed that there were four residents present and only one staff member was present. Additionally, this was reported to have occurred on other occasions as well. Per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.5, there should be two staff on shift when there are 2-4 residents present in a facility with a licensed capacity of 7 or more, and the facility's capacity is 8. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 87065. Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Assistant Clinical Director Jason Braden, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 9/29/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones and informed of the purpose of the visit. During inspection, LPA toured facility and inspected facility records. All residents were at school. LPA observed the personnel files and resident files to be complete. Staff have background clearances. Medications are properly stored and administration appropriately documented. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA found 1 deficiency. LPA observed that there were multiple shards of broken glass around the backyard activity space from the broken window upstairs. The window is scheduled for repair and has been made inaccessible to residents. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80087. See attached LIC 809-D. A continuation inspection is required to complete interviews. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 9/29/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit to follow-up on a submitted incident report. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on the submitted incident report, two residents engaged in consensual sexual activity in the facility during the overnight shift after reportedly waiting for the night staff member to go downstairs and complete tasks downstairs. Administrator confirmed that the report was accurate and that there was only one staff on shift. LPA discussed the ratio requirement for facilities with a capacity of 7 or more, which applies even when the facility census is 6 or below. LPA also discussed that the licensee should continue to provide hiring updates but that the ratio requirements must be followed following this incident to ensure compliance. Lastly, LPA discussed the process of reducing the capacity, since the facility does not typically go over 6 residents, and doing so would make the ratio requirement for this facility the same as that for the licensee's other facilities. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87065. Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios. See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 05/08/24 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management to follow up on an incident report received by the Department regarding an incident that occurred on 04/17/24. LPA met with Administrator Maurice Jones who helped facilitate the inspection and informed on the purpose of this visit. LPA conducted an interview with Administrator Maurice Jones, requested documentation, and conducted physical plant of the facility. No citations were issued during this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 05/28/24 at 1:15PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced inspection to the facility for the purpose of conducting a follow - up case management inspection regarding an incident that occurred on 04/26/24. Based on additional records review and confidential interviews, it was confirmed that information was omitted from the incident report that was submitted regarding the incident that occurred on 04/26/24 between a staff and client. LPA found that a physical restraint was utilized during the incident and was not reported to the Department. LPA discussed the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan (EIP) that was revised in August 2023 which states that was facility is a hands-off facility and will not utilize restraints to address assaultive and aggressive behaviors. LPA also discussed that if the facility chooses to utilize physical restraints as a last resort for the safety of staff and clients then the facility's EIP needs to be revised to reflect Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87095.22(f) Emergency Intervention Plan. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87022(f) Plan of Operations and section 87061(i)(7) Reporting Requirements. See attached LIC809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 06/07/24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Celeste Aparicio and Kristin Pierotti made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection to follow up an incident that occurred on 05/22/24. Based on confidential interviews and records review, residents engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior due to a lack of supervision from overnight staff. Facility immediately acted and reported the incident to the Department in timely manner. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.2(b)(1) Personal Duties. Licensee also received a Technical Assistance. See attached LIC 809-D and LIC9102. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Maurice Jones, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 06/05/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio made an unannounced visit to the facility to conduct a case management inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Maurice Jones and informed the Administrator on the purpose of this visit. During the walk through of the facility LPA observed remodels being done to the facility. LPA observed new kitchen cabinets, counter tops, and flooring on the first level of the facility. LPA observed there to be no changes to the physical plant of the facility. LPA advised that facility submit in writing all the plans for the reconstruction, including a statement on how the staff plan to maintain client safety and limit disturbances for programming. A new staff member who is in training was present during the inspection. The new staff member, S1, (see LIC811) is not fully cleared on Guardian, but is under constant supervision for shadowing and not yet working with the clients in care. S1 has been in the Guardian system since November 2024. Due to the new staff being from out of state the Guardian process is taking longer. { Report continued on LIC809-C }. During a review of the programs House Rules, LPA observed a rule that does not allow residents to be in each other's bedrooms without the permission of staff. LPA discussed the importance of having residents obtain permission when hanging out in each other's bedrooms so that proper supervision can be provided. LPA identified areas in which a Technical Assistances would be beneficial, LPA is issuing a Technical Assistances for Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87088(j) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies, 87022 (f) Plan of Operation, and 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with the facility.

narrative: On 07/24/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio conducted a random annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator, Maurice Jones and informed the Administrator on the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the facility site and observed that facility to be clean, free from obstruction, and in good repair. The facility is currently installing new fencing in the backyard. The facility has already provided LPA Aparicio with a renovation plan document detailing on how clients safety will be maintained throughout the renovation process. During the inspection LPA reviewed five client files and five staff files. LPA observed both client and staff files to be complete and secured in a locked cabinet located in the staff office. LPA identified an area in which a technical assistance maybe beneficial. LPA provided a technical assistance for California Code of Regulations Section 80069(c)(1). At the time of the inspection four clients were present at the facility. LPA conducted two client interviews and one staff interview. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct the annual inspection. No deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the facility.

On November 10, 2021, at 8:35am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Ronnesha Fountain and Leslie Corvurriabias conducted an announced inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on October 05, 2021. LPA's already completed the physical inspection, staff records, and staff interviews of the facility. During this annual inspection continuation LPAs interviewed four of the six clients to ensure the STRTP are meeting the Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), see LIC 811 dated 11/10/21. The client interviews are located under the LIC 809 dated 10/22/21. Based on interview with clients, there was some confusion over the "point system" used that determines the amount of cash a client can keep on them physically, but the amount that is deposited into their savings does not change. In-addition, there was some concern over the food menu; however, it was noted that staff allows for the clients to give suggestions and they will do their best to accommodate them. The STRTP appears to be meeting Core Services/Supports requirements. Due to only the physical plant, and client interviews being completed this inspection will be continued at a later date. No deficiencies were found during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the residential manager Anne Lacy.

***This is an Amended Report of the report issued on 10/05/21. On October 5, 2021, at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Leslie Covarrubias and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith arrived at Lyon, Short Term Residential Program (STRTP). LPA and LPM met with Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. At 11: AM, Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun, led the physical inspection of the facility. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedroom #2- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedroom #3- Was furnished with one twin bed. No client is placed in this room at this time. Bedroom #4- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedroom #5- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedroom #6- Was furnished with one twin bed. Sleeps one client. Bedrooms are arranged so that only one child is placed per room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The dresser drawer in room #2 was observed to be cracked approximately in the middle of drawer and on the verge of breaking off. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility's kitchen area, three refrigerators/freezers, food storage areas, client rooms, two bathroom/showers, and community gathering area and dining area. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for client's recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and the menus were posted. At the time of inspection the facility license was observed to be posted in the staff office, which is not a public area of the facility. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsperson poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored inside staff office. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathrooms was measured to be an appropriate temperature. Per the Residential Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA and LPM inspected the facility vehicle, and observed that the second row seat belt buckles are missing the outside covers. The facility was advised not to allow use of the second row until repair of the seat belt buckles is completed. LPA and LPM also inspected the First Aid Kit and found it was missing tweezers and scissors. Licensee has Mental Health Program Approval that is valid through 12/2021. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation that is valid through 10/2021. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of $0. No deficiencies were cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC9102 and appeal rights were provided to Residential Manager, Tyresha Calhoun.

narrative: and encourage them to stay. If clients AWOL staff will contact the appropriate parties to report the AWOL. Further details stated that there are some clients that chronically AWOL from the facility. Other details gathered from confidential interviews state that staff does not prevent clients from AWOL and does not do much to prevent clients from leaving the facility. Regarding the allegation that staff yells at minor and staff does not treat minor with dignity and respect, confidential interviews disclosed that staff yells at minors. Other interviews provided information that staff will use a stern tone of voice in order to re-direct and de-escalate minors when clients become aggressive towards staff or other peers in the home. Further details gathered from confidential interviews, state that clients and staff will joke with one another and that sometimes staff or clients will go too far and clients' feelings will get hurt. Further information gathered, denied that staff yells at minors and that every client is treated with respect and did not witness or hear staff yelling at minors in care or not treating minors with dignity and respect. Regarding the allegation that staff confiscated minor's privilege of phone and television usage, confidential interviews disclosed that staff denies clients phone and television usage. Other confidential interviews stated that staff will take away privileges but that clients get the privileges back. Further details gathered disclosed that some clients misused their usage and therefore had privileges taken away but were later given them back. Based on record review and confidential interviews the allegations alleging that minor went AWOL from facility, staff yells at minor, staff does not treat minor with dignity and respect, and staff confiscated minor's privilege of phone and television usage, may or may not have occurred. However, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute these allegations; Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of this report was given to Administrator, Linda Poythress.

narrative: On October 2nd, 2023, at 9:53 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, met with Lynda Poythress, Facility Administrator, to deliver a case management deficiencies report. LPA observed that the window blind in Bedroom # 4 was not in good repair. The window blind was missing pieces and coming undone. LPA met with Human Resources Administrative Manager to conduct the Staff Records review portion of the inspection on November 13, 2023 at Olive Crest (336425183) located at: Technology Court Suite Riverside, CA 92507. LPA reviewed five personnel records, to ensure they contained required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Five out of five personnel records reviewed were associated to the facility and had completed background clearances: Department of Justice (DOJ), Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and Child Abuse Central Index (CACI) on file. Five out of five personnel records reviewed had a health screening and tuberculosis (TB) test on file. Five out of five personnel records reviewed had annual training's, current cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), and first certification on file. Based on staff/client interviews, the facility appears to be meeting Core Therapeutic Services, and Supports, and Emergency Intervention Plan requirements. Based on observation and record review, there are no deficiencies noted at this time during the inspection. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided; And a copy of this report was provided to Residential Manager, Linda Poythress.

On December 19, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Emina Preciado, conducted an unannounced visit at the facility for the purpose of an independent investigation. While at the facility, LPA conducted a health and safety inspection. During the inspection, LPA observed the following: the facility did not have an adequate supply of non-perishable food to meet client ratio, bathroom #2 had exposed electrical wires from an uncovered light switch, there were holes in the facility walls (living room & hallway), and a hole on the door of bedroom #4. Based on observation, interviews, and evidence gathered, the facility is cited for California Code of Regulations (CCR), Buildings and Grounds 80087(a), "The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors." and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Food Service, 87076(c)(1) "Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days shall be maintained on the premises." which poses an immediate health and safety risk to clients in care. Additionally, LPA advised Residential Manager, Linda Poythress about a distinct odor that LPA observed in a cabinet, under the facility's kitchen sink. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided; And a copy of the following reports: LIC809 and LIC809-D were given to Lynda Poythress, Residential Manager.

Confidential interviews reported that staff created a plan for C1 not to have phone privileges due to behavior issues and house rules, and C1's authorized representative agreed to the plan. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was using the phone for extended periods and using the phone outside of the house rules time. Confidential interviews reported that C1 would take the facility's house phone, hide it in their room, and keep it for personal use. Confidential interviews revealed staff created boundaries for C1's phone use due to C1's history of talking with unknown people and becoming physically upset whenever C1 would finish the phone call. Confidential interviews and documentation revealed that after C1 talked with unknown people, staff feared that C1 would become physical in interacting with staff. Confidential interviews revealed when C1 was on hold of the facility house phone, and if C2 and C3 requested to use the phone, staff would allow them to use the staff phone for their calls. Based on inconsistence confidential interviews, the allegations that staff are not allowing youths in care (C1, C2 & C3) to use the telephone is unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Stacey Rougely, Administrator.

narrative: ***This is an amended report of the original report on 11/30/2021.*** On November 30, 2021, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias, Lisi Leon, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith arrived at Olive Crest - Lyon Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on October 5, 2021. LPAs and LPM already completed the physical inspection of the facility on the first day of the annual inspection. During this annual inspection continuation, the LPAs and LPM reviewed 5 of 5 client files (see LIC 811, dated 11/30/21). Client files are kept in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Client #2 (C2) did not have medical insurance information, such as medical card, therefore the facility is being cited for ILS 87070(b)(9) Children's Records. C2 and Client #3 (C3) did not have a TB test on file, therefore, the facility is being cited for CCR 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessments. All clients (C1-C5) did not have the ambulatory status defined by a licensed physician, therefore the facility is being cited for CCR 80069(c)(4) Client Medical Assessments. Client #1 (C1) and C3 did not have staff initials on the medication log to indicate that they supervised the medication being administered, therefore the facility is being cited for ILS 87070(b)(12)(H) Children's Records. LPAs and LPM reviewed and 7 of the 7 personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are usually maintained at the corporate office in Riverside. Staff #2 (S2), #3 (S3), and #5 (S5) were missing documentation of required training, therefore the facility is being cited for ILS 87066(b)(4) Personnel Records. S2, S3, and S5 were missing required training, therefore the facility is being cited for ILS 87065.1(c) Training Requirements. S S3 and S5 were missing required training, therefore the facility is being cited for ILS 87065. Training Requirements. [...] Due to time constraints the annual inspection will be completed at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with LIC 809D, LIC 811 and Appeal Rights were given to Residential Manager, Randall Brown.

met_with: Jorge Cervantes,Imelda Cervantes,Akila Crane, Laura Hartney
narrative: On September 17, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jessica Peete and Cynthia Urena met with Makade Behavioral Center applicant Jorge Cervantes to complete Component II, the face-to-face interview, for the Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program (STRTP) application process. Also present were Board Secretary Imelda Cervantes and Chief Operations Officer Akila Crane, who attended via Microsoft Teams, and the prospective Administrator Laura Hartney. The applicant previously attended Component I, the STRTP orientation, on February 25, 2025. The purpose of today's meeting was to address any questions or concerns and to review the application packet and process, ensuring that the applicant, designated administrator, and all relevant parties understand and can provide the services outlined in the Program Statement and Plan of Operations in compliance with Community Care Licensing regulations. LPA reviewed the application documents, addressing and correcting discrepancies on the LIC Application for Community Care Facility and LIC Applicant Information. Policies and procedures submitted as part of the application, including discipline policies, program description, population to be served, and personal rights, were also reviewed. The facility staff plan was discussed to ensure compliance. The applicant does not yet have direct care staff but stated that a temporary staffing plan is in place. LPA reminded the applicant of the required staff-to-client ratios and reviewed the relevant regulations outlined in STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87065.5. Additionally, LPA reviewed the qualifications and educational requirements for the Administrator, Social Worker, and Facility Manager. As the applicant is required to have three months of operating expenses, LPA reviewed the necessary financial LIC forms to ensure sufficient resources to operate the STRTP. LPA also discussed the required financial documentation, including the LIC Monthly Operating Statement and the supportive financial verifications. LPA informed the applicant and attendees of the next steps in the application process and requested the following documentation to be provided by or before the scheduled technical assistance meeting: Updated LIC Monthly Operating Budget LIC Personnel Report Administrator qualifications for prospective Administrator Laura Hartney Verification of social worker educational requirements LIC Designation of Facility responsibility with either the board meeting minutes or a resolution confirming the authorized designee is permitted to sign. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the applicant

narrative: On July 28, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted a Case Management inspection regarding excessive calls of service for Fresno Police Department. LPA was met by Administrator Garnett Fountain and a discussion with regards to this issue was conducted. Mr. Fountain indicated that this has been a problem with certain minors in care. Mr. Fountain stated to rectify this situation they have implemented an additional swing shift so that there is adequate staff to follow minors that leave without authorization. He also indicated that staff is now instructed to follow the minors in vehicles until they lose sight of the minor. Mr. Fountain will contact Detective Hodge to start conversations with the Police Department so that this issue can be handled in a timely manner and explain what measures that the facility has instituted. There were no deficiencies cited during this Case Management Inspection.

narrative: Licensing Program(LPA) Corina Carrillo and Licensing Program Manager Angela King(LPM) conducted a case management inspection June 22, 2023 at 11: AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, June 22, 2023.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma- informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo and LPM King observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Levon Manucharyan.

narrative: On August 2, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) conducted a Case Management inspection with regards to a incident on 4/23/2023 (Law Enforcement Contact Report). The purpose for the inspection is to seek clarification and gain additional information with regards to that incident. The report stated that staff had to redirect client throughout the whole morning but failed to give specifics as to what type of redirection was given. Ms. Yrigollen stated that she has already instructed staff to be more specific on reports. This was addressed with the facility earlier when a Case Management Inspection for Law Enforcement Contacts was conducted on June 22, 2023 by LPA C. Carrillo and LPM, A. King. There were no deficiencies cited during this Case Management Inspection.

On this date, September 21, 2023, an unannounced random annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki. LPA was met by facility Manager, Elena Yrigollen. LPA inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications and sharps are maintained in a locked closet in a locked cabinet. LPA inspected the medications for the minors in care. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced July 18, 2023. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one week supply of nonperishable and a two day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. Hot water temperature measured 117 degrees. There are no pets in the facility. Mental Health Program Approval was approved by Fresno County on September 18, 2022. They are currently in the MHPA audit for recertification. Facility is currently waiting for an on site inspection for approval. There was 1 staff and 1 minor present during this inspection. Both staff and minor's files reviewed. Interviews with staff and minor were conducted. LPA reviewed the facility's disaster plan, sampled medication and reviewed facility logs. LPAs requested the following updated documents be sent to Community Care Licensing by October 31, 2023. LIC 308, LIC 309, LIC 400, LIC 500 and LIC 610C There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of the inspection

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Melikian and Reyna Martinez on February 7, 2024 at 9:30AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs met with Levon Manucharyan, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPAs reviewed 0 child's records and 2 staff personnel files on site at the facility as the facility did not have any dependents in placement at this time. LPAs reviewed 0 child's psychotropic medications and medication records as the facility did not have any dependents in placement at this time. LPAs interviewed 2 staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPAs provided a copy of the licensing report to Levon Manucharyan, Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview with Levon Manucharyan, Administrator.

Licensing Program(LPA) Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection June 13, 2024 at 10: AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, June 13, 2024.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma- informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Levon Manucharyan.

On July 30, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Miriam Flores and Briana Placensia conducted a case management inspection at Manuch Aspen and met with Assistant Manager, Irvin Hermosillo. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss concerns with an incident report sent to Community Care Licensing (CCL) dated 07/24/2024 (0000850-FN), regarding a foster child #1 (see 811- Ref #1) reporting that AC was not cooling the house down fast enough. At arrival, temperature measured 72 degrees F. Foster child#1, declined to interviewed by LPAs. LPAs determined this to not be an immediate risk to health and safety at this time. No deficiencies are being cited. LPAs conducted exit interview with Assistant Manager, Irvin Hermosillo.

narrative: On April 24, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Miriam Flores and Sonia Chavez travelled to Manuch Inc Aspen House to conduct an Annual inspection. LPAs met with Facility Manager, Willie Williford and Administrator, Levon Manucharyan At 8:30AM, LPAs reviewed client's files and reviewed emergency intervention plan. There are two clients that require medications, facility has the ability to keep Medications locked and centrally stored. At 10:40AM, LPAs conducted an inspection of the physical plant and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials were observed. Food supply, adequate bedding, storage space, activity space, hot water that measured 120 degrees F. Facility is maintained at 73 degrees. At 11:00AM, LPAs completed interviews with staff and made attempts to complete interviews with youth in placement. At 12:00PM, LPAs reviewed staff files. Youth in placement were present at the facility. Mental Health Program Approval expires on September 17, 2025. CARF accreditation expires on August 31,2025. Violations were cited on under ILS 87065.1(d)(6)(A) and CCR 80019(e). This facility was assessed for a civil penalty. See the attached LIC809D and LIC421BG. At 1:30PM, the exit interview was conducted with the Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia on July 17, 2025 at 9:15am. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code 1538.9(a)(2). During the inspection, LPA met with Levon Manucharyan, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 1 child's records and 2 staff personnel files on site at the facility. On September 16, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Miriam Flores met with Facility Manager, Marie Fierro at Manuch Aspen for the purpose of conducting a Case Management. The purpose of the inspection is to discuss incidents dated 8/31/25, that indicated a medication error made by staff. LPA discussed with Facility Manager details of the incident. LPA highlighted the importance of administering medications appropriately. On 9/16/25, Facility Manager reported that S1 was terminated from Manuch Aspen STRTP. On 9/09/25, Manuch conducted an all staff training on Medication distribution. On 10/08/25, the facility will also be providing a second all staff training, conducted by Shouapa Thao on Psychotropic Medication Monitoring & Oversight. The Department determined this to be a potential risk to health and safety of the children in care at this time, therefore California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC809D. The Agency is being cited for the Interim Licensing Standards Section 87075(c) Health Related Services. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

On the above date, a virtual Meeting is held via Microsoft Teams to Discuss the pending STRTP application. Present at the Teams meeting were Mike Manucharyan, Elena Manucharyan, Hector Cabrera and Candis Bazely representing the Applicant. Present from Community Care Licensing (CCLD) were Lisa Slusher, Licensing Program Analyst, Melanie Krage and Lourey Bartolome, Licensing Program Managers. Discussed items outstanding in the application, of specific note: 1. According to the facility, the fire clearance has been completed by the City of Fresno Fire Department, but CCLD has not received the notice. 2. Applicant provided a letter from Fresno City Planning which will serve as an overconcentration clearance and allows applicant to proceed at the above location. Discussed letter sent to the applicant via email on 6/16/21 including all areas of the application, plan of operation and program statement that require revision based on CCLD review. A tentative due date for the revisions has been set for 6/21/21. LPA Slusher to provide applicant with a pre-licensing checklist to be completed prior to pre-licensing inspection. A copy of this report has been sent to the applicant for signature by email.

On June 23, 2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Tamara Melikian, Eduardo Barragan and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Melanie Krage travelled to the facility listed above to conduct a prelicensing inspection. Facility Inspection conducted. Met at the facility by Licensee Mike Manucharyan, Clinician Elena Manucharyan and House Manager Chris Kertzman. 1. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. 2. Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. Licensee noted that outdoor activity items would be added. 3. Chemicals appropriately locked. 4. Locked and centrally stored medications observed. LPA's and LPM discussed procedures for psychotropic medications. 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. 8. The house has 4 bedrooms, double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Only one bedroom will be in use and is furnished at this time. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of a week of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. Facility will add appropriate supply of two days of perishable foods upon placement of youth in the home. 10. Weekly menu posted and accessible to clients. 11. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 12.Facility has two full restrooms, one for client use, one for staff use, both are operable. Facility is to ensure water measures between 105 and 120 degrees. 13. Licensee will forward updated insurance and registration card for facility vehicle. 14. Licensee will associate administrator and corporate board member to the facility. Licensure will be recommended upon approval from the department. Facility license will be valid for one male youth. Facility will be licensed on a provisional basis expiring one year from effective date. Mental Health program approval will be completed in 12 months or an extension will be requested.

narrative: On the above date, LPA Lisa Slusher conducted a scheduled case management for the purpose of evaluating a facility for a increase in capacity. The facility was licensed as an STRTP for 1 on 7/6/2021. The facility is increasing the capacity of the facility to 6. The facility plans to transfer youth from the licensed facility on Donner Ave. 1. Facility Grounds inspected and observed to be free from hazard with appropriate activity space observed. . 2. Facility has had a fire inspection for increased capacity and has verbally been told that a clearance is forthcoming- fire clearance has not yet been received by CCLD, 3. Chemicals stored in a locked cabinet 4. Observed locked cabinet inside locked closet for central storage of medications. Observed first aid kit and manual. 5. Individual bed in good repair observed, along with an appropriate amount of storage space. 6. The house has 3 bedrooms, sufficient for double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Only one bedroom will be in use and is furnished at this time. 7. Adequate food storage space observed. Perishable and non perishable foods were not observed at this time. 8. Dining room observed with appropriate table and chairs. Facility has 2 full restrooms, one for staff use and one for client use. There is also a half bath for client use . Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees. 9. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility with appropriate insurance and registration. Facility has met requirements for capacity increase, pending the receipt of the fire clearance. Facility is to follow up with LIC 500 and 9020, LIC 308 309 and change of Administrator. Facility will submit for MHPA at this facility upon license approval and transfer of youth from the Donner Facility. Facility will update the Admission Agreements.

An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Reyna Martinez. LPA met with Jessica Villalba, Facility House Manager, and inspected the facility, inside and out. Facility Grounds are clean and free of debris or observable hazard. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked closet in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced July 2023. The facility is accredited through CARF valid to August 31, 2025 and MHPA through Fresno County valid to September 21, 2023. The house has 3 client bedrooms, all double occupancy. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 74 degrees. Hot water temperature measures 120 degrees. Facility has no cameras in common areas of the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility has no pool on grounds. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 1 facility manager, 1 assistant house manager, 13 direct care staff, 5 social worker's, 1 clinician, 1 behavior health head of service, and 1 mental health rehabilitation specialist. -Continued on LIC809-C. Personnel Files are maintained at the main office. 5 staff files were reviewed. 2 staff were available to be interviewed. 5 records of clients were reviewed and 1 client was available to be interviewed. 2 clients are currently on AWOL and 3 clients were asleep during time of inspection and did not want to speak with LPA. A review of Licensing Information System on July 18, 2023, indicates that all facility staff associated to the STRTP have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index clearances. No deficiencies are being issued today. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and left with the STRTP.

On November 20, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a Case Management inspection at Manuch- Inspiration Peak and met with Facility Manager (FM) Jessica Villalba. The purpose of this inspection was to discuss concerns with two incident reports sent to CCL. The first with the incident date of 10/12/23, FM states that the facility uses a point system to determine how much allowance a youth gets but that no matter how much points the youth loses that youth will still receive their money for the week. The second incident report dated 10/14/23, FM stated there was several errors and the information was not shared thoroughly. FM will revise the incident report and resubmit the report to CCL. FM stated that during an upcoming training, FM will be re-training staff on the correct procedures for incident reporting. There are no findings or citations at this time, A copy of this report was left at the facility.

investigation_findings: 13On November 20, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Briana Placencia conducted a complaint inspection at Manuch-Inspiration Peak and met with Jessica Villalba. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews which revealed that staff did not provide adequate supervision to the minors in care, in that a youth absconded attempting to obtain the Wi-Fi password from neighbors. Staff on shift could not leave due to begin only staff at the time. Confidential interviews, documentation and video footage reveal that staff did not prevent minors from causing harm to minor in care. Based on the information obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to the facility. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 0

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection on August 27, 2025 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, August 27, 2025). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Corina Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Adrian Pena, Facility Manager.

narrative: On 7/1/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Lisa Slusher, Reyna Martinez, Briana Placencia travelled to the facility listed above to conduct a prelicensing inspection. Facility Inspection conducted. Met at the facility by Licensee Mike Manucharyan, Clinician Elena Manucharyan, Administrator Levon Manucharyan. 1. Facility Grounds contain unlocked chemicals and other items (charcoal grill, lighter fluid, pool chemicals). There is a pool on the property that is currently unfenced and also is green and in need of appropriate cleaning and chemical balance if it is to be used. 2. Outdoor space observed. There are items to be removed, and licensee is to provide outdoor activities. . 3. Chemicals were in unlocked areas upon inspection. . 4. Locked and centrally stored medications were discussed. There is not currently a locked space for medications... 5. First aid kit complete with appropriate manual was not present upon inspection. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed in the garage, but were not yet set up in the house.. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Only one bedroom will be in use and is furnished at this time. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Perishable and non perishable foods were not observed at this time. 10. Weekly menu not observed. 11. Dining room observed. Table and chairs for the STRTP were not observed during inspection. 12.Facility has two full restrooms, one for client use, one for staff use, both are operable. Facility is to ensure water temperature is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees 13. Licensee has a vehicle for use at the facility. When LPA returns, the vehicle including insurance and registration will be available for inspection. 14. Licensee provided transfer requests for board member, administrator, and therapist . Licensee will submit a transfer request for a corporate board member. Fire clearance request has been provided to the city of Fresno Fire Department. The facility requires fire clearance prior to licensure. The facility physical plant requires a deep cleaning. The previous tentant is still in the process of removing their belongings, so that the licensee can move in furniture. The physical plant also smells of cigarette smoke. The licensee provided verification from the City of Fresno Planning department of overconcentration clearance on this date. LPA will conduct a follow-up inspection to verify all the requirements on these two pages are met. LPA will also provide a pre-licensing certification to be submitted back to LPA prior to repeat inspection tentatively scheduled for 7/8/22.

On June 17, 2021, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual/post licensing inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a Provisional STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 27, 2019. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Director, Clete Menke. LPAs toured the facility inside and out at 9: AM. The facility is a one-story residence with six bedrooms and one communal bathroom for the clients. The bedrooms are arranged so that there are two clients sharing a room and one infant. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested at 9: AM and registered at 112.6 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored inside a locked cabinet in the laundry room and inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The facility's smoke detectors were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the Operations Director. LPAs observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There is one camera at the facility located on the wall in the kitchen/living room area. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. See Page Two The facility employs one Executive Director, one Operations Manager, one Program Coordinator, one Staff Manager, one Medical Coordinator, one Facility Coordinator, one Parenting Coordinator, one Clinical Director, one STRTP Clinician, one Social Worker, two Case Managers, and 30 youth support staff. Licensee obtained their Mental Health (MH) Certification on May 17, 2021 and it expires on May 17, 2022. Licensee obtained National Accreditation through COA and the accreditation is valid through October 31, 2024. Licensee has received written and verbal Medi-Cal approval. Per Facility Director, Clete Menke, official documentation of that approval has not been received. Licensing fee payments are current. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. At 11: AM, LPA reviewed a sample of five clients files during the time of inspection. All files contained the required documentation per Title Regulations. At 11: AM, LPA reviewed sample of five staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulations requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging the child abuse reporting requirements. Two facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. Two clients were interviewed during the inspection. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Facility procedures related to requesting exceptions. Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. LPA also discussed Reasonable and Prudent Parenting Standards, and resident involvement in development of planned activities. Based on the facility inspection and files reviewed on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. Note: The annual for Mary's Shelter 2 (#300613291) was also conducted during the time of this inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator.

On July 27, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Lisi Leon, met with Facility Manager, Clete Menke, to obtain a signature for an amended report. A copy of this report was given to Facility Manager, Clete Menke.

Confidential interviews revealed facility staff verbally advised C1 of a 14-day notice during a Child and Family Team meeting held on January 05, 2022, however, facility failed to operate in accordance with their plan of operation and submit notification to authorized representative within seven days. On January 20, 2022, CCL received an allegation staff did not provide minor with clothing allowance. Specifically, it was reported that C1 was not provided C1's clothing allowance for the month of January 2022. Confidential interviews revealed in January 2022, facility had high cases of COVID and staff asked C1 to wait a couple weeks until the COVID cases had dropped prior to going shopping with monthly allowance. Confidential record review revealed C1 would go shopping in the beginning of the month and at the time of discharge C1 still had not gone shopping and was not given monthly allowance of $75.00 at time of discharge. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations unlawful eviction of C1 and staff did not provide C1 with clothing allowance are substantiated and the facility is being cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Interim Licensing Standards Version 4. Plan of Operation 87022(f). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility representative. Confidential interviews revealed client was unable to take all personal belongings at the time of discharge as the car was full. Confidential interviews shared minor was given all confidential and personal documents at the time of discharge in a binder. Confidential interviews also revealed facility staff followed-up with C1 after discharge and provided C1 with all remaining belongings and any mail that was received after discharge. Another confidential interview stated that C1 was not provided C1's birth certificate. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation that staff did not provide C1 with personal belongings may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, this allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to facility representative.

This is an amended report that was issued on November 07, 2023. On November 07, 2023, at 09: AM Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera and Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced annual random inspection at Short Term Therapeutic Program facility. LPA's was met with Facility Director, Clete Menke and Facility Coordinator Kathy McGinty. LPA's toured the facility inside and out. The facility is a one-story residence with six bedrooms and one communal bathroom for the clients. The bedrooms are arranged so that there are two clients sharing a room and one infant. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client's belongings. The bathroom was clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested and registered at 112.3 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored inside a locked cabinet in the laundry room and inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The facility's smoke detectors were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the Operations Director. LPAs observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored inside a double locked cabinet in the staff's office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and a two-day perishable supply of food. There is one camera at the facility located on the wall in the kitchen/living room area. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA's reviewed six client files and all required documents were in the files. LPA's reviewed six personnel records/files. Staff have Criminal Background and Child Abuse Clearances which are complete and current for all employees. The licensing fee payments are current. Based on the facility inspection on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Kathy McGinty.

met_with: Derrick Perry, Vice President of Operations
narrative: On 08/21/25, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Gilbert Marquez and Stefanie Mutialu met with Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland and Vice President of Operations, Derrick Perry, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve 11 ambulatory residents 12-21 years old and six infants 0-24 months of age. The current census is five clients. The facility is current with licensing fees. The facility is a single-story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with Vice President of Operations, Derrick Perry and included the following checks: six bedrooms, one communal bathroom for the clients, kitchen, medication room, dining room, living room, seven staff offices, visitation room, sensory room, and outdoor living space. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattresses were in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. No bedroom occupied more than one client and one infant and not used for other purposes. The water temperature was tested in the clients' main bathroom which measured 117 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to all staff and had all required supplies. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. **Continued on LIC809C** **LIC809** Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested by fire clearance; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. LPA observed a bottle of "ALL" laundry detergent accessible to clients located on the closet top shelf in client bedroom #1 and a bottle of Clorox bleach spray, two containers of Lysol wipes accessible to clients in an unlocked cabinet in the unlocked laundry room. Per Facility Manager, Kathy McGinty, all cleaners, disinfectants, and toxic chemicals are locked up and inaccessible to clients, however, staff give these items to clients for use but sometimes clients do not return them. For this, the facility is receiving a type A citation. LPA also reviewed one of five client medication records. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Due to time constraints, LPA will return on another day to conduct client and staff interviews, and review staff and client files. Based on LPA observation of cleaning chemicals being unlocked in client bedroom #1 and accessible in laundry room, the facility is receiving a type A citation for violation of Title Section 80087(g) Physical Plant. An exit interview was conducted with the Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland to explain this report, the LIC809D page, and a plan of correction for the deficiency. The appeal rights were discussed. A copy of the Facility Evaluation Report, along with LIC809D pages, the Confidential Names List LIC811, and the appeal rights were given to Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland and additionally will be kept in the facility file.

On August 22, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Stefanie Mutialu and Gilbert Marquez continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on August 21, 2025. LPAs met with Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland. During the inspection LPAs reviewed five staff files (S1-S5). Five out of five files contained the required documents including verification of criminal background check clearance, signed acknowledgment of mandated child abuse and neglect reporting requirements, and health screening. During inspection and Guardian verification, LPAs discovered S6 did not obtain required background clearance as required by Title 22 regulations. LPA's were unable to review client files as the facility did not make client records accessible. During the Annual Inspection on 08/21/25, upon arrival LPAs requested client records be accessible for review by 12: PM, after 12: PM LPAs were advised the files will be available electronically as the Quality Assurance Specialist (QAS) was working on sending the electronic files. After 2: PM LPAs were advised the QAS was having challenges sending the files, LPAs then received three client files but unable to open and review while in the field, Vice President of Operations (VPO), Derrick Perry then offered to go and pick up files at the corporate office that is a mile and a half away. Due to time constraints, LPAs were unable to wait and advised VPO to ensure all client records were available for review first thing on 08/22/2025. Upon LPAs arrival today, 08/22/25 at AM, QAS and VPO were not onsite, and the present staff did not have access to client files.The facility is receiving a citation during today's visit. *Continued on Page 2* CONTINUED FROM PAGE LPAs conducted interviews with three staff (S1- S3) and with two clients (C1-C2). The facility is being cited for one type B citation for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division six, regulation 80070(d)(1): Client Records and one type A citation for Health and Safety Code 1522(c)(1):Administration and civil penalties of $500 ( X $100) will be assessed as per California Code of Regulations, Title Division six, regulation 80051(a)(2): Serious Deficiencies An exit interview was conducted with Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland. A copy of this report and confidential names (LIC 811) dated 08/22/2025 was provided to Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland.

narrative: On September 4, 2025, at 4:10 pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Charmaine Linley and Gilbert Marquez conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Vanessa Ruiz, Residential Staff Manager. LPAs inquired where the Administrator was and were told the Administrator is off site at a training. This inspection is to discuss information that was reported to the Department and based on LPAs observations on August 21 and August 22, 2025. On August 21, 2025, LPAs Gilbert Marquez and Stefanie Mutialu arrived at the facility for an Annual Inspection and were at the facility from 9:31 am-5:15 pm and the Facility Administrator was not at the facility and did not arrive during the Annual Inspection. On August 22, 2025, LPAs Marquez and Mutialu arrived at the facility for a continuation of the Annual Inspection and were at the facility from 10:00 am-1:00 pm, the Facility Administrator was not at the facility and did not arrive during the Annual Inspection. LPAs inquired if the Facility Administrator would arrive during the Annual Inspections and were told the Facility Administrator was only available via phone contact. Confidential interviews indicated that the Facility Administrator is not at the facility twenty hours per week as required; the Facility Administrator is present one day a week at the facility. Facility Administrator/CEO and Vice-President of Operations called LPA and stated they would drive to the facility and arrive at 5:00 pm and arrived at 5:05 pm. Based on confidential interviews and LPA's observations, the facility is being cited for a Type B violation of the Interim Licensing Standards STRTP 87064(b)(1) Administrator Qualifications and Duties.
