On June 17, 2021, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual/post licensing inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a Provisional STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 27, 2019. LPA was met at the facility by Facility Director, Clete Menke. LPAs toured the facility inside and out at 10: AM. The facility is a one-story residence with five bedrooms and two bathrooms for the clients. Four bedrooms are arranged so that there is one client and their infant in a room. One bedroom is arranged so that there are two clients' sharing a room and two infants. There is adequate closet and drawer space for client's belongings. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested at 10: AM and registered at 115.1 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet in the kitchen. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by the Operations Director. LPAs observed facility posted items in the hallway that included: Disaster Plan, Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Client's medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored inside a locked cabinet next to the toddler play area. LPAs observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There is one camera at the facility located on the wall in the kitchen/living room area. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. See Page Two The facility employs one Executive Director, one Operations Manager, one Program Coordinator, one Staff Manager, a Medical Coordinator, one Facility Coordinator, one Parenting Coordinator, one Clinical Director, one STRTP Clinician, one Social Worker, two Case Managers, and 30 youth support staff. Licensee obtained their Mental Health (MH) Certification on May 17, 2021 and it expires on May 17, 2022. met_with: Derrick Perry, Vice President of Operations
narrative: On 08/21/25, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Gilbert Marquez and Stefanie Mutialu met with Derrick Perry, Vice President of Operations for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve five ambulatory clients ages 12-21 years old and six infants 0-24 months. The current census is four clients. The facility is current with licensing fees. The facility is a single-story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with Kathy McGinty, Facility Coordinator, which included the following checks: five bedrooms and two communal bathrooms for the clients, kitchen, medication room, dining room, living room, one staff office, playroom for the infants, therapy room, and outdoor living space. One bedroom is approved for two infants; all other bedrooms are approved for one infant. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. The water temperature was tested in client bathroom #2 which measured 115.3 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to all staff and had all required supplies. There is one camera at the facility located on the wall in the kitchen/living room area. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were **continued on LIC809C** **continued from LIC809** tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. During the inspection, LPA observed staff S4 change the diaper of a client's baby on a marble counter. The facility is receiving a type B violation. LPA also asked staff S5 if any of the babies were more than 24 months. S5 stated that one was 28 months old. The facility is receiving a type B violation. Medication Records of four clients out of four (C1 - C4) were reviewed with Vanessa Ruiz, Residential Staff Manager. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Due to time constraints, LPAs will return on another day to conduct client and staff interviews, and review files for clients and staff. Based on LPA's observation of a staff changing a baby that was not on the floor or using a changing table, the facility is receiving a type B violation. This is not in compliance with Interim Licensing Standards Section 87096.77(d) Personnel Services. Based on LPA review of client roster and short interview with a staff stating that a baby was over 24 months old, the facility is receiving a type B violation. This is not in compliance with California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Section 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. An exit interview was conducted to explain the facility evaluation report, along with LIC809D page, the Confidential Names List LIC811, the plan of corrections, and the appeal rights were given to Licensee, and additionally will be kept in the facility file.

narrative: On September 4, 2025, at 4:30 pm, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Charmaine Linley and Gilbert Marquez conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with Vanessa Ruiz, Residential Staff Manager. LPAs inquired where the Administrator was and were told the Administrator is off site at a training. This inspection is to discuss information that was reported to the Department and based on LPAs observations on August 21, 2025, and August 22, 2025. On August 21, 2025, LPAs Gilbert Marquez and Stefanie Mutialu arrived at the facility for an Annual Inspection and were at the facility from 9:30 am-5:00 pm and the Facility Administrator was not at the facility and did not arrive during the Annual Inspection. On August 22, 2025, LPAs Marquez and Mutialu arrived at the facility for a continuation of the Annual Inspection and were at the facility from 1:01 pm-5:40 pm, the Facility Administrator was not at the facility and did not arrive during the Annual Inspection. LPAs inquired if the Facility Administrator would arrive during the Annual Inspections and were told the Facility Administrator was only available via phone contact. Confidential interviews indicated that the Facility Administrator is not at the facility twenty hours per week as required; the Facility Administrator is present one day a week at the facility. Facility Administrator/CEO and Vice-President of Operations called LPA and stated they would drive to the facility and arrive at 5:00 pm and arrived at 5:05 pm. Based on confidential interviews and LPA's observations, the facility is being cited for a Type B violation of the Interim Licensing Standards STRTP 87064(b)(1) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. Refer to LIC809D. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Jill Dominguez and Derrick Perry. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to the facility.

met_with: Derrick Perry, Vice President of Operations
narrative: On August 22, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Stefanie Mutialu and Gilbert Marquez continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on August 21, 2025. LPAs met with Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland. During the inspection LPAs reviewed five staff files (S1-S5). Five out of five files contained the required documents including verification of criminal background check clearance, signed acknowledgment of mandated child abuse and neglect reporting requirements, and health screening. During inspection and Guardian verification, LPAs discovered S6 did not obtain required background clearance as required by Title 22 regulations. LPA's were unable to review client files as the facility did not make client records accessible. During the Annual Inspection on 08/21/25, upon arrival LPAs requested client records be accessible for review by 12: PM, after 12: PM LPAs were advised the files will be available electronically as the Quality Assurance Specialist (QAS) was working on sending the electronic files. After 2: PM LPAs were advised the QAS was having challenges sending the files, LPAs then received three client files but unable to open and review while in the field, Vice President of Operations (VPO), Derrick Perry then offered to go and pick up files at the corporate office that is a mile and a half away. Due to time constraints, LPAs were unable to wait and advised VPO to ensure all client records were available for review first thing on 08/22/2025. Upon LPAs arrival today, 08/22/25 at AM, QAS and VPO were not on site, and the present staff did not have access to client files.The facility is receiving a citation during today's visit. *Continued on Page 2* CONTINUED FROM PAGE LPAs conducted interviews with three staff (S1- S3) and with one client (C1). The facility is being cited for one type B citation for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division six, regulation 80070(d)(1): Client Records and one type A citation for Health and Safety Code 1522(c)(1):Administration and civil penalties of $500 ( X $100) will be assessed as per California Code of Regulations, Title Division six, regulation 80051(a)(2): Serious Deficiencies An exit interview was conducted with Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland. A copy of this report and confidential names (LIC 811) dated 08/22/2025 was provided to Clinical Supervisor, Kelli Strickland.

narrative: Additional Confidential witness statements indicate that R1 did not receive R1 allowance and was not allowed to hold R1's allowance on R1's person. AD stated that he does not issue nor secures the allowance but was aware that R1 was not give R1 allowance. AD also stated that R1 needed to request for a shopping outing and that facility staff would transport R1 and purchase the items for R1. CSW stated that he never instructed nor gave the facility staff written directives that allowed the facility staff to withhold R1 allowance. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met that the group home staff withheld R1 allowance. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. The Facility is cited for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter Personal Rights 84072(c)(17). Signed reports will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On Novermber 10, 2020 at 9:24am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Jose Gonzalez contacted Administrator (AD), Jerome Jordan of Maywright Group Home to discuss the investigative findings for the allegations noted above due to COVID-19 tele-inspection was conducted. LPA inspected the facility at 9:55 am on November 26, 2019 and reviewed staff's files and five out of five residents' records. During the investigation, interviews were conducted with five out of five residents, Administrator (AD), Facility Manager (FM), and County Social Worker (CSW). The Department received a complaint on November 20, 2019, that alleged facility staff withheld resident 1 (R1) allowance. Confidential witness statements indicate that the facility staff withheld R1's allowance. Additional confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff held R1 allowance because R1 has a history of substance abuse and was using their allowance money to purchase illicit drugs. Confidential witness statements revealed that R1 was not given R1 allowance as a deterrent from purchasing drugs and alcohol. **CONT on 9099C** SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

met_with: Administrator-Jerome Jordan and Facility Manager-Sheila Evans
narrative: On June 28, 2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Maywright Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by facility manager (FM) Ms. Sheila Evans. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were four staff and five clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 10: AM, Ms. Sheila Evans led the physical inspection of the facility with LPA Escobar. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The master bedroom is used as the staff office along with the staff restroom. The facility has a dining area within the kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, and a garage. The laundry area is located in the hallway that leads to the garage. There is a large shed in the backyard of the facility that is used as the clinician's office for therapeutic services as well as the case manager's office. There is a window and air conditioning within the building. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. Bedroom #3 has large holes in two of the walls and the bedroom door also has a hole in it. The dresser in this room is broken, drawers are broken. There is currently only one client in this room. The facility will be given a technical advisory for these issues as they occurred this morning before LPA's inspection began, during client fight. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair, however, the clients remove the linens to their beds. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. During the inspection, it was observed that the basketball hoop in the backyard has fallen over and is on the ground, creating a potential hazard. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Television, computer, board games, video gaming console, and basketball hoop, were observed for client's recreation time. There is no activities calendar posted, however, staff advise due to COVID-19, they are just getting back to scheduling outings and outside activities. Carbon monoxide detector is in appropriate working order and facility smoke detectors are also in working order. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. While the refrigerator in the kitchen had minimal food, both refrigerators in the garage were fully stocked. Per FM, the clients have access to one of the refrigerators for food/snacks. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and stored in a locked box within a locked closet in the staff office. The hot water in the staff and client restrooms was deemed to be at a safe temperature. Per facility staff, there are no firearms or weapons in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a cabinet next to the washer/dryer in the laundry area. Sharp objects/knives are locked and stored in a locked box in the locked closet in the staff office. First Aid Kits are also stored in this locked closet and are complete. A First Aid Manual was also available. It was observed that the licensee has cameras in common areas of the facility as well as the staff office. There is an exception on file for the facility to use the cameras and the facility continues to meet the terms and conditions of the exception, however, the surveillance system is currently not in operating order. Facility will advise when camera system is up and running again. The facility employs one Facility Administrator, six Facility Managers, three direct care youth counselors, one Case Manager, one Head of Service and one Program Director. Facility has not yet obtained Mental Health Certification, however, have submitted the application and are awaiting approval. Facility has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through February 28, 2022. Currently, the facility is up to date with Licensing fees for the facility, with a balance of $0. At 10: AM, five of five client files were reviewed during time of inspection. Client files are kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office. Client 1 (C1), client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), client 4 (C4), and client 5's (C5) files were reviewed at time of inspection, (See LIC 857) dated June 28, 2021. C3 did not have medical consent form in file. Needs and service plans for C1, C2, and C5 are not current/up to date. The facility will be cited under the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section 87068. Modifications to the Needs and Service Plan. C5 did not have proof of current TB test. Technical Assistance Advisory Notes (TA) will be issued for this issue. C3 and C4 are new clients and all missing documents from files will be gathered within 30 days for file completion. LPAs conducted client interviews. Clients indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services are being provided. LPA Escobar began the review of staff files, however, due to time constraints, was not able to conclude the review. LPA Escobar will return to complete staff file review and interviews at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator, Mr. Jerome Jordan.

On June 29, 2021, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar arrived at Maywright Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). The purpose of the inspection was to complete the continuation inspection for STRTP annual inspection that was initiated on June 28, 2021. LPA already completed the physical inspection of the facility and reviewed facility client files on the first day of the annual inspection. During this annual inspection continuation, LPA Escobar reviewed ten personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). Personnel Files are usually maintained in a locked closet inside the staff office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Eight of the ten files that were reviewed were for employees who converted from group home personnel to STRTP personnel. LPA observed the converted staff members were trained according to the STRTP training requirements for employees. File for staff 1 (S1) did not have current job evaluation. Nine of the ten staff files did not have not have employer verification forms in files. Technical advisories will be issued for the aforementioned staff file issues. Administrator Jerome Jordan states he has been the current administrator since 2018 at the facility, however, no documents or requests for administrator change were made to Community Care Licensing (CCL). Incorrect administrator remains on file. Per interviews conducted, the present administrator is not at the facility as required. Facility will be cited under Interim Licensing Standards section Personnel Requirements. Additionally, eight staff files did not have more than 24 hours of annual training recorded in training file. One staff did not have any annual training hours recorded. Facility will be cited under Interim Licensing Standards section 87065. Training Requirements. Lastly, it could not be determined that staff 10 (S10) meets the direct staff personnel requirements based on personnel record and accompanying employee questionnaire in file. Facility is being cited under Interim Licensing Standards section Personnel Requirements. Administrator Jerome Jordan is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator and Facility Manager: incident reporting, including incidents related to Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. On this second day of the continued annual inspection, two youth counselors (direct care staff), one Case Manager, one Facility Manager, and Facility Administrator, were present and were interviewed in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's STRTP program. Staff have no issues or concerns regarding the facility. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. LPA requested the recent board meeting minutes be provided via email by July 6, 2021. LPA also requested an updated LIC500 be sent to LPA as soon as possible. A copy of this report, the advisory notices, and appeal rights, were provided to Facility Administrator, Jerome Jordan.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst, Veronica Whitaker and Licensing Program Manager, Angela King conducted a case management inspection November 16, 2021, at 10: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. 5 of Direct Care Staff and 3 of 3 youth files as identified on the LIC 811 confidential names dated November 16, 2021, were reviewed. 2 of Direct Care Staff and 2 of 3 youth were also interviewed. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedure were reviewed. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Jerome Jordan, Administrator.

not receiving therapeutic services as required, and C1 is not attending school regularly. Specifically, it was reported the STRTP lacks supervision for clients as clients are allowed to stay out past PM. It was also reported C1 is not receiving therapeutic services due to therapist availability issues and facility never notified C1's CSW of this. It was also reported that C1 did not attend school for a month. Several witnesses corroborate that therapeutic services were minimized due to service providers having COVID19 and also STRTP clients declining services. Facility provided LPA verification of mental health treatment service logs which demonstrate weekly services provided to C1 or C1 declining services. Staff confirmed therapist was out with COVID19 on occasion but provided LPA information about staff-led "groups" that were provided to clients in the meanwhile. Finally, staff confirmed C1 was not in school for almost three months, however, facility provided emails from school district corroborating efforts being made to enroll C1 in school, however, the facility had to wait for a school to accept C1 as several had denied enrollment. Several confidential interviews corroborate the allegations are "not true" and corroborate that staff are always supervising clients in the home and some clients are approved by their county social workers to take community walks that can last anywhere from 15 minutes to 1 hour depending on the client. Facility confirms the clients are not generally out past PM, but on occasion, clients may return late. Facility provided LPA with corroborating documentation of this information. Facility took action in each of the allegations reported and followed standard protocol. While a witness maintains these allegations occurred, the majority of all confidential interviews corroborate the information provided by facility. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that staff do not provide adequate supervision, C1 is not receiving therapeutic services as required, and C1 is not attending school regularly, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to Mr. Clifford Moss for signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On April 29, 2022, at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carmen Escobar made contact at the facility with Short-Term Residential Therapy Program (STRTP) acting facility manager (FM) Clifford Moss. LPA Escobar conducted a facility risk assessment interview with FM and proceeded to issue the investigative findings for the above allegations. During the investigation, LPA requested documents from client 1 (C1's), client 2 (C2's), and client 3 (C3's) files including placement agreements, copy of C1's most current needs and service plan, special incident reports involving C1, C2, and C3, verification of mental health services for clients, and visitation documents for clients. LPA also obtained a copy of the facility's client roster. LPA Escobar conducted interviews with the FA, staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), C1, C2, and C3, C1 and C2's county social worker (CSW) and another involved party. LPA Escobar completed the initial ten-day inspection to initiate the complaint with the facility on 10/21/21 at 2: PM, no health or safety concerns were observed. It was alleged that on or around 10/15/21 staff do not provide adequate supervision, C1 is UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: before being enrolled in school, C1 is constantly late to school, and facility is non-responsive to school regarding C1. Specifically, it was reported that C1 is late for school almost on a daily basis. When addressed with C1, it was reported C1 is late to school due to staff being late each morning during shift change. Additionally, C1 was at the facility for over a month before being enrolled in school. Staff confirmed C1 was not in school for about a month, however, facility provided emails from school district corroborating efforts being made to enroll C1 in school. The facility had to wait for a school to accept C1 as several had denied enrollment. Finally, it was also reported a confidential witness has reached out to the facility "time after time" regarding C1's school attendance and school concerns and the facility has not called back or made any effort to communicate with involved party. While a witness maintains this occurs, all other witnesses corroborate clients, including C1, are not late to school because of staff, rather, are late because clients refuse to wake up for school. Several witnesses corroborate staff will provide verbal direction for clients to get up, however, clients refused to get up for school. Facility provided LPA with corroborating documentation of this information in the daily log. Finally, while a witness maintains staff has made no effort to be in communication with C1's school, the majority of all confidential interviews corroborate the facility took a few weeks to get into the habit of being in constant communication with schools, however, once facility began with more communication, the facility has stayed on top of everything and make a constant effort to update schools and county social workers if anything comes up or needs to be addressed regarding clients. Several confidential witnesses confirm the facility is "doing what it needs to do" for clients in their care. The confidential witnesses corroborate they do not like to get up for school and neither did C1 at the time; this always made clients late to school. Other witnesses maintain the facility did not communicate well at first, but within a few weeks, had everything together and have been doing a great job since then regarding client communication with both schools and CSWs. Based on interviews conducted and information obtained, the allegations that C1 was at facility for an extended period of time before being enrolled in school, C1 is constantly late to school, and facility is non-responsive to school regarding C1, may have occurred, however, they are not supported or proven by evidence. The allegations are, therefore, UNSUBSTANTIATED. There are no deficiencies to be cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights, were provided to Mr.Clifford Moss for signature. Signed report will be placed in facility file.

narrative: On October 20, 2022 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Karen Beal, Carmen Escobar and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith arrived at Mayright Group Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs and LPM were greeted and granted access by Mr. Philip Roberts. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a continuation of the annual inspection of the facility that was initiated on October 7, 2022. There was one staff present and six clients present at the time of the inspection. The facility was out of ratio at time of visit. An additional staff (S2) was called to return back to the facility and arrived approximately 10 minutes later. At 10: AM, five of six client files were reviewed during time of inspection. Client files are kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office, which can also be locked. Client 1 (C1), client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), client 4 (C4), and client 5's (C5) files were reviewed at time of inspection. C1, C2, and C3's files are missing their signed medical consent forms. C2, C3 and C4 did not have initial medical assessments in their files. All clients, C1-C5, do not have documentation of mental health services received in their files. C3 and C4 did not have proof of TB test results in files. C5 refused to get a TB test. C4 and C5 did not have signatures from their authorized representatives for the complaint, removal/discharge or discipline policies in their files. C1-C5 did not have personal care and grooming needs documented in their needs and service plans. C1, C2, and C5 do not have visitation approval/restrictions documented in their needs and service plans. C1 and C5's needs and service plans are missing signatures by the clients and the client's authorized representatives. C1 does not have a needs and service plan in their file. C2-C5 do not have current needs and service plans in their files. The last needs and service report is dated August 2022. C2 does not have a signed and dated written order from a physician for the non-prescription medication in the file. C1-C5 did not have a bedroom sharing/compatibility review form in their files. During a review of the disaster plan, the location of the utility shut-off valves and instructions were missing. Per Mr. Roberts they do not have it documented in their emergency plan and it is unknown where the valves are located. The facility will be cited under the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) section Client Records, 87070(b)(11) , 87070(b)(13)(H), 87068.2(b)(6), 87068.2(f), 87068.3(a), 80075(b)(6)(D), Staff & Client Ratios 87065.5(a)(1). Title Regulations Client Records 80069(a), 80069(c)(1), 87087(e), 87070(c)(2), 87068.2(b)(4), 87068.2(f) and Health & Safety Code Disaster Preparedness 1565(a)(6). Due to time constraints the annual will need to be continued on a later date. A copy of this report, advisory notices, and appeal rights, were provided to Acting Facility Manager, Gibron Mall.

narrative: On October 7, 2022 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Karen Beal, Erika Lopez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith arrived at Mayright Group Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs and LPM were greeted and granted access by Mr. Philip Roberts. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were three staff and three clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 11: AM, Mr. Roberts led the physical inspection of the facility. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The master bedroom is used as the staff office along with the staff restroom. The facility has a dining area within the kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, and a garage. The laundry area is located in the hallway that leads to the garage. There is a large shed in the backyard of the facility that is used as the clinician's office for therapeutic services as well as the case manager's office. There is a window and air conditioning within the building. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed and no more than two clients share a bedroom. All client bedrooms have clothing thrown on the floor, dirty dishes and empty food containers. Bedroom #1 has plywood boarding on two of the walls on the left side of the room and a missing window screen. Bedroom #2 has a ceiling fan light bulb that needs to be replaced, the window curtain rod is not secured to the wall and the curtain rod covering the closet is coming away from the wall. Bedroom #3 smells like urine, the wall near the bedroom door is dirty with unknown substance smeared on the wall, the wall has been patched multiple times and needs to painted, the client beds do not have any linens, the curtain for the closet is missing and there is a missing window screen. There was only one set of extra bed linens observed at time of inspection in the hallway cabinet. There was only four client hygiene boxes for six clients at time of visit. LPAs and LPM observed flooring seam cover is broken in the middle in between the laundry room and family room. There is exposed wiring in the hallway where the smoke detector has been removed. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Books and video games were observed for client's recreation time. The screen for the sliding backyard door is broken and laying against the side of the home. Carbon monoxide detectors are properly working. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility had a low quantity supply of perishable and non-perishable foods at time of visit. Mr. Roberts stated that their shopping day is tomorrow Saturday October 8, 2022. The facility appears to be following the posted menu. The Visitation Policies, Personal Rights Form, Complaint Procedures and Activities Calendar were not posted at time of inspection. The menu was observed on a bulletin board in the kitchen which Mr. Roberts states it will be hung on the wall. The Foster Care Ombudsman poster was posted in the hallway. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closet in the staff office. Per, Mr. Roberts the facility does not have a locked container for refrigerated medications but there is a refrigerator in the locked garage. Mr. Roberts also states that they do not have individual containers for clients to store contraceptives. LPAs attempted to test the hot water temperature in the client bathroom and the kitchen and the temperature was 81 degrees and did not deliver hot water. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Chemicals and/or poisons are locked in a cabinet in the laundry room. Sharp objects are locked and stored in the staff office. First Aid Kits are stored in the staff office and facility vehicle. The first aid kit is missing the first aid manual, scissors and thermometer. The board of director meeting minutes were provided. Facility has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through September 28, 2025. The facility licensing fees are current. Copies of the 2022 licensing reports were not available at time of inspection. Based on observation and record review, the licensee is being cited under the following: Title Regulations Physical Plant 80075(g)(1), 80088(b), 80087(a), 80088(e)(1) Interim Licensing Standards(ILS), Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Articles 1 through 10, Physical Plant 87088(c)(2), 87088(c) and 87088(c)(2)(A). Technical violations are being cited for the following: Title Regulations Physical Plant 80075(j), ILS Physical Plant 87075(b)(1)(A), Operational Requirements 87072.2(a)(3) and Health & Safety Code 1538.5(a)(3). Due to time constraints the annual inspection will be continued on a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Mr. Roberts.

On May 19, 2023 at 08: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sarah Lo, arrived at Mayright Group Home Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Facility Manager, Philip Roberts. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There were three staffs and three clients present at the time of the inspection, however, one of the staff was on the way out to take the three clients to school. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 09: AM, Mr. Roberts led the physical inspection of the facility. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The master bedroom is used as the staff office along with the staff restroom. The facility has a dining area within the kitchen area, a living room, a staff office, and a garage. The laundry area is located in the hallway that leads to the garage. There is a large shed in the backyard of the facility that is no longer used as the clinician's office for therapeutic services as well as the case manager's office and it is currently used as a storage room. There is a window and air conditioning within the building. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed and no more than two clients share a bedroom. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 09: AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean, free of debris and hazards free. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Computer, books, TV and games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked closet in the living room area. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Chemicals/poisons are locked in a closet next to the laundry room. (continued on LIC-809C) All sharp objects are locked and stored in the locked closet in the living room area. First Aid Kits are stored in the staff office, in the living room and the locked closet where the medication are located. Contraceptives are available in the staff office and is available to be held individually by clients. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Three bedrooms contained two twin beds. The facility has one bathroom for the client to use. The hot water in the client's bathroom was deemed safe and measured between at 107.2 degrees Fahrenheit. Per Facility Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator, Jerome Jordan is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one facility manager, one assisting facility manager, six direct care staff, one case manager and one therapist. The board of director meeting minutes were provided. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF and the Accreditation is valid through September 28, 2025. The facility annual licensing fees are paid to current. Licensee has mental health approval and good until June 30, 2023. At 11: AM, five of five client files were reviewed during the time of inspection. Client files were kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office. At 11: AM, LPA observed C1 was missing the name, address and telephone number of physician/dentist in the medical file. Per CCR 80070(b) Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: (7) Name, address and telephone number of physician and dentist, and other medical and mental health providers, if any. At 11: AM, LPA observed C2 was missing authorization for medical treatment. Per ILS 87070(b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: (11) Consent forms, completed by the child's authorized representative(s), to permit the facility to authorize medical care. (continued on LIC 809-c) At 11: AM, LPA observed C2-C5 is missing County Social Worker signature on the Needs and Services Plan. Per ILS 87070(c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (1) A copy of the child's original needs and services plan; verification, signed by the child and their authorized representative(s), that they were offered the opportunity to participate in plan development; and verification that the authorized representative(s) have approved the plan. At 11: AM, LPA observed C3 and C5 was missing signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. Per ILS 87070(c) If it is determined that the facility can provide the services necessary to meet the child's needs, the following additional information shall be maintained in the child's record: (2) Signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the child's removal and/or transfer; discipline; and complaints. At 12: PM, LPA observed C1, C3, C4 and C5 were missing the initial medical examination. Per CCR 80069(a) Except for licensees of ARFs, prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client, as specified in Section 80069(c), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the client. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. At 12: PM, LPA observed C1-C5 were missing tuberculosis (TB) test result. Per CCR 80069(c) The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. LPA was unable to complete the staff/client interviews and staff files due to the staff files are located off-site and Facility Manager is unable to leave the facility to pick up the files. Due to time constraint the annual inspection will be continued on a later date. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and deficiencies, and the appeal rights were given to Facility Manager, Philip Roberts.

narrative: Regarding the allegation of staff is giving illegal substances to minors in care, a confidential witness reported that staff was providing illegal substances (speed and marijuana) to minors in care. Multiple confidential witnesses denied that staff would give minors in care illegal substances. Details from confidential interviews stated that they had not witnessed staff giving illegal substances to minors in care. Confidential interviews stated that staff would confiscate illegal substances from minors in care when found. Further details gathered stated that staff would check minors in care for illegal substances at the facility, specifically, when returning from being absent from care. Additional details from confidential interviews stated that minors in care were able to obtain illegal substances, however, it was not from facility staff. Regarding the allegation that minors are doing drugs at the facility, a confidential witness reported that minors are doing drugs at the facility. Confidential interviews denied that minors in care are doing drugs at the facility. Details gathered from confidential interviews stated that minors in care are aware of the facility being drug free and staff had procedures in place to ensure that minors in care were not doing drugs at the facility. Additional details from confidential interviews stated that they had witnessed minors in care doing drugs at the facility. If a minor in care was caught doing drugs at the facility, staff would follow reporting procedures and 14-day removal polices to address these behaviors. Other confidential interviews stated that if minors in care did do drugs, they would do them off of facility grounds. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the above allegations. Based on record review and confidential interviews, the allegations that staff is giving illegal substances to minors in care and minors are doing drugs at the facility, may or may not have occurred; However, it is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed and provided. A copy of the report was given to Philip Roberts, House Manager.

narrative: A confidential interview reported that staff did not take C1's clothes to the Laundromat and did not allow C1 to go to the laundry to wash their (C1's) clothing. Other confidential interviews provided conflicting information and reported that C1 often refused to go to the Laundromat and would not allow staff to take C1's clothes for washing. Confidential interviews denied that C1 or other clients were made to wear dirty clothes and reported that C1 did have clean clothes. However, C1 did not always do their (C1's) laundry and mixed up their (C1's) clean and soiled clothes. In addition, a confidential interview reported that C1's appearance was neat, and C1's clothing was clean and appropriate for the weather. Furthermore, a confidential interview and documentation reported the washing machine was replaced in September 2023, and LPA observed a working washing machine and dryer during the health and safety inspection. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and documentation, the allegation that staff are not ensuring that minor(s) (C1) have clean clothing while in care is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager, Philip Roberts.
investigation_findings: 13On March 6, 2024, at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Maywright Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP)) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. LPA obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed Clients (C1-C5), STRTP staff (S1-S5), and County Social Workers (CSW1 and CSW2). On 12/26/2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff is not ensuring that minor(s) (C1) have clean clothing while in care. It was alleged that the STRTP did not have a washing machine, and C1 could not wash their clothes. Multiple confidential interviews reported that the washing machine at the STRTP was non-operational for a few weeks. Prior to the washing machine breaking, confidential interviews reported clients washed clothes every week or as often as needed. Confidential interviews reported while waiting for the washing machine to be repaired, staff took the clients to the laundromat no less than once a week. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: The incident report also reported that C1 had no adverse side effects from the medication. Confidential interviews reported that the STRTP's medication protocol requires staff to give clients medication in the staff office. Before giving the medication, staff check the labels to ensure they have the right medication and verify the client's identity. Staff will then place the medicine in a cup to be given to the client and complete the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (MAR). Corroborating confidential interviews admitted the incident took place and reported that S2 did not follow the STRTP's medication procedure. A Confidential interview reported that S2 failed to follow the procedure because they (S2) felt "rushed" and gave C1 the medication in the bedroom without verifying the medication was being given to the correct client. During the health and safety inspection, LPA was provided with C1's MAR, and the medication error was documented. However, the staff signature and initials were missing. LPA also observed all medications were centrally stored inside a locked box in the living room closet. All medication was observed to be in their original bottle, with labels unaltered, and stored separately in zip lock bags. Additional documentation provided to LPA shows staff received retraining on medication management on 02/13/2024. Furthermore, a confidential interview reported that S2 has not administered medication since the incident, and the staff was instructed to give the client medications in the staff office, according to the STRTP's standard procedure. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documents, the allegation that staff (S2) mismanaged a child's (C1) medication is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The STRTP is cited with a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87075(a)(c) Health Related Services (a) In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80075, the following shall apply (c) Psychotropic medications shall be used only in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication... The STRTP was issued a LIC Technical Violation (TV) regarding Interim Licensing Standards 87070(b)(14)(h) Children's Records (b) The following information regarding the child shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record (14) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to a child documenting all of the following (h) Staff initials for each time a psychotropic medication is taken by a child... An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Facility Manager, Philip Roberts

narrative: It was alleged that an unknown facility staff had a sexual relationship with a facility client at the facility. Confidential statements obtained indicated contradictory information as statements provided by the former facility client initially insisted that the allegation occurred then subsequent statements provided by the facility client denied the allegation completely. Statements obtained from facility staff could not corroborate the allegation as they neither witnessed nor had any knowledge of any staff at the facility engaging in an inappropriate or sexual interaction with a facility client at any time. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On March 16, 2021, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection, via phone call, at Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) McKinley Children's Center and talked to Talesha Payne, Program Director. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). According to the SIR, on 3/19/20, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 3/16/21) was horse playing with his peers outside of Kiwanis Cottage and then C1 began insulting staff and striking the Cottage windows with his fists. After several redirects from Staff Ref#1 (S1) C1 began to walk away from the Cottage. C1 then quickly made a turn saying, "you thought" and returned towards the cottage kicking the door. C1 then walked away towards the recreation center and returned near his cottage and dismantled a yellow mop bucket top wringer and approached Kiwanis cottage. S1 counseled C1 to make positive choices. As C1 approached Kiwanis cottage, Staff #2 (S2) witnessed C1 attempting to throw the mop at Kiwanis' window. Thus, due to C1's escalating behavior, C1 was escorted (restrained) away from the area with S2 (Right) and S1 (Left) at 1:12pm-1:14pm (both ProAct trained) to Gregory cottage. LPA Flores obtained copies from C1's files: Child and Family Team Meeting (CFT) copy report, Needs and Services Plan, Placement Agreement, Restraint Debriefing Form and Discharge Summary. The documentation reviewed revealed that C1 was transitioned to a standing restraint from 1:14pm to 1:15pm with S1 and S2 remaining in their positions. C1 continued to threaten staff and attempted to free himself from the restraint. C1 was transitioned to a floor assisted restraint with staff remaining in their positions and Staff Ref#3 (S3) securing C1's legs (also ProAct trained) from 1:15PM - 1:24PM (9 minutes). S1 offered deep breathing coping skills for C1 to practice deescalating. cont.# C1 began to take deep breaths and informed staff he was ready to comply with instructions. C1 was then asked to have a seat on the couch to take space and wait for Nurse Genevieve Andrade, to follow up with him. STRTP Management team was updated. The agency nurse conducted the medical assessment of C1. On 3/26/20, a CFT meeting was conducted and C1 agreed to growth in the following areas: provoking, instigating, substance use, fights with peers and how to use coping skills when bored. On 9/10/20, C1 transitioned to the care of his biological mother. No further inspection is needed at this time. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

narrative: On April 21, 2021, at 3:20PM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection at McKinley Children's Center and talked with Talesha, (Title). The purpose of the inspection was to gather information for the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). On 07/10/2020, at approximately 12:00PM, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 04/21/2021) during a conversation with his Clinician disclosed that approximately 2 weeks ago Child Ref#2 (C2) allegedly exposed himself to C1. LPA Flores investigated the incident and interviewed Talesha Payne, Program Director/Administrator and Patricia White, Assistant Director. Documentation from the Children's files was requested and provided. The statements provided and documentation reviewed revealed that on 7/10/2020, C1 alleged that C2 coerced/threatened him into masturbating him under fear of physical harm. cont.# C1 further alleged that C2 began to approach him with his privates exposed, which resulted in C1 feeling uncomfortable and afraid. C1 stated that as C2 approached him, he pushed C2 and left the area. On 7/11/2020, at approximately 10:37AM, San Dimas Sheriff Deputy Zuniga arrived at the STRTP and it was determined that the Special Victims Unit would take over the case, as it was noted as an Indecent Exposure Case Ref #1 (EC1). No further inspection was needed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On April 28, 2021, at 12:30/PM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA),` conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, via phone call, to McKinley Children's Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and spoke with Talesha Payne and Patricia White, Assistant Director. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information regarding the below incident reported in a Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 07/09/2020, around 5:20PM, Lead Campus Supervisor Robert Vazquez requested that Staff Manuel Vigil conduct a community search of San Dimas High School, as there was a report of children on the roof of the Administration building burning an item. Upon Manuel arrival, the Fire and Sheriff Department were seen conducting a perimeter search to locate the fire and the individuals responsible for starting the fire. LPA Flores investigated this incident and interviewed Talesha Payne and Patricia White. LPA Flores requested documentation from the Children's files, the documentation was provided by the facility representative. cont.# The statement obtained and documentation provided revealed that on 07/09/2020, around 2:20PM, Children Ref #1 (C1), Ref #2 (C2) and Ref #3 (C3) walked away from staff and off facility grounds, despite numerous attempts to counsel them against these actions. Campus Supervisor Robert Vasquez was immediately contacted about this situation. The staff continued to follow and attempt to counsel the Children against these actions, but lost visual of them, as they ran through Lone Hill Middle School. A search of the immediate and surrounding area was conducted, but the staff was unable to locate the Children. The San Dimas Sheriff's Department was contacted to file a Missing Persons Report. C2 and C3 were seen running from the scene, C1 required medical attention. Staff Manuel Vasquez informed Law Enforcement that the Children are clients of the STRTP. C1 was transported to a medical facility to receive services due to being intoxicated and a 3-inch gash on his head that he sustained while on runaway status. Around 6:03PM, C2 and C3 returned to the STRTP on their own. A self-search was conducted, and no contraband was found. On 07/11/20, around 10:37AM, San Dimas Sheriff Deputy Zuniga arrived at the STRTP due to the filing of a Suspected Child Abuse Report (SCAR) for a separate incident. cont.# Campus Supervisor Gilbert E. immediately contacted the Director of STRTP, Talesha Payne about this incident. During Deputy Zuniga interview, she met with C1, C2 and C3 individually to determine the next steps. Upon completion of her interviews, she consulted with her sergeant and it was determined that the Special Victims Unit (SVU) would take over the case, as it was noted as an Indecent Exposure Case Ref #1 (EC1). During the SVU investigation, it was discovered that while on runaway status C2 dry-humped C1 while the boys were drunk on the roof of San Dimas High School. Talesha Payne disclosed the C1, C2 and C3 further disclosed that C1 and C2 had been consensually "touchy-feely" on multiple occasions while on runaway status. The Detective informed the Director of STRTP that due to the nature of the case, she was not able to share the details about the incident. No further citations were given to the Children, the Detective from SVU recommended a change in placement for C2 due to this being an ongoing investigation. The County Social Worker for the Children were notified about this incident. No further inspection is needed at this time. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the STRTP representative. Exit interview conducted.

On April 28, 2021, at 11:50AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, via phone call, to McKinley Children's Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and spoke with Talesha Payne and Patricia White, Assistant Director. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information regarding the below incident reported in a Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 08/24/2020, around 1:10AM, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names List LIC811 dated 04/28/2021) was placed on a Psychiatric Hold due to making statements that he was attempting to harm himself due to not wanting to be detained by the Probation Department. C1 further stated that he was going to run away to kill himself and there was nothing that any of the staff could do about it. LPA Flores investigated the incident and interviewed Patricia White. Documentation from C1's file was requested by LPA Flores and provided by the facility representative. cont.# The statement obtained and documentation reviewed revealed that on 08/23/2020, around 8:30AM, C1 exited his assigned cottage with a blanket, walked over to the volleyball court, and laid on the blanket. C1 was joined by Children Ref #2 (C2), Ref #3 (C3) and Ref #4 (C4). Staff Ref #1 (S1) sat outside on the grass to supervise the Children. Initially, C1 was noted to be awake, alert and oriented; but then C1 stated he was not feeling well and alleged consuming over one hundred "triple c's" (cough and cold tablets). C1's breathing was shallow with pupils dilated 7mm. C1 began pulling at his hair and ripping it out. When C1 was prompted to sit up to obtain his vital signs, he began to sweat profusely and became verbally non-responsive. Paramedics were called at 8:57AM, C1 was transported to the Emergency Room, where he received medical assistant. C1 was medically cleared at 5:30PM. After C1's arrival at the STRTP, C1 disclosed that he was attempting to harm himself due to not wanting to be detained by the Probation Department. C1 further stated that he was going to run away to kill himself and there was nothing that any of the staff could do about it. The Psychiatric Mobile Response Team (PMRT) was called for further evaluation, upon its arrival, it was determined that C1 needed to be place in a psychiatric hold for further evaluation. cont.# No further inspection is needed at this time. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the STRTP representative. Exit interview conducted.

On May 07, 2021, at 2:00PM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, via phone call, to McKinley Children's Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and spoke with Talesha Payne and Patricia White, Assistant Director. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information regarding the below incident reported in a Special Incident Report (SIR). The SIR reported that on 09/16/2020, at approximately 11:30PM, Children Ref #1 (C1) Ref #2 (C2) and Ref #3(C3) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 05/07/2021) walked out of their assigned cottages and ran off-grounds despite numerous redirects. Staff followed the Children and encouraged them to return to their assigned cottages, but they refused. The Children ran onto the campus of San Dimas High School, resulting in the staff losing visual of the them. Staff returned to campus and secured a van, they searched the immediate area and surrounding communities, but were unable to locate the Children. The San Dimas Sheriff's Department was contacted, and Missing Person's Reports were filed. According to the SIR, on Thursday, 09/17/2020 at approximately 7:30AM, the Children were located by the STRTP Residential Director, Talesha Payne, exiting a vehicle. cont.# The Children stated that they were sleeping in the vehicle as the owner of the vehicle drove away. Minutes after the Children were checked by the Staff and while talking with Clinicians, C2 stated that while on runaway status on Wednesday evening 9/16/20, he and C1, C3 and two other individuals had been driving around. While they were parked on the street somewhere, the Children were sleeping in the vehicle, C2 reported that he felt something move on the side of him and down the back of his pants, and saw that C1 had put his hand down his pants and was touching his backside. C2 stated that C1 tried a few times to stick his hand down his pants and C2 would try to move his hand away. C2 stated that he, C3 and C1 were all very intoxicated during this time. Clinical Director Hillary Hodgson called the Child Abuse. Patricia White was notified immediately by Clinical Director as she was on-site and STRTP management was notified. On 09/18/2020, at approximately 9:25AM, Deputy Gasso from San Dimas Sheriff's Department (SDSD) arrived on campus. Deputy Gasso spoke with C1, C2 and C3 about an incident that occurred while on runway on 09/16/2020. Deputy Gasso then stated that there was not enough evidence "to hold anyone". No further inspection is needed at this time. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the STRTP representative. Exit interview conducted.
