On June 21, 2022, at 9:20AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at McKinley Children's Center Short Therapeutic Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Patricia White. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 5/25/2022, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 06/21/2022) was restrained for 17 minutes. C1 needed medical assistant and was transported to a medical facility. LPA Flores investigated the incident and interviewed C1, School Support Services Dalton Drumm (DD), Lead Support Specialist Juan Morales (JM), Nurse Katherine Wolfe (KW) and Patricia White. A review of C1's file was conducted, and copies were made. The statements obtained, video surveillance and documentation reviewed revealed that on 05/25/2022, C1 was erratic and was mad because C1 could not to find a pair of shoes. After a while C1 walked inside the administration building at the Canyon View School and was told by DD that he could not be inside the building. cont.# C1 got close to DD and slapped DD's hands multiples times, while DD was evading C1, C1 lunged with a close fist towards C1 and began to chase DD through the hallway. LPA Flores observed in the video footage that C1 closed the glass door and did not allow DD to have access back into the building. DD continued telling C1 that he was not allowed to be inside the building, but C1 refused to leave the building. JM arrived to assist with the incident. While DD asked C1 to leave the building, C1 ran towards DD with two closed fists. C1 attempted to strike DD but he was unsuccessful due to DD evading. Due to C1's aggressive behavior, he was placed in standing restraint by DD and JM, and immediately transitioned into a 2-person floor restraint at 10:27AM, with DD on the right side and JM on the left side. Additional staff was requested to assist. Instructional Aide Miguel Mondragon (MM) arrived and assessed. C1 was placed in a 3-person floor restraint with MM securing the legs. Nurse KW was notified at approximately 10:29AM and arrived to assess C1 noting his speech to be incoherent, rapid, and pressured. During the interview, KW disclosed that she approved the continuation of the restraint after the initial 15 minutes. According to the SIR, C1's skin was cold and clammy to the touch and his pupils were observed as dilated. C1 began to bang the front of his head against the tile floor multiple times, stating "Call 911" and "Help Me" in-between times of incoherent speech. KW determined that C1 might be under the influence of a substance. cont.# Emergency Medical Services (EMS) were contacted at 10:33AM. C1 remained in a floor restraint until EMS arrived and took over care at 10:44 am. EMS transported C1 to a medical facility where C1 was assessed and vitals and blood work were taken. C1 notified the nurse of chest pain and had a hard time speaking to the doctor. When C1 was asked by medical personnel if he had thoughts of harming himself or others, C1 replied "no". At the hospital the nurse proceeded to take a urine sample, and traces of cannabis were found. C1 was cleared and discharged from the hospital. It was recommended for C1 to follow up with a psychiatrist. At 2:23PM, C1 returned to the STRTP, C1 got food and transitioned to his room. At the STRTP, C1 was close monitored by the STRTP staff. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On August 08, 2022, at 9:50AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at McKinley Children's center Short Therapeutic Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Patricia White. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 06/05/2022, at approximately 1:45PM, Staff Ref #1 (S1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 08/08/2022) heard, while driving and transporting children back from a planned outing to the STRTP, Child Ref #1 (C1) telling Child Ref #2 (C2) that Child Ref #3 (C3) and Child Ref #4 (C4) had sex. According to the SIR, no other information was disclosed during the time that the children were inside the vehicle. LPA Flores investigated the allegation and interviewed Patricia White, S1, C2, C3 and C4. LPA Flores was not able to interview C1 because he was reunited with biological family. A review of C3's and C4' file was conducted, and copies were made upon request. The information revealed that on 06/05/2022, C1, C2 and C3 were riding back to the STRTP from an authorized outing with staff. cont.# During the ride, C1 and C2 were arguing with C3. C1 disclosed to C2 that C3 and C4 had had sexual intercourse. The date and place of the alleged incident was not disclosed. S1 heard C1's statement and when they arrived at the STRTP the information was reported to the management team. C3 and C4 denied C1's statement. C3 disclosed that C1 is the type of child that would try to get other people in trouble for something that himself, C1, did. C4 stated that he cannot imagine why someone would say something of that nature when everyone know that is not true he had a sexual encounter with C3 or any other child. LPA Flores observed during the interview process that C3 and C4 were upset with C1's statement and been asked about it. No citation was issued. No further inspection is needed. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the STRTP representative. Exit interview conducted.

It was alleged that youth was raped by another youth in care and staff was abusive towards youths in care. There were no incident or complaint reports found regarding the identified youths and two identified staff (by first name only) named on the complaint. narrative: On September 07, 2022, at 9:45AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced Case Management Inspection, at McKinley Children's Center Short Therapeutic Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with Patricia White. The purpose of the inspection was to gather information about the below incident reported via Special Incident Report (SIR). The STRTP reported that on 08/21/2022, Child Ref #1 (C1) (see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 09/07/2022) went home in a home pass, and the facility nurse packed 2 pills of medication Ref#1 (M1) for the weekend. The STRTP nurse packed the wrong medication and C1 noticed it. Resource Father (RF) called the STRTP and informed about the incident. C1 did not take neither the wrong medication nor the one that he was prescribed and scheduled to take, Ref #2 (M2). LPA Flores investigated the incident and interviewed Patricia White and Head of Health Services Brittini Cochran. A review of C1's file was conducted, and copies were made available upon request. The STRTP representative disclosed that C1 is a child that followed the physician's instructions with taking medication, and he was able to notice that the packed medication was not M2. cont.# When C1 returned to the STRTP, he brought back the pills of M1. C1's physician and County Social Worker were informed about the incident. C1 did not experience adverse effects due to him not taking the medication. C1's physician indicated that C1 is to continue taking medication on 08/22/2022. Brittini Cochran disclosed that this issue was addressed with the nurse and that the nurse has been under additional supervision when packing medication. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC811 was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

Page The Department received a complaint alleging clients in placement engaged in sexual acts while at the facility. The investigation revealed two clients left a scheduled swimming activity and began wandering around the facility, unsupervised by staff. Later that day, clients were observed behind a cottage by staff and, when asked what they were doing, disclosed they attempted to engage in consensual sexual acts. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed the clients attempted sexual acts three times, throughout the facility. Per the facility incident report, the clients are observed on video without staff supervision for approximately twenty-two (22) minutes. There is a total of eight (8) non-consecutive minutes where video visual of youth is lost. The incident report states the clients are first observed at 2: PM walking towards the dining hall. However, information gathered from confidential interviews conducted revealed the initial incident occurred in the restroom near the swimming pool while the swimming activity was taking place, indicating the clients were unsupervised prior to what is observed via video footage. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed youth are knowledgeable of camera locations on campus and, capable of evading them if necessary. Records obtained during the investigation revealed two staff were issued written warnings due to the incident. The written warnings state the staff failed to follow facility supervision protocol resulting in minors engaging in inappropriate acts. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and record review the allegation is substantiated, the standard of the preponderance of evidence has been met. The facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Article 06 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties. Record review and information obtained from interviews conducted confirm two clients engaged in sexual acts due to lack of staff supervision. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report, LIC9099D, Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 11/30/22 and appeal rights were given to the above mentioned facility representative. Per the new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(E), an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending due to the substantiated allegation. If an ECP is warranted, a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment.

narrative: On 05/26/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a case management with Assistant Program Director Dawn Lee to discuss an incident that occurred on May 10, 2021 between staff (#1) and client (#2) resulting in a restraint. Due to restrictions of Covid-19, this case management was conducted by teleinspection with this report being scanned to Ms. Lee with a request for signature and a scan back to this LPA. The agency conducted an investigation and interviewed staff, client and witnesses. At the conclusion of the investigation, it was determined that staff (#1) would be moved to a different facility within the agency and have additional CPI training. On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco traveled to the Creative Alternatives Main Office in Merced and conducted an unannounced Case Management for the Merced Ranch and met with Director Brandi Boheme. narrative: An unannounced annual inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lidia Tinoco traveled to the Merced Ranch STRTP in Merced, CA. LPA met with Administrator, Jeanne Johnson and inspected the facility, inside and out. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 75 degrees. narrative: On 2/11/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd, visited Michigan House to discuss an incident report that was sent in in August of 2021. LPM Angela King requested that LPA look into the incident and the facts of the incident. LPA spoke with Nadia Smith, House Manager, regarding the incident. Nadia Smith told LPA that on that day, the client came into the facility with his own electronics and was told they do not allow them here at this facility. The staff said that client made a comment that the Administrator had given permission to have the electronics, but they had not been made aware of this. Staff said that once the client calmed down and they were able to talk to staff Garnett, he admitted that he had told this client it was going to be allowed and that is was his fault that he did not make staff aware of this. The client was able to keep his electronics and they worked out a plan to ensure that this doesn't happen again.

narrative: On 06/01/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daiquiri Boyd and Wayne Aoki and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Juanita Arroyo conducted an informal conference for the above facility with Administrator Staff of Michigan House and Michigan House 2. The purpose of the conference was to discuss the facility history and current operating procedures. Paperwork was presented to update all facilities with regard to Administrators. Procedures for handling incidents were discussed. Garnett stated that changes have been made through additional staffing and updated training for staff. The facility has reinstated better system for recording incidents and logging of those incidents and the process for reporting to Department of Behavioral Health. LPM discussed ensuring that CFT's are held and documented as well as the Mental Health Team meetings. Also discussed, was the need for better documentation for incident reporting as pre and post events, such as unauthorized absences. Discussed updated Mental Health and Accreditation dates. New contact information for all Administrators and staff will be sent to Licensing.

narrative: On January 11, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) was met by facility manager Nadia Smith for the purpose of conducting a Case Management regarding an incident that occurred on June 26, 2022 regarding M1. M1 is no longer at the facility (6/6/22-11/30/22). During the incident it was reported that M1 broke the lock that was on his bicycle and left the facility without permission. LPA asked Ms. Smith why the minor's bicycle was locked. Ms. Smith explained that the minor requested the lock for his bicycle because the other residents in the home would use it and leave without permission on his bicycle. The facility staff purchased a lock for the minor. On June 26, 2022, the minor was upset and wanted to leave the facility without permission. The minor broke the lock off and did leave the facility. LPA asked Ms. Smith why would the minor have to break the lock off if he has the keys. Ms. Smith explained that the minors in the home do not keep their own keys. When they want their keys they request it from staff and staff will get it for them. LPA asked Ms. Smith if the bicycle was locked to prevent minor from leaving the facility without permission. Ms. Smith stated that the minor locks his own bicycle so others don't take it. They did not lock it up to prevent him from leaving the facility. On the day of the incident, minor was upset and didn't wait for the key and broke the lock off and then left. Ms. Smith explained to the LPA that staff is aware that they are not to lock up minor's personal belongings without their permission unless it is something they are not allowed to have in the home (contraband). There were no deficiencies cited during this Case Management for the incident of June 26, 2022

On August 3, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) was met at the facility by Staff Charles Smith. Mr. Smith contacted Facility Manager, Nadia Smith which arrived at the facility shortly thereafter. The purpose for the inspection is to conduct a Case Management with regards to incident reports dated May 13, 2023 and May 14, 2023. Incident report dated May 13, 2023 stated that minor refused to take medication and lost points due to this. This incident report was also not signed by facility personnel. This incident report in question was vague with details and specifically stated that the minor lost points for not taking medication. Mr. Smith stated that he is the staff that is responsible for completing and submitting incident reports for the facility. Mr. Smith explained that he did not complete the incident reports in question as he was off on vacation during that time. Mr. Smith stated that the facility does not take away points for not taking medication and is not sure why that was put in the report. Ms. Smith stated that while Mr. Smith was out on vacation another staff completed the report. Ms. Smith agreed that this incident report was not properly completed with information and that clarification should had been stated that the loss of points was due to the disrespect (Inappropriate language) to staff and not because of not taking medication. Incident report dated May 14, 2023 was vague and lacked information for a complete incident report. AWOL protocols were followed but that was not conveyed in the report due to the incompleteness of the report. Ms. Smith also acknowledged that the reports were not signed and not reviewed before being submitted to Community Care Licensing. Ms. Smith stated that all staff will undergo re-training on incident report writing. An Advisory Note -Technical Violation was issued on this date, no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

Licensing Program(LPA) Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection March 19, 2024 at 11:04AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 0 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, March 19, 2024.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma- informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Nadia Smith.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced post-licensing inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. LPA utilized the CARE Tool for this inspection. LPA completed the remaining domains in the CARE tool: Staffing and Client Records, and reviewed four client files and three staff files. LPA found that all client and staff files were in compliance, except for the following deficiency areas: Technical Violations (No Citation): 1. S1's Health Screening was not filled out by the physician. 2. C1 has not had a TB test in the five months that C1 has been placed, however, an appointment to do so is already scheduled. 3. C2 and C3 had no mention of money-handling capability in their Needs and Services Plans. 4. Client room sharing compatibility assessments were not completed. 5. C1's visitation information has not been completed. 6. There is no expiration date for medication on the Medication Administration Records, however, it is on the actual medication bottles. Citation - Type B: 1. S2 had 25 hours of verifiable annual training, which is under the required amount of 40 hours annually. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report will be emailed to him with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt for the documents.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced post-licensing inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. LPA utilized the CARE Tool for this inspection. LPA and Administrator conducted a walk-through of the facility. LPA observed three client bedrooms, one staff office, three full bathrooms, a kitchen, garage, backyard, living room, laundry room, and dining room. LPA observed the facility to be safe, clean, and sanitary. All bedrooms, bathrooms, and kitchen were equipped with all necessary items, which were in good repair. Water temperature in the clients' bathroom measured at 108.8 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the required range. LPA observed no deficiencies during the walk-through. LPA reviewed the facility's operations. LPA found during the post-licensing inspection at the Licensee's other facility, that the length of time for each hold was not clear in the descriptions as well as there was not a clear licensee post-restraint evaluation. A Technical Violation advisory note was issued for this. LPA completed the Physical Plant, Operations, Core Services and Supports, and Disaster Preparedness domains from the CARE Tool, and no other deficiencies were found. LPA was unable to complete this inspection on this date and will return on another date to do so to complete the staff and client file reviews. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report will be emailed to him with a read receipt, which will serve as his confirmation for receiving the document.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with staff Beverly Knox (S1) who assisted with the inspection. The Department's Investigations Branch Investigator, Blake Williams (IB), investigated this complaint by conducting confidential interviews with the Administrator, County Social Worker, three staff, and five children on 8/30/2021, 9/23/2021, 9/24/2021, 9/28/2021, and 10/6/2021. IB found that a child involved has a history of making up accusations when he does not get his way, and the child was unable or unwilling to give any details about the allegation. The accused staff denied the allegation, and other children interviewed also denied the allegation occurred. Based on all interviews IB found that there was not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is found to be Unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt. narrative: During the investigation, LPA Baca investigated the complaint Minor was sexually abused by another minor while in care. Interviews with Admin, Staff 1, Staff 3, Director, FY1 and Administrator stated that when staff were called downstairs for a crisis with another youth in the house, in where Staff1 no longer had an eyesight on the upstairs hallway, FY3 took advantage of the situation and went into FY1 and FY2 bedroom, sat on the bed and rubbed FY1 leg and himself while getting an erection and the tip of his penis was briefly seen by FY1, FY1 asked FY3 to leave and FY3 left. After several days FY1 and FY2 told staff about the incident while at an outing, and FY3 was moved to the other facility the same day in Fairfield until his probation officer picked him up. Interview with FY3 stated that nothing happened in the room and refused to talk to LPA about anything Interview with probation officer stated that she believed the incident happened, however does not believe it was to harm FY1. This allegation has been found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED meaning that allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with staff Candace Hill who assisted with the inspection. Later, LPA also met with Administrator Steve Dogan. LPA and Staff conducted a walk-through of the home and LPA observed three client bedrooms, two pantries, one hall closet, one kitchen, two living rooms, a staff office/therapy office space, the backyard, a laundry room, and the garage. LPA observed no deficiencies. LPA observed there were no more towels in the clients' bathroom, however there were more in the house, and they were placed in the bathroom. LPA observed an adequate amount of food and supplies for the clients. There were two clients present at the time, home for Spring Break, and one staff present. LPA interviewed two clients and one staff. LPA observed some Department reports from 2016 to 2020, however newer reports were not maintained at the facility. LPA also observed the register of clients, a required. LPA moved to the Administrative Office located at Georgia St., Vallejo, CA 94590 to conduct the file reviews. LPA reviewed the facility's emergency drill records and found that they have conducted the required emergency drills. The facility is up-to-date on their Licensing bills/fees. LPA reviewed the Board of Director's meeting minutes for the past year and found them to have met as required for December 2022 (Q4). Administrator attempted to get the records for 2022Q2, 2022Q3, and 2023Q1, however, was not able to on this date. LPA reviewed the ProACT trainer certification, training materials, and training records for staff and found it to meet the requirements, however, no competency tests are being conducted. Additionally, no staff are being trained annually on the Emergency Disaster Plan as required. LPA reviewed fingerprint clearances for the staff at the facility and found: All staff are associated as required, however one staff (S1) had errors in their name and date of birth, which will need to be corrected. LPA is unable to complete this inspection on this date. LPA will return at a later date to complete the file reviews. On this date, the facility is being cited for violations of the Health and Safety Code Section 1565(b), and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87095.65(b)(6). Five advisory notes, which are not citations, are being issued as well. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report, confidential names list, and appeal rights were left with him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual continuation inspection at the Administrative Office located at Georgia St., Vallejo, CA 94590 and met with Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. LPA received 2022Q2 and 2022Q Board Meeting Minutes. In the meeting minutes for both meetings, discussed was a new facility for this Licensee called the Haflinger house. LPA ensured that Administrator understood that no clients may reside at this residence until their program statement and application have been reviewed and approved. There has been no application submitted as of this time. Administrator understood and agreed that no children will reside at that house until their program has submitted the application, it has been approved, and a license has been issued. LPA reviewed four client files and five staff files, including one Administrator's, one Social Worker's, and one Facility Manager's files. LPA found that only one staff and the Administrator are acting as Facility Managers at this time, leaving the facility at times without a Facility Manager. Both the staff and Administrator have taken the Administrator's Certification course, and the staff also took an eight hour Facility Manager training course. The records were in compliance for the majority, however a few things were missing: one client out of four did not have record of a TB test being evaluated for or being given in their last medical exam. All clients that share rooms have a compatibility assessment as required however, they are based only on one child and their wants; they do not discuss/evaluate compatibility between two specific clients as required. LPA and Administrator went to the facility to review medications and medication records. All medications and medication records were in compliance. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards Section 87065(f). Two Technical Violation Advisory Notes, which are not citations, were issued as well. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was left with him.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jean Stidman and Connie Goldie on 5/10/23 at 4:15pm.. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA Stidman and Goldie met with Steve Dogan, Administrator, and inspected the facility LPAs observed the facility had three staff present with two clients present. During the inspection one staff and one client left for an outing. LPA reviewed zero child's records and three staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed zero child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed three staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed zero children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Steve Dogan Administrator. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted exit interview with Steve Dogan Administrator.

It was confirmed during a conversation with the Administrator on 4/18/2023, that the electricity to the house was turned off by staff around 10: PM, one night. The reason giving was "the kids should have been in bed at that time and weren't'. C1 also disclosed during a confidential interview that the electricity to the whole house had been turned off. A client interviewed during an Annual Inspection, disclosed the same when asked about the electricity being turned off. There was also a video sent by C1's Case Manger confirming the electricity was turned off as well. It was also confirmed by clients and staff that the electricity to the outlet plugs in the kitchen are turned off. This is to prevent clients from charging their cell phones. Clients sign a contract that they will not have a personal cell phone until they reach a certain level. This is not in the Program Statement or addressed in their Needs and Service Plans. However, C1's cell phone was not taken by staff and remained in C1's possession. There is a phone in the house, that all clients can use to call social worker, lawyers and for their own personal use. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 80072(a)(2), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D." An exit interview was conducted on 5/10/2023, the report/appeal process were reviewed with the Manager. A copy of this report/appeal rights were emailed to the Administrator, Steve Dogan due to technical difficulties.

narrative: Allegation: Staff locked minors out of facility for an extended period of time. It was determined during the investigation that C1 was not locked out of the house for an extended period. The incident was discussed in C1's latest, CFT Meeting. The County Supervising Social Worker stated the incident was embellished and C1 was not locked outside. This discussion occurred in the presence of C1. The Supervising Social Worker was present during the meeting and stated that she talked to C1 outside the home and stated C1 could of went back in the home as well. C1 felt he was locked out due to staff wanted C1 to turn in C1's cell phone. However, C1 did keep his phone and came inside the home after returning from an AWOL. Based on LPA's observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Allegation: Staff did not provide food and water to minor. It was determined during confidential interviews with Direct Care Staff and Behavioral Specialist staff that C1 was offered food/water when C1 was outside the home. The County Supervising Social Worker was on the phone when C1 was ordering food from Panera Bread. C1 choose to leave the home and get food from Panera Bread. All clients interviewed stated there was food in the home and available when they wanted to eat. Based on LPA's observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Allegation: Staff did not allow minor to use bathroom. It was determined during interviews with clients and staff that C1 could have entered the home to use the bathroom. Staff and clients stated during interviews they could use the restroom whenever they wanted. During C1's interview he never stated C1 could not use the bathroom while outside. Based on LPA's observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. No title 22 regulations were cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted on 5/10/2023, the report/appeal process were reviewed with the Manager. A copy of this report/appeal rights were emailed to the Administrator, Steve Dogan due to technical difficulties.

narrative: Both the client and staff denied that there was any romantic relationship between them. On 2/6/2023, C1 left the facility without permission and ED followed the client to an apartment. ED knocked on the door and S1 answered the door. ED told S1 to have C1 come out, however S1 lied and denied that C1 was there. In S1's interview she informed IB this was because she wanted to help C1. ED stated he would call Law Enforcement if C1 did not come out and C1 did come out. S1 was immediately terminated. Interviews with one client revealed that S1 and C1 would often be together in areas of the facility which cameras do not reach, and which are restricted to staff-only, such as the medication room and the laundry room. One staff interviewed stated that S1 did spend time in the laundry room to take breaks. Also revealed in the client's interview was that C1 would make inappropriate gestures about S1, such as a, "butt-smacking," gesture, and described S1 and C1's relationship as, "weird." There were no disclosures from anyone interviewed that there was a sexual or romantic relationship between S1 and C1. Based on IBs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Health and Safety Code Section 1558(a)(2) is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with him.

narrative: On 4/5/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess conducted an unannounced case management inspection at the facility regarding an incident that occurred on or around 1/25/2024, involving a former client and staff, at a Resource Family Home. LPA met with Executive Director Tegre Miles (ED) who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA collected client and staff information from ED, Administrator Steve Dogan, and Program Director Reyes Bonilla. ED and Director will be sending LPA additional information she requested, once obtained. LPA interviewed ED. Further information is needed in order to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Behavioral Tech Manager Robert Smith and Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this CM is to close the Case Management opened on 4/5/2024. The incident that occurred on 1/25/2024 involved staff from Mile High conducting a restraint on a child in placement at a Resource Family Home (RFH). It was alleged the restraint was conducted inappropriately, and that matter has since been referred to Solano County for investigation, as the RFH is licensed by them. LPA investigated the incident to determine how Mile High/MSK Solutions is involved in the RFH, and where the two blend together. LPA conducted this case management investigation by conducting confidential interviews with one child, one staff, the Program Director, The Executive Director, the Facility Manager, an individual associated with Mile High (P1) on 4/5/2024, 4/10/2024, 4/15/2024, 4/19/2024, 5/7/2024, and 5/23/2024, and by reviewing Incident Reports relating to the incident from both Mile High and another agency who witnessed the incident. Through investigation, LPA was informed by P1 that they are not a staff at the Mile High Mountain Top house or Legend house, but is the Executive Director's personal assistant. However, before LPA was informed of this, LPA requested P1's schedule for when they are working at the Mile High houses from the FM, who informed LPA that P1 is only scheduled at, "the Ranch," and that, "that's what [their] timesheets say." LPA requested these timesheets, however when the Director responded, LPA was informed by the Director that P1 is paid privately by him, and not through Mile High; LPA did not receive any timesheets. P1 is associated to both Mile High houses, beginning in 2021. Both the FM and P1 explained to LPA how the incident and restraint occurred. This explanation was in contrast to what was reported by witnesses. LPA was informed that the Facility Manager was called to assist P1 at the Resource Home in containing the youth in care due to the rapport FM already has with the youth, and FM responded, assisting with the restraint and de-escalation. LPA was informed by one staff, that staff from Mile High go to that Resource Home, "every week or every day," "multiple staff, a few staff from Legend house...morning shift and evening shift people." However the staff did not remember any staff names. When asked if staff leave their shift at Mile High to assist at the RFH, the staff confirmed they do and depending on C1's behaviors, they would be gone for about a couple of hours. The staff referred to the RFH as, "the Ranch." LPA learned from ED that MSK Solutions, the Licensee of Mile High homes, has another property called, "the Ranch." MSK Solutions had previously submitted intention to license that location as a facility with CCL on 10/11/2023, however then rescinded that request on 10/24/2023. LPA has visited the location and found that it is marked by a driveway arch that states, "Mile High Sky Ranch." LPA was informed that the Director lives there and it is licensed through Solano County as a Resource Family Home, where a previous client of Mile High is placed. ED informed LPA that the Director rents the home from ED, however it is not related to Mile High/MSK. LPA also learned that the clients at the Mile High houses sometimes visit the RFH to tend to the animals there. FM provided LPA with his timesheet from January 2024, obtained from a time tracking app the facility uses called a uAttend, as well as the LIC500s (Personnel Reports). FM also showed LPA the Line App which the staff and management use to communicate, and the Paychex app, which keeps staff paychecks. An office meeting will be scheduled with MSK Solutions at a future date to obtain more information regarding facility staff involvement at the RFH. An exit interview was conducted with Facility Manager Steven Anderson and a copy of this report was provided to FM.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Brittany Crass made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager, Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. LPAs and FM conducted a walk through of the home and observed no deficiencies. CCL received an incident report dated 7/1/2024 stating that clients were going to therapy at, "the Ranch." LPAs are conducting this case management to gather more information about, "the Ranch," and the therapy held there. LPA interviewed three children, one staff, and the facility manager. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Regional (RM) Manager Margo Castaneda made an announced case management inspection at a separate location and met with Tegre Miles, Executive Director (ED), and Reyes Bonilla Program Director (PR) who assisted with the inspection. LPA and RM are conducting this case management to gather more information in regard to MSK Solutions' fiscal accountability. On November 14, 2024, the Community Care Licensing Division received a letter via Child and Family Services Division in regard to Solano County Behavioral Health Services Division terminating their contract with MSK Solutions, Inc.. The Sacramento Regional Office requested the last 12 months of bank statements, November 1, 2023, through November 1, 2024, for all their accounts pertaining to Mile High Legend Home Facility #487005982, Mile High Mountain Top Facility # 487005059, and any other accounts associated with MSK Solutions, Inc. This will be provided to CCL by 12/10/2024. LPA and RM interviewed ED and PD. An exit interview was conducted with ED and PD and a copy of this report was provided to them.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Staff Tom Arriola and Jose Reyes. Facility Manager Steven Anderson arrived to further assist LPA. CCL received an incident report dated 11/25/2024, sent to CCL on 11/26/2024. LPA is conducting this case management to attain more information. LPA interviewed one client, staff, and Facility Manager. There were no other clients present. Further information is needed to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Interviews with all staff members, FM, S1, S5, and S6, stated that the only time a staff member stays the night at the facility, is if they are working an overnight shift. Additionally, when asking the youth (C1, C2, C3, and C4) if they had ever seen a staff member do drugs at the facility, they all stated, no, never. This Department has investigated the complaint alleging that staff engaged in drug activity in the home posing a risk to minors in care. We have found that the complaint is Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with the Jose Reyes. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were given.

It was alleged that a staff member had been using the facility as their personal living space and doing drugs at the facility. On May 20, 2025, at approximately 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. LPA Areizaga met with Administrator, Steven Dogan who granted LPA access to the facility. On May 19, 2025, LPA Areizaga received an incident report stating the glass on the sliding glass door in the living room near the kitchen was shattered on Sunday, May 18, 2025. During today's inspection, LPA observed that the slider door was boarded on the interior and exterior of the door. LPA also confirmed that a work order was submitted by the licensee for repair. It was noted that the outside contractor will be on site on Wednesday, May 21, 2025, around 1: PM to 3: PM to provide an estimate. Once the estimate is received, the licensee will pay for the repair, submit a copy of the receipt via text or email to LPA Areizaga, and notify LPA once the repairs have been completed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator, Steven Dogan.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with staff Kareem Dupree, who assisted with the inspection. On 2/3/ The Licensee, MSK Solutions, was informed by the Department's Audit Section that they will be receiving a solvency audit for both of their licensed STRTPs: Mile High Legend Home #487005982 and Mile High Mountain Top #487005059. The Department informed the Licensee of the reason for the audit, and all required information needed to perform the audit. The due date for submission of the required information was 3/3/2025. On 3/7/2025, the Department followed up with the Executive Director (ED) Tegre Miles regarding not having received the required documents to conduct the audit, nor a request for an extension of time. On 3/12/ ED responded with their concerns, and that they intended to finish everything by the coming Friday (3/14/2025). The Department responded to ED addressing their concerns and granting an extension until 3/14/2025. Failure to submit the required documents would result in the completion of the audit, documenting noncompliance with the Department's Inspection Authority. On 3/17/2025, ED responded to the Department with their concerns, however no documentation was provided. For the related citations and repeat civil penalty, please refer to the 809 dated 5/8/2025 under the Mountain Top facility #487005059. An exit interview was conducted with staff and a copy of this report was provided to him.

met_with: Jose Reyes, Steven Anderson, Corri Collins
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met staff Jose Reyes and Administrator Steven Anderson who assisted with the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility with staff and Administrator. LPAs observed: three client bedrooms, two pantries, one hall closet, one kitchen, two living rooms, a staff office/therapy office space, the backyard, a laundry room, and the garage. The client bathroom did not have paper towels/towels. There was no sign posted denoting the hot water for the coffee maker. The floors and surfaces throughout the facility were sticky. The area above the stove on the cabinets and ceiling had crease/grime. The facility had a limited variety of non-perishable food for 7 days for 5 clients. LPA advised to obtain more variant non-perishable foods. There was a low amount of fresh vegetables. Two of the client dressers were in disrepair. The medication was inaccessible as required. The hot water measured at 112.4 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the required temperature range of 105-120. There was a working carbon monoxide detector. LPA's inspected the facility van and saw that it was in working condition with fair tires, no problem indicator lights, and working seat belts. The first aid kit was present and had all required elements. LPA Areizaga took photos of facility on state-issued cellphone. LPA interviewed two clients. The facility has a client register as required, however it needed to be updated as they recently got a new client in the house. Client cash resources/records were inaccessible as required. There was no planned activity schedule. The items planned on the menu were not present in the facility in these cases: Today lunch planned was salad with grilled chicken. However, there was only one small romaine heart and the chicken was still frozen, for tomorrow: no bagels were present in the house, and no ramen, which was planned for tomorrow's lunch. For Thursday there was no pancake mix, which was scheduled. One staff mentioned having PB&J sandwiches planned, however there was no bread. FM stated that he would be going shopping right now and the usual staff who buys the food was off. Client cash resources are maintained in a binder, kept locked in a closet. One client's allowance was incorrectly documented as having had no previous balance, then was issued $20 on 4/4/2025, marked as withdrawn $20, and then marked as having a $20 balance. However, there was no $20 in the binder. Admin stated the record was incorrect and should be a $0 balance. Administrator will have the record corrected and the client re-sign for the correct amount when they return from school on today's date. The Board meets quarterly as required. LPAs could not complete the inspection on this date, and will return on another date to complete the annual inspection. On this date, the facility is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Section 80087(a). Technical Violation Advisory Notes, which are not citations, were also issued. Additionally, LPA provided Administrator with the letters of revisions needed for Mile High's Program Statement and Plan of Operation update. The due date for revisions is 5/21/2025, and LPA scheduled a date to meet with the agency with Administrator Steven Anderson to go over any questions they have, for 4/21/2025 at 10: AM. A Microsoft Teams meeting was sent to Administrator for that date and time. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to him.

met_with: Jose Reyes, Steven Anderson, Corri Collins
narrative: At 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced annual continuation inspection at the facility's Administrative Office where their files are stored. No one answered the door and LPA called Administrator Steven Anderson, who stated he will be on his way. Later, LPAs checked the door again and Office Assistant Corri Collins answered, stating LPAs could not access the office, as there would be a meeting happening soon. LPA informed OA that they need to complete the annual and as the files are located at the office, they are there. OA informed LPA that a supervisor is not available, and LPAs may not use any place in the office. LPM Jodean Hall called Administrator to help facilitate the annual inspection. Administrator arrived and LPA provided him a list of all information needed to complete the annual. LPAs took a break to allow Administrator time to gather the documents and arrived at the Legend Home facility at 12: PM to continue the annual as agreed. At 12: PM Administrator arrived with the documents. LPA was provided the licensing documents retained for the past three years. The most recent report presented was dated 5/10/2023. The facility did not maintain Licensing Reports for the past three years as required. There was no manual restraint log. The facility is conducting disaster drills on a monthly basis, however does not conduct them at least once per shift, per six months. The Administrator brought staff files for staff from the Mountain Top house and needed to return to the Admin office to get Legend Home staff files. LPAs reviewed one Administrator file and one Clinician file. Once Administrator returned with the correct files, LPAs reviewed one Facility Manager file, and two staff files, finding: All staff are fingerprint cleared and associated as required. The Administrator and Clinician meet all requirements. The Clinician's (MH1) CPR/First expired 11/30/2024. On 4/7/2025 and today 4/8/2025 when LPAs arrived at the facility, S1 was the only staff present, who does not meet the education and experience requirements of a Facility Manager. There were no qualified Facility Managers present until Administrator arrived to assist. LPAs advised Administrator about the exception request process. All staff reviewed met the annual training requirements. LPAs reviewed four client files and found: The Needs and Services Plans (NSPs) did not include any information about clients having the need to be routinely searched. Through interviews and based on LPA observation, clients get searched with a metal detecting wand, and have their possessions searched, when they enter the facility as a standard practice. This is a violation of the clients' right to be free from unreasonable searches. The two clients observed to be searched (C1 and C2) on 4/7/2025, and C2 on 4/8/2025 had no indication in their NSP for the authorization of routine searches. Administrator stated C1 and C2 had no need to be wanded/searched. Administrator informed staff during this inspection. There was not a staff person designated to facilitate/plan the planned activities and there was no planned activities calendar. LPA was not provided a current record of mental health services provided to the clients for the past 12 months despite requesting one. A record of mental health services was provided to LPA on 3/7/2025 for an unrelated reason, and today, LPA was informed that is the record she should use, as directed by Interim Executive Director Jamek Johnson. The record shows that all clients have not received "psycho therapy" since the end of January 2025. LPA interviewed one staff and one Administrator on this date. LPA found they were knowledgeable about their roles and the clients. LPA advises for some refreshers on the mandated reporter process. One client's JV223 dated 6/24/2024 is expired. There is an email dated 5/8/2024 requesting review for renewal, however no other follow-up included in the file. Administrator is unsure if the client no longer takes psychotropic medications because they were refusing them, or because the JV223 expired. LPA issued an advisory note to inform LPA of the reason. On this date the facility is being cited for sections of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 5, Sections 87072(c)(10), 87065(f), and 87089.1(g) on the attached LIC809-Ds. LPA also issued Technical Violation advisory notes, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report, confidential names list, and appeal rights were provided to him.

deficiencies.title: (f) The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present

Mental Health

(g) A short-term residential therapeutic program providing care and supervision to children diagnosed by a physician, psychologist, or licensed clinical social worker as mentally disordered shall make provision for at least monthly consultation from a psychiatrist, or clinical psychologist, or licensed clinical social worker regarding the program of services, or more often as appropriate to the needs of the child or nonminor dependent.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by

narrative: On June 19, 2025, at approximately 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced visit to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting a case management. LPA Areizaga met with Administrator, Steven Dogan who granted LPA access to the facility. On June11, LPA Areizaga received an Incident Report (IR). The date the IR occurred was June 2, 2025. Based on file reviews, LPA Areizaga confirmed that the STRTP did not meet the reporting requirements, as no 24 hour notification nor a 7-day follow up report was submitted to the department at the time the STRTP was aware of the incident. The STRTP is being cited per 80061(b) Reporting Requirements for failure to report an incident on the LIC 809-D. This is a potential Health, Safety, and Personal Rights risk to children in care. This report was discussed with Administrator, Steven Dogan and a copy of this a copy of the report and appeal rights were printed and left at the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced post licensing inspection at the facility and met with Reyes Bonilla, Program Director (PD), and Steve Dogan, Administrator, who assisted with the inspection. LPA utilized the CARE Tool for this inspection. LPA completed the rest of the domains in the CARE Tool, and found: two out of five clients reviewed had not had a recent TB test completed and five out of ten staff reviewed did not meet the 40 hour annual training requirement. LPA issued two type B citations for these deficiencies. LPA also found that the majority of all clients' Needs and Services Plans reviewed had either no signatures, or one or two signatures; there was a lack of visitation information in the files; there was not a complete manual restraint log, however there were incident reports with attached descriptions; the length of time for each hold was not clear in the descriptions; two staff did not have complete proof of education or verified experience in their files; the facility was utilizing "fines" to be repaid back from a portion of the client's allowance to a fund for activities; and room sharing compatibility assessments were not completed. LPA issues Technical Violation advisory notes for these issues. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and PD and a copy of this report will be emailed to them with a read receipt, which will serve as their confirmation for receiving the documents.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced post licensing inspection at the facility and met with Reyes Bonilla, Program Director (PD), and Tegre Miles, Executive Director (ED), who assisted with the inspection. LPA utilized the CARE Tool for this inspection. LPA and PD conducted a walk-through of the facility. LPA observed one deficiency: In the clients' bathroom, the water tap delivered water at 125.6 degrees, which is 5.6 degrees too high. LPA issued a Technical Violation advisory note for this. The water heater was turned down during this inspection. LPA completed the Physical Plant and Operations domains from the CARE Tool, and no other deficiencies were found. LPA was unable to complete this inspection on this date and will return on another date to do so. An exit interview was conducted with ED and PD and a copy of this report will be emailed to them with a read receipt, which will serve as their confirmation for receiving the document.

An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill on 9/9/21 at 11: AM. During the inspection, LPA Hill met with Steven Dogan, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. During the facility tour of the facility, LPA Hill observed the medication storage location is currently in a restroom on the first floor as the normal medication storage location is on the second floor but there is currently a youth in isolation in that room. LPA observed that the medications are currently in a locked location in the facility. LPA reviewed two youth files on site at the facility during the inspection at 3: PM. LPA was unable to interview one youth during the site inspection as the youth is currently in school. LPA set up for one youth to be interviewed at a later date. LPA did interview one youth during the inspection at 3: PM. LPA reviewed two staff personnel files on site at the facility at 2: PM. LPA interviewed two staff on site at the facility during the inspection at 12: PM. LPA observed that of the two youth taking psychotropic medications one has authorization by a parent/guardian and another has a current JV223 that expires in November 2021. Facility was cited for Facility cited for violation of Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Regulation 87070(b)(12)(H) and (E) Children's Records. LPA observed that the Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) document was not signed upon administration of psychotropic medications for C1 (see LIC811 dated 9/9/21) on 9/8/21, 9/9/21 and C2 on 9/3/21. In addition, one of C1's documents had the incorrect dosage noted on the PMAR. LPA conducted an exit interview with Steven Dogan, Administrator upon completion of the inspection.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess returned to the facility's Administration Office located at Georgia Street, Vallejo, CA 94590 to complete the file review for the Annual Inspection started yesterday, 2/23/2022. LPA reviewed 3 client files and 6 staff files, including the Administrator and Facility Manager. Yesterday and today, LPA found in the client files, that all clients were missing their original Needs and Services Plans (NSPs), however, Administrator was able to retrieve them and show to LPA. Also missing were certain details in the NSPs, described in the attached citations and advisory notes. All clients were missing evidence of mental health services received. All clients had a health screening, TB test record, school information, placement agreements, required signed documents, JV220s and JV223s if necessary for psychotropic medications, consent forms, authorized representative information and cash/personal valuable records. All clients receive an allowance and can use the facility telephone. Based on the level system, the clients may also earn personal phone privileges. For the staff records reviewed, LPA found: all staff had the appropriate criminal record clearances and association to the facility. All staff met the education and experience requirements. All staff had their health screening and TB test. All but one staff had their required annual hours of training. The one staff who's annual training is not complete, was prevented from completing the requirement due to COVID-related travel issues. Additionally, three out of six staff reviewed had expired CPR/1st Aid training. On this date, the facility is being cited for the following violations of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 4 and the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, found during this annual inspection on 2/23/2022 and 2/24/2022: 1. 87095.61(f)(3) 2. 87095.61(f)(6) 3. 87065.1(d)(6)(A) 4. 87070(b)(14) 5. 87087(e) 6. 87068.2(b) 7. 80075(k)(7) Eight Technical Violation Advisory Notes (not citations), were issued for the other issues found during this inspection. Additionally, LPA issued two Technical Assistance Advisory Notes to the facility, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report, all Advisory Notes, Confidential Names List, and appeal rights were emailed to him with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Connie Goldie and Alyssa Burgess, made an unannounced required two-year annual inspection and met with Administrator, Steve Dogan who assisted with the inspection. LPAs and Facility Manager Jamilliah Cabunoc conducted a walk through of the facility and observed: three client bedrooms, one media room, one kitchen, on garage, the living room area, staff office, and backyard. The facility was clean and in good repair, aside from one client bedroom which had a boarded window from a client behavioral incident. Plans to repair the window are in effect. Also in that bedroom, there was a hole in the wall from a punch or kick. This is also planned to be repaired. LPAs learned that the facility had a minor issue with mice, however the facility already has been dealing with it and the pest control company treated the issue by servicing it today and will return in two weeks to treat it again. The water temperature measured at 111 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the required temperature range of 105 - 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPAs observed an adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable foods. All bedrooms had adequate bedding and supplies. All lights were working. All poisons and disinfectants were locked and inaccessible. Medication was locked and inaccessible. Medication records showed that the Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Records were out of date. All other regulations and requirements were met for medications. LPAs interviewed three clients. LPAs reviewed two client files. LPAs found that the two client files reviewed were missing items involving the Needs and Services Plans and other details required to be in the file. Due to not being able to finish the client file review on this date, these issues will be addressed in the annual continuation inspection. LPAs observed the facility's Board of Directors minutes, which have completed adequately and as required. LPAs observed a current fire clearance. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Steve Dogan and a copy of this report was emailed to him with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Monica Roberts made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with staff Tom Hermann, Program Director (PD) Reyes Bonilla, and Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. LPAs, staff, and PD conducted a walk-through of the facility and LPAs observed the following: a missing door handle on the first section of the upstairs bathroom, a broken window screen in the living room, three broken rolling chairs in the media room missing backs and arms with frame exposed, one ripped up couch cushion in the media room, broken outside table/bench with missing bench part - exposing the metal frame, broken thin metal beam in trash pile in corner of back yard, accessible poison rodent trap on the ground in the backyard, the kitchen table was in disrepair, and LPAs had no access to the staff office as neither staff nor PD had access to it. PD stated that they are planning on replacing the chairs and having the couch repaired. PD called Executive Director Tegre Miles to request to get rid of the broken outside table and connected seating, which he stated he can do today. PD threw away the poison trap and stated that it was an old one. PD also threw away the thin metal beam during this inspection. PD messaged the maintenance workers about the bathroom door handle and the broken window screen during this inspection. Due to the facility's recent renovations and door lock changes, the PD did not have the new key, but it is at the Administration Office. Later in the inspection at around 12: PM Administrator Steve Dogan arrived, and he has access to the staff office. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 22, Division 6, Section 80087(a), Buildings and Grounds. An Advisory Note for a Technical Violation was also issued, which is not a citation, for the office door being inaccessible during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to him.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with staff Thomas Hermann, who assisted with the inspection. Present at the facility was one client and one staff. Another staff arrived not long after. There were no facility managers at the facility. Administrator Steve Dogan arrived a little bit later. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 5, Section 87065(f), Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Steve Dogan and a copy of this report and appeal rights were given to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced Plan of Correction (POC) inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) Tom Hermann who assisted LPA with the inspection. On 12/29/2023, LPA issued the citation: Type B - 87065(f): Personnel Requirements. The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when one or more children are present. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on observation and statements, the facility failed to have at least one facility manager present at all times one or more clients are present. This is a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. POC: By POC due date of 1/29/2024. The facility will have trained all eligible staff as facility managers, with the topics specified in section 87065.1(b)(5)(A-M) and will submit the monthly staff schedule for February 2024 with facility managers noted on all shifts with children, and will submit the training records. Administrator Steve Dogan sent LPA the POC during LPA's inspection. No further action is necessary. LPA advised Administrator to ensure that POCs are sent timely, by the POC due date, to prevent the assessment of civil penalties for the failure to correct. An exit interview was conducted with PD and a copy of this report and clearance letter were sent to Administrator Steve Dogan and PD.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) Tom Hermann who assisted LPA with the inspection. CCL received an incident report dated 1/27/2024 stating that client C1 (see confidential names list dated 2/7/2024) went to C1's room and was yelling because C1's door was removed, "as part of [C1's] suicidal watch." Earlier, C1 had barricaded in C1's room, so C1's door was removed. Staff intervened when C1 was yelling and C1 then did property destruction and threats. In another incident report dated 1/27/2024, it stated that earlier in the day, C1 was kicking a pool table, yelling at staff, and was attempting to harm themselves with a piece of plastic, which the staff was able to remove. LPA interviewed FM Tom Hermann and Administrator Steve Dogan. An emergency Child and Family Team Meeting was held on 2/5/2024 for C1. LPA reviewed CFT Notes and Action Plan and found they discussed placement. However, they did not discuss C1's safety in the facility, or any of the behavioral issues C1 has been displaying, C1's recent mental health struggles, or psychiatric hospitalizations. Program Director Reyes Bonilla will be requesting the next CFT be moved up sooner to be able to adequately address these issues. PD will inform LPA when this meeting is scheduled. After the meeting, the facility will send the notes to LPA. After investigation into these incidents LPA has found that while the intent behind removing the client's door was for safety, it is not clear that the steps to ensure it was not a personal rights violation were taken. LPA is issuing an advisory note, which is not a citation, to address this. Additionally, the incident report describing C1 attempting self-harm with a piece of plastic was limited in details to evaluate the danger of the plastic. LPA advised Administrator Steve Dogan to include more information in the incident report, such as where C1 was scratching with the plastic, what was the piece of plastic from, was it sharp, were there any marks on C1, etc. An exit interview was conducted with Program Director and a copy of this report was sent to Administrator Steve Dogan and PD.
