Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Health Program Specialist (HPS) Kayla Haith made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. LPA, HPS, and Administrator conducted a walk through of the facility. LPA observed: three client bedrooms, one media/relaxation room, one dining room, kitchen, laundry area, garage, living room, three bathrooms, and staff office. Medications were inaccessible as required. Client Medication Administration Records were completed as required. There were separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records for the psychotropic medications as required. There was an adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable food as required. The facility was clean. There was available foodware, in good condition. The hot water in the clients' bathroom measured at 143 degrees Fahrenheit, which is outside the required range of 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. Clients had appropriate bedding and hygiene supplies. All clients had clothing as required. One client dresser was in disrepair with broken tracks/drawers. Outside in the backyard, there was an approximately 5 inch in diameter drain hole which was uncovered. There were no paper towels or soap in the media room bathroom. One seat out of eight passenger seats in the facility van had a broken/inoperable seat-belt buckle fastener. Disinfectants and knives were inaccessible to clients. LPA interviewed one staff. The staff was knowledgeable about the facility, however LPA recommends a refresher on mandated reporter requirements, and abuse reporting process. LPA and HPS went to the facility's administrative office located at Georgia Street, Vallejo, CA to conduct a file review and found: The board is meeting as required, and minutes are maintained. Board minutes were accessible to LPA. There are two clients placed currently, so the ratio is kept at 1:3, and staff are currently not conducting restraints unless another trained staff or Administrative staff come in to assist. LPA did observe the facility Pro-Act certified trainer's certification to be up-to-date. The facility plans to train additional staff on emergency interventions. All staff in the roster were fingerprint cleared and associated as required. All files were accessible to CCL as required. The client who is taking psychotropic medications had an accurate and updated JV223 as required. LPA was unable to complete the inspection and will return on another date to do so. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. On 1/4/2024, LPA received allowance records for a client for the months of February 2023 through December 2023. LPA observed some unclear and incorrect entries. When LPA visited the facility again on 3/6/2024 for an annual inspection, LPA observed a random sample of a client's allowance sheet in which LPA again observed errors. LPA addressed this with the Administrator during that inspection. LPA also later brought this to the attention of the Executive Director, reviewing the records together, who then also discussed this with Administrator. LPA conducted an investigation into a complaint allegation in which it was alleged that the facility staff do not safeguard minor's personal belongings. LPA found this allegation to be unsubstantiated (see LIC9099 dated 5/6/2024 for the full report), however during LPA's investigation she reviewed clients' cash resources/allowance records, which due to these errors made the records unreliable. On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80070(b)(14). An exit interview was conducted with FM, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. CCL received an incident report dated 4/1/2024 which LPA is gathering more information about. LPA spoke to FM about the incident. LPA reviewed client records and found: the client received a prescription for a medication they needed related to this incident, on 4/1/2024. The client's Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record shows that the client was not placed with that medication. The client was placed on 3/23/2024. LPA took photos of the CSMDR and the current month's Medication Administration Record. LPA is requesting the following be sent to LPA: 1. C1's MAR from March 2024 and April 2024. 2. Any placement background information which would state what conditions the client has and any medication the client is currently on. 3. Records of the hospital visits on 3/31/2024 and 4/1/2024. 4. Referral from the County for placement of C1. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report was provided to FM and Administrator.

There were also multiple incidents in which one client was sexually inappropriate with another client by flirting, trying to show their genitals, dry-humping, and more. Interviews revealed that for the majority of the time, staff did intervene to stop this from occurring, however some clients stated that it was not at all times. One staff stated these incidents sometimes occurred quickly and out of view of staff. Clients stated they would often rough-house with each other, and some stated staff would tell them to stop. In one incident, a client allegedly poked another client in the anus. When staff became aware of the allegation, it was immediately reported and investigated by the facility. After the facility investigated, they issued a discharge notice for the client on an emergency basis to keep the other clients safe. Based on interviews LPA found there was a clear pattern of one client being physically inappropriate and aggressive with other clients in the home, and while action was taken with the aggressing client it is unclear if action could and should have been taken sooner, based on the information provided. During interviews with seven clients, six staff, the Clinician, the Administrator, and the Executive Director, LPA was informed that the house is clean. Clients have chores and do them daily. If a client does not do their chore, staff clean up after the clients or incentivize other clients to cover the chore for more points. Additionally, all individuals interviewed except for one stated that a mess does not last more than a day, and most of them stated it lasts less than hours. One client stated it might last up to a day and a half. One client stated that after a client was in the bathroom sometimes there would be pubic hair, feces, urine, and soap. One staff stated the floors are sticky sometimes. LPA has visited the facility unannounced on many occasions over years, and has not observed the home to be messy or dirty. (continued)... During interviews with clients, staff, a witness, Administrator, and the Executive Director, LPA learned that a client had their money stolen on at least one occasion, but possibly more than once. The client stated the money was locked up with staff and it went missing. Other clients stated another client stole the money, or that they heard that it was a staff. The Administrator stated it was looked into and it was unclear, as sometimes the client kept their belongings in their room instead of locking it up, as well as brought money in without telling staff how much there was. The Executive Director was unsure of the outcome and thought that management had figured it out, as well as stated that if the money was lost by staff, then it would be replaced. All clients stated they are allowed to lock their personal belongings up with staff for safe-keeping, and some choose to do so. Staff repeatedly encouraged the client to safeguard their money. One staff stated they brought up the missing money during management meetings, and it was brushed off. Additionally, in LPA's review of the client's allowance sheets, there were some errors and entries that were unclear. LPA brought this to the attention of the ED, who discussed this with Administrator. In another visit to the facility for an annual on 3/6/2024, LPA observed a random sample of a client's allowance sheet in which LPA again observed errors. LPA addressed this with the Administrator during that inspection. Based on conflicting information, and lack of information, it is unclear if in this instance the facility failed to safe-guard the client's money. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to him.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing client allowance records and conducting interviews with seven clients, six staff, a witness, the Administrator, the Clinician, and the Executive Director on 12/29/2023, 1/24/2024, 4/5/2024, 4/9/2024, 4/15/2024, 4/16/2024, 4/17/2024, 4/19/2024, and 4/22/2024. During interviews with clients, staff, a witness, Administrator, and the Executive Director, LPA learned of various incidents involving the clients which were inappropriate in nature. In one incident, two clients were fighting which resulted in one client being bitten by the other one, and going to the hospital. LPA was informed of mixed details during interviews. A witness stated the staff on shift responded immediately and appropriately to the fight. One client stated it took about five minutes for staff to respond. Another client stated when one client assaulted the staff, the staff left the situation, however the staff denied this. All interviews stated staff intervened and separated the clients. After this incident, the client was given a room change to keep the other client safe. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: During interviews, one staff stated that due to the facility's consequences/level structure, it does not meet the clients' mental health needs as a therapeutic environment. One client felt the facility gives, "shitty," therapy, however they met with the therapist twice a week. The client refused to see the facility psychiatrist, and saw their Kaiser psychiatrist instead. LPA was informed by the Clinician and one client that this client sometimes refused to engage or participate in the mental health services offered to them by Mile High. Another client stated they did get therapy at the facility, but stated it was not all that they needed. When asked what else they needed, the client stated they did not know and it was only something, "someone," told them. One client stated there are Behavioral Techs at the facility but all they want to do is take them to the library and not talk to them, but the client also stated they refused to meet with mental health staff to have their mental health needs met, so it is unclear if they actually did not meet the client's needs. During other interviews with all other clients, they confirmed their mental health needs are met. There are Behavioral Techs who are in the facility daily to meet with the clients about their mental health and clients meet with the Clinician at least twice a week. Additionally, LPA was informed by the Clinician that a psychiatric nurse practitioner comes to the facility to assess the clients' medications and make recommendations. The facility has a psychiatrist as well who diagnoses clients and prescribes them medications. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 5, Section 87089.1(a). An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to him. In an interview with another client, they stated that Admin has a, "slick mouth." When asked why they feel that way, they said because Admin told them, "if you keep acting up you're not going to get your full allowance," and, "always yelled." LPA clarified the meaning of yelling with the client, who maintained that Admin yelled, however gave no description of yelling. In another client interview, LPA was informed that Admin, "yells all the time." The client stated Admin yelled at a client to get out of another client's room. When clarification questions were asked, the client determined Admin was not yelling, only raising his voice. The other clients stated Admin does not yell at them. Staff informed LPA that Admin is the one to address consequences with the clients. The Program Director explained that because of this he gets a, "bad rep," but he is not yelling. LPA was informed that Admin has a, "stronger," voice and some clients will say he is yelling, "but he is just being firm." All staff interviewed denied that Admin yells at the clients. LPA was informed by one client that Executive Director (ED) Tegre Miles has cussed at them, telling them, "you're on bullshit." Another client stated ED yells at the clients, but it is only to get his point across and not to scare them. The other clients denied ED yells at them. LPA learned from the Program Director that ED is also the one to address the clients' behavior and consequences with them. LPA was informed that it is true that ED could have a softer approach with some of the more, "sensitive," clients, and they, "could see how some kids can perceive some things negatively, though it is never inappropriate." LPA was informed that ED will explain to clients the consequences of their actions and they won't like it. One staff stated that ED speaks to the clients, "very bold, disrespectful, and yelling and cursing." When asked for an example of this, the staff stated ED says, "I don't give a shit," "I don't give a damn." The staff stated however, that it is nothing abusive. Another staff stated ED has said to clients before to, "cut this bullshit out." When asked about cussing to the clients, ED stated that he sometimes does talk to the clients in their language, or paraphrases what they say to him. ED stated he does not yell at the clients, but is a straight-talker with them. Based on this information it is not clear if ED and Admin do yell at the clients, or if it is a perception by the clients due to the nature of the conversations, the language used, and/or the natural voices of the ED and Admin. During interviews with seven clients, six staff, the Clinician, the Administrator, and the Executive Director, LPA was informed that the house is clean. Clients have chores and do them daily. If a client does not do their chore, staff clean up after the clients or incentivize other clients to cover the chore for more points. Additionally, all individuals interviewed except for one stated that a mess does not last more than a day, and most of them stated it lasts less than hours. One client stated it might last up to a day and a half. One client stated that after a client was in the bathroom sometimes there would be pubic hair, feces, urine, and soap. One staff stated the floors are sticky sometimes. LPA has visited the facility unannounced on many occasions over years, and has not observed the home to be messy or dirty. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. LPA is issuing an advisory note to address the language used by the Executive Director with the clients. An exit interview was conducted with __ and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to __.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing CFT notes and conducting interviews with eight clients, six staff, a witness, the Administrator, the Program Director, the Clinician, and the Executive Director on 12/29/2023, 1/24/2024, 4/5/2024, 4/9/2024, 4/15/2024, 4/16/2024, 4/17/2024, 4/19/2024, and 4/22/2024. One of the clients had been experiencing an increase in mental health crises and adverse behaviors. An emergency Child & Family Team Meeting (CFT) was scheduled to address this. After the emergency CFT was held on 2/5/2024, LPA reviewed the notes and found that neither the client's safety, nor the client's mental health concerns were discussed in the CFT, for which the purpose of the meeting was. Instead, only school and placement plans were discussed. When LPA asked Admin and Program Director why this was, they were unsure. LPA instructed Admin and PD to ensure another CFT is called to address these areas of concern. Both agreed to this, and the meeting occurred on 2/13/2024 in which the client's mental health needs and safety planning were discussed. A safety plan was created and the client was moved to Mile High's other house to improve the client's mental health. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steve Dogan who assisted with the inspection. This inspection is to close the case management opened on 5/6/2024. The incident was in regard to a client (C1 - See Confidential Names List dated 7/10/2024) having to go to the emergency room due to asthma symptoms, and did not have an inhaler. LPA reviewed medical records, medication records, and emails. The client was placed on 3/23/2024, and on 3/25/ Administrator emailed the County Social Worker, informing her that the client stated they need an inhaler. The County Social Worker was not aware that the client needed an inhaler, and the client did not come to the facility with one. On 3/31/2024, as stated in the incident report dated 4/1/2024, the client went to the ER for shortness of breath, but did not want to stay to be seen. On 4/1/2024, the client was again taken to the ER by the facility to be treated for asthma symptoms and was prescribed medication to assist with them. On 4/19/2024 the client had a doctor's appointment and the doctor did not prescribe an inhaler, but assessed the client to have allergies. Since then, the client has had no other symptoms. LPA found the facility took the client to be treated for symptoms as required, and the facility was not informed prior to placement that the client needed an inhaler as the County Social Worker was not aware, and the client did not come to the facility with one. This case management is now closed, no further action necessary. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced Plan of Correction inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. On 7/10/2024, the facility was cited: 87072(c)(11). The plan of correction that was agreed upon by LPA and Administrator was, "By POC due date of 7/11/2024 the ED and FM will have been refreshed on de-escalation techniques, observed by Admin, and will submit a document acknowledging the different steps that could have been taken prior to restraint." LPA advised Administrator on 7/10/2024 that even if the citation and finding was disagreed with, the POC still needs to be completed as required. On 7/11/2024, Administrator emailed LPA informing her that they would not be completing the POC as they will be appealing, which is their right to do so. However, the POC was still required to be completed. LPA and Admin further discussed the citation-->POC-->appeal process. On this date, the facility is being assessed a Failure to Correct Civil Penalty in the amount of $700, which is $100 per day that the citation was not corrected after the POC due date of 7/11/2024. Further failure to complete the POC will result in a continuation of $100 being assessed for every day the POC is not submitted. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this case management inspection is to deliver the findings to the case management which was investigated by the Department's Investigations Branch Investigator (IB) Nathan Gonzalez, regarding an incident report received by the Department on 4/15/2024 by the facility. The reported incident stated that one client (C1) had been sexually assaulted when C1 was forced by a client (C2) to perform oral sex on C2 on the night of 4/15/2024. See confidential names list dated 8/9/2024. IB conducted this investigation by reviewing police reports, facility file information, and by conducting confidential interviews with one County Social Worker, three clients, three staff, the facility Administrator, and the facility Program Director, on 5/1/2024, 5/21/2024, 5/23/2024, 6/20/2024, 7/13/2024, 7/17/2024, and 7/23/2024. IB had also requested staff and Administrator write-ups relating to the incident from the Program Director on 7/17/2024, 7/26/2024, and 7/30/2024, which IB never received. IB found through their investigation that on 4/16/2024 a staff informed the Program Director that a non-consensual sexual encounter had occurred between clients. Clients were interviewed by Law Enforcement (LE) and informed LE that they were forced to smoke marijuana with C2 and play truth or dare. During truth or dare, C2 forced C1 to perform oral sex on them, under threat of physical violence. One staff (S1) was present at the facility during this incident and had called the Administrator of the facility, who was the on-call staff that night, three times for assistance with other escalated client behaviors with no response. S1 admitted to feeling that she, "neglected," some of the clients who were upstairs during her shift. Staff reported to IB that they are directed to supervise clients from the upstairs media room during overnight shifts, and S1 acknowledged that she should have more effectively supervised the clients from the media room. Administrator confirmed to IB that he missed three calls from S1. Administrator informed IB that he and S1 were both reprimanded for this incident. The Program Director informed IB that staff are to follow the emergency phone call procedures when needing management assistance, however S1 did not think to do that in the moment. Based on information obtained by IB, IB found that S1 and Administrator failed to provide adequate supervision to clients during the early morning of 4/15/2024, which resulted in C2 sexually assaulting C1 while in care. On this date the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80078(a), Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision, and Section 80044(c), Inspection Authority. See attached LIC809-D. An exit interview was conducted with FM, and a copy of this report, confidential names list, advisory note, and appeal rights were provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Tom Hermann, who assisted with the inspection. CCL received an incident report from the facility dated 10/5/2024 regarding client C1 (See Confidential Names List dated 11/6/2024). LPA is conducting this case management to attain more information regarding the incident. LPA spoke with staff Tom who was not aware of the incident. LPA collected client information. No clients or other staff present. Further information is needed to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with staff Tom and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Regional (RM) Manager Margo Castaneda made an announced case management inspection at a separate location and met with Tegre Miles, Executive Director (ED), and Reyes Bonilla Program Director (PR) who assisted with the inspection. LPA and RM are conducting this case management to gather more information in regard to MSK Solutions' fiscal accountability. On November 14, 2024, the Community Care Licensing Division received a letter via Child and Family Services Division in regard to Solano County Behavioral Health Services Division terminating their contract with MSK Solutions, Inc.. The Sacramento Regional Office requested the last 12 months of bank statements, November 1, 2023, through November 1, 2024, for all their accounts pertaining to Mile High Legend Home Facility #487005982, Mile High Mountain Top Facility # 487005059, and any other accounts associated with MSK Solutions, Inc. This will be provided to CCL by 12/10/2024. LPA and RM interviewed ED and PD. An exit interview was conducted with ED and PD and a copy of this report was provided to them.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager Steven Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. This Case Management was opened at the facility on 11/6/2024. CCL received an incident report from the facility dated 10/5/2024 regarding client C1 (See Confidential Names List dated 11/6/2024). LPA reviewed this incident report by conducting confidential interviews with five clients and the Administrator from 11/6/2024 - 1/7/2025, and reviewing the facility investigation into the subject of the incident report. Based on interviews and all information, LPA found the accusation in the incident was not true, as confirmed by the client. This case management is now closed. No further action necessary. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report was provided to him.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Orlando Areizaga, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall met with Administrator Steven Anderson via Microsoft Teams. The purpose of this visit was to provide any technical assistance needed regarding the facility's Program Statement and Plan of Operation updates, detailed in the revisions letter provided to the facility on 4/7/2025. During the review it was agreed upon that the letter is understood, and Administrator will reach out if any additional guidance is needed. The revisions are due to CCL by 5/21/2025. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was provided to him. Administrator will send a signed copy back to CCL.

Review of the police reports revealed: LE arrived and observed ED and FM restraining C1 on the bed. C1 informed LE that ED pinched C1 during the restraint and twisted C1's arms, when he came in from the window. C1 also also reported ED was digging ED's elbow into C1's back. LE did later observe on C1, "fresh abrasions with bruising and redness to [C1's] left forearm, which is the side ED restrained C1 on," and where it was alleged that ED pinched C1. Interviews with the children revealed: one child stated they did not see the restraint but heard, "just a bunch of shouting and yelling." The child denied that any staff have hurt any child at the facility. One child stated ED and FM came into the room saying nothing and just restrained C1 on a dresser and then on a bed where C1 was on their stomach for a while until C1 stated they could not breathe. Then ED and FM flipped C1 over, and picked C1 and, "put [C1's] head against the wall." The child stated ED told LE that they were restraining C1 due to them spitting on ED and FM. C1 admitted to LPA they had been on the roof out of boredom, then went to another client's room waiting for the ED and FM to arrive. C1 explained that ED and FM pulled C1 off of the bed to restrain them by taking their arms up and putting them on the bed on their stomach, "to where I couldn't breathe." C1 explained then ED was, "talking crap," to them and pinching them on their arm, which left bruises. FM was not doing anything that was hurting C1. The restraint ended when the police arrived. Interviews with staff revealed: one staff did not witness the restraint as they were supervising the other clients. One staff stated it was when C1 kicked out at ED/FM that they initiated the restraint. The staff denied that anyone fell and that C1 was not put on their stomach. FM informed LPA that when he and ED arrived, they entered the room, asked the other client to leave and C1 was, "talking trash, doing threatening (gestures), so we went into the restraint." C1 was being threatening by, "looking like [C1] was going to swing at [ED]." Once on the bed, C1 was, "just sitting there, no struggle, just verbal threats," but they continued the restraint until LE arrived. FM confirmed they advanced on C1 in the room, and C1 was only making verbal threats. ED informed LPA he and FM attempted to verbally de-escalate C1 while C1 was sitting on a bed. C1 became upset and swung their fist out which is when the restraint was initiated, and they stood C1 up against a dresser. They moved to the bed and C1 was still making verbal threats until police arrived after about 15 to 20 minutes. LE arrived and took over. ED denied C1 was ever on their stomach, denied he was upset, and denied that he was hurting/pinching C1 during the restraint. FM and the staff denied FM or ED were rough with C1. FM admitted other things could have been tried before restraint. ED stated he could not evade because he did not have the space. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with Admin, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to you.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steve Dogan, who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing two police reports, the facility incident report, staff Emergency Intervention training records, and by conducting confidential interviews with three children, two staff, the Executive Director (ED), and the Facility Manager (FM), on 3/14/2024, 4/9/2024, 4/10/2024, 4/16/2024, 4/17/2024, and 5/6/2024. The facility incident report described the client (C1 - See Confidential Names List dated 7/10/2024) having been engaging in dangerous behavior of getting on the roof in the rain from their bedroom window, moving their bed into the hallway, trying to get into the attic, and throwing things at staff. ED and FM were called to assist. When ED/FM arrived, they saw C1 hanging outside of his window and entered the room. Then, C1 aggressively approached ED and FM, "within 3 feet," and had closed fists. That is when ED and FM placed C1 in a restraint. A struggle ensued and at one point they fell to the bed. ED and FM transitioned to a seated restraint with C1 on the bed and Law Enforcement (LE) was called. Once LE arrived, C1 was released from the hold and LE took over. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Interviews with staff and clients informed LPA that the client (C1 - See Confidential Names List dated 5/7/2025) struggled with substance use. Staff informed LPA that C1 would hallucinate during use. During one incident, staff informed LPA that they were following C1 when C AWOLd and appeared to be under the influence. C1 was trying to jump or pass through a fence and the staff tried to prevent C1 from doing so due to safety concerns. During this incident, C1's sweater got caught on the fence and tore. All clients informed LPA that staff have not handled clients in a rough manner. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report, Confidential Names List, and appeal rights were provided to him.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Steven Anderson who assisted with the inspection. LPA investigated this complaint by reviewing incident reports, and by conducting confidential interviews with two clients, four staff, the Facility Manager, the Program Director, the Administrator, and the County Social Worker between 11/26/2024 and 4/29/2025. Despite making 11 attempts to speak with the client involved, LPA was unable to make contact with them. Confidential interviews with all facility personnel and all children informed LPA that staff have not made inappropriate comments towards clients, specifically calling a client a "pendejo." All clients informed LPA that staff do not speak inappriopriately to them. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Tamara Hill and Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Steven Anderson, Administrator to discuss the inspection. On 2/3/ The Licensee, MSK Solutions, was informed by the Department's Audit Section that they will be receiving a solvency audit for both of their licensed STRTPs: Mile High Legend Home #487005982 and Mile High Mountain Top #487005059. The Department informed the Licensee of the reason for the audit, and all required information needed to perform the audit. The due date for submission of the required information was 3/3/2025. On 3/7/2025, the Department followed up with the Executive Director (ED) Tegre Miles regarding not having received the required documents to conduct the audit, nor a request for an extension of time. On 3/12/ ED responded with their concerns, and that they intended to finish everything by the coming Friday (3/14/2025). The Department responded to ED addressing their concerns and granting an extension until 3/14/2025. Failure to submit the required documents would result in the completion of the audit, documenting noncompliance with the Department's Inspection Authority. On 3/17/2025, ED responded to the Department with their concerns, however no documentation was provided. On this date the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Chapter 1, Section 80044(c) Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency, Section 80062(a) Finances, Section 80063(a) Accountability, and Section 80064(a) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. A repeat civil penalty in the amount of $250 is assessed for violation of Section 80044(c). Civil penalties in the amount of $100 per day will continue to accrue until the POC is met. LPA Hill did advise the administrator, Mr. Anderson, that while they have a plan of correction date of 5/15/25, civil penalties will continue to accrue on the citation related to Inspection Authority until the documents have been provided to the Audit Section per the request. LPA Hill advised the agency that they need to provide the requested documents as soon as possible to prevent further accrual of the civil penalties. LPA Hill advised that the civil penalties include an initial penalty of $250 plus $100 per day until the document(s) have been provided per the audit request. An exit interview was conducted with Mr. Anderson and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided

narrative: In regards to the allegation that the facility staff did not prevent C5 from AWOLing, confidential interviews revealed that staff conducted 15 minutes room checks while C5 was in the bedroom and other confidential interviews revealed that staff did not conduct 15 minutes room checks while C5 was in the bedroom which resulted in C AWOLing from the facility. LPA did not receive any documentation that staff conducted 15 min room checks while C5 was in the bedroom. Based on confidential interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the allegations that facility has pests and facility staff did not prevent C5 from AWOLing, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to Licensee Beverly Boone for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On October 26, 2020 at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted tele-inspection with Licensee Beverly Boone due to COVID-19. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed five of five clients and 10 of 10 staff. LPA also interviewed one witness and one county social worker. LPA reviewed C1, C2, C3, C4's Appraisal Needs and Services Plan and C1, C2, C3, C4's Treatment Plans. LPA reviewed the facility overnight bed check logs as well as Special Incident Reports. The Department received a complaint on July 22, 2020, that the facility has pests, facility staff are not meeting minor's needs and facility staff did not prevent minor from Awoling. In regard to the allegation that the facility has pests, confidential interviews revealed that staff and clients observed a mouse and cockroaches in the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that it took months for an exterminator company to come out and spray the facility. However, the exterminator company's invoices showed that in July 2020, the facility was sprayed for pests and mouse traps were placed inside the facility. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On June 21, 2021 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted unannounced annual/required inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Licensing Beverly Boone. LPA tour the facility's outside and inside. There were five clients currently residing at this facility. Due to time constraint, LPA will interview clients on another date and time. The facility is a one-story home with pool and two car garage. Bedroom#1- two twin beds, mattresses, mattress pads, linens, blankets, pillows, dresser drawers and closet. Bedroom #2- two twin beds, mattresses, mattress pads, linens, blankets, pillows and dresser drawers and closet. Bedroom #3- two twin beds mattresses, mattress pads, linens, blankets, pillows and dresser drawer and closet. Bathroom #1 and #2 - Sink and tub operable, no common towels. Cleaning solution, disinfectants other hazard items are locked in cabinet located in the library, knives are inaccessible to clients and locked in cabinet in staff's office, staff to client ratio met, five clients (all required forms signed updated) and 10 staff files, centrally stored medications are recorded and logged and JV220 and medical consent forms were updated in clients' file, National Accreditation is current, Mental Health Certification will be approved in July 2021, Child and Family Teams (CFTs) are being utilized by facility, clients are allowed to make and receive calls to friends, family CCL and clients' authorized representatives, clients attend activities outside the facility, Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty plan posted, personal rights were posted and hot water temperature is reading at 113 degrees. LPA observed plenty of non-perishable and perishable foods, including snacks. LPA reviewed Board of Directors Meeting minutes dated March 31, 2021. A review of Licensing Information System on June 21, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. LPA observed in the staff's file initial and annual trainings. Facility Administrator is present at the facility at minimum of 20 hours a week. LPA observed in the pool area, a 5ft. 2 inches wrought iron fence that surrounds the entire pool area, the access gate swings away from the body of water, with a pad lock on the gate. Based on observations made during the inspection and file reviews no deficiencies observed during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and this report was reviewed with Licensee Beverly Boone a copy of this report was provided.

Confidential interviews revealed that staff conducted room checks and did not witness C1 and C2 engaging in any inappropriate behavior. However, when staff was made aware of the alleged allegation C1's room was changed, and staff were directed to increase supervision on both C1 and C2 to ensure proper supervision was carried out. Documents reviewed indicated that there was no indication that C2 needed extra supervision. Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed during the investigation, the allegation that C1 was inappropriate touched by C2 at the facility, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee Beverly Boone.

narrative: On March 3, 2022 at 12: PM, an unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Val Wilson. During the inspection, LPA Wilson inspected Milestone Group Home, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), inside and out with Executive Director, Beverly Boone. During the tour of the facility, LPA Wilson observed the staff office with the locked medication storage cabinet. Inside the cabinet is a locked medication box holding the medications. LPA reviewed three clients' records on site at the facility beginning at 1: PM. LPA reviewed three of three child's psychotropic medications and medication records at 1: PM. LPA Wilson reviewed one staff personnel file on site at the facility beginning at 1: PM. LPA interviewed one staff and the Executive Director on site at 2: PM. LPA interviewed two of three children currently taking psychotropic medication at 2: PM and 3: PM. LPA conducted exit interview with Beverly Boone, Executive Director, at 4: PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Beverly Boone upon completion. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Beverly Boone, Executive Director, at 4: PM

placed a Facetime call to the staff inside of the facility. Regarding the allegation that the facility has pests. Confidential interviews report that the facility has slugs, roaches, and mice. Confidential interviews reveal they have seen roaches in the bathroom and hallways. Confidential interviews reveal that they have seen mice in the house at night. Confidential interviews and documents revealed that there were monthly pest control services at the facility, however, the dates of the services were after the facility was made aware of the allegation roaches, slugs, and mice were present in the facility. Based on confidential interviews and record review of facility documentation, the allegations that the staff is not properly supervising the minors and the facility has pests. are substantiated which poses a potential health, safety, and personal rights risk to clients in care. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, 80078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. The facility is cited for violation of the California Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 07, regulation 80076(a)(17) Food Service. A copy of this report was provided to and reviewed with Beverly Boone, Executive DIrector, along with the appeal right and the LIC 811. A signed copy of the report will be kept in the Facility file. or paraphernalia. Confidential interviews revealed that staff increases their supervision level if they suspect clients are using drugs. Other confidential interviews revealed that clients have smoked in the bathroom and outside of their bedroom doors and covered it up with perfume. Other confidential interviews revealed that staff have smelled smoke in the facility and had not asked the clients if someone was using drugs. Regarding the allegation that the facility vehicle is not in proper driving condition. Confidential interviews and reports revealed that the facility van was replaced in July 2021 and has not had any issues since the transmission was replaced. Other confidential interviews revealed the vehicle struggles and makes sounds while driving up hills. Confidential interviews revealed that clients are offered the opportunity to clean the vehicles once a month and earn an extra allowance. Other confidential interviews revealed that staff will take the vehicle to an automatic car wash and pay for it themselves. Based on interviews and information obtained, the allegations that minors are using drugs on the facility premises, and the facility vehicle is not in proper driving condition, may or may not have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report was provided to and reviewed with Beverly Boone, Executive DIrector , along with the appeal right and the LIC 811. A signed copy of the report will be kept in the Facility file
investigation_findings: 13On April 29, 2022, at 12:21 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Beverly Boone, Executive DIrector of Milestone to discuss the investigative findings for the allegations noted above. Confidential interviews revealed that certain clients are more talkative and engage with staff that clients perceive as favoritism. Confidential interviews revealed that there was no specific client that was given preferential treatment. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem, conducted a case management inspection on 6/14/2022 at 9:55AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated June 14th, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to the Administrator Beverly Boone.

narrative: On January 06, 2023, at 2:20 am, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Eduardo Barragan and Lucero Jauregui went to Milestone Group Home and met with Beverly Boone, Executive Director and Desiree West, Clinical Director.. The purpose of this visit was to address a deficiency that was noted. On November 09, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Vallenzuella were at the facility and they overheard staff calling C1 by a name that C1 did not identify as. C1 then started yelling at staff saying, "I already told you that's not my name," yet the staff continued to call C1 by the name that he did not identify as. Additionally, on December 08, 2022, LPA's Barragan and Jauregui came to the facility to speak with a client and staff. While visiting on December 08, 2022, LPA's were informed that C1 was not being called the name that he identified as. C1 stated that he had verbally told staff the name he identified as, yet staff was refusing to call C1 the name that he identifies as because "they felt uncomfortable." LPA's then spoke with Beverly Boone, Executive Director about the concern and Beverly Boone mentioned that some staff did not feel comfortable with calling C1 by his preferred name; therefore, staff wouldn't call C1 by the name. Based on interviews, the Licensee did not ensure that C1 was accorded dignity within his personal relationships with staff, due to staff not calling him by his preferred name One deficiency is being cited on today's visit. An exit interview was conducted and plans of correction were discussed. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Beverly Boone, Executive Director and Desiree West, Clinical Director.

narrative: Confidential interviews indicated that C1 had texted S3 to request a ride home from school, while S3 was in a meeting and did not see the text for an extended period. LPA observed C1's phone which showed that the staff was aware that C1 needed a ride and had been responding to C1's texts. The staff made C1 wait at least two hours before picking C1 up from school. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was not getting along with roommate C2 and staff placed C1's mattress on the floor next to the front door which gave C1 no privacy. C1 had to sleep there for three nights. LPA observed pictures of the mattress placed on the floor of the room next to the front door. Confidential Interviews indicated that C1 left the facility without permission and staff packed up C1's belongings for safeguarding. Confidential interviews revealed that when C1 returned to the facility C1 did not receive all their belongings. Based on confidential interviews, and LPA's observations the allegations that staff did not pick up C1 in a timely manner, the staff made C1 sleep by the facility entrance/exit door, and the staff confiscated C1's belongings are SUBSTANTIATED because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. This posed a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to C1 in care, the facility will be cited for violating Interim Licensing Standards, STRTP, Article 06, 87072(c)(11) Personal Rights, and 87072(c)(6)(C) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed with Beverly Boone, Executive Director. A copy of the report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to the facility administrator.

On April 3, 2023, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Lucero Jauregui and Eduardo Barragan conducted an announced annual facility inspection. LPA's met with Beverly Boone, Executive Director who provided LPA's with a guided tour of the facility both indoors and outdoors. The facility is a three bedroom, two bathroom (for client use) in a single story home. The home consisted of three bedrooms, dining room, kitchen, two living rooms, a office and a clinician room. All three bedrooms are equipped to serve two clients each. All beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. However, two of the dressers needed to be repaired due to both of them missing a drawer. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The hot water temperature was measured in the main bathroom and is currently 111.0 degrees which is in ration. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA's observed the following items posted Personal Rights, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policy, Facility sketch, Activity Schedule, Menu, Staff Schedule and Emergency Plan. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris however, the fence in the backyard needed to be repaired due to the fence not latching/closing correctly. There is a pool in the backyard and it is fenced. The enclosure was measured to be 5 feet with a self-latching gate that swings outward. Facility has one camera inside the staff break room and there is three cameras on the exterior of the house. Continued... Prior to inspection LPA's reviewed personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. However, staff was missing a current CPR that was expired. LPA's also reviewed client records as well and ensured that all files contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Four deficiency were administered at the end of this visit and one Technical Advisory were administered during this visit. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Beverly Boone, Executive Director.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Jose Gonzalez and Joon Choi on March 5,2025 at approximately 9: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA's Gonzalez and Choi met Administrator Michelle Zambrana and Director Care Staff Elizabeth Reimann, and conducted a tour of the facility. During the visit there were two staff present and one client at the facility. LPA reviewed three client's record and two of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPA reviewed three client's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed one child (C1) on site that are currently prescribed psychotropic medication. LPA will conduct an interview with child (C2) at a later time. After reviewing client records at the facility, no deficiency is being cited at this time. The facility was provided a Technical Advisory (TA). LPA provided a copy of this licensing report, LIC 809, TA and conducted an exit interview with Administrator Michelle Zambana.

On July 11, 2025 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced required facility inspection. LPA met with Beverly Boone, Executive Director who provided LPA with a guided tour of the facility both indoors and outdoors. The facility is a three bedroom, two bathroom (for client use) in a single story home. The home consisted of three bedrooms, dining room, kitchen, two living rooms, a office and a clinician room. All three bedrooms are equipped to serve two clients each. All beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The hot water temperature was measured in the main client bathroom. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. LPA observed the following items posted Foster Care Ombudsman, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, If You See Something Say Something, Personal Rights, Mental Health postings, Meal Menu, Snack Menu, Daily Schedule, Chore Chart and Responsibilities, and Laundry Schedule. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is a pool in the backyard and it is fenced. The enclosure was measured to be 5 feet with a latching gate that swings outwards. Facility has one camera inside the staff break room and there is three cameras on the exterior of the house. Continued...... LPA reviewed five out of five personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. LPA reviewed five out of five client records and contained all required items. LPA conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews. LPA is administering one Technical Violation during this visit, [SEE LIC9102]. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Beverly Boone, Executive Director.

On 01/14/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the licensee does not ensure adequate hygiene care items are provided to children in care. Regarding the allegation that the licensee does not ensure adequate hygiene care items are provided to children in care, it was specifically reported that the facility does not provide hygiene products that accommodate clients' special needs and that the facility provides the least expensive brand-name products to clients. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that the facility provides adequate hygiene products and that there are extra hygiene products stored in the facility. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that the facility did not provide special hygiene products to accommodate curly hair, heavy menstrual flow, and sensitive skin. A confidential interview disclosed that clients may get preferred hygiene products with their allowance. Confidential interviews stated that the staff purchase hygiene products to accommodate a variety of hair types such as curly hair, heavy menstrual flow, and sensitive skin. LPA received conflicting information and couldn't determine if the allegation occurred. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that the licensee does not ensure a comfortable temperature for children is maintained in the facility. Regarding the allegation that the licensee does not ensure a comfortable temperature for children is maintained in the facility, it was specifically reported that during the summer months, the facility gets very hot and during the winter it gets very cold. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that the client's bedrooms can get very hot during summer and very cold during winter. Confidential interviews stated that the house temperatures are adjusted during the summer and winter time. Per confidential interviews, during the summer, the fans are turned on and during the cold months, the heat is turned on for the clients. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that clients have fans in their bedrooms and there are heaters available. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that the licensee does not ensure adequate hygiene care items are provided to children in care and the licensee does not ensure a comfortable temperature for children is maintained in the facility are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Desiree West, Clinical Director. On 01/14/2025, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that the licensee does not ensure facility is kept free of pests and the licensee does not ensure the facility is kept in clean sanitary conditions. It was specifically reported that the facility has a rodent infestation and has roaches as well. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there are mice at the facility. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there have been roaches at the facility. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that mice have been in multiple areas of the facility, including but not limited to the clients' bedrooms. Confidential interviews stated that mouse droppings have been observed in bedrooms, the kitchen, and other areas of the facility. It was specially reported that there is rodent feces in numerous areas of the facility. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that there were mice droppings in various parts of the facility including but not limited to the client's bedrooms and drawers. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that staff do not deep clean the facility. During the inspection, LPAs observed mice droppings at the facility. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff does not ensure children are spoken to in an appropriate manner. It was specifically reported that S1 was verbally aggressive and created a hostile environment. During the investigation, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that S1 has yelled at clients resulting in clients becoming upset and crying. In addition, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 would speak aggressively towards clients. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that clients did not like how S1 spoke to them and clients expressed this to staff/administration numerous times and nothing was done. Confidential interviews stated that S1 was observed yelling at the clients on serval occasions. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined that the licensee did not ensure facility was kept free of pests, the staff did not ensure children were spoken to in an appropriate manner, and licensee did not ensure the facility was kept in clean sanitary conditions. Therefore, the allegations are substantiated. The facility is being cited for the violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter Article 07, Physical Environment, Buildings and Grounds 80087(a) and Title 22, Division 6, Chapter Article 06, Continuing Requirements, Personal Rights 80072(a)(1). (See LIC 9099D) An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Desiree West, Clinical Director.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff made inappropriate comments in the presence of minors, it was specifically reported that S1 has been making political statements about the elected head of state and about the LGBTQIA+ community in front of minors, who have disclosed that S1 comments make them feel uncomfortable. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that S1 made negative remarks regarding C2's looks, it was specifically disclosed that S1 called C2 disgusting. Confidential interviews disclosed that they never witnessed S1 discussing any political topics, the LGBTQIA+ community, or the elected head of state in front of clients. LPA received conflicting statements and was unable to determine if any inappropriate comments were made in front of clients. Regarding the allegation that staff did not address minor by their preferred gender pronouns, it was specifically disclosed that S1 was angry that S1 had to refer to a client (C1) by their preferred pronoun. It was specifically disclosed that S1 disregards C1's preferred pronoun and purposely refuses to use C1's preferred pronoun. During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that C1 has been addressed by their "dead name" (birth name) several times and that S1, S2, and S3 purposely address C1 by their (C1) "dead name" which makes C1 uncomfortable. In addition, multiple confidential interviews disclosed that they never witnessed staff not referring to C1 by their pronoun and calling them by their "dead name". Regarding the allegation that staff touched minor in a physically inappropriate manner, it was specifically disclosed on 01/15/2025 that S1 touched C1 on the shoulder and arm in a non-sexual manner, but without consent, and called C1 "sweetie" and "honey." During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 grabbed C1's elbow and shook it, and another time S1 tapped C1's knee. Another confidential interview disclosed that they witnessed S1 touching C1's knee which made C1 feel uncomfortable. Other confidential interviews stated that they did not witness S1 grabbing C1's elbow and shaking it, observed S1 tapping C1's knee, or calling C1 inappropriate names. Regarding the allegation that staff did not comply with reporting requirements, it was specifically disclosed that on 12/14/2024, S1 yelled at C2 which resulted in C2 crying, and that C2 filed a grievance the next day and left it on S4's desk but there has been no resolution, and the incident was not addressed. During the investigation, a confidential interview disclosed that C2 wrote a grievance, and the results are unknown. Other confidential interviews disclosed that when situations/incidents have been reported from staff/clients to the administration, the administration does not do anything about it nor follow up with those who make a report. Other confidential interviews stated that when a grievance is reported to the administration, a discussion occurs to come up with a solution. Multiple confidential interviews disclosed that the grievance protocol is posted on the wall. LPA observed the grievance protocol and complaint hotline number posted in the facility. Furthermore, confidential interviews disclosed that staff understand reporting requirements such as grievances and special incident reports. Regarding the allegation that staff did not provide minors with adequate food services, it was specifically reported that minors have complained there is not enough food in the house because S1 only shops on Fridays and the food that's bought is poor quality. During the investigation, multiple interviews disclosed that there was enough food at the GH. A confidential interview disclosed that a lot of the time there is rotten/expired food, however, LPAs did not observe any expired or rotten food during the inspection. In addition, multiple interviews disclosed that clients are not allowed to request specific groceries and clients don't like the groceries the GH provides. Other confidential interviews disclosed that staff at the facility cook dinner for the clients and there are other food options if clients do not like what the staff has prepared. LPA Lucero took pictures of food and LPA Chavez observed two days of perishable food and seven days of non-perishable food. Confidential interviews stated that the menu is posted but sometimes staff cooks something different from what's on the menu. Confidential interviews stated that when clients do not like the brands of food options, staff purchase the brands of food clients prefer. Furthermore, a confidential interview disclosed that staff takes into consideration the brands/groceries the clients prefer. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that staff made inappropriate comments in the presence of minors, staff did not address minor by their preferred gender pronouns, staff touched minor in a physically inappropriate manner, staff did not comply with reporting requirements, and staff did not provide minors with adequate food services are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Desiree West, Clinical Director .

narrative: In addition, the children get 75 dollars a month to go shopping but the shopping trips were never planned, and some of the newer children do not have the standard number of outfits required and clothes are not being replaced when the children need new clothes. Confidential interviews stated that clients were taken shopping upon request. LPAs couldn't gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that facility staff handle children in a rough manner, it was specifically reported that previous staff grabbed a child on the elbow and shoulder even though the child doesn't like being touched, however, the staff grabbed the child with force. It was unknown if any injuries were sustained as a result of this grabbing. Confidential interviews state that staff utilize verbal de-escalation to diffuse situations. Confidential interviews stated there were no observations of staff grabbing clients by force. Other confidential interviews didn't observe the interaction between the child and the previous staff. Regarding the allegation that facility staff do not ensure the facility floor is in good repair, it was reported that the home has running water and electricity, but tiles are coming off the ground and they are being repaired with duct tape. Confidential interview denied the allegations, however, LPAs observed that the kitchen floor had minor damage where it was covered with a kitchen rug. The facility staff stated that they were actively collecting funds to replace the flooring of the facility. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations facility staff are not providing children with adequate clothing, facility staff handle children in a rough manner, and facility staff do not ensure facility floor is in good repair may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with appeal rights were explained and given to Beverly Boone.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher Rollins conducted an unannounced annual inspection. During the inspection, LPA met with Jasmine Remson, Facility Manager (FM) and inspect the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed files with Facility Manager. The group home is licensed to served 6 clients ages 12-17 and non minor dependents. Present during the inspection was 2 staff. At 10: AM LPA Rollins and Facility Manager did walk through of the facility inside and out. The kitchen is clean. The water measured 114.6 degrees F which is currently between 105 - 120 degrees. The facility has plenty of nonperishable and perishable food supply. Medication and Knives are locked away. There are enough folks, spoons, plates and cups. All passageways are unobstructed. All smoke detectors are update and working. The home is clean, safe, and sanitary. There are no firearms on the property. The fire extinguisher has been checked and is up to date. First aid kit is complete and fully stock. There are no bodies of water on the property. LPA observed clients' medication log to be up to date. At 12: PM, LPA Rollins conducted a file review with Facility Manager. LPA reviewed 5 clients files and Staff files were reviewed. LPA observed all five client files and found no deficiencies. The documentation in the clients file are complete. LPA observed all staff files to be complete, all correct documentation and all staff were up to date with there 40 hours of training for the year. The facility consists of 3 bedrooms (3 for clients), 1 shared bathrooms and 1/2 bathroom (No Shower). The facility is licensed for 6 residents (all can be non-ambulatory) and currently 4 clients reside in facility. No more than two clients share a bedroom. During inspection, LPA requested a updated copy of the LIC Personnel Report to maintain their file current. LPA also spoke with Administrator, Facility Manager and Program Manager about the conversation from Group Home to Short Term Residentail Therapeutic Program (STRTP).A review of Licensing Information System on June 15, 2021 indicates that all facility staff associated to the facility had DOJ, FBI and child abuse index check clearances. Per Title Regulations, no deficiencies were cited during this inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left at the facility.

On 04/15/22 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made a case management visit to go over items that LPA Mendoza discovered during LPA Mendoza investigation for Complaint Control #14-CR-20211115114149, dated 11/15/21, and observed in the IB report, Case # CD1421-11166. LPA met with Facility Manager, Tanya Langley and discussed the below items: Based on confidential interviews, it was stated that the facility requires the clients to sign in and out whenever they are going on an outing-for example, going for a walk, store, work, and school. On 3/8/22, LPA Mendoza requested a copy of all "Sign In" documents from September to November. After reviewing the sign-in/out sheet, LPA noticed several entries starting in October where clients were not filling out the form completely. LPA reminded the facility that if the facility will require clients to sign in and sign out, then the facility is responsible for ensuring that the form is completed entirely by each client. Based on IB report, it was reported that (S1) (please refer to LIC 811, dated 04/15/22 for confidential names ) fingerprint clearances is pending in the Licensing Information System (LIS). (S1) resigned back in January. However, (S1) is still showing associated to the facility in a "pending" status. LPA requested the facility to disassociate (S1). Also, reminded the facility the importance of ensuring that all staff members are fingerprint cleared before working at the facility. LPA Mendoza is requesting the facility to submit an electronic copy of the facilities STRTP program statement to LPA Mendoza no later than Friday 04/22/22. Please continue to LIC 809-C... investigation_findings: 13This is an amended report, original date was 10/19/22. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) amended this report due to including additional finding on this LIC 9099. On 11-8-22 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Millie's Youth Services and met with Tonya Lashley, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and documentation research. An incident had occurred on 9-17-22 at approximately 7: PM. There was a verbal altercation that was de-escalated while in the presence of authorities. Based on document review, there was no evidence of a physical altercation. Based on confidential interviews, inconsistent information was provided, only an unintentional reflexive touch may have occurred during the verbal altercation. While authorities asked staff questions regarding client safety, the client misunderstood staff's response as being derogatory. Although the above allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that; staff hit minor in care, staff shoved minor in care, and staff speak inappropriately to minor(s) in care. Therefore, these allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Tonya Lashley, Facility Manager.. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: continued from LIC During document research, there was no evidence of any other unauthorized visitors for (C1). Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff allow unauthorized visitors in the home. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED On the allegation of staff allow minors to drink in the home: Based on confidential interviews of staff and clients, all staff and all clients stated that consuming/possessing alcohol is prohibited on or around the facility. Conflicting information was provided stating that some clients drink in the yard and staff confiscate alcohol immediately. Other clients state that they have never seen consumption or possession of alcohol in the facility. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff allow minors to drink in the home. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. On the allegation of staff allow minor to sell marijuana: During confidential interviews, conflicting information was provided. Staff and clients stated that possession and sales of marijuana are prohibited at the facility. Staff state if they see marijuana, it will be confiscated. One client stated that she has never seen marijuana at this facility. Another client stated that she brought marijuana in the facility without the knowledge of staff. Document research shows that there is no evidence that staff allow minors to sell marijuana or paraphernalia of sales such as cash, baggies, or scales found. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that staff allow minor to sell marijuana. Therefore, the above allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Tonya Lashley, Facility Manager, whose signature confirms its receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 11-30-22 1: PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) George Karkazis conducted a complaint investigation with Millie's Youth Services and met with Tonya Lashley, Facility Manager. The purpose of this inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The complaint was taken by Community Care Licensing's (CCL's) Investigative Branch (IB) and assigned to investigator Melissa Weaver. On the allegation of staff allow unauthorized visitors in the home: During confidential interviews, staff (S1), see LIC Confidential Names dated 9-2-22, stated that the client's representative authorized a visit from an unspecified male friend. The client's representative specified that the client (C1) could have one visitor once per month, for one hour. Upon the friend's arrival, staff (S3) took a photo of the visitor's identification. (S3) noticed that the visitor was not age appropriate, immediately reported to (S1), still allowed the visit to occur as there was nothing stating that it was not approved. (S3) supervised the visit, which took place in the backyard, and ensured conversations were appropriate. The visitor left after one hour as directed. continued on LIC 9099-C UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
