At 12:17PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 109 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 71 which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a cabinet in the front room.. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed 1 staff and the client declined the interview. At 12: LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time there were no deficiencies. . An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Tanya Lashley, Facility Manager.

An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio on 08/07/24. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPA met with Facility Manager, and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed two of child's records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility.LPA reviewed two of child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPA interviewed two of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA interviewed two of children currently prescribed psychotropic medication. During the review of staff files LPA observed two of the three staff files to not contain documentation to show the completion of the required annual training. LPA is issuing a citation of Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87065.1(e)(7). See LIC809-D. LPA provided technical support in the form of an advisory for the facility to maintain initial training within the staff files. See LIC Technical Assistance. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to Garrin Davis.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with CEO Jenero Jefferson to conduct the pre- licensing evaluation. The following was observed. This is a 4 bedroom single family dwelling located in the City of Los Angeles. There are 2.5 bathrooms in the home. There are no fireplaces on the premises. There are no bodies of water. There are no security bars on bedroom windows. There are smoke detectors in each bedroom and a carbon monoxide detector in the dining area. There are four fully charged fire extinguishers in the home. There is a locked box for medications and a first aid kit. Three of the bedrooms have two twin beds each with the required linens, drawer and closet space. A fourth bedroom will be used as an office and visitation room. In the dining area there is a dining table with six chairs. There are adequate dishes and utensils for the requested capacity. There is working refrigerator and gas stove The following are required prior to licensure: 1. Arrange beds and bedroom furniture so that they do not block the exit windows. 2. Adjust the water heater to bring hot water to the required temperature 3. Make sure all closet doors are on track. 4. Obtain a phone for the home. 5. Remove debris from the backyard and repair fence. 6. Obtain scissors, thermometer, and a first aid manual for the first aid kit. 7. Adjust front left stove burner so that it lights automatically. 8. Arrange to have the garage open for inspection. 9. Obtain storage for refrigerated medications. LPA will return at a scheduled time to verify corrections.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward conducted a follow-up to the pre-licensing inspection to verify needed corrections: The following were found to be corrected: 1. The beds in the third bedroom were moved to a larger room so that windows are no longer blocked. What was the third bedroom is now reserved as an office space. 2. The hot water temperature was set to the required range. 3. All sliding closet doors are on track. 4. There is phone service and Internet service in the home. 5. The backyard is clear of debris and the fence was repaired. 6.The supply of first aid items is now complete. 7. All stove burners light properly. 8. The garage was opened and found to be empty. 9. There is a box for refrigerated medicines. At this time the facility meets all physical plant requirements.

On February 3, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kenrick Ellis arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing Inspection. LPA met with Thomas Washington, Administrator who provided a tour of the facility. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision for up to six female children ages 7 -17 years old and nonminor dependents aged 18-22, ambulatory only. There is no pool or bodies of water on the premises. The census today is five. The home is set-up as follows: This is a single-story home located in a residential neighborhood with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry area, detached garage, a staff office, and a backyard. Living Room: Equipped with three sofas, a mounted TV, Dining Area: Equipped with a table and six chairs. There is a large black cabinet that contains extra hygiene products for clients with snacks included as well. Kitchen: Equipped with a stove with four working gas burners. A microwave oven mounted above the stove, a dishwasher, and a refrigerator/freezer. There is a large kitchen island located in the center of the kitchen with cabinets for storage of kitchen appliances. The home was not observed to have one week of perishable and non-perishable food.Clients are provided nutritious snacks between meals. Trash can is equipped with a lid. Sharp knives are kept in a locked closet in the staff office. Medications that do not require refrigeration are kept in a locked cabinet in the staff office. There are no clients that require refrigerated medications. Laundry Area: Located along the back wall near the garage. Extra linens are located in a cabinet under the kitchen island. Extra hygiene products for clients and the other contains laundry detergent and cleaning supplies. All cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to clients. Office: Located near the back of the facility across from the kitchen wall and kept locked. The office is equipped with two desks, two chairs, and a closet with facility files. Client and staff files are kept stored in the office and inaccessible to clients. LPA conducted three staff interviews and three client interviews. LPA reviewed three staff records and three client records which contained copies of the Needs and Service Plans and Medical Authorizations signed by each client and their authorized representative. Facility issued technical advisory for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 80076(a)(1). Facility did not produce enough food of quality and in quantity necessary to meet the needs of clients in care. Multiple client interviews and LPA observations provided evidence that facility does not have enough food of quality and quantity for clients in care. Clients in care are always supervised and protected. Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Clients can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. It was reported that clients in care attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities.

Continued on LIC 9099-C Backyard: There is an outdoor seating area as well as a table with two (2) chairs, basketball court, a boxing bag and a BBQ grill. LPA also observed multiple trash cans for recycling and waste. Garage/Shed: The garage is in the back of the house and is used as a storage space. There are tools. ladders and an extra refrigerator for surplus items. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants/cleaning solutions and poisons inaccessible to clients. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures is maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F). All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care locked in a security box that is stored inside staff office #2 upstairs. Chef logs out the knives when they will be used. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. Children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Facility has non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days. Medications locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. Children not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Children accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Children can contact the licensing agency or foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. Facility maintains client cash resources, personal property and valuables. LPA unable to review Children's records at this time due to nature of visit being conducted virtually. Children and staff files will be reviewed at a later date. Adults working/residing in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances. Adults working/residing in the facility have Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations. There were no deficiencies cited at this time of the visit. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to CFO & Facility Manager.

Fannie Linnear - Facility Manager On December 10, 2021 at 12:49pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Mindful Growth Foundation #1 for the purpose of conducting a case management for an incident that occurred on December 6, 2021. investigation_findings: 13Staff returned confiscated marijuana to minor. Staff is harassing youth. Staff perform unreasonable searches of minors' belongings. On February 2, 2022 at 1:33pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Mindful Growth Foundation #1 and spoke with Sherlyn Johnson, Administrator. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the investigation, a total of three (3) clients and five (5) staff were interviewed. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence provided in Special Incident Report #787099 did not substantiate the allegation that staff returned confiscated marijuana to minor. Documentary evidence also reveal client's knowledge and agreement of the house rules as it relates to the policy on marijuana possession and their use on the physical premises of the facility. Confidential interviews conducted did not reveal staff perform unreasonable searches of minors' belongings. Confidential interviews conducted did not reveal staff is harassing youth. LPA obtained signed copies by three (3) clients of the house rules, Code of Ethics, and admissions agreement for the clients in care. LPA also obtained copies of the Special Incident Reports regarding the allegation staff returned confiscated marijuana to minor. Based on the interviews conducted, documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. No deficiencies were observed or cited at the time of this investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator. narrative: On March 22, at 11:00AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Charmetha White made an announced visit to Mindful Growth Foundation #2 for the purpose of conducting an STRTP Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA met with the Chief Executive Officer, Jenero Jefferson who granted access into the home and together a tour was conducted both inside and out. The home will provide care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The census today is zero (0). The facility will also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W & I code 16501.1 (C) (1). The home is set up as follows: This is a three (3) bedroom, two (2) bathroom home is located in a residential neighborhood. The home has a living room, dining room, kitchen, a laundry area, a staffing office, and a detached garage. The Living Room: is equipped with a rectangle wooden storage desk, a sofa, a mounted TV, and has a decorative fireplace mount. Dining Area: is equipped with a wooden table with six (6) chairs, there is also a small desk and chair for client use. Kitchen: is equipped with a stove/oven with five (5) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave, a deep fryer, an air fryer, and a refrigerator/freezer. The home was observed to have one (1) week of nonperishable and two (2) days of perishable food supplies. Bedroom #1: is located off the living room and has a picture window facing the front of the home along with an exit window facing the side of the home. Bedroom # 2: is located to the left of the hallway and has two (2) exit windows facing the side of the home. Bedroom #3: Is located to the right of the hallway, has two (2) exit windows facing the back of the home, and bathroom #2 is located inside of this room. All bedrooms were observed to have adequate closet space and lighting. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located in the hallway between bedroom #2 and #3 and it is equipped with a bath tub/shower combination, a toilet, and a sink. Bathroom #2 is located inside of bedroom #3 and it is equipped with a standing shower, a toilet, and a sink. Both bathrooms were checked and were in operating condition. Laundry Area: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a washer and dryer, it also has a door leading to the back yard. Report continued on LIC 809C. Staffing Office: is located off of the dining room, the room is equipped with a desk, chair, a computer, and it remains locked when not in use by staff. Detached garage: is located in the back of the home and was observed to be used for storage. There are no security bars on the windows. There are no weapons located in the home. All smoke detectors, carbon monoxide, and fire extinguisher were available and working properly in the home. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons items are made inaccessible to clients. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care. Medications are locked in a tool box stored in the staffing office. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide are operable. The home has two (2) regulation fire extinguishers. Children in care are supervised & protected at all times. Children accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children will be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children will be able to contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman in confidence without threats or punishments for making complaints. Children will be accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children will not be restricted in telephone use except by court order. Caregiver will ensure to have written authorization to obtain medical and dental care. Licensee will ensure to have personal rights forms in children's files as well as the Needs and Services plan. Caregiver acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Staff working in the facility have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances, and Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limit. There were no deficiencies cited at this time of the visit. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to the Chief Executive Officer.

On March 8, 2022 at 9:06am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Mindful Growth Foundation #2 for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Thomas Washington, Facility Manager who granted access into the home and together a tour was conducted both inside and out. The home is licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility will also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W & I code 16501.1 (C) (1). The census today is six (6). The home is set up as follows: This is a three (3) bedroom, two (2) bathroom home and is located in a residential neighborhood. The home has a living room, dining area, kitchen, a laundry area, a staff office, and a detached garage. Living Room: Equipped with a rectangle wooden storage desk, a sofa, a mounted TV, and has a decorative fireplace mount. Dining Area: Equipped with a wooden table with six (6) chairs, there is also a small desk and chair for client use. Kitchen: Equipped with a stove/oven with five (5) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave and a refrigerator/freezer combination. The home was observed to have one (1) week of nonperishable and two (2) days of perishable food supplies. Bedroom #1: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds with adequate storage and closet space. Bedroom # 2: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds with adequate storage and closet space. Continued on LIC 809-C Bedroom#3: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds with adequate storage and closet space. (Bathroom #2 is located inside of Bedroom #3). All bedrooms were observed to have adequate lighting, mattresses in good repair and clean linens and bedding. Bathroom #1: Located in the hallway between Bedroom #2 and #3. Documentary evidence of SIR #810391 revealed Client #1 (C1) AWOL'd with another peer on 4/29/2022 and incident was cross reported to all agencies including C1's County Social Worker (CSW). Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator.

narrative: On January 30, 2023 at 8:44am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Mindful Growth Foundation #2 for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Domonique Grigsby, Direct Care Staff and Jasmine Sampson, Executive Director who granted access into the home and together a tour was conducted both inside and out. The home is licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility will also provide services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W & I code 16501.1(C)(1). The census today is six (6). The home is set up as follows: This is a three (3) bedroom, two (2) bathroom home located in a residential neighborhood. The home has a living room, dining area, kitchen, a laundry area, a staff office, and a detached garage. Living Room: Equipped with a rectangle wooden storage desk, a sofa, a mounted TV, and has a decorative fireplace mount. Dining Area: Equipped with a wooden table with six (6) chairs, there is also a small desk and chair for client use. Kitchen: Equipped with a stove/oven with four (4) burners, all working at this time. There is a microwave and a refrigerator/freezer combination. The home was observed to have one (1) week of nonperishable and perishable food supplies. Bedroom #1: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds with adequate storage and closet space. Bedroom # 2: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds with adequate storage and closet space. Bedroom #3: Occupied. Equipped with two (2) twin sized beds with adequate storage and closet space. (Bathroom #2 is located inside of Bedroom #3). Continued on LIC 809-C All bedrooms were observed to have adequate lighting. All beds were observed to have comfortable mattresses, clean linens, blankets, and pillows, all in good repair. Bathroom #1: Located in the hallway between Bedroom #2 and #3. Equipped with a bathtub/shower combination, a toilet, and a sink. Clean and in operable condition. Bathroom #2: (Located inside of Bedroom #3). Equipped with a standing shower, a toilet, and a sink. Clean and in operable condition. Laundry Area: Located off the kitchen. Equipped with an operable washer and dryer. Laundry supplies, cleaning solutions are locked in a cabinet with a key accessible by staff. There is a door leading to the back yard. Staff Office: Located off the dining area. Equipped with a desk, chair, a computer, and it remains locked when not in use by staff. Detached garage: Located in the back of the home and was observed to be used for storage. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. The front and back yards were inspected and found to be clear of hazards and debris. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons items are made inaccessible to clients. All knives and sharp objects are made inaccessible to the clients in care. Medications are locked in a toolbox stored in the staff office. There are no security bars on the windows. There are no weapons located in the home. First aid kit was checked and found to be complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and First Aid Manual. Hot water was tested and is in a safe temperature range All smoke detectors, carbon monoxide detectors tested audible and are working properly. The home is equipped with two (2) fully charged regulation fire extinguishers. During this visit, LPA conducted two (2) client interviews and reviewed five (5) client files which contained copies of Needs and Service Plans and Medical Authorizations signed by each child and their authorized representative. Children in care are supervised and protected. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsperson in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. It was reported that children attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Continued on LIC 809-C LPA conducted three (3) staff interviews and reviewed five (5) staff files. Caregiver(s)/adults working/residing in the home have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Checks. Emergency Mass Disaster Casualty Plan was available for review. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. The home is operating within the capacity and limitations of the license. All other posting requirements were met. Facility vehicle is in good repair with current and valid vehicle registration and insurance. LPA requested and was provided with a current LIC 500. LPA provided facility with new Foster Youth Bill of Rights poster to display. Based on the observations made during today's inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator.

Documentary evidence revealed client's acknowledgement and agreement of the house rules as it relates to the policy on marijuana possession and their use on the physical premises of the facility. LPA obtained copies of the House Rules and Code of Ethics signed by clients, client Needs and Services Plan, staff shift notes, and client incident reports. LPA also obtained signed copies of the incentive plan contract as it relates to the drug policy for the facility. Based on the interviews conducted, documentary evidence, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegation. LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegation occurred, therefore the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. Based on the observations made during today's inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Administrator.

narrative: On 06/16/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian and Licensing Program Manager Melanie Krage conducted an unannounced annual inspection at the above facility. Met at the facility by Administrator Torella Minor. Staff files and client files inspected. An inspection of the physical plant was conducted indoors and outdoors. The facility was clean and sanitary and there were no observable hazards. The temperature was a comfortable temperature and met the intent of the regulation. The food was ample and sufficient for both perishable and nonperishable items. There were no bodies of water at the facility. Per the Administrator, there are no firearms at the facility. The facility has one small dog. The medications are double locked and all chemicals and cleaning agents are locked. The personal rights are posted in the facility. The hot water temperature measured at 106 degrees. The current status of the facility's mental health program and accreditation status are discussed with the Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date.

On July 7, 2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian conducted a case management inspection at the above facility. Met at the facility by Executive Director Torella Minor. The purpose of the inspection was to discuss the status of the facility's mental health program approval. The 24 month provisional license for the facility expires on July 11, 2021. Ms. Minor was informed by the county that a site inspection would be conducted prior to the July 11, 2021 expiration of the provisional, however, at this time the inspection has not been scheduled. Ms. Minor will contact the county on this date to attempt to schedule an inspection. Community Care Licensing will be immediately informed on whether an inspection will be completed prior to the expiration of the license. Ms. Minor will also submit a closure plan and client roster to Community Care Licensing on this date. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date.

narrative: On the above date, a meeting was held via Microsoft Teams. Present were Licensing Program Analysts Lisa Slusher and Tamara Melikian and Licensing Program Manager Lourey Bartolome. During this call, the upcoming deadline for Accreditation was discussed. It is noted that the agency is already beyond the 24 month regulatory requirement for Accreditation. FFPSA (Family First Prevention Services Act) legislation requires Accreditation by 10/1/21. Currently the agency is scheduled for an accreditation survey by CARF in mid-October, but is trying to schedule the survey for earlier. Administrator Torella Minor will contact the authorized representatives for the 3 youth currently placed in the facility, will contact CARF and inquire about survey/accreditation target dates, and will contact the Foster Care Rates Bureau. An update will be provided to community care licensing.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess had a call with Administrator Misty Jackson to complete this case management inspection. LPA met with Administrator via Google Duo, a video conferencing application. LPA also met with Administrator Kamiko Lucas. At 9: AM, LPA conducted a virtual walk-through of the facility, led by Administrator. LPA observed no deficiencies. CCL received an incident report on 10/27/2020 dated 10/19/2020 reporting that during a facility outing on a hike, client C1 (see confidential names list dated 11/5/2020) appeared tired at the end. C1 stopped to take a break and staff waited with her. Staff noticed C1 becoming disoriented by mumbling her words. Client then collapsed and was unresponsive. Staff called for assistance and 911. Other staff arrived with water for C1 but C1 was unresponsive. First responders arrived 15 minutes later and client was transported to a hospital, and later transported to a different hospital and a Liver Transplant unit for further treatment. On the same hike, another client, C2, became dehydrated. LPA is investigating what was provided to clients during the hike as far as food and water, why client went to the Liver Transplant unit, and what the outcome is. The incident report did not describe the outcome of C1's health. In speaking with Administrators Misty Jackson and Kamiko Lucas, LPA learned that C1 brought her own 32 ounce water bottle on the hike and had it refilled once, as well as got an additional 8 ounces. Clients had lunch for 1 hour. The hike was 7 miles, easy level, and they could go as slow as they wanted. C1's condition is improving and she did not need a liver transplant. LPA collected contact information for staff and C1's parents. LPA learned that C2 was provided with food and water as well. This case management requires further investigation into C1's case before a resolution can be made. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Lucas, and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: After releasing FY2 the foster youths ran through a pasture and onto a neighboring yard. S3 confirmed seeing FY2 hit S2 in the face. S4 did not witness any assaultive behaviors by staff or foster youths. S3 and S4 verified the two foster youths ran through a pasture to a neighbor's yard. FY1 and FY2 were both unavailable for statements. Based on the interviews conducted the allegations that staff inappropriately grabbed a minor in care, staff hit minors while in care, and staff inappropriately restrained a minor, are UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to Misty Jackson.

Based on interviews, the facility's quick action is what saved the client's life. The client's condition is not a fault of the facility, and could not have been predicted. facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess had a call with Administrator, Misty Jackson, to deliver this case management inspection. LPA met with Administrator via Google Duo, a video conferencing application. On 7/24/ CCL received an incident report dated 7/19/2020 describing a client in crisis who left the facility and walked to Walmart. While in Walmart, the client hid from staff, grabbed some items, went into the bathroom, then left Walmart. The client approached strangers asking them to call Law Enforcement (LE), but they did not respond. Staff attempted to talk to the client but the client was not receptive and ran away to a nearby Shell gas station where she again solicited help in calling LE, but was denied. LE arrived and the client told them that she was being mentally abused at this facility. LE counselled the client and eventually she returned to the facility. The client wanted to call her mother and someone else that she was not permitted to call. Staff asked the client to take a time-out before the call with her mother. The client left the facility again and LE was called. LE attempted to talk to the client but the client walked back towards the facility and picked up rocks and threw them at the facility vehicle, breaking the windshield and driver side window. LE detained the client in handcuffs and returned her back to the facility. Staff made a plan with the client and she was released from the handcuffs. The client started a time-out but stopped and picked up a "log-sized" stick and charged into the facility vehicle's windshield, breaking it more. LE instructed the client to put the stick down but she did not. LE pulled their taser out and threatened the client that they would use it if she did not put the stick down. The client refused and LE told her to get on her stomach, which she did. The client was then placed in handcuffs and detained once more. The client was taken to Juvenile Hall. LPA investigated this case management by interviewing six clients and three staff on 8/12/2020, 12/15/2020, and 12/23/2020. During interviews with clients, they stated at least one staff in particular has been speaking to clients in a way which is aggressive, intimidating, and mentally abusive. During LPA's interviews with the clients, both former and current, they brought up this staff's name independently and gave similar kinds of examples for how this staff spoke to them and others in an inappropriate or abusive way. During LPA's interviews with staff, they denied that staff had said the things that were alleged. Staff stated that the accused staff is a firm or strict staff, but denied any abusive behavior. The accused staff denied all abusive claims, but did state that she has had trouble with her tone and how she comes off to the clients. The staff stated that because of that she could possibly be seen as abusive by the clients, however that is not the case. The staff stated she has been working on this issue with her tone of voice, as well as keeping the clients accountable so they can successfully graduate from the program. The staff recognized that she needed to correct her tone because the clients can come from environments in which people were abusive. The staff explained that she is the staff that enforces rules and holds the clients accountable, which they do not like. Based on all the information given, it is evident that while the staff many not have set out to intentionally cause harm to the clients with the way she speaks, that is the effect it has had on the clients. Clients stated this has created a negative affect on their mental health and emotional health, and has affected their behavior and program success. The way the staff speaks to the clients is at times not trauma-informed and has resulted in the clients feeling mentally abused. On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1, Section 87072(d)(11). At 4: PM, an exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was sent to her by email with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: During that AWOL incident, the client ingested glass in the presence of staff when they caught up to her and was hospitalized because of it. LPA addressed the client's dangerous ingestion of harmful objects previously with the facility during Case Managements dated 3/13/2020 and 6/25/2020. On 6/25/ LPA issued an advisory notice advising staff to ensure they take into consideration clients' previous behavior patterns to assess at what point they should physically intervene when a client is being unsafe. The same client ingested glass pieces and broke her tooth while biting a pen during an incident that lasted from 2: PM to 3: PM on 3/30/2020. Staff did not physically intervene until after the client was able to self harm by ingesting the items. During IB's investigation an individual stated that the client needed 1 on 1 supervision. IB found that the lack of supervision allegation that a resident was hospitalized from incident that occurred while in care is SUBSTANTIATED, or true. Additionally in IB's investigation there were statements made about staff treating the clients poorly. This was addressed by LPA during a Case Management dated 12/23/2020. LPA cited the facility on that date. During IB's investigation, another staff's name was mentioned who treated the clients poorly, however that staff no longer works at the facility. IB found that the facility did not report the incident to the authorized representatives timely. The mother of the child did not know there was an incident until she was contacted by the hospital days later requesting permission to anesthetize the client in the hospital. The assigned County Social Worker was not notified until days after with a partial report. Then, the CSW received a full report the following week. IB found the allegation that the facility did not report the incident to the authorized representatives to be SUBSTANTIATED, or true. On this date the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Sections 80078(a) and 80061(f). At 11: AM an exit interview was conducted with Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to Administrator with a read receipt which will serve as her signature.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess called the facility to inform them that she needed to deliver the findings to this complaint. LPA met with Administrator Kamiko Lucas over FaceTime, a video conferencing application. Based on IB's interviews and records reviews, IB found that the client had a history of ingesting harmful objects and had other self-injurious behaviors. IB found that the client was not followed right away when she AWOL'd from the facility on 7/18/2020. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Administrator Misty Jackson and staff Sydney Barber, who assisted with this inspection. LPA and Staff conducted a walk-through of the facility. LPA observed three clients present. Two clients are home for visits, and one client was just recently discharged. LPA observed no deficiencies. CCL received an incident report on 12/14/2021 and 12/15/2021 which described a client being restrained by staff, and then by police officers, due to the client's behaviors and for safety. After the restraints, the client complained of wrist pain and was taken to the ER the following day where the client was diagnosed with a broken arm. The incident report states that it was after the restraint with the police officers that the client disclosed pain, and that it was the officers who were too rough with the client. LPA is investigating this incident report to gather more information and to speak with the client, staff, and Administrator. The client is currently not at the facility, but is on a family visit. LPA interviewed one client, one staff, one facility manager, and the Administrator. LPA collected staff schedules and contact information. Further investigation is required in order to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report was emailed to her with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Regarding the allegation that staffs' behavior posed a risk to clients in care, this concerned two areas - staff being on their phones and not paying attention to clients, and one male staff being inappropriate with one client in care. During interviews, all but one interview corroborated that the male staff was not inappropriate towards that client, even when the client was being inappropriate towards him. The staff met with the client and the client's therapist to help in setting boundaries. The staff made all attempts and efforts to stay away from that client. LPA found no basis in the accusation that this staff was inappropriate towards the client. LPA learned that staff used to be on their phones sometimes when they were not supposed to. The facility addressed this at the time by discussing phone rules with them while they are working. Even though staff would be on their phones sometimes during working hours, they also communicated with each other about work, or taking work notes. While the staff may or may not have been on their phones when they weren't supposed to be, there was not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that this did or did not pose a risk to clients in care, therefore LPA has found this allegation to be unsubstantiated. Regarding the allegation that staff withheld food from clients while in care, statements made during interviews were conflicting. All staff denied this allegation occurred. Two clients stated it occurred, however gave different stories about how it occurred. One client denied this ever occurred. Based on the conflicting information, LPA found that while this allegation may have occurred or is valid, there was not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that it did or did not occur, therefore LPA has found it to be unsubstantiated. For the allegation claiming that staff inappropriately restrained a client while in care, LPA also received conflicting information. Two clients stated they have not been in, nor observed an inappropriate restraint from any staff. All staff denied inappropriately restraining any client in care. One staff stated that one staff does grip too tightly during restraints, but does not bend or twist the client in an inappropriate way; the holds are appropriate. Based on the conflicting information, LPA found that while this allegation may have occurred or is valid, there was not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that it did or did not occur, therefore LPA has found it to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with FM, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was emailed to FM with a read receipt which will serve as the record of receipt.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: On 05/23/22, at 10: AM,, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Connie Goldie, met with Program Manager (PM)Misty Jackson to conduct an unannounced Annual/ Required inspection of a single story, four bedroom, 2 bath home. At 10: AM, Staff Francine Rivera greeted LPA Goldie and shared that PM Jackson was on her way in. PM arrived at 10: AM and stated that the current census was six clients. An Entrance Checklist was provided to the PA. LPA Goldie conducted the physical plant inspection with PM Jackson. The tour began at 10: AM in the laundry room. LPA Goldie observed a functioning washer and dryer, the Foster Youth Rights were posted along with youth in care schedules. LPA Goldie advised PM to obtain updated Foster Youth Rights posters. We proceeded to the office area, where LPA Goldie observed the license, the emergency intervention plan, the activity schedule and the menu for week 4. LPA observed two individual bedrooms with clean linens and a closet space. Each of these bedrooms had dressers with drawers that needed repair- missing knobs. The tour continued to the kitchen where PM opened all cabinets, perishable food for two days and non-perishable food for five days, adequate table ware and clean sink and stove were observed. Cleaning supplies were inaccessible and compliant. The living room/ dining area were spacious and allowed seating for clients and visitors and clear pathways were observed. Fire extinguisher pin in place, smoke detector and fire alarms tested and compliant. The home temperature was a comfortable 68 degrees. Bedrooms 3 and 4 had two beds with clean linens, dresser storage, and closet space. Water temperature tested at 111 degrees in bathroom within compliant range. Two bathrooms were observed to have soap and paper towels. Clients hygiene and extra linens available.Medication was adequately stored in locked cabinet in locked office. Outside LPA Goldie observed three swings, a space to take time as needed and an area free of debris. All windows and screens were in good condition. The three vehicles all contained first aid kits and were clean. Continued on LIC809C LPA Goldie interviewed 3 clients , C1, C2 and C3 and two staff PM and Mental Health worker. One Title Violation , type B is being issued today. Additionally, a technical advisory and a technical violation are also being issued. These are not deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted with PM Jackson at 4: PM. A copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Interviews were conducted and with six facility staff, four youth, three law enforcement officers, a medical professional and guardian from 5/3/2022- 7/19/2022. (See LIC 811, dated on 8/4/2022). Sacramento County Sheriff Report was obtained on 5/2/2022, resulting in an unsubstantiated allegation. Medical records were obtained on 5/24/2022. The allegation is whether Staff 1 (S1) sexually assaulted Youth 1 (Y1) in a bathroom at the facility. Y1 reported being sexually assaulted in a facility bathroom by S1. Y1 was interview by law enforcement then subsequently by Investigator Weaver. The details Y1 reported were not consistent in both statements. Y1 later admitted to lying about the incident due to being "mad". S1 denied the allegation. Additional interviews, three days of video surveillance and medical records did not corroborate or exclude the allegation. Based on the investigation, camera surveillance, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: According to the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan and Interim Licensing Standard 87095.22(f)(2)(a), written approval is required from the administrator or designee (not staff involved in the restraint) to continue a restraint past 15 minutes. In addition, C1 should have been checked for any possible injuries which was not assessed. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D for the violations of Interim Licensing Standard, Article 6, 87095.22(f)(2)(a), and 87095.01(a)(14) which is an immediate risk to the health and safety or personal rights of minors in care. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email. However, C1 was not receptive during this incident. The facility's internal investigation and interviews conducted with two staff and C1, were not able to confirm all of the statements made by staff to C1, it is not possible to determine if any statements were inappropriate. The last allegation is whether staff members yelled at C1 during an incident on 7/4/22. C1 admitted to yelling at staff during the incident and restraint on 7/4/22. C1 was able to provide details that C1 was yelling about. C1 made general statements that staff yelled at her, but C1 was not able to provide any details of the comments. Three staff denied yelling at C1. No specific details of statements made by staff to C1 were described or corroborated as "yelling". Therefore, it is not possible to determine if any staff yelled at C1 during the incident and restraint on 7/4/22. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint findings are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

The facility's internal investigation and interviews conducted with three staff and C1 confirm the restraint lasted for more than 15 minutes, despite not documenting the exact length of the restraint. facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Monica Roberts made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Administrator (Admin) Misty Jackson and Facility Manager (FM) De'Jana Crockett, who assisted with the inspection. LPAs and staff conducted a walk-through of the facility and found there to be clean and adequate bedding, supplies, an adequate amount of perishable and non-perishable food, the house was at a comfortable temperature, there were no obstructions in the halls or walkways, and there was an adequate amount of silverware, plates, and cups and they were in good condition. LPAs observed one window screen in an unoccupied client room to be in disrepair, the excess refrigerator in the shed to be dirty, and ziplock bags in the chemical cabinet, which would be used for food. LPA instructed staff to move the ziplock bags, that the refrigerator needs to be cleaned, and the screen repaired. License and complaint procedure were posted. LPAs observed the facility vehicle to have a cracked windshield, spidering across the entire windshield in three directions, the air conditioning in the car works, and the car turned on. LPAs observed no evidence of smoking in the facility or on the grounds as required. There was no cushioned material under the swingset, and the swingset was secured to the ground as required. There was a vent grate coming off of the side of the trailer building, which needs to be secured. The kitchen water temperature measured at 129.5, which is above the required range of 105 to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The blinds in the kitchen were not clean. LPAs reviewed the clients' allowances and found all to be accurate. LPAs reviewed the client medications and found all Medication Administration Records to have all required elements on them, and all client medications were maintained appropriately. LPA reviewed the disaster drill logs and found the facility to be conducting them as required. On this date the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 5, Chapter 1, Section 80074(c) Transportation, and 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds. Additionally, the facility is receiving five Technical Violation Advisory Notes, which are not citations, lack of cushioning under the swings, not having a register of clients per regulation, and the ziplock bags being stored in with the chemicals, and the water being inconsistent temperatures, occasionally exceeding the 120 degree limit. An exit interview was conducted with Admin and FM and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with them.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) De'jana Crockett who assisted with the inspection. LPA spoke with staff and clients regarding the facility. During confidential interviews with three staff, one Administrator, one Clinician, and two clients, LPA found that in the past around 2020, clients have been made to be outside for extended periods of time, and denied entrance into the facility. One client stated a client had to stay outside the facility for a few hours after returning from an AWOL. Another client stated they were not allowed inside of the facility because they were a, "danger," to the others. The client stated they were outside for the whole day, and this happened on about three occasions. One staff confirmed that client had been outside for many hours before, and was not allowed inside. The staff described that client as a, "trouble-maker." The client had AWOLd and was self-harming. The client had repeatedly run away that day and when returned, the staff and another staff were told to keep the client isolated and in timeout, so for a half a day, that client was made to stay outside in the timeout spot. When LPA asked that staff if the client was ever outside overnight, the staff stated no, however, "for almost all day [the client] would be out there for her not being respectful or being off baseline. We would separate [the client] from the girls and let her be isolated." LPA asked the staff how often that client or other clients would be left outside like that and the staff stated, "if I had to guess...[the client] was our main problem-child and we had to deal with her everyday and I would say she was out there four to five times a week...when she was bad, she was bad, so we would rather have her outside than disrupting the group inside." The staff stated that client was, "out there sometimes all day." When LPA asked the staff if that client had to be outside in the dark, the staff confirmed the client did. When LPA asked the staff if the client was locked out of the facility, the staff confirmed, and stated it was because the client wanted to harm the other clients inside the facility so the client was locked outside to protect the other clients inside. One staff stated that if clients are escalated outside, they do not want the clients to come inside and harass the other clients, or break things, so they keep them outside. Another staff confirmed that clients have to stay outside the facility until they are calm. LPA asked the staff about the client being locked outside, with staff there, and the staff confirmed this, stating, "yeah, until she calmed down." The Clinician confirmed that one of the clients was kept outside a lot, and not allowed back in. The Clinician explained, "their standard is they have to show they are back in program to come back in." The Administrator stated they do not keep clients outside for hours, "but an incident could last for hours with a client that's outside." The Administrator also confirmed that clients could be outside in the timeout shelter at nighttime if they are off baseline. Administrator also confirmed that if a client is outside and wants to come in to harm another client, they are not allowed inside. Based on the collective information gathered, LPA found that the facility inappropriately kept clients outside of the facility. Although the facility is now a Group Home, at the time this occurred they were still a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program, therefore Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1 (2020), Section 87072(d)(11), Personal Rights is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with FM, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with her.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-BAR DU
narrative: One staff stated clients were not denied any meals, "unless they were off baseline and weren't acting right we'd be like, 'you get a snack,' it's too late for dinner." The staff stated that even when they made the snacks (items like chicken nuggets or something similar), the clients always ate something, and this happened on at least two occasions. One staff denied that clients had food withheld and stated if there were escalations during mealtime they would call another staff over to help and ensure the clients got to eat. Another staff stated if there were escalations during dinner time, the clients would get sandwiches. The Clinician and Administrator had no knowledge of food being withheld. Regarding the allegation that staff caused an injury to minor in care, confidential interviews revealed the following: one client does not remember that happening. One client stated they do not think this happened. Another client stated there was an escalation one time where a staff grabbed a client by the wrist, hard, which was not during a restraint. One client stated they had bruises and their arm hurt after being restrained. That client stated the staff intentionally hurt them and grabbed them hard. The client also stated they did not receive medical care for the injury, however this was unable to be corroborated. All staff and Administrators denied having knowledge that medical care was not obtained when any client needed it. One staff stated they never witnessed any staff hurting a client. One staff stated they have hurt a client before unintentionally during restraints due to clients squirming, however when told that the client was hurting, the staff loosened their grip or rearranged. When asked if the staff has ever lashed out physically to a client, the staff admitted that they may have held onto a client tighter. The Clinician stated that staff have, "probably," hurt a client during a restraint because that's the nature of them, "the fight between bodies." One staff thought they remembered one client's arm hurting after a restraint but did not remember the details. Both Administrators had no knowledge of this occurring. While staff may have unintentionally caused discomfort to clients during restraints, there was not a preponderance of the evidence that staff caused injury to them. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with her. When one Administrator was asked what does taking clients' shoes after an AWOL have to do with safety, the Administrator stated, "if the client shoes were taken we would go back and look at why were the shoes taken for AWOLing, it would just have to be looking at who that kid was and why," which did not answer the question. The Administrator stated that sometimes clients AWOLed with no shoes on. The Clinician confirmed that staff took away clients' shoes, but stated clients were not made to go outside without their shoes. When LPA asked one staff what the circumstances would be that a client would not have their shoes, the staff stated, "if they AWOLed and they wouldn't have shoes." LPA asked the staff if that is because staff would take clients' shoes if they AWOLed, which they responded yes." This instruction came from the supervisors. Two staff and one Administrator stated that clients would also AWOL without their shoes. Interviews with staff revealed client shoes would be confiscated from clients for up to two days. When LPA asked one staff why the shoes are taken away, the staff stated, ""so it's easier to restrain [them] and not let [them] run away." When LPA asked one staff if a particular client had to be outside without shoes on, the staff confirmed and stated, ""we took [the client's] shoes off all the time, well not all the time, but it was more of a repeated offence in the same day, so we would take [the client's] shoes." Interviews with clients revealed that clients did have to be outside without their shoes on. One client stated that they would have to go to the, "timeout shelter," outside when the client was off baseline. This included when the client did not have any shoes on, and the client was not permitted to put them on. Another client stated when they went outside their shoes were confiscated, so the client was not able to put them on. The client also stated that on one occasion they had to go outside in the timeout shelter with no shoes on when it was rainy and cold outside. Staff confirmed that the timeout shelter was used to take timeouts for the clients. Another client stated their shoes were taken away for it, "being a danger," that they would AWOL, and they had to do PE outside with no shoes. Two clients stated the shoes would be confiscated for up to a week. LPA learned from interviews with staff that they are no longer taking clients' shoes, and this only happened in the past. Based on interviews LPA conducted, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Although the facility is now a Group Home, at the time of this allegation they were still a Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program, therefore Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards, Version 3.1 (2020), Section 87072(d)(11), Personal Rights is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with FM, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with her.

This specific regulation allows for reasonable restrictions in the implementation of clients receiving and making confidential phone calls, including (2) "Restrict phone use in accordance with the facility discipline program. (3) Impose restrictions to ensure that phone use does not infringe on the rights of others or restrict the availability of the phone during emergencies." And (c)(8)(B) "All restrictions shall be documented in the child's needs and service plan or the facility's discipline policies, and be signed by the child's authorized representative." The facility discipline program includes "direction following" and timeouts when the client is "out of program" and escalated or dysregulated. Client Needs and Service Plans were obtained and reviewed, which includes detailed limitations for each client and is signed and authorized. According to the facility's policy " Client Phone Policy and Procedure", restrictions include: 1) "phone calls are not scheduled during school..." hours (onsite); 2) "...mental health group times..." 3) "...calls are limited to 15 minutes to ensure all residents the opportunity to make calls." In addition, it acknowledges these restrictions do not apply to "Exceptions: clients can place calls to CCL, a parent, guardian, attorney, CASA Worker, Foster Care Ombudsperson or placement worker at any time.) Details in client interviews were not corroborated due to the lack of specifics. So, it is not possible to determine whether all restrictions of phone usage were in compliance with the ILS. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.

met_with: Misty Jackson, Administrator and Tara Silafau, Program Director
narrative: The first allegation is whether "Direction Following" and timeouts outside during days of extreme heat were inappropriate forms of discipline. Online research concluded there were 12 days in August and 9 days in September 2022 that temperatures exceeded 100 degrees, of which 10 were consecutive days. However, resources did not conclude on a specific duration that was unhealthy to be outside but identified other risk factors to consider like water intake, type of clothing, and specific time of day. The facility's program statement regarding their "Positive Discipline Policies" does not include specifics on direction following and timeouts. In addition, the agency does not have an extreme weather policy that addresses how their program will adjust client discipline or other outdoor activities. All client interviews reported generally being outside up to 20 minutes for disciplinary type reasons. However, due to the other risk factors are unknown like water intake, type of clothing, and specific time of day, it is not possible to determine if the regular discipline practices were inappropriate during this specific time. The next allegation is whether staff is rude or yells at clients. All staff and client interviews lacked any specific details or situations that could be compared or corroborated. Interviews were consistent that some clients and staff talk loudly in the facility, but less clear if the yelling is directed at clients. Some interviews said there were no incidents of disrespectful or rude behavior or language by staff. However, since inadequate details were available, it is not possible to confirm whether the allegation occurred or not. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email. The allegation is whether the facility meets the staff to client ratio of 1:3 during morning and evening shifts. Client interviews included a variety of details when only one staff was present: during "1:1" (specific supervision of unsafe clients), and when a staff leaves to follow a client who has left the facility without permission. The interviews did not clearly indicate a violation of staffing ratio since additional details were unknown, like when additional staff arrive. However, four of eight staff interviews confirm the staffing ratio was not 1:3, during various escalations and additional staff either was not scheduled or available. Some staff believed the approved ratio was 1:4. Escalation that result in restraints can also result in staffing ratio not being met. Based on the investigation, records reviewed and interviews conducted, this allegation is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D for the violations of Interim Licensing Standard, Article 6, 87065.5 (a)(1) which are an immediate risk to the health and safety or personal rights of minors in care. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were provided to the facility via email.
