narrative: On November 7, 2024 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Sarah Lo, arrived unannounced at New Alternatives, Inc. # Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Susan Shannon, Senior Manager and Att Yuwana, Program Director, arrived shortly after. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. Susan Shannon, Senior Manager and Att Yuwana, Program Director led the physical inspection of the facility. The front building consists of a Therapy room, a Visitation room, a Clinic office, a Quality Assurance office, a Residential Director, a Clinic Director office, and an activity room. The back building consists of nine bedrooms, seven toilets rooms, one half bathroom and one full bathroom. There is a common area with a couch and television for clients to rest, a staff office, a dining room, a kitchen, a laundry area, a storage room and a medication room. There is a shed in the backyard of the facility used to store miscellaneous items. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed and no more than two clients share a bedroom. LPA began a physical plant inspection and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean, free of debris and hazards free. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Books, TV, basketball court, bicycles, scooters, roller skates and games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; there are two fire extinguishers in the front building and four fire extinguishers in the back building and are properly charged and serviced. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food to prepare the items on the posted menu. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. (continued on LIC 809c) Refrigerators are located in the front and back building and are maintained in a good temperature. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan, etc. The medications are locked and centrally stored in the back building inside a locked room. The medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. The chemicals/poisons are locked in a closet inside the kitchen area in the back building and inside the staff room in the front building. All sharp objects are locked and stored in the locked cabinet in the kitchen area. There are two First Aid Kits and are stored in the medication room and in the front office. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Seven bedrooms contained two twin beds and two bedrooms contained one twin bed. The facility has seven toilets that are attached to the bedrooms with two bedrooms sharing one toilet, one half bathroom containing a shower and bathtub and one full bathroom containing a shower, bathtub and toilet for the clients to use. The hot water in the client's bathrooms were deemed safe and measured between 105 to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Per Susan Shannon, Senior Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The Program Director, Att Yuwana, is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one Program Director, four Supervisors, twelve Child Care Workers, one Clinical Director, and two Clinicians. The board of director meeting minutes were provided. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF and the Accreditation is valid through September 30, 2026. The facility annual licensing fees are paid to current. Licensee has mental health approval and good until March 13, 2025. LPA reviewed five out of seven client files during the time of inspection and each file met the minimum requirement per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All client records reviewed had the required documents including admission agreements, personal rights, medical history, immunization records, medical consent form, and an initial or updated needs and services plan on file. Client files were kept in a locked file cabinet within the staff office. (continued LIC 809c) LPA reviewed five staff files and each file met the minimum requirement per the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). All personnel records reviewed have the verification of Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigations, and Child Abuse Index Check clearances. All staff have proof in file of acknowledging confidentiality and mandated child abuse reporting requirements. All personnel records reviewed met the required education and experience requirement. All personnel records reviewed had a completed physical exam on file. Due to time constraint, the annual inspection will be continued at a later date to conduct staff and client interviews. Based on the findings of today's visit, the facility will be cited for one Type B violation. A exit interview was conducted. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Att Yuwana, Program Director.

On 05/21/25, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Porsha Draper (Clinical Director), Danielle Saporita (Program Director), and Susan Shannon (Senior Manager), for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve 16 ambulatory children ages six to 13 years old. The current census is five children. The Facility is a single story dwelling. A physical plant inspection was completed with Cynthia Harrison, Supervisor (S4 - See Confidential Names List) and included the following checks: kitchen, medication room, dining room, living room, five staff offices, visitation room, sensory room, and outdoor living space. A couple of bedrooms contain two twin beds, and other bedrooms contained one twin bed. The facility has three hallway bathrooms, and some bedrooms contain an entry to a private bathroom. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. No bedroom occupied more than one client and not used for other purposes. The water temperature was tested in bathroom one which measured 118 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to all staff and had all required supplies. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. **Continued on LIC809C** . **Continued from LIC809** Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. All client files are stored in the medical records office. LPA reviewed five client files (C1 - C5) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. Client files had education records, physical examinations, Needs and Services plans, and case manager notes were digitally stored and accessible to LPA. LPA also reviewed five client medication records. Due to time constraints, LPA will return on another day to conduct client and staff interviews, and review staff file reviews. LPA conducted two staff interviews (S3 and S4) and one client interview (C1). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. An exit interview was conducted, this report was discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Danielle Saporita. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file

On 05/30/25, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Clinical Director, Porsha Draper, and Senior Manager, Susan Shannon, for the purpose of conducting the continuation of the annual inspection of the facility that began on 05/21/25. The Facility is licensed to serve 16 ambulatory children ages six to 13 years old. The current census is five children. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a single story dwelling. A shortened physical plant inspection was completed with Allison Leather, Supervisor and included the following checks: kitchen, dining room, living room, visitation room, sensory room, and outdoor living space. LPA reviewed five staff records (S4-S8) and five client (C1-C5) records, please refer to Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 5/30/2025. All staff files are stored in the locked Quality Assurance office in a locked cabinet. Files were reviewed to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. All staff files also had applications, job descriptions, resumes, physical health screenings, driver's licenses, and training certificates. All client files are stored in the locked Quality Assurance office located next to the Clinical Director's office in a locked file cabinet. Review of the files indicated that three (C2, C4, and C5) out of five clients did not have a required TB test within the regulated timeframe. All other required documents met Community Care Licensing Standards. ***Continued on LIC809C** **Continued from LIC809 dated 5/30/25** LPA conducted one staff interview (S7) and one client interview (C1). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Client Records, Section 80069(c)(1) The medical assessment shall include the following: The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. An exit interview was conducted, a plan of correction was created, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, LIC811, and appeal rights were provided to Susan Shannon, Senior Manager. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On June 9, 2021, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Jose Gonzalez and Babatunde Aborchie conducted an unannounced annual inspection. LPAs were met at the facility by Administrator Pernell Sullivan. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the medication room. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be complete. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. LPAs also, observed on the female side of the facility in bedroom #2, closet doors need to be repainted, in bedroom #3, right wall need to be repainted, in bedroom #8, one of two blinds were damaged. Restroom #1 had multiple brown spots where the ceiling and wall connect and bathroom #2 shower head was leaking. On the male's side of the facility bedroom #4 closet doors need to be painted, bedroom #5 closet doors need to be painted, and bedroom #7 tagging on the wooden bed frame. The hot water in two of the six client restrooms was measured to be 96.8 degrees in the girls' restroom and 121.2 degrees in the boys' restroom. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of client and staff file reviews, as well as conduct interviews with clients. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator Pernell Sullivan.

On June 14, 2021 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jose Gonzalez conducted an unannounced case management Inspection to continue the annual that began on June 9, 2021. LPA met with Administrator, Pernell Sullivan at time of inspection. LPA disclosed the purpose of the inspection. Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in directors office in a locked cabinet. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. A review of client records was also completed on this date. Per client file reviews, LPA observed TB tests were missing in 6 out of 9 files reviewed. Technical Assistant Advisory Notes (TA) will be issued. Client and staff interviews were conducted and revealed that the staff is aware of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program. Client interviews revealed that the clients are aware of the personal rights and they are involved in their Client and Family Team Meetings. LPA requested the recent board meeting be provided to CCL by June 21, 2012 at 11:00am. A copy of this report and the advisory notice was provided to Administrator Pernell Sullivan.

interviews reported A1 was specifically told to drop the Xanax in the bushes of the facility between 10:00pm and 10:30pm because there are less staff members watching residents during those hours. Confidential interviews confirmed the facility had one staff member (Staff #1 (S1)) in the girls' cottage with six residents at the time of the incident. Confidential interviews confirmed that S1 had set up movie night for the residents and was busy cleaning and therefore S1's attention was not fully on what the residents were doing. Confidential interviews revealed that due to S1's attention not fully being on the residents C1 was able to remove C1's bedroom screen climb out of the bedroom, retrieve the Xanax left by A1 from the bushes and return to C1's room, at which point C1 and C2 were able to consume 3 tablets. Record review confirmed at approximately 11:00 pm S1 checked on C1 and C2 and observed C1 to be "walking funny" and C2 to be unresponsive. Record review revealed C1 and C2 were taken to the Emergency room where both C1 and C2 tested positive for Benzodiazepine (Xanax). Based on confidential interviews, and record review of county, medical and facility documentation, the allegation foster youth (Child #1 (C1) and Child #2 (C2)) overdosed on Xanax while in care is substantiated. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards v.4, regulation 87065.2(b)(1) Personnel Duties (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties (1) Supervision, protection, and care for children at all times, individually and in groups. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to New Alternatives, Inc. Program Manager, Pernell Sullivan.

narrative: On December 21, 2022, at 10:00 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted an announced Pre-Licensing inspection at New Alternatives Inc. LPA met with Pernell Sullivan, Administrator. The facility is decreasing there census from 30 clients to 16 clients. This facility consisted of 2 halls (The boy hall and the girl hall.) The Boy hall consisted of 8 bedrooms, 8 beds, 4 bathrooms, a living room and was single story. The Girl hall consisted of 8 bedrooms, 8 beds, 4 bathrooms, a living room and was single story. In the middle of both halls there was a joint kitchen that connected/separated both halls (boys and girls.) A physical plant inspection was completed on both halls and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than one client resided in each room. Each client is accorded there own mattress, bed and room. There is adequate shelving and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom's and in the kitchen was measured to be 111 degrees, which is in range (105 degrees and 120 degrees). All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and double locked in a cabinet in the Medication room. Cleansers/chemicals are double locked and inaccessible to client and were located in a closet in the hallway. The First Aid Kit is located in the medication room. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallways were operable. The carbon monoxide detector located in hallways were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Pernell Sullivan, Administrator. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. The postings were located in each hall. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility has two cameras on the outside of the home and one camera in the kitchen.. Sharp knives were made inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen The facility has demonstrated compliance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal was provided to Pernell Sullivan, Administrator.

On June 15, 2023, at 10:20AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Garcia arrived to the facility unannounced for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPM Valenzuela and LPA Garcia met with Assistant Program Manager, Diana Post. The facility is licensed for 16 ambulatory clients. There are currently nine clients in placement; three female and six males. LPM Valenzuela and LPA Garcia reviewed five client files and five staff files. All staff files contained training documents, TB tests, Driver Licenses and clearances: Department of Justice, Federal Bureau of Investigations, and Child Abuse Index Clearance. All staff met the Title 22 requirements within there scope of employment. Clients files were complete, which included placement documents, Psychotropic Authorizations (JV-220), TB Tests, Needs and Service plans, and visitations. LPA Garcia and LPM Valenzuela interviewed two client and two staff were unavailable due to client and family team meeting. Due to time constraints this annual inspection will be completed at another date and time. Based on the file reviews, there are no deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and was given to Assistant Program Manager, Diana Post.

On the date listed above at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced to the facility for the purpose of conducting collateral interviews with two clients that are currently residing at the facility. LPA met with Brian Xu, Residential Supervisor, and explained that the complaint investigation is not on their facility. LPA conducted one interview with one client and one client declined to be interviewed. LPA toured the facility and the facility was in compliance with Title 22 regulations, Chapter 5, therefore no deficiencies were cited. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Administrator.

On 04/24/25, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez met with Diana Post, Administrator, for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve 16 ambulatory children ages 12-17 years old and non-minor dependents. The current census is eight children. The Facility is current with their licensing fees. The Facility is a single story dwelling and contains a Boys Hall and Girls Hall. A physical plant inspection was completed with Norberto Garrido, Supervisor (S2) and included the following checks: kitchen, medication room, dining room, two living rooms, therapy room, four staff offices, day room, gym, outdoor living space, and each hall. Both halls contained nine rooms: seven rooms are for client use, one room used for CFT's and one for extra bed storage. All beds were observed with appropriate bedding and mattress in good repair. Bedrooms contained adequate drawers and closet space. No bedroom occupied more than one client and not used for other purposes. Both halls contained one restroom and two showers with a toilet. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and the Emergency Disaster Plan. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced.**Continued on LIC809-C** **Continued from LIC809** Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. The water temperature was tested in the eastern male bathroom which measured 108 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The first aid kit was accessible to everyone and had all required supplies. All client files are stored and maintained in binders and were locked in medication room. LPA reviewed five client files (C1 - C5, see LIC Confidential Names list) to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed five client medication records. LPA reviewed five staff files (S1, S2, S5, S6, S7) to ensure staff had all required documents per Title 22 regulations. Staff records are stored via a secured records portal. Per a review of Guardian, all staff have a criminal record clearance. After reviewing the current LIC500 and Guardian, one staff member, Staff #8 (S8) did not have a criminal background clearance. LPA conducted three staff interviews (S2, S3, and S4) and two client interviews (C1 and C5). Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division 6, regulation 80019(e)(2): Criminal Records Clearance. Record review confirmed staff S8 worked since 03/06/23 at least five shifts. An immediate civil penalty is issued for $500 ($100 per day, for a maximum of five days) per staff member found in violation. Therefore the total is $500. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the civil penalty assessment, the LIC811, and appeal rights were provided to Diana Post, Administrator. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On January 14, 2020, Community Care Licensing received allegations that lack of supervision resulting in C1 engaging in inappropriate activities with C2, facility staff did not report C1 missing, facility staff did not safeguard C1's personal property, and the facility staff did not inventory C1's personal belongings. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility staff investigated the alleged inappropriate interaction between C1 and C2, but statements obtained by facility staff revealed that they could not determine if there was any inappropriate interaction between C1 and C2 as there were conflicting statements to what had occurred. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was reported as a runaway to the police department; however, confidential interviews could not determine which staff member called the police department or when they called the police department to file the runaway report. Confidential interviews revealed that facility staff does secure and inventory a client's belongings when they run away; however, confidential interviews revealed conflicting information on how soon after C1 ran away staff secured and inventoried C1's belongings. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that lack of supervision resulting in C1 engaging in inappropriate activities with C2, facility staff did not report C1 missing, facility staff did not safeguard C1's personal property, and facility staff did not inventory C1's personal belongings may have occurred; however, they not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to the facility representative for signature. The original signed report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: On December 6, 2022 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lucero Jauregui conducted an unannounced inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to conducted an annual required inspection. LPA Jauregui met with Program Director (PD) Tracey Renwick. The facility services children ages 12- 17 years old and non-minor dependents. There are currently three clients in care. The facility is located in residential neighborhood in a single-story house. LPA Jauregui inspected the interior and exterior of the facility with PD Renwick. The home is a five-bedroom, two-bathroom home with a kitchen, living room, dining area, storage closet, office, laundry room, locked storage closet for chemicals and cleansers, hallway with built-in storage and make up room, and an attached two-car garage. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom #1 contains two twin beds; all required linen, is present and mattresses are in good condition. Bedroom #2 contains two twin beds; all required linen is present and mattresses in good condition. Bedroom #3 contains two twin beds; all required linen is present, and mattresses are in good condition. Bedroom #4 contains two twin beds; all required linen is present, and mattresses are in good condition. Bedroom #5 contains one twin bed; all required linen is present, and mattress is in good condition. The bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a bedroom. There is adequate closet and drawer space for children's belongings. All bedrooms have emergency access doors that open to the outside that are alarmed for resident's safety and security. The water temperature was measured to be 120 degrees Fahrenheit, which is in the required range of 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The two bathrooms were found to be free of dirt and grime and in good working order. In the hallway near the bedrooms, there is a linen closet where extra blankets, towels and pillows are kept. Continued... The facility has smoke alarms in all bedrooms, the hallway, and the make-up room. The smoke alarm was tested and found to be operable. There is a carbon monoxide detectors located in the kitchen, which were also tested and found operable. The last disaster drill was held on 11/21/22. The laundry room contains a washer and dryer and utility sink, as well as a locked cabinet that contains the First Aid Kit, which contained all required items, facility's Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) there is also a fire extinguisher. The make-up room contains a desks, a computer monitor, and mirrors. The dining room contains a table, with eight chairs. The living rooms contains three couches, a TV, games and toys. The kitchen had all required items, including utensils, plates glasses and cooking implements. Proper food storage was noted. LPA Jauregui observed that there is a two-day supply of perishable foods and seven-day supply non-perishable foods for the current census. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. The kitchen has an alcove area which contains a second refrigerator used for overflow foods. Just outside the office is a small hall with built in cabinet that contains extra water and snacks. The staff office contains office supplies, office furniture, filing cabinets, child and staff files, and sharp knives. The medication is located in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office, along a locked medication refrigerator. The locked garage is used for storage and contains decorations, extra bedding, overflow storage for residents' personal items, suitcases, old office files, art supplies and several locked cabinets that contain chemicals and cleansers. The outdoor space contains a grassy lawn both in the front and back yard. In the front yard there is a patio area that contains two outdoor chairs and a couch. There is also a canopy swing for residents' use. There are no guns or weapons as stated by the PD Renwick at this time. There is no body of water in the facility. The following required posted items were observed and accessible to children: Ombudsman and Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation Policies, Neighbor complaint Policy, and house rules. LPA Jauregui conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews. LPA Jauregui reviewed three client files and five staff files (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 12/6/22). Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted; this report was reviewed, copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to PD Renwick.

On December 20, 2023, at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted an unannounced inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Program Director (PD) Tracey Renwick. LPA inspected the interior and exterior of the facility with PD Renwick. The home is a five bedroom, two bathroom home with a kitchen, living room, dining area, storage closet, office, laundry room, locked storage closet for chemicals and cleansers, hallway with built-in storage and make up room, and an attached two car garage. The home is set up as follows: Bedroom 1: designated for two clients, two twin beds, two dresser drawers, two night stands, closet space and one bathroom. Bedroom 2: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser drawer, one night stand, closet space. Bedroom 3: designated for two clients, two twin bed, one dresser drawer, one night stand and closet. Bedroom 4: designated for two clients, two twin beds, two dresser drawers, two night stands, closet. Bedroom 5: designated for one client, one twin bed, one dresser drawer, one night stand, closet. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. The bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a bedroom. There is adequate closet and drawer space for children's belongings. All bedrooms have emergency access doors that open to the outside that are alarmed for resident's safety and security. The hot water temperature was measured in the kitchen sink and bathroom by the kitchen reading at 113 to 121 degrees Fahrenheit. PD Renwick turned the hot water temperature down. PD Renwick contacted maintenance to check the hot water pressure. The facility has smoke alarms in all bedrooms, the hallway, and the make-up room. The smoke alarm was tested and found to be operable. There is a carbon monoxide detector located in the kitchen, which were also tested and found operable. The laundry room contains a washer and dryer and utility sink, as well as a locked cabinet that contains the First Aid Kit, which contained all required items, facility's Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) there is also a fire extinguisher. The make-up room contains a desk, a computer monitor, and mirrors. The dining room contains a table, with eight chairs. The living rooms contains three couches, a TV, games, and toys. LPA observed that there is a two day supply of perishable foods and seven day supply non-perishable foods for the current census. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. The kitchen has an alcove area which contains a second refrigerator used for overflow foods. Just outside the office is a small hall with built in cabinet that contains extra water and snacks. The staff office contains office supplies, office furniture, filing cabinets, child and staff files, and sharp knives. The medication is in a locked cabinet in the locked staff office, along a locked medication refrigerator. The locked garage is used for storage and contains decorations, extra bedding, overflow storage for residents' personal items, suitcases, old office files, art supplies and several locked cabinets that contain chemicals and cleansers. The outdoor space contains a grassy lawn both in the front and back yard. In the front yard there is a patio area that contains two outdoor chairs and a couch. There are no guns or weapons as stated by the PD Renwick at this time. The following required posted items were observed and accessible to children: Ombudsman and Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation Policies, Neighbor complaint Policy, and house rules. LPA conducted two staff interviews and two clients refused to be interviewed. LPA reviewed three client files and five staff files, and all the necessary forms were in the files. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted; this report was reviewed, copy of this report was provided to PD Renwick.

There are currently seven clients in care. The facility is located in residential neighborhood in a single-story house. The laundry room contains a washer and dryer and utility sink, as well as a locked cabinet that contains the First Aid Kit, which contained all required items, facility's Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) there is also a fire extinguisher. The staff office contains office supplies, office furniture, filing cabinets, child and staff files, and sharp knives. The locked garage is used for storage and contains decorations, extra bedding, overflow storage for residents' personal items, suitcases, old office files art supplies and several locked cabinets that contain chemicals and cleansers. The outdoor space contains a grassy lawn both in the front and back yard. In the front yard there is a patio area that contains two outdoor chairs, a couch and an umbrella. There is also a canopy swing for residents' use. There are no guns or weapons as stated by the licensee at this time. There is no body of water in the facility. It was reported that clients were able to use the staff shower however, clients were refusing to use the restroom due to the restroom being dirty. Confidential interviews revealed that sometime in late October to early November, a plastic panel was installed in the bathroom shower located near clients' rooms. Confidential interviews revealed that the need to install the plastic panel was due to water continuously falling out of the shower causing water damage to the wall and base board of the bathroom. Confidential interviews revealed that the panel was installed in phases and after completely being installed, clients were unable to use it for the sealant to completely dry. Confidential interviews revealed that a sign was added to the shower informing clients not to use it. Confidential interviews did not reveal an exact time of how long the note remained posted and how long the shower remained in out of use status. Confidential interviews revealed that clients were instructed to use the second full bathroom located in the facility which can be used by both clients and staff. Confidential interviews revealed that staff informed clients to utilize the alternative bathroom shower while the other remained inoperable. Confidential interviews revealed clients were not utilizing the alternative shower due to it being small and "dirty" however, other confidential interviews revealed that the shower was not dirty but rather old. During a walk-through inspection completed by LPA Saeteurn on November 14, 2024, LPA Saeteurn was able to confirm that the shower located in the bathroom near client rooms had a plastic panel added and was being used once again by clients. Additionally, an inspection of the alternative bathroom near the facility kitchen revealed the shower was smaller in size compared to the bathroom near client bedrooms, and it appeared worn with superficial cracks on the tile flooring. Confidential interviews revealed that clients are encouraged to clean after themselves, however, the facility has also hired staff who are responsible for the cleaning of the facility. Additionally, during the walk through performed by LPA Saeteurn on November 14, 2024, a staff member was seen cleaning the facility grounds. Based on interviews and observations, the allegation that facility staff did not ensure client's shower was clean and in good repair is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. Continued... An exit interview was conducted with Tracey Renwick, Facility Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Tracey Renwick, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

narrative: On May 06, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abby Saeteurn met with Tracey Renwick, Facility Administrator to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained during the course of an investigation conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL), the facility did not report multiple incidents to CCL. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, it was revealed that during December 2024 through January 2025, there were multiple Special Incident Report and Law Enforcement Contact Reports for client (C1) for unauthorized absences, truancy, refusal for medical services and other critical incidents that were maintained in the facility's files but were not submitted to CCL. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, 88361(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements.

During the investigation, confidential interviews reveal the facility provides therapeutic serves to all resident on site in the form of individual and group therapy. Confidential interviews reveal that all residents of the facility are informed of the expectation of participating in such services upon intake, however, residents will sometimes decline to participate. Confidential interviews revealed that although clients have the option to refuse services, facility staff will encourage residents to participate. A confidential interview and review of records revealed C1 was a resident at the facility from December 11, 2024, through January 16, 2025. A confidential interview and a review of records revealed that during C1's stay at the facility, C1 participated in individual therapy sessions on December 13, 2024, January 7, 2025, and January 13, 2025, however, conflicting confidential interviews revealed C1 did not receive therapeutic services while at the facility. Additionally, a review of records revealed C1 missed one therapy session on December 20, 2024, due to S2 missing the contracted therapy. Based on conflicting confidential interviews and record review the allegation staff did not ensure a minor received regular therapy or counseling while in care is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Program Director, Tracey Renwick. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Tracey Renwick, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

were the sole person who distributed allowances. It was also advised that Client #1 was employed at the facility and would be paid weekly wages as well. It was reported that children were not treated fairly due to consequences being different between gender. No specific or additional information was obtained. Interviews conducted stated the expectations and consequences of clients are set and there are no disparities between female and males clients. Interviews stated there were no advisements of this allegation. It was reported that staff retaliate against minors for reporting to the licensing agency. Interviews conducted stated that clients are advised and encouraged to contact licensing. It was advised that licensing contact information is posted throughout the facility and clients are able to utilize the facility or personal phones. Staff also advised that clients are aware of the grievance procedures. It was stated that there were no issues regarding retaliation for notifying any investigative agency. It was also reported that staff members do not protect minor's private information. Information provided stated that clients do not have access to other clients information, including contact information or needs and service plans. The needs and service plans, as well as clients charts, are locked and secured in the staff office. It was advised that clients names and levels are on a white board, but the board is in the staff office also and clients do not have access. Confidential interviews reported that there are no additional confidential client details listed on the board. It was reported that staff do not meet clients basic needs. Confidential interviews advised that administration and staff provide as much as they can to all clients by having resources, hygiene, clothing, bedding, food, and additional items in surplus. It was stated that all resources are available to all clients. Client #1 refused to comment on any of the allegations. Client #1 stated all the issues were handled and there were no further concerns. Client #1's Probation Officer stated there were no concerns regarding any of the allegations advised to her. Based on interviews and information obtained, the allegations of staff withhold minor's allowance, children are not treated fairly, staff retaliate against minor for reporting to licensing, staff do not protect minor's private information, and staff do not meet minor's basic needs, may have occurred; however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to ************************ via email.

narrative: On 09/08/2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPM Valenzuela reviewed ten client files (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 09/08/2021). All client files had the required forms per regulations requirements. The client files are stored and locked in a cabinet in the office area within the units. Medication is kept in a locked cabinet behind a closed door. Due to time constraints, the annual inspection is being extended for staff files review, staff interviews, clients interviews and physical plant. Based on record review, the licensee did not comply as 1 out of 10 children's psychotropic medication administration records (MARs) which did not have staff initials on two days (08/24/2021 and 08/25/2021) for C5 which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Title 22, ILS version 3.1 section 87070(b)(12)(H). See LIC809D for the cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was reviewed with APD Bond and a copy of this report was provided.

On 09/09/2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Danielle Garcia and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted unannounced inspection to the facility. The purpose of the inspection is to conducted an annual continuation. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Garcia met with Assistant Program Director (APD) Shomari Bond. The facility serves 81 ambulatory minors ages 11 to 17 and non-minor dependents. There is 29 clients in care. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks toured the facility inside and out. The facility is set up as follows. There are six units: Courage Cove, Destiny Way, Serenity Cove, Harmony Point, Hope Mountain and Inspiration Peak. Courage Cove and Destiny Cove units are no currently in use. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks inspected Courage Cove. The water temperature measured at 112 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks inspected Destiny Way. The water temperature measured at 110 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks inspected Serenity Cove. The water temperature measured at 114 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza -Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. Bathrooms are located inside bedrooms. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Garcia observed recreation and milieu areas for clients to use. The medication was locked up in the staff office in a locked cabinet in each unit. The cleaning solution, disinfectants other hazard items are locked inaccessible to clients in a closet in each unit. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. See LIC 809C LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks inspected Harmony Point. The water temperature measured at 110 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza -Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. Bathrooms are located inside bedrooms and outside next to the bedrooms. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Garcia observed recreation and milieu areas for clients to use. The medication was locked up in the staff office in a locked cabinet in each unit. The cleaning solution, disinfectants other hazard items are locked inaccessible to clients in a closet in each unit. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks inspected Hope Mountain. The water temperature measured at 118 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza -Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. Bathrooms are located inside bedrooms and outside next to the bedrooms. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Garcia observed recreation and milieu areas for clients to use. The medication was locked up in the staff office in a locked cabinet in each unit. The cleaning solution, disinfectants other hazard items are locked inaccessible to clients in a closet in each unit. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPA Garcia, APD Bond and APD Michelle Jenks inspected Inspiration Peak. The water temperature measured at 118 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza -Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, beddings and storage space. Bathrooms are located inside bedrooms and outside next to the bedrooms. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Garcia observed recreation and milieu areas for clients to use. The medication was locked up in the staff office in a locked cabinet in each unit. The cleaning solution, disinfectants other hazard items are locked inaccessible to clients in a closet in each unit. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. The following required posted items were observed and accessible to children: Ombudsman and Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation Policies, Neighbor complaint Policy, house rules and current menu. Cafeteria prepares all meals and menu posted. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed sufficient perishable and non-perishable food. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed all areas inspected in the cafeteria to be clean, sanitary and in good repair. On February 17, Community Care Licensing received allegations that facility staff improperly restrained youth, staff speak inappropriately to youth in care and staff threaten youth in care. Specifically, it was reported C3 had scratches on their back from a restraint and staff threatened C3, saying "they would kick [C3] out". In Addition, C2 had marks left on their arm from a restraint, and that S1 has cussed C2 out in the past. Confidential interviews revealed that C2 is known to make marks on themself. Confidential interviews revealed that C2 did not seek medical attention after restraint. Confidential interviews revealed C3 did have scratches on their back which occurred during physical education in the morning and C3 did not request to see nurse for scratches. Confidential interviews noted that C3 never mentioned scratches on their back. In addition, there were no witnesses to any staff telling C3 "they will kick [C3] out". Confidential interviews could not confirm or dispute that facility staff improperly restrained youth or spoke inappropriately to youth in care and staff threatened youth in care. Based on confidential interviews and record review, although the allegations of Facility staff improperly restrained youth, Staff speak inappropriately to youth in care, and Staff threaten youth in care may or may not have occurred, however it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided along with appeal rights New Alternatives, Inc. # Facility Manager 1, Jared Farmer.

narrative: On August 24, 2021, the Department received allegations that staff mishandled a C1's personal belongings while in care, staff mistreated a C1 while in care, staff did not seek timely medical attention for a C1 while in care, C1 did not have access to a telephone while in care and staff mishandle minors while in care. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 and S2 conducted a room search for contraband in C1's room. Additional interviews revealed inconsistencies in how the room search was conducted that staff was throwing C1's belongings and slamming furniture. Confidential interviews revealed that allegedly S1 and S2 mocked and laughed at C1 regarding C1's gender identity during the room search, however, the interviews revealed that C1 was laughing during the room search therefore there are inconsistencies in the interviews. Confidential interviews revealed allegedly staff did not provide medical attention when C1 requested it however staff had to contact medical response team twice due to the team not responding in a timely manner at the first request. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 had access to make phone calls to people on C1's county approved list however C1 wanted to call a person, who is not on C1's approved list. Confidential interviews revealed that the staff is allegedly dragging youths by their arms and pushing them around however no staff has witnessed the alleged incident. There were no witnesses to the alleged incidents. Based on confidential interviews the allegations staff mishandled a C1's personal belongings while in care, staff mistreated a C1 while in care, staff did not seek timely medical attention for a C1 while in care, C1 did not have access to a telephone while in care and staff mishandle minors while in care may or may not have occurred, however, the allegation is not supported or proven by the evidence gathered. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were emailed to ADP Bond due to printer malfunction.

On May 10, 2023, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct an annual random. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPM Valenzuela met with Co-Program Director (CPD) Shomari Bond. The facility serves 81 ambulatory minors ages 11 to 17 and non-minor dependents. There are 29 youths in care. LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPM Valenzuela, and CPD Bond toured the facility inside and out. The facility is set up as follows. There are six units: Courage Cove, Destiny Way, Serenity Cove, Harmony Point, Hope Mountain, and Inspiration Peak. Courage Cove and Destiny Cove units are not currently in use. Each unit has a first-aid kit with all the required items LPA Meza-Gonzalez, LPM Valenzuela, and CPD Bond inspected Courage Cove. The water temperature was measured at 112 degrees Fahrenheit (F) which is within Community Care Licensing (CCL) regulations of 105 degrees F to 120 degrees F. LPA Meza-Gonzalez observed the unit to be clean, sanitary, and in good repair. LPA Meza -Gonzalez observed the rooms to have sufficient beds, bedding, and storage space. On May 12, 2023, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection of the facility. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct an annual continuation to interview staff and clients and review the Board of Directors' minutes. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Co-Program Director (CPD) Shomari Bond. The facilty serves 81 ambulatory youths ages 11 to 17 and non-minor dependents. There are 29 youths in care. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews (see confidential name list, LIC 811, dated May 12, 2023). LPA Meza-Gonzalez was unable to review the board meeting minutes as the facility could not provide the board meeting meets during the annual inspection. This is a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) version 4 - Accountability section 87063(a)(10) - Ensure that all minutes of the board of directors' or governing body meetings are kept electronically or on paper and made available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit, and copy upon demand during normal business hours. Minutes may be removed if necessary for copying. LPA Meza-Gonzalez was unable to verify sections 87063(a), 87063(a)(8), and 87063(a)(9) of the ILS for the annual inspection. Based on observations made during the inspection, the facility is being cited for ILS version 4 of Accountability sections 87063(a)(10), 87063(a), 87063(a)(8), and 87063(a)(9) observed during today's visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this amended report was given to CDP Bond along with LIC811 and LIC809D. ***This is an amended document***

On July 28, 2022, the Department received a complaint report, with the allegations that S1 caused bruising to C1, S1 inappropriately restrained C1, S1 and S2 encouraged C1 to engage in a physical altercation with C2 and C3 and S1 and S2 spoke inappropriately to C1 while in care. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistencies in whether C1 was involved in an inappropriate restraint that resulted in bruising. Additional interviews revealed that C1 was restrained by S1 and S1 twisted C1's arm back. C1 has been in restraints however there was no notation that there were marks left after the restraint. Confidential interviews revealed inconsistencies in whether S1 and S2 instigated a physical altercation with C2 and C3. Additional interviews revealed that S1 and S2 told C1 to fight C2 because C2 was instigating C1. Additional interviews revealed that S1 and S2 told C1 to fight C3 because C3 was being disrespectful towards C1. Additional information revealed that no staff witnessed C1 fighting C2 or C3. Confidential information revealed inconsistencies in whether S1 and S2 made inappropriate comments to C1. Additional interviews revealed that S1 made comments about C1's statue and S2 made inappropriate comments about C1's mental health however there was not witnesses to the inappropriate comments towards C1. Based on record reviews and confidential interviews, S1 caused bruising to C1, S1 inappropriately restrained C1, S1 and S2 encouraged C1 to engage in a physical altercation with C2 and C3 and S2 spoke inappropriately to C1 while in care are unsubstantiated. The details gathered for the incidents did not provide a preponderance of evidence to prove or disprove the allegations. LPA Meza-Gonzalez conducted an exit interview and provided a copy of this report along with appeal rights to APD Bond.

narrative: On October 05, 2022, the Department received a complaint report, with the allegation Staff did not provide adequate supervision to prevent inappropriate sexual interaction between C1 and C2 while in care. Confidential information revealed inconsistency in whether C2 touched C1 on C1's genitalia while sitting on the couch. C1 and C2 were being supervised by S2 while S1 was hanging Halloween décor. C1 and C2 were sitting on the same couch with a couch arm dividing them facing forward, and there was a shared blanket across C1 and C2's laps. S2 was sitting across from C1 and C2 supervising them. investigation_findings: 13On February 28, 2024, at 10:045AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with Administrator Program Director (APA) Michelle Jenks to deliver finding of the above allegation. During the investigation, LPA reviewed Client 1 (C1) and Client 2 (C2) files. LPA interviewed three of four staff, and one of two clients. C2 was unavailable to be interviewed. LPA left messages for staff; LPA did not receive return calls. LPA reviewed C1 and C2's Appraisal Needs and Services Plans, San Diego County Health, and Human Services Quarterly Reports, Child, and Family Team Meetings (CTF), Chula Vista Police Department investigative report as well as Special Incident Report. The Department received a complaint on August 7, 2023, alleging staff did not ensure a safe and healthful environment for minors in care. Confidential interviews revealed that while C1 was in the bathroom, C2 walked into the bathroom and punched and grabbed C1's legs and dragged C1 out of the bathroom at the facility. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting information. Continue next page...... UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: ...CONTINUED Confidential interviews indicated that prior to the punch, staff attempted to intervene in the verbal mistreatment from C2 towards C1 while C2 was preparing for a physical altercation by removing their rings. The Department also received an allegation that staff did not seek timely medical attention for a minor (C1). Specifically, it was reported that C1 did not receive medical care or have someone examine C1's eye after being punched. Confidential interviews indicate that staff (S2) examined C1's eye, offered C1 an icepack, and suggested taking C1 to the nearby hospital. Confidential interviews indicate that C1 declined medical attention and was not injured from the punch. Confidential interviews indicate that staff provided enhanced supervision of C1 for the remainder of the evening as a precaution. The Department also received an allegation that staff did not properly report an incident involving a minor (C1). Specifically, it was reported that staff did not report the altercation between C1 and C2 after the incident occurred. A record review of SIRs and emails received from the facility revealed that a full report was sent to CCL and the County Social Worker. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that staff did not prevent a minor (C2) from attacking another minor while in care (C1), staff did not seek timely medical attention for a minor (C1), and staff did not properly report an incident involving a minor (C1) are unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Michelle Jenks, Program Director, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided.
investigation_findings: 13On March 5 2024, at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Michelle Jenks, Program Director of New Alternatives #16 (NA16), to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Clients (C2 and C3) and Staff (S1-S5). Client (C1) declined to be interviewed. LPA Salem reviewed the Needs and Services Plans of C1 and C2, Special Incident Reports (SIRs), and other pertinent documents. On November 17, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff did not prevent a minor (C2) from attacking another minor (C1) while in care. Specifically, it was reported that staff allowed C2 to punch C1 in the face while wearing rings. Confidential interviews indicated that staff (S3) positioned themselves between C1 and C2 with raised arms to block any strikes. Confidential interviews indicate that C2 managed to land a single punch to C1's face before staff successfully redirected C2 away from C1. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: 0

narrative: ...CONTINUED Confidential interviews indicate that C1 was told by staff they could not have make-up out of their purse from the staff office, even though another client was doing their make-up. Conflicting confidential interviews indicate that C1 wanted the bank checks from their purse and was told no. A record review of a SIR indicates that C1 requested their entire purse and became threatening toward staff and destroying the property after being told they could not have their purse. Confidential interviews stated that staff found a vape cartridge in the client's purse. The Department also received an allegation that facility staff (unknown) engaged in physical altercations with youths (unknown). Confidential interviews indicated that on 11/18/2023, two physical conflicts occurred between staff and clients, caused by clients attempting to enter the staff office and then trying to run away from the unit. Confidential interviews indicate that a client (C2) attacked a member of staff (S2) while trying to run away and that S2 "punched back" at C2 and ripped off C2's necklace. Conflicting confidential interviews indicate that S2 was utilizing proper defensive techniques per ProAct and accidentally ripped off C2's necklace while attempting to deflect C2's strikes using ProAct training. Confidential interviews indicate that after witnessing the necklace break, another client (C1) attacked S2 out of defensiveness for C2, which involved C1 holding S2's arms behind their back. Confidential interviews indicate that this resulted in a larger struggle involving additional clients (C3, C4, and C5) who began to state that they witnessed S2 trying to hit C2. Confidential interviews stated that S5 and S8 witnessed C2 punching S2 and S2 not punching back and only blocking. Other confidential interviews stated that a few staff were not looking because they were focused on the other clients involved. In addition, confidential interviews stated that S5 observed S2 using appropriate emergency interventions. Based on conflicting confidential interviews, the allegations that facility staff (unknown) engaged in a verbal altercation with youth (C1) and facility staff (unknown) engaged in physical altercations with youths (unknown) are unsubstantiated. narrative: On March 28, 2024, at 4: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with New Alternatives #16 (NA) Michelle Jenks, Program Director to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL), S3 engaged in an improper emergency intervention technique on 11/18/23 because of a client (C2) being physically aggressive with S3. Specifically, it was disclosed that C2 crawled under S3's legs and attempted to lift S3 during a larger struggle between clients (C1-C3) and staff (S1, S2, S3, S5, and S8). S3 "swung C1 out from under his legs" approximately two to three feet away. The incident was witnessed by another client (C4). It was disclosed that C2's shoulder was in pain due to a prior injury after the incident. LPA collected all the pertinent documentation, and interviews were conducted with the Staff (S1-S10) and Clients (C1-C2 and C4-C7). See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated 3/28/24. Based on staff and client interviews, the facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards version 5 section 87095. Emergency Intervention Prohibition (b) "...any emergency intervention technique not approved for use as part of the licensee's emergency intervention plan must not be used at any time." Facility staff (S3) did not utilize an approved emergency intervention technique by throwing C2 from underneath him, which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights and LIC 811 to Michelle Jenks, Program Director.

narrative: ...CONTINUED A record review of the SW letter indicates that NA kept C1 home from school past the period of suspension due to behavioral and safety concerns. A confidential interview indicates that NA staff regularly sent C1 back to their residential unit, costing C1 educational progress. Conflicting confidential interviews indicate that NA and the school Administrator created a plan for C1 to complete schoolwork with teachers in an alternative area (residential unit) during C1's behavioral escalations. Confidential interviews indicate that C1 was regularly disruptive and threatening towards school staff and peers. A confidential interview also indicates that NA does not keep students' home from school for more than a day unless the student requires one-on-one supervision and is being assessed for a psychiatric hold (5150). Although a confidential interview with C1 disclosed that C1 wanted to be in class and was kept from attending, a conflicting confidential interview indicates that C1 would frequently walk out of class and refuse school in the morning. The Department also received the allegation that staff inappropriately acted as the youth's (C1) Education Rights Holder. A confidential interview and record review of the SW letter indicates that NA initiated an independent study for C1 without the approval of C1's Educational Rights Holder (EHR). A conflicting confidential interview indicates that EHR was informed and discussed the independent study with C1's school. Confidential interviews indicate that although C1 was often directed to leave class and complete schoolwork in their (C1) residential unit, C1 was never placed on an independent study. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff did not allow youth (C1) to attend school on-site as a form of discipline and that staff inappropriately acted as the youth's (C1) education rights holder are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. narrative: In regard to the allegation that staff misuse non-minor dependents' cash resources, confidential interviewed reported that staff used C1's Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) card to purchase food for clients at the facility. However, confidential interviews denied the allegation and indicated that food is provided for clients at the facility, and clients do not purchase food to provide for clients. Regarding the allegation that staff open non-minor dependent's personal mail, confidential interviews revealed that C2 was given opened mails several times. However, confidential interviews revealed that staff deliver unopened envelopes and packages to the staff supervisor on the unit to give to clients. LPA received a conflicting information. Concerning the allegation that staff confiscated non-minor dependent's personal property without cause, confidential interviews reported that staff searched C2's room for no reason. However, confidential interviews stated that if staff have a reasonable suspicion that a client is under the influence, staff will ask the client if they can search their room for safety concerns. Confidential witnesses didn't disclose specific information regarding the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff withhold non-minor dependents' personal records from them, confidential interviews indicated that C1 was a non- minor dependent and must ask staff for C1's identification card and birth certification when seeking employment. However, confidential interviews stated that non-minor dependents are allowed to keep their identification cards and birth certificates in their possession. Other confidential interviews reported that the facility can store clients' birth certificates and identification and clients can request the items as needed. Regarding the allegation that staff do not allow non-minor dependents to keep their personal passwords private, confidential interviews revealed that staff told C1, C2, C3 provide passwords to all social media accounts or clients will be given a consequence. However, confidential interviews denied asking clients for personal passwords to cell phones and social media accounts. LPA received inconsistent information. Based on confidential interviews and information gathered during the investigation the allegation that staff misuse C1's cash resources; staff open C2's personal mail; staff confiscated C2 personal property without cause; staff withhold C1 personal records and staff do not allow C1, C2, C3 to keep their personal passwords private, may or may have occurred, however, it is not supported for proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Administrator Program Director (APA) Jenks.

narrative: On December 19, 2024, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with New Alternatives #16 (NA) Michelle Jenks, Administrator to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL), the female clients' personal rights were not upheld during contraband searches that occur when clients return to the facility after school. Confidential interviews indicated that after female clients were asked to lift their bra wire, they were also instructed to jump repeatedly and shake their bra. Confidential interviews indicated that these contraband searches occurred primarily outside by the front gate and that female clients were checked next to or within seeing distance of male staff and peers. A confidential interview indicated that participating in this search with males present caused discomfort and embarrassment for at least one client in care. Confidential interviews indicated that female clients who attend a different school went through the contraband search process inside a private office with no other clients present or within line of sight. Confidential interviews indicated that the bra check described above occurred regularly for female clients, rather than as a response to suspected possession of contraband. Confidential interviews indicated that staff apply disciplinary consequences when clients refuse to participate in the bra check. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that clients are allowed to refuse the bra check, but that staff place clients who refuse on enhanced supervision. Confidential interviews indicated that staff do not touch clients during the contraband search process. Based on confidential interviews, the facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards version 5, section Personal Rights (c)(15) "The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, and below, as applicable: ... To be accorded dignity in their personal relationships with staff and other persons." Continued... ...CONTINUED Facility staff did not accord female clients dignity by conducting inappropriate searches outdoors in the presence of male staff and peers, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of the report and appeal rights were provided to Michelle Jenks, Administrator.

Interview with S3 disclosed that when confronted by S1, S2 she continued to go on with her job and not become confrontational in front of the clients. Other confidential interviews revealed that when S1, S2 started to get loud, C4 and C1 came out of their rooms becoming defensive for S3. Confidential interviews disclosed that clients felt re-triggered with the communication between the staff on 6/28/20. Other confidential interviews disclosed that S1 was moved to a different facility. Record review revealed that S1, S3 had employee actions taken and were given training on boundaries with peers and communication skills. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence has been met and the allegation that clients felt threatened when S1, S2 discussed a concern with S3 in front of the clients in care is substantiated. The facility is being cited for Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Version 3, Section 87072 (d) (11) PERSONAL RIGHTS. Clients felt threatened when S1 and S2 became argumentative with S3 in front of or in listening distance of clients. This poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to clients in care. narrative: Other confidential interviews disclosed that staff would follow the clients out the door or windows but clients wore dark clothing and hid until staff stopped looking for them. Record review of SIR dated 9/28/20, disclosed the staff immediately reported client's AWOL to all necessary agencies including local law enforcement. Interview with CSW revealed that staff had consistent contact with C1 and would immediately notify her when C1 went AWOL. Based on confidential interviews and record review, that staff did not prevent minors from AWOLing, and staff did not report C1 missing from facility may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence.
