narrative: On June 24, 2021 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Anastasia Flores and LPA Linda Haynes, arrived at New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facility (STRTP). LPA's were greeted and granted access by Direct Care Staff, Debbie Peralta. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There was one facility manager and two therapists, one program director and one staff present at the time of the inspection. There were six clients present and appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 09: AM, Ms. Peralta and Jalisa Brown led the tour of the facility. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility includes a dining area, kitchen area, living room and laundry room/garage utilized for storage. The facility has a staff office and there is an office entry through the garage utilized by therapists.The facility has two offices with entrances from the backyard that are utilized by Program Director and Head of Service. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. Bedroom #2 and #3 have a single bed and a crib. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair during inspection. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Gym equipment/ toddler play area and other activities were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. At 9: AM the hot water in the master bathroom was measured to be 112.2 degrees, bathroom #2 was measured at 9: AM to be 115.5 degrees and at 10: AM , the kitchen measured at 115.5 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Program Director/Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one therapist, one facility administrators, one facility manager, 12 direct care staff, one head of service and one Program Director. Facility has obtained Mental Health Certification effective 08/28/2020. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through 11/30/2022. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of zero. At 10: AM, six of six client files were reviewed during time of inspection. Required documents were in files. Personnel Files are maintained off site at the corporate office in Riverside, Ca. However, during inspection staff files were brought to the facility for review. At 12: PM, ten personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). LPA's reviewed 10 staff files. Staff files were complete with First Aid/CPR certificates, certificates for training hours, and all required documents were signed and present. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. T At 11: AM, LPA's interviewed one direct care staff and one facility manager that were present, in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's program. One of six clients present during inspection volunteered to be interviewed, five clients refused. Client indicates that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Program Director, Michelle Hicks.

narrative: On July 20, 202 at 12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson met with New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facilities- New Beginnings, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Supervising Facility Manager, Jalisa Brown, to address the client's right to be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. CCL received Law Enforcement Contact dated 07/06/2022 that stated upon return from AWOL, C1 was instructed to do a self-search. Confidential interviews indicated this protocol is in the Program Statement. Review of the Program Statement Runaway Policy noted the youth are asked to turn out their pockets, remove their shoes and socks, shake their blouse, etc., and run their fingers through their hair. Based on confidential interview and record review, the facility did not ensure youth rights to be free from unreasonable searches of personal belongings. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility is being cited for Interim Licensing Standards, Article 06, Personal Rights(c)(19) To exercise their personal rights without harassment, punishment, or retribution. See 809D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to the group home Supervising Facility Manager.

On October 27, 2022, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analysts(LPA) Val Wilson met with Program Director (PD) Michelle Hicks to deliver a case management deficiencies report. LPA Wilson was at the facility on 12/28/2021, conducting a complaint investigation. Specifically, it was reported Client #3 (C3) room visited Client #2 (C2) in the bathroom and in C2's bedroom on the evening of 12/18/22. Although, staff followed supervision protocol when C3 refused to leave the bathroom C2 was in, corroborating confidential interviews revealed two staff [Staff 1 (S1), Staff 2 (S2)] did not follow room visiting protocol when C3 refused to leave Client #1 (C1) and C2s bedroom, which is bedroom #4. Additionally, surveillance video was reviewed confirming staff S1 or S2 did not remain outside bedroom #4 during C3's bedroom #4 visit resulting in direct care staff (S1, S2) receiving corrective action. A short-term residential therapeutic program is a residential facility operated by a public agency or private organization and licensed by the department pursuant to Section 1562.01 that provides an integrated program of specialized and intensive care and supervision, services and supports, treatment, and short-term 24-hour care and supervision to children and/or nonminor dependents. The licensee shall employ direct care staff to meet the needs of children as specified in 87065.2 and provide adequate care and supervision to children. Facility staff (S1, S2) failed to provide adequate supervision by remaining outside the door in the hallway upon refusal of C3 to leave Bedroom 4. (Continued) The facility is being cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87065.2 (b)(1) Personnel Duties (b) Direct care staff shall perform the following duties: (1) supervision, protection, and care of children at all times, individually and in groups. A copy of this report, LIC 811, LIC 809-D, and appeal rights were reviewed and then provided to Michelle Hicks.

However, there was not sufficient information to support sexual activity between clients occurred. Based on confidential interviews, there was not sufficient information to determine that staff did not prevent inappropriate sexual interactions between clients C2 and C3 while in care. Although the allegations may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. During the investigation, the LPA interviewed two children [Client #1 (C1) and Client #2 (C2)] and six STRTP employees [Administrator (ADM), Facility Manager (FM), Assistant Program Director (APD), Quality Assurance (QA), Therapist (TH), and Program Director (PD)]. narrative: On June 9, 2022 at 4:31 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Val Wilson, met with Administrator, Michelle Hicks, regarding a complaint investigation. On June 9, 2022, LPA conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility inside an outside. LPA observed, in the garage freezer, frozen meat labeled with a sell by date of June 6, 2021, and an expiration date of June 6, 2022. The administrator requested a direct care staff to dispose of the expired meat. During inspection of the kitchen, LPA Wilson observed the same package of expired meat in the kitchen refrigerator. LPA asked again about the expired meat and the administrator shared the direct care staff moved the meat to the kitchen refrigerator to thaw instead of discarding the expired meat. Based on evidence gathered, the facility failed to store food in a safe and healthful manner which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility will be cited for a violation of California the Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, regulation 80076(a)(1): Food Services. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Michelle Hicks.

On December 20, 2022, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, conducted a case management inspection for the purpose of delivering amended reports and obtaining signatures. A copy of this report was given and explained to Jalisa Brown.

On June 6, 2021 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith, and Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Jason Dalton and LPA Val Wilson, arrived at New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facility Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPM and LPA's were greeted and granted access by Facility Manager, Jalisa Brown. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual/random inspection of the facility. There was one supervising facility manager, two administrators, and one program director and one direct care staff present at the time of the inspection. There were four clients and two infants present and appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 09: AM, Jalisa Brown led the tour of the facility and was later joined by the program director. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility includes a dining area, kitchen area, living room, laundry room, garage with a visitor area, and therapist office. The facility has two staff shed offices in the backyard that are utilized by Program Director and Head of Service. There are three locked storage containers with client files and one shed with holiday decorations and miscellaneous items. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. Bedroom #2 and #3 have a single bed and a crib. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair during inspection. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Gym equipment/ toddler play area and other activities were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. At 11: AM the hot water in the client bathroom was measured to be 105.1 degrees. Per facility staff, (Continued) (Continued) no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Program Director/Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one therapist, one supervising facility manager, 11 direct care staff/facility mangers, one head of service, one quality assurance, and one program director. Facility has obtained Mental Health program approval effective 08/28/2023. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through 11/30/2023. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a zero balance. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. T At 11: AM, LPA's and LPM interviewed one direct care staff/facility manager, one case manager, and one supervising facility manager that were present, in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's program. Four clients were interviewed during inspection and indicated that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services are being provided as well. No deficiencies were noted during today's visit. Due to time constraints, the annual/random inspection will be completed on a a subsequent visit. An exit interview was conducted. LIC 811 and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Program Director, Michelle Hicks.

It was reported to CCL that C1 was sexually assaulted by C2 while in care however, it was also disclosed that C1 inappropriately touched C2 in care. During investigation, confidential interviews stated that staff learned about inappropriate sexual behaviors between C1 and C2 through a law enforcement visit to the facility. Confidential interviews stated that C1 and C2 were roommates prior to the incident being reported and when staff learned about the incident a safety plan was put in place. Confidential interviews denied that lack of supervision resulted in inappropriate sexual activity among C1 and C2 in care, and interviews added that both am, and pm staff conduct routine room checks every 15-20 minutes. Another confidential interview maintained that C1 was inappropriately touched by C2 and confirmed misuse of a cellphone during the incident. Furthermore, a confidential interview disclosed having knowledge of the incident and being aware that an unknown male who was familiar to C1 and C2 participated in C1's and C2's arranged sexual activity via a voice call. Another confidential interview stated being made aware of the incident and believes that staff handled the situation appropriately. Confidential interview added having no concerns about the placement. C2, and CSW1 could not be reached for comment regarding the allegations. LPA received inconsistent information regarding the facility staff lack of supervision resulting in C1 and C2 inappropriate sexual activity. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that C1 was sexually assaulted by C2 while in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and due to technical difficulties a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Supervising Facility Manager, Jalisa Brown.

investigation_findings: 13On September 8, 2023, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, met with Senida Zamora, Administrator, at New Beginnings, Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), to issue the investigative findings for the above stated allegation. See Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated September 8, 2023. On September 16, 2022, at 10: AM, a safety inspection was conducted and there were no noted health and safety concerns. LPA reviewed facility files, and four client files [client 1(C1), client 2 (C2), client 3 (C3), and client 4(C4)], and LPA also obtained and reviewed copies of the client roster, house log, LIC 500, face sheets, needs and services plan, and special incident reports (SIRs). During the investigation, interviews were conducted with C1, C2, C3, C4, staff 1 (S1), staff 2 (S2), program director (PD), administrator (ADM), and facility manager (FM). On September 8, 2022, the Department received a complaint that alleged staff do not treat minor with respect. Specifically, it was reported staff are rude and talk disrespectfully to C4. (continued) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: In regard to the allegation that staff were not providing a safe environment for clients, confidential witnesses stated that staff provided appropriate supervision to the clients and if clients were physically aggressive, staff would intervene immediately. County social worker 5 (CSW5) stated that she was not informed that staff would not intervene when clients were involved in physical altercations or intervene when clients were in an unsafe environment. Other confidential witnesses maintained that facility staff would instigate physical altercations and staff would not prevent the clients from fighting. Regarding the allegation that staff withheld minor's allowance, confidential witnesses stated that facility staff would not withhold clients' allowances and clients were always given their full allowances. However, confidential witness disclosed that facility staff would not always give clients their full allowance if clients were to miss their previous allowance. Referencing the allegation that facility was not providing clients with a variety of foods. Confidential witnesses stated that the facility would follow the approved menu and there were no issues with the food served. Additionally, it was reported that clients would have group meetings where suggestions for future food options were given by clients and the facility would implement the suggestions in the menu. Other confidential witnesses stated that meetings were held, and food options were suggested, but the facility would not implement the food suggestions on the future menus. Regarding the allegation staff threatened clients, it was specified that staff would threaten clients by threatening to calling to call Child Protective Services (CPS). Confidential witnesses stated that they did not observe staff threatening to call CPS on clients. County social worker 2 (CSW2) stated that she was not informed that staff threatened clients with CPS. Another confidential witness mentioned that staff would sometimes say that they will be calling CPS if the clients were not complying. With regard to the allegation that staff were discussing minors amongst other staff members, it was specifically alleged that the therapist was sharing confidential information with staff. Confidential witnesses stated that they were unaware of the therapist disclosing confidential information to other staff. County social worker (CSW) stated that she was not told that a facility therapist shared confidential information with other staff. Other confidential witness stated that they had observed a therapist share confidential information with other staff and seen staff gossiping regarding the information that was shared. (continued on page 3...) Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations; that staff were not providing a safe environment for clients, staff withheld client's allowance, facility was not providing a variety of foods to clients, staff threatened clients, and staff were discussing clients amongst other staff members may have occurred, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Jalisa Brown.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed that S3 had misgendered C1 when C1 just arrived at the placement; C1 had asked S3 "Do I look like a girl or a boy?" C1 was not happy with S3's opinionated response. Confidential interviews revealed that S3 did not address C1 by C1's preferred name and pronouns; however, since than S3 has been corrected and has never addressed C1 with the incorrect name or pronouns. Confidential interviews revealed that another staff had also misgendered C1 before but has since corrected themselves. Confidential interviews stated that the facility was new to transgender clients and these incidents were not intentional. investigation_findings: 13On 05/30/2024 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo met with Administrator, Michelle Hicks, to deliver the finding for the above complaint allegation at New Beginning Residential Treatment Facilities Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). On 12/21/23, LPA Valerie Wilson inspected the facility's physical plant, and no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with three staff (S1, S2, S3), Facility Manager (FM) and two clients (C1, C2). Clients' Needs and Services Plans and case notes were reviewed. On December 20, 2023, Community Care Licensing received an allegation stated that staff are not referring to minor (C1) by their preferred gender name and pronouns. Specifically, it was reported that S3 had misgender C1 several times and called C1 by C1's "dead name". (continued on LIC 9099c) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Confidential interviews disclosed that clients have smoked in the house before. Confidential interviews stated that they never observed C1 smoking a marijuana vaporizer in the facility or C1's bedroom. Other confidential interviews reported that smoking is not allowed in the home. Staff do room checks consistently, and if clients are in the bathrooms for an extended period, they start knocking on the doors to request that they finish and come out of the bathrooms. Confidential interviews reported that staff also checks the bathrooms when doing bedroom checks. Confidential interviews stated that staff supervise clients, and clients are never alone at the facility. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation of lack of care and supervision, resulting in injuries sustained by the infant (T1) while in care. It was alleged that C1 hit T1, and T1 received bruises and marks. Confidential interviews reported that T1 occasionally has marks due to their (T1) age and exploration as a toddler, and no marks have raised concerns, but no witnesses have seen C1 hit T1. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff did not ensure the infant (T1) was being adequately fed, that the lack of supervision resulted in infant (T1) needs not being met while in care, and that the staff did not seek medical attention for the infant (T1). It was alleged that C1 had gone over half a day without feeding T1. Confidential interviews reported that T1 eats regularly throughout the day and that C1 has been encouraged to feed T1 independently and has continued to feed T1. It was alleged that T1 is not being treated for a diaper rash and is not being bathed consistently. A confidential interview disclosed that C1 bathes T1 at least once daily and has applied ointment/cream to T1's diaper rash when T1 previously had one. Confidential interviews reported that staff would provide diaper cream ointment for T1 whenever necessary but that T1 had a history of getting diaper rashes. Other confidential interviews stated that staff haven't recently observed T1 with a diaper rash. Confidential interviews reported that staff will bathe and provide food for T1 whenever needed if C1 does not. Confidential interviews stated that if staff observed T1 with a diaper rash, ointment/cream would be applied to the diaper rash immediately and consistently until T1's skin is healed if needed. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for minors (C1) in care. Confidential interviews reported that staff are not correcting, redirecting, or taking any action towards C1's behavior when needed. Additional confidential interviews reported that staff worked with C1 to help C1 transition to transitional living. (..) When behaviors are challenging, the facility discusses those behaviors with C1 and implements an appropriate plan to ensure that C1 follows the facility rules while being prepared to transition to transitional living. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations of lack of care and supervision resulting in the minor (C1) smoking marijuana vaporizer while in care, lack of care and supervision resulting in infant (T1) sustaining unexplained injuries while in care, staff did not ensure infant (T1) was being adequately fed, lack of supervision resulting in infant (T1) needs not being met while in care, staff did not seek medical attention for infant (T1), staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for minors (C1) while in care are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Jalisa Brown, Facility Manager.

narrative: During the investigation, confidential interviews reported that the intimate relationship did occur between A1 and A2 but denied it happened in the STRTP. However, the time frames given for the relationship did not match the documentation. Further documentation reported that A2 visited A1 during A2's work hours and used the company car the day after the client left the STRTP. The client was considered an adult, and A2 was put on work suspension. Documentation reported pictures and videos of A1 and A2 being together on social media. However, no dates and times were established when the photos and videos were taken. LPA received conflicting information and could not determine if A2 engaged in an inappropriate relationship with A1 when A1 resided at the facility. On 05/24/2024, Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that staff (S4) made inappropriate comments towards minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, and C5). Confidential interviews stated that S4 called some clients "ugly and ghetto" and that the minors were not going to be anything when they grew up. Confidential interviews reported that S4 would comment to other staff about the clients but was unsure if S4 ever said anything to clients or made inappropriate comments towards the clients. In addition, confidential interviews disclosed that S4 has never said anything inappropriate about clients or towards clients and that S4 has a good relationship rapport with the clients. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff (A2) engaged in an inappropriate relationship with a minor (A1) and staff (S4) made inappropriate comments towards minors (C1, C2, C3, C4, and C5) are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Senida Zamora, Assistant Program Director.

Other staff members intervened to assist in encouraging C1 to calm down when S1 removed themselves from the situation. Regarding the allegation that staff are not treating minors (C1) equally. Confidential interviews reported that staff were not fair to C1. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was becoming increasingly agitated towards staff members and this caused staff to be more cautious in their approach with C1 but denied any unfair treatment. LPA was unable to determine if the allegations occurred or did not occur. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a minor and that staff are not treating minors equally are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Michelle Hicks, Program Director.

narrative: On the above date and time Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Michael Almaraz, met with Administrator, Jalisa Brown, and conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a confidential interview (see confidential names list LIC 811 dated June 19, 2025). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to Jalisa Brown.

Confidential interviews reported that staff make remarks to clients that are not welcoming and do not create a welcoming environment for the clients in the home. Confidential interviews denied that clients are not treated respectfully. Confidential interviews stated that staff is not speaking to clients inappropriately. CCL also received an allegation that staff (S4) use inappropriate forms of punishment. It was alleged that S4 turned off the facility Wi-Fi as a result of C1 returning to their room. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was out in the living room with toddler 1 (T1) late at night due to T1 not going to sleep when S4 came out and told C1 to turn off the television (TV) and return to their (C1) bedroom. C1 stayed in the living room and was turning on the TV for T1 when the Wi-Fi connection went out. Confidential interviews reported that S4 was overheard saying "We're not doing this tonight" and "Go back to your room". Confidential interviews denied S4 turning off the Wi-Fi as a form of punishment. CCL also received an allegation that staff does not ensure clients' transportation needs are being met. It was alleged that the STRTP's facility car was unsafe due to the breaks locking up while clients were in the car. Confidential interviews reported that clients were being transported for an outing when S3 was complaining of the car brakes locking. S3 then returned the car and took another facility car to transport the clients. Confidential interviews reported that all facility cars get serviced weekly or every other week to ensure that they are safe for transportation. CCL also received an allegation that staff do not ensure that age-appropriate utensils are made accessible to clients. Confidential interviews reported that C1 requested more utensils for T1 and had to wait a month for new items to be available for T1. Confidential interviews reported that upon client request for more items they are made available for client's use. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that staff do not ensure clients are treated with respect, staff speak inappropriately to clients in care, staff use inappropriate forms of punishment, staff do not ensure clients transportation needs are being met, and staff do not ensure age-appropriate utensils are made accessible to clients are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Jalisa Brown, Administrator.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that staff follow CCL regulations protocol and ensure that all medications whether taken or not taken are documented and accounted for. Confidential interviews reported that staff also ensure that all clients are being scheduled for their medical appointments, and staff encourage clients to attend their medical appointments. Additional confidential interviews reported that there is a wait on medical appointments due to medical insurance issues, but staff try and stay proactive about the situation during the wait period. CCL also received an allegation that staff (unknown) are not providing adequate food service to minors (unknown). Confidential interviews reported that the facility went without fresh food and staff are not incorporating the client's wishes for food items. Confidential interviews reported that the facility will go once a week for a big store purchase and if anything runs out in between the week then the staff will return to the store for whatever items are missing. Confidential interviews reported that staff do take client's requests and will ensure that the clients are being heard. Documentation reported that the facility went food shopping multiple times during the months. CCL also received an allegation that staff (unknown) are not treating minors equally and staff (S1) made inappropriate comments towards minors. Confidential interviews reported that staff (S1) commented that Licensing was not "doing anything" after a Licensing visit to interview C1. Confidential interviews reported that S1 denied making this comment. Confidential interviews reported that staff (unknown) treat clients differently and will take other clients out to eat and not take all clients. Confidential interviews reported that per facility policy, if a client is on facility "concern" status they are not able to attend "paid outings" as part of their restriction. CCL also received an allegation that staff (unknown) retaliated against minors (unknown) for reporting to Licensing. Confidential interviews reported that C2 was put on the facility "concern" after speaking with Licensing and was not aware of or told the reason for concern before. Confidential interviews reported that C2 was put on the facility "concern" for a separate issue not relating to Licensing. (Continued on LIC 9099C...) CCL also received an allegation that staff (unknown) are not providing diapering supplies for minors (C1) babies and staff (S1) did not provide minor (C1) with a monthly allowance. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was allotted five hundred dollars for baby items and then was told they were not allowed to receive monthly allowance the next week. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was requesting to go shopping for their baby's necessities such as blankets, clothes, and bottles. Confidential interviews reported that C1 was aware that the five hundred dollars was an advance of C1's allowance. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and documentation, the allegations that staff are mismanaging minors medication, that staff are not seeking medical attention for minors, staff are not providing adequate food service to minors, that staff are not treating the minors equally, that staff did not provide minor with a monthly allowance, staff are not providing diapering supplies for minors babies, that staff made inappropriate comments towards minors, and that staff retaliated against minors for reporting to licensing are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report LIC 9099 and the appeal rights were discussed and provided to Jalisa Brown, Administrator.

narrative: On August 21, 2025, at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA') Jessica Peete and Cynthia Robinson (LPM) arrived at New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facility Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA's were greeted and granted access by Facility Manager Michelle Lofton; later joined by Administrator Jalisa Brown. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual/random inspection of the facility. At 9: AM, LPA Peete began the physical plant inspection; Facility Manager Jalisa Brown assisted LPA in touring the facility's interior and exterior grounds. During the facility inspection, LPA observed cameras in the common areas. The cameras are not pointed toward client bedrooms or bathrooms. According to Administrator Brown's statement, the video cameras do not capture audio and do not replace staff supervision. The facility consists of four client bedrooms and two bathrooms, one of which is a staff bathroom, that clients still have access to and are able to use. All toilets, sinks, and showers are maintained in safe, sanitary, and operating condition. Additionally, the water in each bathroom measured between 105°F and 120°F. The facility features a dining area, kitchen, living room, laundry room, garage with a visitor area, and a therapist's office. The facility's outside grounds have two sheds, in the backyard, which are utilized as offices by the Program Director and Head of Service. There are four locked storage containers containing client files, and one shed housing holiday decorations and miscellaneous items. All client bedrooms have individual beds with adequate drawers and closet space for each client. In addition, LPA observed that each client's bedroom was equipped with a small combination safe to store personal items or contraceptives. The clients' bedrooms are arranged so there are no more than two clients per room. LPA observed that all client beds had the appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Extra linens and toiletry items are stored in the garage and hall closet closest accessible to clients as needed. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, and all exits and entrances are unobstructed. A toddler play area and patio furniture were observed in the backyard, along with other age-appropriate games and activities located in the garage, for the client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and placed throughout the facility. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPA observed a minimum of seven days of non-perishable food and a two-day perishable supply, and the facility appears to be following the posted menu. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are stored separately from all food items in a locked cabinet located in the garage. The cooking knives and all other sharp items are stored in the staff office, located inside a locked cabinet. All required forms are posted, including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. No observable safety or health hazards were observed during the physical plant inspection, and no deficiencies were cited. LPA Peete reviewed the facility's operations, disaster preparedness, emergency interventions, and core therapeutic services. The core therapeutic services demonstrated that the appropriate services and supports for clients are trauma-informed, culturally relevant, and age- and developmentally appropriate. All required documentation was observed, and no deficiencies were found in the above-mentioned areas. LPA Robinson completed a review of five client files (C1 through C5). During the file review, it was noted that five of the clients did not have the required tuberculosis test. The licensee was cited with a type B violation of the Title California Code of Regulations 80069(c)(1) Client Medical Assessments. LPA Robinson also completed one client interview (C2), C5 declined. Based on observations made during the inspection, a deficiency is being cited (see LIC D). Due to time constraints, LPA's will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights and the LIC Confidential Names List, was provided to the facility Administrator, Jalisa Brown.

narrative: On June 17, 2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Anastasia Flores, arrived at New Beginnings Residential RAJA Facility (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by direct care staff, Julie Chester. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There was one staff, one administrator and five clients present at the time of the inspection. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 9: AM, Administrator, Stacy Rougely led the tour of the facility. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility includes a dining area, kitchen area, living room and laundry room/garage utilized for storage. The facility has a staff office and one room utilized by therapists. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. During inspection, bedroom #2 did not have linens due to client recently discharged and linens are being sanitized. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Gym equipment/toddler play area and other activities were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order with exception of room #4, however the smoke detector was replaced during the inspection. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. At 9: AM, the hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 120 degrees, master bathroom #1 was measured to be 109.5 degrees. At 3: PM the hot water temperature in client bathroom #2 was measured to be 117.6 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. () Administrator Stacy Rougely, is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one mental health rehabilitation specialist, one facility administrator, nine direct care staff, one head of service and one Program Director. Facility has obtained Mental Health Certification effective 04/09/2019. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through 11/30/2022. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of zero. At 10: AM, six of six client files were reviewed during time of inspection. There were required documents not up to date in the client files, but due to time constraints, deficiencies and/or advisory notes will be issued on a separate date. Personnel Files are maintained off site at the corporate office in Riverside, Ca. However, during inspection staff files were brought to the facility for review. At 1: PM, personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). LPA reviewed five staff files. Staff files were complete with First Aid/CPR certificates, certificates for training hours, and all required documents were signed and present. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. One staff and one administrator present during inspection were interviewed in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's program. Four of five clients present during inspection volunteered to be interviewed. All four clients indicate that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Program Director, Michelle Hicks

narrative: On April 30, 2021, this agency received allegation that facility is in disrepair. LPA observed during facility inspection, back slider screen door falling off the rails, landing on LPA's head. ADM informed LPA that, "it slips off the rails once in a while, had a maintenance request for a couple of weeks." Confidential interviews disclosed the back-screen door and repairs necessary in the master bedroom have been unrepaired for over a month. During inspection on 05/05/21, LPA observed the dressers in the master bedroom were broken, drawers off the rails, the curtain rods were bent and unable to hold curtains for closets appropriately. Interview with ADM said there was two dressers in the garage to replace one dresser had broken drawers, was unaware of the two dressers in the master bedroom broken. ADM showed LPA that one of the faucets in the master bedroom was not currently working, ADM informed LPA that the pipes were needing to be fixed and maintenance was in the process of correcting it. LPA observed the couch in the living room to have a large stain in the long cushion. LPA took photos of the repairs needed. Based on confidential interviews and LPA's observation the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the department has determined the allegations that S1 has threatened or harassed clients in care on at least one occasion and the facility is in disrepair. The facility is being cited for STRTP Interim Licensing Standards, article 6, section; 87072(d)(10) Personal Rights, the STRTP did not ensure that each child in care is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare & Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable, to be accorded dignity in his or her personal relationships with staff and other persons, this poses an immediate Personal Rights risk to children in care. The facility is also being cited for Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, article 7, section; 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds, the STRTP did not ensure that the facility was clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients in care, this poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the youth in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to facility representative. Confidential interviews revealed that staff question clients in front of other clients about the use of drugs. Other confidential interviews disclosed the staff will talk with clients in the office or somewhere away from other clients. Interview with ADM disclosed that staff are trained to walk out of ear shot of other clients when talking about anything in regard to a client for privacy. Based on confidential interviews the allegations that staff did not provide medical care and staff did not allow residents privacy in the STRTP may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. No deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were explained and handed to Senida Zamora.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Veronica Whitaker and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection on October 27, 2022 at 11:04 am, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated October 27,2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and client de-escalation worksheet, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM Angela King and LPA Veronica Whitaker observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Senida Zamora, Administrator.

On November 9, 2023 at 2:08 pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland, met with New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facilities - Raja Program Director, Michelle Hicks, to deliver a case management deficiencies report. On September 27, 2023, LPA Strickland conducted a records review of six facility staff (Staff #1 [S1], Staff #2 [S2], Staff #3 [S3], Staff #4 [S4], Staff #5 [S5] and Staff #6 [S6]). Information obtained by Community Care Licensing (CCL) revealed five out of six staff members S1, S3, S4, S5, and S6 do not hold a valid First aid/CPR certificate as required by Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) v.4. Record review revealed S1, S3, S4, S5, and S6 had certificates for CPR issued by the NationalCPRFoundation.org. LPA confirmed with the organization that the certificates held by the staff members did not include a first aid component to the training. LPA gathered further information about the training program issuing the certificates for first aid which revealed the training provided to the staff does not meet the requirements as set forth in ILS v.4 standard 87065.1(b)(8)(A) SUPERVISION, EVALUATION AND TRAINING REQUIREMENTS (A) completion of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and first aid training shall be demonstrated by current and valid CPR and first aid cards issued by the American Red Cross, the American Heart Association, a training program approved by the State Emergency Medical Services Authority pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1797.191, or from an accredited college or university. Record review revealed New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facilities Program Statement/ Plan of Operation dated 4/09/2019 page 4 states, The Human Resource Department is responsible for maintaining comprehensive documentation of training education received for staff, peer partners and volunteers. Proof of successful completion of the training is verified by certificates, timesheets, and participants sign-in logs. Record review revealed the facility failed to verify S1, S3, S4, S5 and S6's training certificates were valid and met the requirements set forth in ILS v.4 standard 87065(b)(8)(A). This is a violation of ILS v.4 87022(f) ****** PLAN OF OPERATION The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the plan of operation and may be cited for not doing so. The facility is being cited for violation of Interim ILS v.4 standard 87065.1(b)(8)(A) SUPERVISION, EVALUATION AND TRAINING REQUIREMENTS and violation of ILS v.4 standard 87022(f) PLAN OF OPERATION. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facilities - Raja Program Director, Michelle Hicks

facility_name: NEW BEGINNINGS RESIDENTIAL TREATMENT FAC.- RAJA
narrative: confirmed S4 did not conduct room checks between 1530 hours and 1630 hours at which time C1 was found unconscious. When S4 was interviewed by SI, S4 admitted she had not conducted the room checks. Confidential interviews and medical records note overdose as cause of C1 being found unconscious. Confidential interviews and record review reported after C1 was observed to be unconscious S4 called S2 who was not at the facility at the time of the incident for assistance. Confidential interviews and record review further confirmed S2 arrived at the facility and began cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) as well as instructed S4 to call 9-1-1. Confidential interviews reported S4 did not attempt or assist with any CPR or any life-saving measures until directed by S2 to call 9-1-1. Based on confidential interviews and record review the allegations alleging due to a lack of care and supervision minor (Child #1 [C1]) overdosed while in care and Minor (C1) did not receive medical treatment in a timely manner are substantiated. The complaint allegations are valid because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility is cited for violation of Interim Licensing Standards(ILS) v.4 standard 87078(a) RESPONSIBILITY FOR PROVIDING CARE AND SUPERVISION (a) In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80078, the following shall apply, and ILS v.4 standard PERSONAL RIGHTS (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9 as applicable. The facilities violation of ILS v.4 standard PERSONAL RIGHTS (c) which resulted in C1 not receiving prompt medical assistance when C1 overdosed requires the facility to be assessed an immediate civil penalty per Health and Safety Code 1548(c)(1). An Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending. If an ECP is assessed a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with Civil Penalty assessment and appeal rights to New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facility - Raja Program Director, Michelle Hicks.

narrative: On December 18, 2023 at 2: PM, Associate Governmental Program Analyst (AGPA) Kim Robinson met with the short-term residential therapeutic program (STRTP) director, Michelle Hicks and administrator, Senida Zamora, in order to assess an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP). On November 9, 2023, the Department concluded a complaint investigation alleging the direct care facility manager (S4) neglected to properly supervise and provide timely medical attention for a 16-year-old client #1 (C1). As a result, C1 was found unconscious from an overdose and later passed away. The allegation was determined substantiated, and the STRTP was cited from Interim Licensing Standards Section 87072 (c), Personal Rights and Section 87078(a) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. An immediate civil penalty of $500.00 was assessed. See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated November 9, 2023. Based on the findings from the medical report, consistent interviews and findings from the Riverside County Sheriff report the Department has determined that an enhanced civil penalty is warranted for S4's lack of supervision and prompt medical attention for C1. As a result, C1 suffered an overdose and loss of life while under the direct care of STRTP S4. Pursuant to the Enhanced Civil Penalty law, the Health and Safety Code 1548 (e)(3) states a violation the Department determines "resulted in the death of a person receiving care through a short term residential therapeutic program" the Department will issue an immediate civil penalty of $7,500.00. An exit interview was completed, and appeal rights discussed. A copy of this report, the Confidential Names List, and a Civil Penalty Assessment - Serious Bodily Injury/Physical Abuse (Form 421-D) were provided to the administrator. The signed copy will be retained in the facility file.

On 04/22/2024 at 9:45am, Licensing Program Analyst's (LPA's) Cynthia Robinson and Cynthia Velasquez, conducted an unannounced inspection at New Beginnings Residential Treatment- Raja STRTP for the purpose of conducting a required two-year inspection. LPA's met with Senida Zamora, Assistant Program Director. A physical plant inspection was completed. The facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in operating order. All required forms are posted including the complaint procedures, personal rights, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. The hot water was measured to be at 109 degrees and read at 10:40am. There are currently no clients in care. There are four bedrooms, each room has two twin beds. Each bedroom has a dresser for each client that provides drawers for storage and a closet for additional storage. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room and there is one client per bed. There are 2 and a half bathrooms in the home. LPA's reviewed one staff file (S1). LPA's reviewed Operations Plan, Emergency Intervention and Disaster Plan, all documents were sufficient. LPA's conducted one staff interview. A copy of this report was provided to Senida Zamora, Assistant Program Director.

narrative: On June 23, 2021 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Anastasia Flores and LPA Valerie Wilson, arrived at New Beginnings Residential Shalom Facility (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Facility Manager, Ajah Jelks. The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility. There was one facility manager and one therapist present at the time of the inspection. Two clients were in school and one client was on home pass. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. At 10: AM, Ajah Jelks led the tour of the facility. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. The facility includes a dining area, kitchen area, living room and laundry room/garage utilized for storage. The facility has a staff office and bedroom #4 is utilized by therapists. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. During inspection, bedroom #2 did not have an operable fire alarm, however it was fixed and working prior to leaving the facility. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The screen by the kitchen table, sliding screen door to backyard and two screens on the master bedroom need to be replaced and there was no screen on the master bathroom window. Program Director called maintenance and is having them fixed and replaced on 06/26/21. Gym equipment and other activities were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. At 10: AM, the hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 110.4 degrees, master bathroom #1 was measured at 11: AM to be 113 degrees and at 11: AM bathroom #2 measured at 113.4 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. () Administrator Stacy Rougely, is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one therapist, one facility administrator, one facility manager, nine direct care staff, one head of service and one Program Director. Facility has obtained Mental Health Certification effective 04/09/2019. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through CARF effective through 11/30/2022. Licensing fee payments have been paid and there is currently a balance of zero. At 11: AM, six of six client files were reviewed during time of inspection. There were required documents not up to date in the client files, but due to time constraints, deficiencies and/or advisory notes will be issued on a separate date. Personnel Files are maintained off site at the corporate office in Riverside, Ca. However, during inspection staff files were brought to the facility for review. At 12: PM, personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS). At 12: PM, LPA's reviewed 10 staff files. Staff files were complete with First Aid/CPR certificates, certificates for training hours, and all required documents were signed and present. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. There were six staff files that needed updated medical records. At 2: PM, LPA's interviewed three direct care staff and one facility manager that were present, in regard to their job duties, training, and services provided at the facility. All staff were able to provide sufficient information in relation to the facility's program. Four of five clients present during inspection volunteered to be interviewed, one client refused. All four clients indicate that their basic needs are being met at the facility and core services being provided as well. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Administrator, Stacy Rougely.

On June 24, 2021 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Anastasia Flores, arrived at the New Beginnings Residential Treatment (STRTP) and met with Program Director, Michelle Hicks. The purpose of this inspection was to deliver technical violations as part of the annual inspection conducted on June 23, 2021. During inspection on 06/23/21, there were required documents not found in the client files a technical violation is being issued today 06/24/21. LPA;s observed the screen sliding door off the tracks that needs to be fixed, two screens on the master bedroom window that need to be replaced, one screen on the dining room window with a hole. And no screen on the master bathroom window. Program Director called to have the screens replaced and showed LPA Flores a work order for the corrections to be made on 06/26/21, however on 06/24/21, Program Director showed proof with photos and receipt for work completed.. Based on inspection dated 06/17/21, the facility is not in compliance. Facility is being issued a technical violation for Interim Licensing Standards 87068. Modifications to the Needs and Services Plan. LPA observed the needs and services plan was not updated in the clients file in five out of six client's files. The facility is being issued a technical violation LIC TV, 80087 (a) Buildings and grounds for the window screens not being in good repair, during the inspection on 06/23/21, the facility had screens that needed to be replaced and/or fixed. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report, LIC 859 client Records Review, LIC TV, and appeal rights were reviewed and given to facility representative.

Other confidential interviews revealed that C1 jumped out of the van while Staff #2 (S2) was trying to pull over to the side of the road for safety. Confidential interviews disclosed that S2 was backing up slowly when C1 jumped out of the van. Record review reveal the van was stopped when C1 jumped out of the van and that S1 was helping another client when C1 jumped out the back doors to the van. Interview with S1 and S2 revealed that the van was moving slowly in reverse to park when C1 jumped out. LPA attempted to obtain video footage from STRTP, however was informed by ADM that the cameras on the van were not in working. Based on confidential interviews the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the department has determined the allegation that the staff did not prevent client #1 (C1) from jumping out of the facility van while in motion is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), article 6, section 87065.2 (b) (1) Personnel Duties; staff did not ensure proper supervision, protection and of children on at least one occasion. This poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to the youth in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were explained and handed to Stacy Rougely. Interview with S1 denied saying anything to C1 that would make C1 feel uncomfortable. Interview with S2 denied hearing S1 say anything to C1, stating the music was turned up in the van by another client. Other confidential interview disclosed this was not the first time that C1 has caused the staff to try to calm C1 down while in transport, causing other clients to be late to court or family visits. LPA attempted to obtain video footage from STRTP, however was informed by ADM that the cameras on the van were not working. Based on confidential interviews and confidential record review the allegation that staff made clients feel uncomfortable while in transport in the facility van on at least one occasion may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC811 and appeal rights were explained and handed to Stacy Rougely.

During investigation, confidential interviews stated that staff members cannot restraint a client from leaving the facility, but that staff do implement the facility's Absent Without Leave (AWOL) protocol each time a client leaves or attempts to leave out of the care and supervision of staff. Confidential interviews further stated that C1 was absconding from the facility on a continuous basis and was engaging in Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC) activity while in care. Confidential interviews stated that C1 was provided with resources while in care, and meetings with CSW were conducted to further address C1's behaviors. Other confidential interviews stated liking the placement and added that clients can walk out of the front door at any time despite staff efforts. Another confidential interview confirmed that C1 was engaging in CSEC activity in the past but denied that C1 had engaged in CSEC activity at the time of this allegation. A CSW was unable to comment on the allegation. LPA received inconsistent information about whether C1's CSEC activity out of care was a result of staff not preventing C1 from leaving the facility. Based on confidential interviews, and record review the allegation that staff did not prevent C1 from AWOLing resulting in C1 engaging in CSEC activity, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and due to technical difficulties a copy of this report along with the appeal rights will be emailed to Facility Administrator, Senida Zamora.

On October 24, 2023 at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Val Wilson, arrived at the New Beginnings Residential Treatment Facility (NBRTF), Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and was greeted and granted access by LaShanique Youngblood, Direct Care Staff/Facility Manager. LPA identified the purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the facility and provided the Entrance Checklist. LPA then met with Nannette Lewis, Administrator and Quality Assurance. Upon arrival, there was one facility manager, one administrator, and two clients at NBRTF. Two clients were in school and one client is on an unauthorized absence. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during the inspection. LPA was provided a work area in the main office area and then the LPA and Administrator began the inspection tour at 12: PM. Three out of three staff interviews and three out of three client interviews were completed during the inspection. The facility consists of four bedrooms and two bathrooms. All bedrooms have individual beds and drawer space for each client. The facility ensures that there is one client per bed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The facility also includes a dining area, kitchen area, living room, laundry room/garage, garage storage room, a staff office/medication room and bedroom #4 is utilized by the therapist. All fire extinguishers, facility smoke detectors, and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsman poster, and activity schedule. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. The hot water in the kitchen was measured to be 111 degrees, master bathroom #1 was measured to be 112.2 degrees, and bathroom #2 measured at 110.6 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. A current maintenance log is kept with the van along with a current vehicle registration and insurance card. (Continued) (Continued) LPA observed and took pictures of the following during the inspection: Bedroom #3 missing the screen in the bedroom window; removed for repair and will be picked up today. The doorjambs of two doors (bedroom #3 and garage storage room) are split. There are multiple areas in the garage and the house that have been repaired that need paint touch ups. The upper half of the staff office/medication room door is cracked and separated on the bottom right corner. The facility does not have a current plan for provision of emergency power that identifies a suppliers of backup generators, a permanently installed generator, or a portable generator. Based on observation, the facility is being cited on the following areas: Type B- Disaster Preparedness 1565(a)(7)(A), Type B- Buildings and Grounds 80087(a) and Technical Violation- Physical Plant 80088(b). Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC 809D,LIC 9102, and appeal rights were provided and explained to the Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on 09/24/24 at 10: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 09/24/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and youth safety plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator, Michelle Hicks.

On August 26, 2025, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete arrived at New Beginnings Residential Shalom Treatment Facility Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was greeted and granted access by Administrator Nannette Lewis.The purpose of the visit is to conduct an annual/random inspection of the facility. At 12: PM, LPA Peete began the physical plant inspection; Administrator Lewis assisted LPA in touring the facility's interior and exterior grounds. During the facility inspection, LPA observed cameras in the common areas, the therapist office, hallways, and the outside perimeter, both front and back of the home. The cameras are not pointed toward client bedrooms or bathrooms. According to the Administrator's statement, the video cameras do not capture audio and do not replace staff supervision. The monitors in the staff office display live feed from the facility's cameras. The facility consists of four bedrooms, three of which are client bedrooms; bedroom four is utilized as the therapist's office. There are two bathrooms, one of which is a staff bathroom, that clients still have access to and can use. All client bedrooms have individual beds with adequate drawers and closet space for each client. The client bedrooms are equipped with a small combination safe for storing personal items or contraceptives and are arranged so that there are no more than two clients per room. LPA observed that all client beds had the appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Extra linens and toiletry items are stored in the garage and entryway closet, accessible to clients as needed. All toilets, sinks, and showers are maintained in safe, sanitary, and operating condition. Additionally, the water in each bathroom and in the kitchen measured between 105°F and 120°F. The facility also features a dining area, kitchen, living room, garage with a washer and dryer, and a designated central storage area with extra household supplies and hygiene products. The storage is accessible to staff as needed to ensure the STRTP is maintained with sufficient supplies. The Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. The facility maintains its fire clearance, and all exits and entrances are unobstructed. LPA observed adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The facility's outside grounds were observed to be well maintained, free of debris, and in good condition, with patio furniture that appeared suitable for client use. Additionally, LPA observed age-appropriate games and activities for the client's recreational time. The facility smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector are in appropriate working order. The fire extinguishers are properly charged and placed throughout the facility. The facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods, including a variety of snacks for clients. LPA observed a minimum of seven days of non-perishable food and a two-day perishable supply, and the facility appears to be following the posted menu. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are stored separately from all food items in a locked cabinet located in the garage. The cooking knives and all other sharp items are stored in the entryway closet. The Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. All required forms are posted, including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Additionally, the facility maintains two vehicles for client transportation. Both vehicles are in good working condition and have current registration and valid insurance. No observable safety or health hazards were noted during the physical plant inspection, and no deficiencies were cited. LPA Peete also reviewed the facility's operational requirements and no deficiencies were noted for this area of the inspection. Based on observations made during the inspection, no deficiencies are being cited. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights, was provided to the facility Administrator, Nannette Lewis.

A1 indicated that C1 was already with A1 and A1 was the one who transported C1 to the facility to pick up some of C1's belongings from the facility. Both staff and A1 could not confirm why C1 did not get his belongings and could only recall C1 getting upset and walking away. It was reported that staff failed to ensure that child received medications. A1 confirmed that staff denied giving C1 his medication but both staff and A1 confirmed that staff stated it was due to being unable to give the medication to an unauthorized party (which is A1) and staff is not authorized to give the medication to a client when the medication is to be administered by staff to child. Per interviews, C1 was not returning to the facility that day and wanted to pick up some belongings to go back with A1. Additionally, LPA could not interview C1 after multiple attempts to obtain pertinent information. Based on the inconsistent information obtained during confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Administrator.

narrative: Additionally, interview statements revealed that staff would make effort in having C1 call his grandmother to prevent C1 from awoling. narrative: Administrator denied the allegation and provided LPA with photographs of the RP's vehicle showing no dents.
