Furthermore, it was reported that a neighbor was trying to drive her car out of the driveway, and 3 boys surrounded her car and would not let RP drive her car out of her driveway, and then 1 of the boys threw a ball, very hard, "purposely hitting and slamming" the hood of RP's vehicle . LPA could not confirm this incident due to RP indicating that RP was parked on the sidewalk not RP's driveway in front of RP's house. RP was trying to exit the parking spot to the center of street and clients were playing football in proximity to RP's car causing her to have difficulty leaving her parking spot. Additionally, clients were not saying anything inappropriate to the RP but RP felt they were too close. It was also indicated that there was a staff watching the children. S1 indicated that he was outside during this alleged incident and he did not see the ball purposely hit the car. S2 indicated that she was outside when during this incident and the boys were playing on the street; however, the ball did not hit RP's car and went under another car and in addition S2 did not observe any inappropriate behavior from the boys to the RP. Furthermore, S2 confirmed that RP did say to S2 if the clients can the clients play some place else. That was when RP went to the front door for a quick moment to get a staff in charge to speak to RP but RP had already LPA could not determine if there was a lack of supervision resulting in youth in care acting inappropriately due to not being able to confirm if the clients threw the ball at RP's car purposely or accidentally. In addition, it was indicated that the clients did not say anything or act inappropriate to the RP. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. narrative: LPA observe on the Video footage, C1 was in danger to himself and S1 intervened due to reasonably expecting to achieve safe control of C1. It was observed in the video footage, time being 7 minutes and 10 minutes, that in the process of C1 pulling down a shelf, S1 can be seen holding C1 from behind due to the shelf coming down; C1 and S1 landed on the floor with the shelf on them and from there, S1 conducted a floor restraint due to C1 being extremely combative and the early intervention techniques were not effective. Although S1 felt he made the right call to keep C1 safe, Staff did not follow facility's Emergency Intervention Plan that requires a staff team of two or more trained people to conduct the restraint. It was informed to LPA that S2 was making a phone call to the police while S1 was conducting the restraint. LPA could not determine if C1 obtained an alleged bruise due to LPA being unable to interview the RP and C1 after multiple attempts and no pictures were taken of C1. Based on the interview statements and documentation obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Facility cited for Violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 80022(k) Plan of Operation: The facility shall operate in accordance with the terms specified in the Plan of Operation and may be cited for not doing so. Video footage confirmed that S1 failed to follow facility's plan of operation by conducting a restraint by himself when the restraint requires a staff team of two or more trained people to conduct the restraint. See 9099-D A copy of this report and appeal rights will be emailed to the administrator. Per interviews, C1 left the house and staff went out to go get the clients food due to dinner that was prepared getting thrown on the ground. S1 assumed C AWOLed and bought food for the clients that were present in the home. It was revealed in interviews that when C1 returned, C1 got upset because the food that was bought by staff, was not bought for him. It was reported that staff withhold food from clients due to their behavior. It was informed to LPA that staff has not withheld food from clients and clients are free to make there own food; clients confirmed that they do have adequate amount of food. In addition, interviews revealed that there is a refrigerator in the kitchen with perishable, non-perishables and frozen foods for the clients to make. Furthermore, it was reported that a staff locked C1 out and didn't let C1 back in until C1 called the police back out to the home. It was also reported that after they opened the door a staff threatened C1 and slapped C1's phone out of his hand. It was reported that C1's roommate (C2) witnessed this. LPA attempted to interview C1 but C1 refused to speak with LPA multiple times. Furthermore, S3 denied this allegation and there was no witness to confirm this occurred. Based on the information obtained during confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of the report will be left at the facility.

narrative: On November 22, 2021 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Annual inspection. LPA met Sueretta Small/ Administrator who granted access into the facility, and who provided a copy of LIC 500 and resident roster. A tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is designed to provide care/supervision for six (8) males, ambulatory only clients, ages 12-17 years. Plus, Non -minor Dependents, Ambulatory only. The home is set up as follows: This is two story, four (4) bedrooms, two & half (2.5) bathrooms home located in a residential neighborhood. There is also a covered patio with a table and adequate amount of seating. Yard is well maintained and has locked shed with yard tools. The sides of the house and clear of any debris and landscape is well maintained. Downstairs (main floor) has the following: There is a living room with 3 sofas. This room is equipped with a camera with a view of activities in living room. There are 3 bookshelves filled with books and games. a flat screen TV. There is desk equipped with computer and house phone. There is therapist room off front entrance way equipped with desk, computer, fireplace covered with security screen and adequate seating for client services. There is a storage room off the front entrance with locked sharps. Kitchen has fully charged fire extinguisher,upper cabinets with adequate bowls, plates and spices. Lower cabinets equipped with pots, pans and food storage containers. Dining room has seating for 8 residents. The kitchen is stocked with non-perishable foods for one week. There is an emergency doorway to facilitate evacuation from the front door, garage door off kitchen and back door off the living room. Garage is equipped with extra freezer and refrigerator for extra food supplies. There are 2 washers and 2 dryers for laundry with laundry soap and disinfectants in upper cabinets above washer. There is additional cabinet equipped with extra linens and laundry soap. continued on LIC 809 c There is additional closet off the main entryway equipped with fully charged fire extinguisher as well as extra supply of snacks and extra keys in locked box. Camera in front entrance with view of all activities in downstairs entrance way. Upstairs (2nd floor) equipped with camera with a view of all activities in hallway only. Bedroom #1: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, lighting and functional smoke detector. Bedroom #2: Is equipped with one (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, lighting and functional smoke detector. Bedroom #3: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, lighting and functional smoke detector. This room has an attached bathroom with hot water is within an acceptable temperature range. Bedroom #4: Is equipped with one (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and functional smoke detector and lighting . Bathroom: full equipped tub and shower combination, sink, the hot water temperature is within an acceptable temperature range. Hall closet equipped with extra hygiene products and linens and extra household supplies. Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible. There are no firearms/dangerous weapons. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperatures are maintained between 105 and 120 degrees (F). Children in care will be supervised and protected at all times; Children will attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. All smoke detectors were tested and are operating properly in the home at the time of visit. Carbon Monoxide alarms were tested and functional in the home at the time of the visit. Medications locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. Facility posts child's rights on living room wall.Facility license posted in main office. Exit interview was conducted and no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA Phillips will travel to corporate office to view staff files. LPA will return at a later date to review client files. No parking was available at corporate office, administrator agreed to bring files on LPA return visit to facility. A copy of the report was emailed to administrator.

Based on the interviews conducted and documentary evidence obtained the information did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. Due to inconsistent statements LPA Phillips was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be Unsubstantiated meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged incidents occurred. No deficiencies cited at the time of this investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and copy of this report was left with facility administrator.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Torres conducted a case management inspection March 22, 2022 at 9:03am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 10 out of Direct Care Staff and 8 out of 8 youth files were reviewed. 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 7 out of 8 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated March 22, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA David Torres observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Sueretta Small, Administrator.

Based on the interviews conducted, administrator's admission,records reviewed, and LPA observation, the preponderance of standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. narrative: On March 14, 2021 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Annual Random inspection. LPA met Sueretta Small/ Administrator who granted access into the facility, and who provided a copy of LIC 500 and resident roster. LPA conducted a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. This facility is designed to provide care/supervision for six (8) males, ambulatory only clients, ages 11-17 years. This facility also provides services to non -minor dependents. Naloxone waiver on file. The current census is five (5). The home is set up as follows: This is a two story, four (4) bedrooms, two & half (2.5) bathrooms home located in a residential neighborhood. There is also a covered patio with a table and adequate amount of seating. There is a therapy pod in yard with phone, two large chairs, book case, desk with chair. Yard is well maintained and has locked shed with yard tools. The sides of the house are clear of any debris and yard is well maintained. Downstairs (main floor) has the following: There is a living room with 3 sofas. This room is equipped with a camera with a view of activities in living room. There are 3 bookshelves filled with books and games, two (2) flat screen television. There is desk equipped with computer and house phone, complaint box with forms available on wall mounted paper holder. There is therapist room off front entrance way equipped with three (3) desk, computer, fireplace covered with security screen and adequate seating for client services. There is a storage room off the front entrance with locked sharps. The kitchen has fully charged fire extinguisher, upper cabinets has adequate bowls, plates and spices. Lower cabinets equipped with pots, pans and food storage containers. The dining room has seating for 8 residents. The kitchen is stocked with non-perishable foods for one week. There is an emergency doorway to facilitate evacuation from the front door, garage door off kitchen and back door off the living room. Garage is equipped with two (2) extra freezers and refrigerators for extra food supplies. There are 2 washers and 2 dryers for laundry with laundry soap and disinfectants in locked upper cabinets above washer. There is an additional cabinet equipped with extra linens and laundry soap. cont on 809c There is an additional closet off the main entryway equipped with fully charged fire extinguisher as well as extra supply of snacks and extra keys in locked box. There is a camera in front entrance with view of all activities in downstairs entrance way. Fire pull station in hallway. There is staff office to the downstairs with three (3) desk and computers, storage cabinet for staff personal belongings, locked cabinets with extra gloves, mask,covid test kits and gaming controllers. LPA inspected two (2) facility vehicles Chrysler and Toyota mini van and confirmed all seat bels working, first aid kit and both have valid registration and insurance. Upstairs (2nd floor) equipped with camera with a view of all activities in hallway only. Bedroom #1: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, lighting and functional smoke detector. Bedroom #2: Is equipped with one (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, lighting and functional smoke detector. Bedroom #3: Is equipped with two (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, lighting and functional smoke detector. This room has an attached bathroom with hot water is within an acceptable temperature range. Bedroom #4: Is equipped with one (2) twin size beds. There are adequate drawers, closet space, and functional smoke detector and lighting overhead with ceiling fan combo. Bathroom: equipped with tub and shower combination, sink. cont on 809 c . LPA conducted three staff interviews, LPA was able to conduct one (1) client interview and all other client in school or away from facility. LPA conducted three (3) client files and reviews NSP, admission agreement, client cash resources and confirmed in compliance. LPA reviewed medication log and confirmed compliance. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are made inaccessible. There are no firearms/dangerous weapons. Temperatures in rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Children in care will be supervised and protected at all times; Children will attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. All smoke detectors were tested and are operating properly in the home at the time of visit. Carbon Monoxide alarms were tested and functional in the home at the time of the visit. Medications locked and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. All sharps locked in cabinet and stored in locked box in the cabinet. LPA observed facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Exit interview was conducted and no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA will return at a later date to review staff and files. On 06/12/2023 at 10:30AM am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Zena Phillips and (LPA) Kenrick Ellis arrived at the facility to deliver findings for the Case Management-Incident regarding SIR #1040662 . LPAs were greeted by Shalane Brouchet/Program Manager and granted access to the facility. On 05/23/2024 a Special Incident Report (SIR), SIR #1040662 was submitted in regard to a client that was restrained due to self harming. SIR indicated that client was engaged in self harming behavior. During the case management-incident, LPA conducted confidential interviews, reviewed documentary evidence, and reviewed video footage of incident. LPA observation of video footage reveal that a restraint was not conducted but safety intervention. Based on the incident reports, confidential interviews and documentary evidence; statements were consistent that appropriate emergency intervention procedures and protocols were implemented to support the needs and safety of the client and staff involved in the incidents on 05/23/2024. There was no corroborating evidence that supports that a violation has occurred. This case management-incident has been found to be unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Shalane Brouchet/Program Manager. A copy of this report will be provided to the facility Licensee.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA interviewed all involved parties and reviewed Special Incident Report dated May 27, 2023. During the course of the investigation LPA received conflicting accounts of the incident. Staff persons denied engaging in a physical altercation other than using approved restraint techniques for approved purposes. Staff denied purposely causing injury to clients or speaking inappropriately to them. One client declined to be interviewed and another maintained that the staff conducted inappropriate restraints and spoke insults to the clients. All parties that were interviewed denied that clients did not receive proper medical assessment or treatment for their injuiries. Based on the available information, there is lack of consensus as to exactly what happened, therefore the allegations are resolved as unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated finding means that although an allegation may be true, there is lack of of sufficient evidence to prove that it did happen UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analysts Zena Phillips and Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegations. LPA Phillips interviewed Staff and Clients. LPA Jones-Steward reviewed the work schedule, client roster, locker agreement and menus for September and October 2022. During the investigation, Staff denied that they mishandle or disrespect client property during room searches or speak to them inappropriately. Staff stated that the food served is of good quality & quantity and that appropriate hygiene products are provided. Administrator stated that during the time in question only one client requested a locker for his belongings. Staff stated that the only time the clients are not allowed to use the facility Internet during the day when they are home because they refused to attend school. LPA Jones-Steward observed on 08/2/2024 that the food supply met Title 22 requirements for fresh, non-perishable and snack foods. and that there were surplus hygiene products available for client use. Based on the investigation LPA Jones-Steward was not able to gather sufficient information to substantiate the above allegations. Therefore they are resolved as unsubstantiated. narrative: The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099-D for violations of the Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) for STRTP, Section 87065.5(b)(2)(c), due to failure to maintain awake supervision and comply with direct care staff-to-child ratio requirements. Even if staffing ratios were met, a staff member sleeping in an area accessible to youth compromised supervision, posed security risks, and highlighted the need for stricter oversight to ensure regulatory compliance. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Sueretta Small, Administrator and Shalane Brouchet. The facility is required to submit a corrective action plan addressing the cited violations to ensure compliance with CDSS regulations and prevent the recurrence of similar incidents.
investigation_findings: 13On 03/06/2025 at 10: AM, LPA Jarmin arrived at New Concept STRTP to discuss the findings of the investigation into staff sleeping during shifts. LPA met with the Office Manager and explained that the investigation concluded on February 12, 2025, at 4: PM. During the investigation, LPAs conducted confidential interviews, assessed health and safety conditions, and reviewed relevant documents. The findings confirmed the allegation, showing that the licensee violated staffing ratio requirements for a census of eight children and failed to enforce the facility's policy prohibiting sleeping during shifts. Evidence also revealed security and supervision concerns, indicating a failure to ensure proper oversight and protect personal dignity. Based on LPA interviews, record reviews, and evidence obtained, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegation of Neglect/Lack of Supervision is SUBSTANTIATED. Deficiencies are cited to the facility for failure to provide adequate supervision as required by licensing regulations. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On June 17, 2025, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) C. White and C. Wilkerson arrived at New Concept II located at W 78th Street Inglewood, CA. 90305 for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA's were met by Applicant, Sueretta Small and Administrative Assistant, Shalane Brouchet. The applicant is requesting to license the facility as a Short Term Residential Program to provide to provide care and supervision to six (6) male children, ages 12-17 years old, and Non-Minor Dependents, ambulatory only. Currently the census is zero (0). The home is set up as follows: This is a single story 3-bedroom, 3-bathroom, home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry area, 2 staffing offices, a backyard, a detached garage, and a detached shed. Living room: is equipped two (2) sofas, two (2) mounted TV's, a desk with a chair and a computer. Dining room: is equipped with a round table and four (4) chairs. Additionally, the kitchen has an extended bar countertop with four (4) bar chairs for clients to sit and eat. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), a microwave (above the stove), an air fryer, and a blender. Sharp knives are kept in a double combination lock box, located in a locked hall cabinet and made inaccessible to children in care. LPA's observed a covered trash can, ample plates, cups, eating utensils, pots and pan. LPA's observed a posted menu and ample nonperishable food items. The applicant will ensure that three (3) nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. Laundry area: is adjacent to the mental health staff office. The area has a washer, dryer, built-in cabinets, and a door leading to the left side of the house. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 1 of 3) Staffing Offices: one staffing office is located to the left of the front entrance. The office will be used by the STRTP staff and is equipped with three (3) desks, chairs, and computers. Additionally, the office has a mounted TV, a non-operational glass enclosed fireplace, lockers, a filing cabinet, a window that looks out into the living room, and a split door that has deadbolt locks. The second staff office is located past the kitchen and will be used by the Mental Health staff. The office is equipped with three (3) desks, chairs, and computers. Additionally, the office has an attached bathroom, and a window that looks out into the kitchen. Detached Garage: contains two (2) refrigerator/freezer for extra food supplies and medication requiring refrigeration; three (3) locked cabinets for disinfectants, cleaning supplies, extra bedding, and emergency food/water supplies; a table with chairs; and a locked gated water heater. Detached Shed: will be used as a therapy room. Currently the shed is unfurnished. Bedrooms: are bedrooms are equipped with two (2) twin beds, drawers, closets, a desk and chair, laundry baskets, two (2) small combination safes for client to store personal supplies, windows, and combination ceiling fan/lights. Bathroom #1: is located in the hallway between bedroom #1 and bedroom #2. The bathroom has a toilet, sink, and a tub/shower combination. The bathroom is equipped with a combination lock door as the bathroom contains a locked cabinet for medication storage and medication log. This bathroom will be utilized by staff only. Bathroom #2: is located inside Staff Office #2. The bathroom contains a toilet, sink, and a shower. Bathroom #3: is located adjacent to bedroom #3. The bathroom has a toilet, tub/shower combination, and double sinks. This bathroom will be used by clients. All bathrooms were checked and found to be in working order. Hot water was tested and found to be between 105-120 degrees. Vehicle: The applicant will use a White Chrysler Voyager to transport clients. The vehicle is in good condition with current registration through 10/10/2025 and insurance with Nonprofits Insurance Alliance that expires 04/04/2026. Report continued on LIC 809C (Page 2 of 3) LPA's observed two (2) regulation fire extinguishers. Extra linens and hygiene supplies are stored in locked hallway closet next to bedroom #1. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinets in the laundry area and in the garage. Medications will be kept locked cabinet located in the staff bathroom. The First Aid kit was checked and found to be complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. There are no security bars on the bedroom windows. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. There are no bodies of water on the premises. LPA's observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. LPA's observed the electrical shut off valve located in the garage, the gas shut off valve is located on the right side of the home behind a gated fence, and the water shut off valve is located in the front of the home to the right of the entrance. The following was discussed with the facility Administrator: Children will be accorded personal rights. Children in care will be supported, encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care will be able to contact the licensing agency. Children will be supervised and protected at all times. Children will be accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children will not be restricted in telephone use except by court order. Applicant will provide and ensure three nutritious meals, snacks, and special diets. Applicant will ensure to have written authorization to obtain medical and dental care. Applicant will ensure to have personal rights forms in children's files. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Staff working in the facility will have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances, and Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility will operate within license conditions and limitations including capacity limit. Facility meets posting requirements, including COVID-19 best practices signs and emergency telephone numbers are in prominent locations. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Applicant, Sueretta Small. (Page 3 of 3)

LPA remined Licensee that children in care are to be supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children in care will be able to contact the licensing agency. Children will be supervised and protected at all times. Children will be accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Children will not be restricted in telephone use except by court order. Licensee will ensure the facility has a written plan of operation, written authorization to obtain medical and dental care for clients and ensure to have personal rights forms in children's files. Licensee acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Licensee will provide the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirm that staff ratio meets the regulations. Licensee will ensure that all staff working in the facility will have DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances, and Child Abuse Index Checks. Facility meets posting requirements. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee, Sueretta Small.

On 4/14/23 the Department received a complaint alleging C1 has access to a vape pen and staff threatened client in care. It was alleged that C1 vapes in the facility and staff told C1 that they were going to have someone beat C1 up. The facility staff when interviewed indicated no staff has threatened to have C1 beaten up by someone else. Staff stated C1 did vape and smoke at the facility without permission. Staff would attempt to redirect C1 from smoking and staff would report each time C1 was found smoking or vaping. C1 when interviewed refused to answer questions and refused to participate in the interview. Two other clients interviewed indicated staff has not threatened any of the clients. Staff did not say they were going to have someone beat up any of the clients. The two clients stated C1 would smoke, however staff would redirect C1 who would not listen to staff. LPA reviewed CFT meeting notes and incident reports which indicated staff would report C1's smoking and attempted to redirect and seek help for C1's smoking. The other agency's investigative report and C1's interview indicated C1 denied any physical abuse by staff. All clients interviewed denied witnessing C1 get hit by staff. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mention above. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: On October 10, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carrie Palmer conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the agency above and spoke with the representative above regarding a special incident report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on July 19, 2023. The SIR indicated the client disclosed using a razor blade found in the bathroom's medicine cabinet to self-harm. LPA Palmer toured the facility and interviewed children regarding the accessibility of sharp objects. During the review of the facility, LPA did not observe any sharp objects that might be accessible to the residents. LPA observed knives in a locked cabinet. LPA interviewed all residents present in the facility. All residents disclosed that they do not have access to sharp objects in the facility. However, C1 shared that C1 found a razor on the ground outside and C1 states C1 tried to cut himself with the razor. LPA Palmer interviewed The Facility Manager who states that staff conduct a detailed inventory of the children's belongings when they come home from school and every time residence come back to the STRTP. The Facility Manager also stated that a safety plan was developed and implemented and that C1 has met with C1s therapist for support. There are no violations of Title 22, of the California Code of Regulations. No deficiencies were cited during today's inspection. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 was provided to the facility representative above and an exit interview was conducted.

One bathroom is used for clients and the other 2 are used by staff. There is also a kitchen, living room and dining area. Outdoor activity space is also present and available for use. LPA Palmer was able to see food supply and verified there was enough perishables and non-perishables items. The facility was observed to be clean, safe, sanitary, in good repair and passageways were unobstructed. There were no bodies of water on the premises. Cleaning solutions, were not locked in the laundry area, but was corrected during the visit. Over the counter medication was observed to be locked in a drawer. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were present and tested today and are working. During the inspection LPA Palmer observed the children's Personal Rights, Ombudsman flyer, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, and foster youth bill of rights were posted. LPA Palmer received a copy of the LIC 500 dated September 30, 2024 and the Client Roster. The facility was unable to identify who the Facility Manager was on duty during the visit, but provided via email a client roster listing all residential counselors as Managers on Duty. The current facility manager listed on the LIC 500 was not present at the time of the visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to staff. This annual requires a continuation. No deficiencies cited during the visit.

narrative: On 6/23/2021 at 1: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the New Dawn facility for the purpose of a Annual/ Required inspection. LPA met with Facility manager Regina Head and together did a walk thru of the facility both inside and out. LPA observed the following: This is a single story single family residence with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, game room, TV room, living space, kitchen, dining room, mental health area, attached garage and outdoor activity space. TV room, living room, game room, kitchen, dining room, bathroom, mental area and attached garage were all observed to be clean and in good repair. Mental health area, office area with attached staff bathroom consisted of desks, computers and office area had two (2) locked filing cabinets containing sharp objects and medications and one(1) locked closet that are only accessible by staff. Kitchen has required perishable and non-perishable food supply. Water temperature was checked in bathroom #1 and temperature measured at (144.7 degrees Fahrenheit). All areas observed at this time were clean, working and furniture was in good repair. Garage housed water heater, extra supplies, (2) additional deep freezers, extra fridge and additional locked cabinets with snacks. Bedroom #1 occupied by 2 children located opposite office area two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #2- located across from common bathroom Occupied by 1 child, two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #3- located adjacent to common bathroom Occupied by 1 child two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bathroom #1- consisted of toilet, sink, shower/tub combination. Water temperature tested and measured at 144.7 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA reviewed three (3) children folders including one (1) child medication log, five (5) staff folders and vehicle maintenance logs. Additionally, LPA ensured all smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines were in working order. Files were maintained and required documents were present. Facility vehicle was last serviced on 4/22/2021. LPA observed the following deficiencies: At 1: PM LPA observed water temperatures in all bathrooms to be over the required temperature of 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Temperatures in community bathroom was 144.7 degrees Fahrenheit. Per Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies (e) Faucets used by clients for personal care such as shaving and grooming shall deliver hot water. (1) Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water delivered to plumbing fixtures used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). Exit interview completed, the following deficiencies were cited and a copy of this report was given to Facility manager.

During the course of the investigation Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha conducted a record review on 8/6/21 and obtained copies special incident reports, client's (C1) needs and services plans, health and education passport, placement agreement, entrance survey, special interest form, court documents, child family team meeting notes and medical and medication records. Investigator Douglas Real conducted interviews with one County Social Worker (CSW) on 8/16/21, interviewed one House Manager 9/1/21, one Detective on 9/8/21, one Therapist on 9/29/21, one Client (C2) on 10/13/21, one Residential Counselor (RC1) on 10/21/21, one Assistant Director on 10/21/21, a second Residential Counselor (RC2) on 10/21/21, a third Residential Counselor (RC3) on 10/30/21, a fourth Residential Counselor (RC4) on 10/31/21, one Care Giver (CG1) on 11/2/21, a second Care Giver (CG2) 11/12/21. Investigator Real obtained a copy of the Chino Police Department police report regarding the incident on 9/8/21. On 8/5/21 the Department received a complaint alleging a facility client died from a drug overdose due to neglect by staff. Facility employees denied the allegation. Statements obtained from confidential interviews conducted revealed facility staff do not permit clients to use drugs and conduct safety checks every thirty minutes. Staff reported C1 did not disclose or present with behaviors indicating he intended to self-harm. However, C1 stated he wanted to "get high" while he and the facility therapist were processing a recent family visit. Staff reported safety checks were conducted on C1 every thirty minutes. Record review revealed the safety checks were notated on C1's activity log. Based on information gathered through interviews conducted and record review the allegation is found unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid the standard of the preponderance of evidence was not met. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and confidential names form dated 1/10/22 was provided the above-mentioned facility representative. No deficiencies were cited.

narrative: During the course of the investigation Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha conducted a record review on 8/6/21 and obtained copies special incident reports, client's (C1) needs and services plans, health and education passport, placement agreement, entrance survey, special interest form, court documents, child family team meeting notes and medical and medication records. Investigator Douglas Real conducted interviews with one County Social Worker (CSW) on 8/16/21, interviewed one House Manager 9/1/21, one Detective on 9/8/21, one Therapist on 9/29/21, one Client (C2) on 10/13/21, one Residential Counselor (RC1) on 10/21/21, one Assistant Director on 10/21/21, a second Residential Counselor (RC2) on 10/21/21, a third Residential Counselor (RC3) on 10/30/21, a fourth Residential Counselor (RC4) on 10/31/21, one Care Giver (CG1) on 11/2/21, a second Care Giver (CG2) 11/12/21. Investigator Real obtained a copy of the Chino Police Department police report regarding the incident on 9/8/21. On 8/5/21 the Department received a complaint alleging facility staff failed to conduct safety checks on C1 every fifteen minutes. The investigation revealed the facility therapist placed C1 on suicide watch after C1 visited his dying mother. The facility therapist instructed RC2 to inform facility staff regarding the modified supervision plan. RC2 composed an email that was sent to staff on 8/3/21 at 6: PM. The email stated that safety checks were to be conducted for C1 every fifteen minutes. Statements obtained from interviews conducted with staff who worked during the evening of 8/4/21 to the morning of 8/5/21 revealed staff were not aware C1 was placed on suicide watch and conducted safety checks every thirty minutes. Record review of C1's activity log on 8/4/21 and 8/5/21 revealed staff conducted safety checks on C1 every thirty minutes, indicating the modified supervision plan was not followed by staff. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and records reviewed the allegation is substantiated. The facility staff failed to check on C1 every fifteen minutes as requested by the facility therapist. The allegation is valid because the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six regulation 80078(a): Providing Care and Supervision. Exit interview conducted. Appeal rights were provided and discussed. A copy of this report, confidential names form and LIC9099D dated 1/10/22 were provided to the above mentioned facility representative. Per the new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(E), an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending due to the substantiated allegation. If an ECP is warranted, a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment.

narrative: On 09/28/2022, the Department received a complaint alleging allegations that the facility was not maintaining a comfortable temperature for clients in all areas inside. The Administrator denied the allegation that the central air conditioning (AC) was not working and stated preventive maintenance was performed, however, it was then stated that another service technician was called to inspect the system on or about 03/22/2022. The Administrator stated that staff workers never informed him that the AC was not working. In confidential interviews, individuals associated with the facility (staff & clients) provided consistent statements that the AC system was not working for at least several months. It was disclosed that there were several times that a service repair technician was observed working on the AC system but was not operational and continued to remain in this state. Licensing Program Analyst observed a small window air condition unit in the living room area and was informed by the Administrator that it was recently installed because "it was hot". LPA also observed several (3-4) pedestal fans that were provided for the clients in each bedroom as a result of the AC not working. LPA Vargas together with the Administrator and then separately with the House Manager conducted a room temperature check in different areas within the facility using an infrared thermometer. The following readings were obtained: all client bedrooms were between 89 -90 degrees, the staff office was 90 degrees, the living room/dining area was 89 degrees and the window ac unit was already turned on. The central AC unit was running on cool mode, the air temperature exiting from the vents was 89 degrees at 12: PM. It should be mentioned that during the months of August and September 2022, there were days with temperatures that exceeded 100 degrees based on historical reports using the website Weather.com. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the facility was not maintaining a comfortable temperature inside the facility as a result of the air conditioning system (AC) not being operational and repaired in a timely manner. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Following a review of the deficiencies cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 8.8 of the California Code of Regulations, and listed on the LIC 9099D on page 2 of this report, LPA Vargas conducted an exit interview, explain appeal rights.

narrative: On 2/23/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Portillo made an announced visit to New Dawn Short Term Therapeutic Residential Program STRTP for the purpose of a Complaint inspection. Inspection was completed in conjunction with a case management. LPA met with the representative above and discussed the following observed deficiencies. At 9: AM LPA observed the following and informed the licensee on 87076(c)(1) Food Service (c) The licensee shall meet the following food supply and storage requirements: (1) Supplies of staple nonperishable foods for a minimum of one week and fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days shall be maintained on the premises. 87072.2(a) Complaint Procedures (a) The licensee of a short-term residential therapeutic program shall develop, maintain and implement written complaint procedures by which children, or their authorized representatives are permitted to file complaints, without fear of retaliation, with the facility administrator regarding facility staff or operations. The Location in the facility where such procedures are accessible to children, NMDs and their authorized representatives was not available. On 3/2/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the New Dawn Facility for the purpose of a case management incident inspection. LPA met with Facility and discussed the below identified incident Video of teacher striking student at school. Possible late reporting: Facility manager stated the following: Incident occurred on January 12, 2023. The incident that transpired was child struck the teacher at the school. Child was suspended from school and school sent child to the hospital. Staff picked up child from hospital that afternoon and upon returning to home another child in the home disclosed to staff that child involved with incident had a video of what had transpired that day. Facility manager stated they reviewed video the next day and went to the school to discuss the incident. School stated they would not expel child from school but that they would request to have child relocated to another school. Facility sent two additional addendums one January 17th and February 2nd notifying all agencies of schools investigative findings and after suspension was completed for child. LPA observed submitted special incident reports (SIRs) and school investigative findings. Based on information received and documents reviewed incident was documented and addressed in adequate time and all appropriate agencies were notified. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies cited and a copy of this report was provided to facility manager.

On 4/27/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an unannounced visit to the New Dawn Facility for the purpose of a case management other inspection. LPA met with Facility manager and discussed the below identified incident. Food supply and facility management overnight: LPA and facility manager did a walk thru of the home where food supply is stored. LPA observed the required perishable and non-perishable food supply for all kids in care. Facility provided documentation to LPA Claudia Portillo of food purchased on March 10, 2023 and LPA Mahecha observed during this inspection that facility still has required amounts of food. Additionally, LPA told facility manager that facility must have a facility manager on duty within STRTP at all times of the day and night. At this time facility was observed to be in good repair. Exit interview completed, no deficiencies observed or cited and a copy of this report was given to facility manager.

Confidential interviews revealed that staff are not following the approved plan of operation/program statement which identifies the proper way to discard discontinued medications. The staff were utilizing an RX destroyer pharmaceutical disposal liquid to dispose medication at the facilty but never informed Community Care Licensing (CCL) of the change. The STRTP is allowed to change a policy with an approval from CCL. In addition, the staff were not documenting the disposal on the Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record form (LIC 622) for destroying prescription medications when no longer needed by clients or residents correctly. In addition, the staff are not documenting an explanation on why the client refused their psychotropic medication on specific dates on the PMAR or equivalent form. The equivalent form is missing specific information required to be on the separate log. Confidential interviews indicated that the staff failed to log the forms correctly and were informed by the department of mental health to not utilize the LIC 622B form from CCL and to create a new form. LPA Portillo did not receive documentation on the denial from DMH. Based on interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegations that the STRTP is not utilizing the forms correctly to document refusal or destruction on medications for record keeping purposes is substantiated. This posed a potential health and safety risk to the children placed in care. These actions are in violation of the Health and Safety 1507.6 and Title 22 Health Related Services. See attached LIC 9099D for cited deficiency. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report and appeal rights were provided. Confidential interviews denied allegations that facilty staff failed to accommodate the needs of C1s medical treatment by not checking his glucose on time and not taking clients to their scheduled medical appointments. In addition, LPA toured the facilty and observed a lack of forks for clients that should have been accessible for clients. However, staff had additional utensils in the staff office to replenish the use of silverware. According to confidential interviews, the staff are proactive with the clients' medical needs and utilize the company vans to transport them to scheduled appointments such as medical, dental, school, outings etc. Other confidential information received stated that the reason for a shortage of forks is due to the clients throwing them away in the trash, taking them in their room or hiding them. Therefore, the staff monitor the silverware that's available for usage when requested. In addition, LPA Portillo inquired about the availability of plastic forks and the facilty placed some out for usage in case the clients prefer to throw them out due to specific reasons such as COVID. LPA spoke to C1s assigned County Social Worker (CSW1) who stated that at this time they did not have any concerns regarding C1's safety or the STRTPs level of care. There were no other known witnesses to this incident. Confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. Based on interviews and confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegation that staff are not equipped with enough medical supplies, lack of transportation or denial of silverware, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with an advisory note was provided.

narrative: Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegation as details obtained provided inconsistencies as one foster child did not want to speak to LPA and the other one denied feeling uncomfortable with the temperature of the air conditioning (AC) claiming that it was broken but repaired immediately. Foster children indicated fans were provided and the temperature was at a reasonable temperature. Interviews with staff denied the allegation that the temperature was uncomfortable for staff and clients. It was reported by one staff member that the central AC unit was not working, however the other wall ACs units were operational. Based on record review, it was determined that the AC outlet was broken and repaired by the maintenance crew in a timely manner. Staff and foster children reported that group meetings are part of the program and clients are highly recommended to attend to ensure they get the full benefits of the program. Resident council meetings are voluntary and highly recommended for clients to attend in order to voice their concerns and make suggestions. It was denied that the fans were removed from their rooms if they didn't attend group meetings. Based on the information gathered, the allegation is unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met although the allegation may have happened or is valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On 2/15/2024 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the New Dawn facility for the purpose of a Required 2 year inspection. LPA met with Facility manager Regina Head and together did a walk thru of the facility both inside and out. LPA observed the following: This is a single story single family residence with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, game room, TV room, living space, kitchen, dining room, mental health area, attached garage and outdoor activity space. TV room, living room, game room, kitchen, dining room, bathroom, mental area and attached garage were all observed to be clean and in good repair. Mental health area, office area with attached staff bathroom consisted of desks, computers and office area had two (2) locked filing cabinets containing sharp objects and medications and one(1) locked closet that are only accessible by staff. Kitchen has required perishable and non-perishable food supply. Water temperature was checked in bathroom #1 and temperature measured at (141.6 degrees Fahrenheit). All areas observed at this time were clean, working and furniture was in good repair. Garage housed water heater, extra supplies, (2) additional deep freezers, extra fridge and additional locked cabinets with snacks. Bedroom #1 occupied by 2 children located opposite office area two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #2- located across from common bathroom Occupied by 2 children, two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bedroom #3- located adjacent to common bathroom Occupied by 1 child two twin beds, dresser and closet space available Bathroom #1- consisted of toilet, sink, shower/tub combination. narrative: On 03/05/21 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Pamela Silva and Zeyda Loera conducted a Post-Licensing Tele-inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) as a result of COVID-19 related restrictions. LPAs met with Lead Facility Manager, Ariana Lopez. The facility currently has a provisional STRTP license. The STRTP has National Accreditation and has obtained a Mental Health Certification. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) male ambulatory clients ages 7-17 and is also licensed to provide services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are five (5) clients currently in placement. PHYSICAL PLANT Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The STRTP license, Mental Health Certification, National Accreditation and the Emergency Disaster Plan are posted at the hallway near the entrance of the facility. Passageways are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and other chemicals are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are kept locked in the kitchen cabinet. The temperature inside the facility is maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperature does not exceed 120 degrees F. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarm were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguishers are fully charged. Facility has a working telephone. First Aid kit is complete. All confidential files are in a locked cabinet inside the staff office. The facility has cameras installed in the common areas of the facility. There is a swimming pool in the backyard that is made inaccessible by an iron picket fence. The pool fence is at least 5 feet high and the bottom of the fence is no more than two inches from the ground. No door or window of the facility provides direct access to the pool. The pool gate is kept locked at all times and can only be unlocked by authorized staff. There are no firearms and ammunition in the facility. CARE & SUPERVISION The staff to client ratio at the time of inspection was 2:5. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Facility provides nutritious meals and snacks. Medications are centrally stored and locked in the hallway closet and accessible only to employees responsible for stored medications. The monthly menu is posted in the kitchen. PERSONAL RIGHTS Children's Personal Rights are posted. Children live in a safe, healthy and comfortable home. Activity schedule for clients is available in a binder. Children are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. CLIENT RECORDS LPA Silva reviewed three (3) client files. LPA reviewed Admission Agreements; health screenings; consent forms; weight records; ID and Emergency information; Needs and Services Plans; Immunization Records; TB test results; Safeguards for Cash Resources and Property/Valuables; and Personal Rights. Needs and Services Plan are assessed every 30 days and is updated as needed. STAFF RECORDS LPA Silva reviewed three (3) staff records. LPA reviewed First Aid/CPR Certificates; fingerprint clearances, Child Abuse Index Checks; education verification, Personnel Records/Job Applications; health screenings; TB test results; Criminal Record Statement, Employee Rights, and annual training records. A review of Licensing Information System (LIS) indicates that all staff have received fingerprint clearances and child abuse index clearances.Facility staff meet qualification and training requirements. Facility is recommended for STRTP permanent licensure. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the LIC809, LIC 858, and LIC 859 were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative. There were no citations issued during today's tele-inspection.

Facility Staff denied the allegations and further indicated that they try to provide whatever programs are available to the youth and adhere to their individual needs and services plans. Staff indicated that the morning staff is responsible of waking clients for school and making breakfast. Staff further indicated that they try to motivate clients by offering different type of outing or rewards, however at times clients will still refuse to get out of bed and sign in for their zoom classes. Staff denied withholding any personal belongings however, further disclose that staff will collect the school borrowed chrome books after clients have completed their school work due to a chrome book being stolen from one of the rooms and exchanged for money. Information obtained from C1 and C2 revealed that staff is very supportive and encourage clients to complete their program and are always informing the clients on the importance of attending and finishing school. C2 indicated that with the help and consistent push from staff he was able to graduate and now is looking forward to attending college. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the STRTP Lead Facility Manager. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was given to the Lead Facility Manager.

narrative: On 12/02/21 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Pamela Silva and Zeyda Loera conducted an Annual Required inspection to the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs met with Administrator Gina Sodaro and Lead Facility Manager Byron Butler. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) male ambulatory clients ages 7-17 and is also licensed to provide services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are five (5) clients currently in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. At 9: AM, LPAs conducted a walkthrough of the entire facility. Physical Plant The STRTP license, Mental Health Certification, National Accreditation and the Emergency Disaster Plan are posted at the hallway near the entrance of the facility. Passageways are unobstructed. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and other chemicals are kept locked in the hallway closet. Sharps and knives are kept locked in the kitchen cabinet. Medications are centrally stored in a locked cabinet inside the office. The temperature inside the facility is maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F). Hot water temperature does not exceed 120 degrees F. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarm were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguishers are fully charged. Facility has a working telephone. First Aid kit is complete. All confidential files are in a locked cabinet inside the staff office. All sinks, showers and toilets are in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. There were adequate supply of beddings and linens. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. The facility has cameras installed in the common areas of the facility. There is a swimming pool in the backyard that is made inaccessible by an iron picket fence. The pool fence is at least 5 feet high and the bottom of the fence is no more than two inches from the ground. No door or window provides direct access to the pool. The pool gate is kept locked at all times and can only be unlocked by authorized staff. There are no firearms and ammunition in the facility. Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conducts meeting to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Client Records LPAs reviewed four (4) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. Staff Records LPAs reviewed three (3) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. Annual training records and certificates are on staff files. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. LPAs interviewed two (2) staff members. LPAs were unable to interview clients due to no client was present in the facility at the time of inspection. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPAs discussed the findings with the facility administrator. LPAs agreed to work with the facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title 22 regulations. The administrator was provided with information on where to locate the Provider Information Notices (PINs), guidance to the new CARE Tools inspection process and Guardian. There was no deficiency cited during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report and LIC811 were provided to the facility administrator.

On 02/17/2022 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an unannounced follow up case management inspection at the above facility. LPA met with Facility Manager, Ariana Lopez, regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing on 12/14/21. The SIR indicated that client C1 (reference confidential names form LIC 811 dated 02/17/22) told staff to call the ambulance because he had taken too many of something. The facility Administrator clarified during an interview with LPA that C1 just came from AWOL when the incident happened. When asked what C1 took too many of, C1 stated "Triple Cs". Triple Cs stands for "cold, cough and congestion" medication. After C1 informed staff that he needed an ambulance, staff immediately tried to call an ambulance. However, while calling for an ambulance, C1 told staff not to call the ambulance and that he was okay. C1 was offered ambulance and medical services multiples times but C1 refused. C1 also refused to sign a medical refusal form. Staff observed that C1 seemed okay and was acting normal. Staff monitored C1 closely throughout the night. Based on interviews with the Administrator, C1 must have obtained the Triple Cs while he was on AWOL. C1 refused to state where and how he obtained the Triple Cs. Upon return to the facility, C1 agreed to a search by taking his shoes off and emptying his pockets, in compliance with the facility's AWOL protocol. No contraband was found. LPA interviewed C1's county social worker (CSW) via telephone on 02/15/22. CSW stated he has no concerns about the facility regarding the care that was provided to C1. C1 is no longer residing in the facility effective 12/31/21. Based on the interviews conducted and documentation obtained, there are no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations and no violations of Interim Licensing Standards Version 3 (ILS.3) Chapter 8. Foster Family Agencies, Articles 9, and Subchapter 1. No deficiencies were cited during today's inspection. A copy of LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative and an exit interview was conducted.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection on March 17, 2022 at 8: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 9 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated March 17, 2022. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA, Dina Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Gina Sodaro, Administrator.

Staff on duty reported that minor did not appear to be under the influence and was responding and acting normal. Staff checked minor every fifteen minutes after statement was made, to make sure minor was safe. During another incident, staff observed a dot of blood on the bathroom wall after minor took a shower. When staff inquired about the blood on the wall, staff observed cuts on minor's legs. Minor admitted to staff that minor attempted to hang himself using the towel rack, but the rack became loose. Minor gave staff the belt used and a toothbrush with a sharpened edge and no bristles. Staff called the police who responded then assessed and transported minor to Mary K. Shell. Staff reported minor took a long shower which was not unusual for minor. Staff checked minor every fifteen or twenty minutes by calling out on minor who staff could hear singing from inside the bathroom. Staff reported that minors are checked every fifteen minutes when inside their rooms, but the room checks are only documented by the graveyard shift when minors are asleep. Minors gave different responses when asked about room checks. Placement agency confirmed that since minor's placement at the facility, staff informed the placement agency of minor's reportable behaviors sometimes multiple times a day. Incident reports were submitted, in addition to phone calls to the placement agency. Based on information obtained during the Department's investigation, the allegations are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there was no preponderance of evidence found to prove neglect or lack of care and supervision by facility staff. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this signed report, the Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights forms were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during the inspection.

Investigation revealed the following: It was alleged that minors engaged in inappropriate behavior while in care. Facility manager denied the allegation. Manager stated that they received no information or indication from either child that they engaged in inappropriate behavior. Manager stated that children identified in complaint investigation initially shared a room but had a history of aggressive behavior with one another. Facility addressed the issue by separating children to different rooms for an extended period of time but later children requested to share a room again, so children were placed together again until allegation was presented to facility. After allegation children were separated immediately and facility spoke with children about the alleged incident with no clear indication that the allegation happened. Interviews conducted with children had similar statements where children denied the allegation. Children stated that they have never observed or had anyone in the home touch them inappropriately. Children stated they felt comfortable coming to staff if issues or incidents occur and staff will address the issues. One child identified in the complaint investigation refused to speak to LPA. LPA was unable to contact county social workers and other witnesses to speak with someone about the alleged incident. LPA reviewed supportive documents provided by facility and incidents were documented and submitted to overseeing agencies of what was reported. No documents reviewed identified a problem with clients placed in the home or facility staff. Based on the information gathered, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report Confidential Names Form, and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On 05/6/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the New Start Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the findings to the above identified complaint investigation. LPA spoke with Lead facility manager Ariana Lopez and informed manager of investigative findings.
