narrative: On 07/20/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez met with Lead Facility Manager Ariana Lopez (S1) for the purpose of completing a case management inspection. On 06/23/23, the department received a special incident report. The report indicated that S1 and C1 went to the store, and C1 was involved in a disagreement. During the inspection, LPA Martinez interviewed S1 (Please see confidential names on LIC 811 dated 07/20/23) LPA Martinez also reviewed C1's case file and needs and services plan. Based on the information reviewed during the inspection, no Title 22 violations are to be cited, and no further follow-up is needed at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to the facility manager.

On 09/08/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez conducted an unannounced visit to the facility listed above and met with Ariana Lopez, Lead Facility Manager (S1).The purpose of the visit was to conduct a case management inspection. On 08/22/23, the Department received a special incident report (SIR) stating an incident occurred at school where C1 became aggressive and attacked staff. Staff attempted de-escalation techniques but were unsuccessful, leading to involvement from school security and campus police. Returning home, the youth grabbed the steering wheel of the van, causing it to hit into a parked car. Law enforcement was called to the scene, but no medical attention was required for either the staff or the youth.(Reference Confidential Name Form LIC 811 dated 09/08/23). During this inspection, LPA Martinez interviewed S1 regarding the incident. No clients were home at the time of the inspection. LPA Martinez also inspected SIR. The interview with S1 revealed that this was C1's first incident that involved grabbing the van steering wheel.. Despite staff's attempts at de-escalation, the situation escalated to the point of a vehicle accident, though no injuries were reported. S1 reported that Immediate safety measures have been implemented, including a change in C1's seating arrangement in transport vehicles. C1 is no longer allowed to sit in the front seat. A Child and Family Team (CFT) meeting is going to be conducted, but no official date has not been set. After reviewing the documents and speaking with S1, the inspection reveals that the agency took appropriate measures regarding the incident. There is no further follow-up needed. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the signed LIC 809 was given to S1.

On 08/23/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez conducted an unannounced visit to the facility listed above and met with Ariana Lopez (S1) The purpose of the visit was to conduct a case management inspection. On 03/26/23, the department received a special incident report (SIR) stating that C1 departed the facility on his bike and was later struck by a car. Law enforcement documented the event, and C1 was transported to the hospital for treatment. (Reference Confidential Name Form LIC 811 dated 08/23/23). During this inspection, LPA Martinez interviewed S1.S1 indicated that C1 is no longer living in the facility and was not interviewed for this inspection. LPA Martinez also requested and reviewed the daily log notes for C1. During the interview , it was disclosed that C1 had permission to ride his bike as part of his community pass. C1 was hit by a car during this time. Law Enforcement assessed the situation and decided C1 should go to the hospital. Facility staff arrived to the scene and were also present to pick up C1, when C1 was discharged the following day. After reviewing the documents and speaking with S1, the inspection reveals that the agency took appropriate measures regarding the incident.There is no further follow-up is needed. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the signed LIC 809 was given to S1

On 10/12/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez conducted an unannounced visit to the facility listed above and met with Ariana Lopez (S1) Lead Facility Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a follow up case management inspection. On 08/07/23, the department received a special incident report (SIR) stating that C1 expressed intentions of leaving the facility and disclosed to staff his concerns with C2, when staff are not within sight. (Reference Confidential Name Form LIC 811 dated 10/12/23). During the inspection, LPA Martinez reviewed personnel reports, client rosters, and incident reports. LPA Martinez conducted interviews with one staff member. C1 declined to be interviewed. The interviews revealed that staff members made efforts to engage and prevent C1 from leaving the facility. Staff spoke with C1 and took him for a walk to discuss his feelings and concerns. Following this discussion, the staff informed the facility's manager, administrator, and head of service about the situation. Since the incident in question, both C1 and C2 have not been involved in any further incidents. A review of documentation confirmed that communication had been maintained between staff during shift changes. The findings from the interview and document review indicate that staff members took proactive steps to address the concerns of C1. Communication and follow-up measures were taken to ensure the well-being and safety of the clients in the facility. There is no further follow-up needed. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the signed LIC 809 was given to S1.

On 01/09/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez conducted an Annual/Random Inspection of the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA Martinez met with Facility Manager (FM) Ariana Lopez. The STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) male ambulatory clients ages 7-17 and is also licensed to provide services to Non-Minor Dependents (NMD). There are four (4) youth in placement. The facility is a single-story home located in the city of Bakersfield. The front yard displays well-kept green grass and a concrete pathway leading from the sidewalk to the front door.The path is clear and open, allowing unobstructed front door access. LPA Martinez conducted walk through of the entire facility with FM. Physical Plant: • The Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license, Mental Health Certification, National Accreditation, and Emergency Disaster Plan are posted in the facility. • Passageways are unobstructed. • Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, other chemicals, sharps, and knives are locked in the hallway closet. • Medications are centrally stored in a locked closet. • The facility maintains a temperature range of 68 to 85 degrees (F). • Hot water temperature measured between 105 and 102 degrees (F). • Carbon monoxide and smoke detectors are operational. Physical Plant: • Fire extinguishers are fully charged. • A working telephone is available. • All confidential files are in a locked cabinet. • All sinks, showers, and toilets are functional. • No more than two clients share a bedroom. • All beds have good springs, clean mattresses, and pillows. • There is an adequate supply of bedding and linens. • The facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. • Overall, the facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Interviews; • Two (2) staff interviews • No youth were interviewed because they were attending school at the time of the inspection. No deficiencies were cited during the inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of the LIC 809 was provided to the Facility Manager. The inspection will resume on another day.

It was alleged that client was sexually abused by another client while in care. Confidential interviews reveal that the client/victim recanted the allegation after interviewed by placement agency and mental health staff, as well as law enforcement. The victim/client apologized to staff and the alleged perpetrator. The client/victim is known to make inappropriate statements and staff often has to redirect the client. The client denied the allegation to IB and stated that nothing happened, that it was all a lie because the client wanted attention. There were pertinent documents found to support the statement provided by the client/victim to IB. Additional records show that the client/victim maintained that the abuse occurred while client fell asleep for about ten minutes, after being given pills by the other client. The client/victim felt a slight pain in the anus which the client did not feel prior to falling asleep. The client/victim, however, could not explain what happened after waking up and stated that another client told the client/victim that the client/victim was penetrated by the other client, which both clients denied. Staff and other clients in placement denied witnessing any inappropriate behavior by the alleged perpetrator. They stated that the client/victim has sexualized and attention-seeking behaviors. The SART exam did not find any evidence of trauma or tearing. Based on information obtained during the investigation, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there was no preponderance of evidence found to support it. A copy of the following reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection: LIC 9099, LIC9099-C and LIC Confidential Names Form. Appeal rights form was given and explained. No deficiency citation was issued.

investigation_findings: 13On July 15, 2024, at 3: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney conducted a complaint inspection at the above Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) and met with the Lead Facility Manager Ariana Lopez. The inspection aimed to deliver the finding(s) regarding the complaint allegation(s). On January 29, 2024, the Community Care Licensing Division of the California Department of Social Services received a complaint from the Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegation(s): The staff did not prevent minors from bringing drugs into the facility; The staff did not provide adequate supervision, resulting in minor getting bullied while in care. This LPA conducted the investigation of the above allegation(s) and it consisted of but was not limited to a review of records, including the client's needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with three staff members (S1), (S2) on 2/08/24, S3 on 2/28/24, (S3) on 1/24/24, two clients (C1) on 2/08/24, C2 on 3/06/24, the reporting party (RP) on 2/21/24 and the CSW on 2/28/24. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated July 15, 2024). Reported Allegations: 1. The staff did not prevent minors from bringing drugs into the facility. The facility staff (S1, S2, and S3) refuted the accusation and emphasized that they implement preventive actions like visual bag inspections and requiring clients to conduct self-searches in the presence of staff prior to entering the premises. However, despite these precautions, clients have previously attempted to smuggle contraband back into the facility after an unauthorized absence. This contraband, which cannot be visually detected by staff, is typically discovered during random room checks conducted for the safety of all clients. Any confiscated contraband is documented and disposed of appropriately. 2. The staff did not provide adequate supervision, resulting in minor getting bullied while in care. The facility personnel (S1, S2, and S3) denied the allegation by affirming that all staff members are well-versed in trauma-informed care and are dedicated to upholding a secure and healthy setting for both staff and clients. They made it clear that any form of bullying will not be accepted under any circumstances and urged clients to promptly report any such incidents to the staff or licensing authorities. Additionally, the personnel uphold transparent communication with clients and are prepared to step in when needed, either through verbal guidance or by separating individuals to avoid physical or verbal altercations. Information acquired from C1 and C2 contradicted the alleged accusations and confirmed the aforementioned details, expressing a sense of security while residing at the facility and acknowledging the staff's assistance in achieving their individualized plan. Moreover, the CSW noted that the facility staff are vigilant, conducting visual searches of items brought back to the facility and confiscating any contraband discovered. The CSW mentioned that she had no concerns about the care and supervision that was being provided by staff and indicated that the staff kept great communication via phone and email. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegation(s) are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation(s) may have happened are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the Foster Family Agency. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the STRTP Lead Facility Manager. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 06/27/25, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joe Martinez initiated a case management inspection at the Short Term Residential Treatment Program (STRTP) and met with the facility representative above. LPA Martinez interviewed 1 staff and reviewed 1 youth records. Due to insufficient current information, further review is necessary. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA Martinez conducted an exit interview and provided the STRTP Representative with a signed copy of the LIC809

Confidential interviews were completed on 03/04/25 with R1, R2, 06/27/25 with C2,C3 and 07/17/25 with CSW2. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated July 18, 2025) Interviews revealed the following: Staff stated they did not observe any unusual behavior or signs of distress during the alleged incident. Interviews with staff confirmed that upon placement, the facility contacted school representatives to discuss the youth's needs. Staff and documentation showed multiple communications between the facility, school personnel to assist the youth in achieving educational and treatment goals. Documentation reviewed during the investigation. supported the existence of regular communication between the facility, school staff. Staff interviews expressed that facility staff and school personnel reached an agreement on strategies to better support the youth, focusing on educational needs and providing consistent attention to ongoing health concerns. Youth interviews revealed that staff provide support when residents are emotionally upset and offer coping activities such as walks or outings. The youth also reported that therapy services are provided regularly, typically once per week. Interviewed youth did not have direct knowledge of any peers being denied help when needed. CSW 2 reported no concerns about the STRTP's ability to meet mental health needs. The CSW2 confirmed that services such as therapy are provided and that staff assist youth with their treatment goals. CSW 2 stated that she has not observed any issues requiring follow-up or concerns regarding mental health services in the home. Based on the confidential interviews and records reviewed, the complaint is unsubstantiated. An unsubstantiated determination means the allegation lacks a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the violation occurred. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. LPA Martinez conducted an exit interview and provided a signed LIC 9099 to the facility representative.

narrative: On 02/04/2021 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced inspection to the above-said facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Sauk met with the Facility Manager (FM), who granted access to the facility, and who provided a tour of the entire facility, inside and out. Due to the Coronavirus pandemic, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) male clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only (See confidential name list LIC-811 dated 02/04/2021). LPA observed the following: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, garage, and staff office. All three bedrooms were observed with equipment to be in good condition, sufficient lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #1: sleeps two clients (C3 and C6), equipped with two twin-size beds. Bedroom #2: sleeps two clients (C4 and C5), equipped with two twin-size beds. Bedroom #3: sleeps two clients (C1 and C2), equipped with two full-size beds. This bedroom has an attached bathroom. Garage: Has an extra refrigerator, and equipped with weight lifting equipment, and a treadmill There is no swimming pool or any other bodies of water on the premises. The passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met. The outdoor space is free of debris and any hazards. Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients. Medication is locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and in multiple places around the facility that was operable at the time of inspection. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2) The first aid kit is fully stocked. The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. The facility has a working telephone. FM states that there are no weapons or guns on the premises. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. The facility has a Toyota Sienna passenger van and Toyota Corolla to transport clients. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 3, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Manager (FM), in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

investigation_findings: 13On 02/16/2021 at 11:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk met with the Facility Manager (FM), over the phone due to the coronavirus pandemic, for the purpose of delivering findings of this complaint investigation, in regards to the above allegation. LPA Sauk interviewed one client (C4), before reaching the investigative finding. Based on all of the interviews conducted, the Department has concluded the above allegation of a Personal Rights violation to be Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Although the grievance procedures were not posted, the phone number was available for clients to call and make complaints, and some of the clients reported being aware of the phone number to call in case they had a complaint. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. investigation_findings: 13On 02/16/2021 at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk met with the Facility Manager (FM), over the phone due to the coronavirus pandemic, for the purpose of delivering findings of this complaint investigation, in regards to the above allegation. Based on all of the interviews conducted, the Department has concluded the above allegation of a Personal Rights violation to be Substantiated, meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Supporting evidence includes the following: In response to a offensive comment by one of the clients, the Facility Manager (FM) admitted to using a curse word in an angry manner, and other clients were witnesses to it. FM also admitted that all staff have cursed at the clients, but try not to. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. investigation_findings: 13On 03/26/2021 at 4:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk met with the Facility Manager (FM), over the phone due to the coronavirus pandemic, for the purpose of delivering findings of this complaint investigation, in regards to the above allegation. Based on all of the interviews conducted, the Department has concluded the above allegation of a Personal Rights violation to be Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Supporting evidence includes the following: Although there are altercations that occur in the home, although some clients complain about staff indifference, although there were some reports that staff do not shadow clients who run away from the facility, although there are some concerns that arose from all of the interviews, these reports are not consistent with the other interviews, and there is not a preponderence of evidence to substantiate Neglect / Lack of Supervision. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to FM, in order to obtain FM's signature. Signature will be on file. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

Based upon interviews and record review, the allegations that 1) Facility staff caused injury to minor in care; 2) Facility staff handled minor in a rough manner; 3) Facility staff inappropriately restrained minor in care and 4) Facility staff did not prevent minors from engaging in a physical altercation are found to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have occurred or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with House Manager, Ricardo Contreras. A copy of the report and appeal rights have been given to the Administrator who's signature on this form confirms the receipt of these documents. There were no deficiencies cited at this time.

On 03/22/2022 at 10:00AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia made an unannounced to New Way for the purpose to conduct the Post Licensing Inspection. LPA Rosas met with Staff#1(S1), Staff#2 (S2) who granted access to the facility and an inspection of the facility was conducted together. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 03/22/22. Temperature and health checks are conducted at the entrance in the sign-in area. LPA met with Staff#1 (S1), who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant. This facility has Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) licensed to provide care and supervision for six (6) children ages 12-17 years old, Ambulatory only. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents. The facility currently has Accreditation with Joint Commission dated 01/16/2021 and valid for 36 months. The facility has active Mental Health Program Approval with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County with an effective date of 02/07/2022 and expiration date of 02/07/2021. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Rosas inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a (3) three bedroom, (2) two bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. There is two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by wooden fence and is observed to be good condition. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of Laundry Room: The laundry room is located next to the garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. Garage: The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. There is two (2) vehicles available to transport youths; make and model are a Toyota Sienna, and Toyota Sienna Van. The vehicle has full coverage auto insurance with Farmers Insurance. Dining Area/Kitchen/Family Room (Den): There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a television and working fireplace with a cover. One table with six (6) chairs is next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and a toaster oven. LPA observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the children locked in the staff office. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Additional Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living room has dining table with six (6) chairs and televisions. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, and medication are locked in storage closet in the living room making inaccessible. There is a fireplace that is non-operable with a cover. Staff Office: It is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). The medication is triple locked inside of the staff office. The client files are kept in a locked closet. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, cleaning solutions, and medication. Bedroom # 1: Occupied by two (2) clients, the bedroom is equipped two (2) twin sized beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) wall closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. This bedroom was a bathroom. Bedroom # 2: Currently occupied by one (1) client, has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Page 2 of Bedroom # 3: Currently occupied by two (2) clients. The bedroom has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. Bathroom #1 is the common bathroom for the clients. It is a full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and tub/showers. Bathroom #2 is located inside of Bedroom#1 is full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children's Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The home has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted. All posting requirements were met LPA observed a First Aid Kit complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptic and a 1st Aid Manual in the staff office. All posting requirements were met. Children will be accorded personal rights. The facility current License, Mental Health Certification; Ombudsperson Grievances and Personal Rights; are posted on the wall. Children are not restricted to make phones calls based on the court and or authorized representative. The lounge is utilized for clients to make phones calls and the Phone Call Log is kept near the facility phone. LPA observed the child's Needs and Services plans kept in clients personal file; (filed in an individual binder). Children are accompanied to outside extracurricular activities and social events and alternate activities have been implemented. LPA Rosas reviewed following during the inspection: LPA Rosas requested the following forms for review, Register of Youth (LIC 9020), Current Census, Personnel Report (LIC 500), Emergency Disaster Plan, Mental Health Approval certificate, The Joint Commission approval certificate. LPA Rosas was not able to review client or staff files during this visit and will return to continue with the annual inspection. Page 2 of A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 03/22/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. LPA Rosas by send by email the following PINS to S PIN 20-17-CRP: New Background Check Requirements, Assembly Bill 819 (Chapter 777, Statutes of 2019), PIN 21-20-CRP: Statewide Launch of New Inspection Tools for Children's Residential Licensees, PIN 21-05-CRP: The Family Urgent Response System (FURS), Medications Guide TSP 2017-03 (version 08/23/21) There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

The investigation included, but not limited to, confidential interviews with three clients, staff members, review of medical records, review of Oxnard Police Department report, review of staff records, and corresponding related incident report. It was revealed on August 29, 2021, an incident occurred involving C1 who reportedly displayed behavior outburst resulting in C1 being restrained by Staff member #1 (S1) and law enforcement being called. C1 was transported for an evaluation and upon medical assessment, C1 was found to have computed tomography (CT) imaging notable for multiple spinous process fractures sustained while in the facility. Witness statements, records reviewed, and police reports revealed corroborating evidence to support the alleged. Based on information obtained, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation of physical abuse is Substantiated. This poses an immediate health and safety risk to children in care. The facility is issued a citation in accordance with the Interim Licensing Standards, Chapter 7.5, Version 3, Personal Rights (d)(11) [See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiency]. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were discussed. A copy of this report, Confidential Names List and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator via email. (Continued on page LIC9099-D)

LPA Rosas determined that the Personal Rights allegations that facility did not seek medical attention, did not allow youth to shower and did not address youth's hygiene needs, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the findings are unsubstantiated. LPA Rosas and AGPA Barnes-Woodard conducted interviews that provided information on the shower schedule, medical and hygiene procedures for the facility. Interviews disclosed that Client#1 (C1) would refuse to take showers, get his hair cut and would self-harm. Facility provided Special Incident Reports and Hospital visit summaries with information for the incidents for C1. The facility had overstock of hygiene products and have monthly hair cut appointments for youth in care. Interviews with pertinent parties provided information on C1 behaviors. Results from the Department's investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On October 11, 2022, at 09:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas conducted an unannounced inspection to New Way Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) for the purpose to conduct a Case Management- Deficiencies inspection and to gather additional information regarding the Unusual Incident/Injury Report (SIR) dated 09/04/2022. During the inspection, LPA Rosas met with Staff#1 (S1), Staff#2 (S2) and the deficiency was discussed. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 10/11/22. On 09/09/2022, Department was reported that New Way facility had incident that occurred on 09/04/2022 were Oxnard Police Department was dispatched to the facility. Client#1 (C1) did property damage by to throw cement bricks to parked vehicles in the facility. Client#2 (C2) had had contraband of pocketknife and was placed in custody because he assaulted three police officers. The non-emergency Oxnard Police Department was called for assistance for Client#3 (C3) who was experiencing Suicidal ideations. The facility submitted Law Enforcement Contact Report to the Department on 09/19/2022 by Head of Service staff. During the inspection Corporal Junded, District Coordinator from Oxnard Police Department arrived at the facility to discuss the incident that occurred on 09/04/2022. It was discussed how clients should be allowed to make calls to the police. Facility should be calling Law Enforcement for serious incidents and continue to utilize FURS, and Ventura Crisis Team. LPA Rosas conducted record review and was found that the facility did not report incident report within seven days of occurrence of the incident that occurred on 09/04/2022 to the Department which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care. Report continues on LIC One deficiency was observed (refer to LIC 809D) and facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, 80061(b) Reporting Requirements: The facility upon the occurrence, facility the operation of the facility of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. Technical Violation Note was issued for California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, 87061(i)(2) Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Version 4 (i)(2) A detailed narrative, describing the incident and the events leading up to the incident. 87061 (4) Description of the facility's plan for the child, in response to the incident, including modifications to the child's needs and services plan. If the child has been involved in previous incidents, explain what the previous modifications were to the child's needs and services plan. 87095.22 (b) The emergency intervention plan is to be included in the program statement for the short-term residential therapeutic program. narrative: On 06/13/2021, the Department received Special Incident Report (SIR) Child#1 (C1) was provoking Child#2 (C2) through the morning despite facility staff intervening multiple times and encouraging C1 to use cooking skills. C1 went to the kitchen and threw a plastic bowl at C2 and retaliation C2 grabbed a wooden spatula and threw it at C1 and striking them in the head. C1 was taken to Urgent Care due to small cut on the head and eye pain. Urgent Care applied four staples versus adhesive glue to C1 head wound due to the position of the injury. On 09/07/2021, LPA Rosas inspected the facility and saw the eye and head injury on C1 healed. C1 expressed not having pain or discomfort. Interviews revealed that residents were counseled, and staff was present during the incident, but the attack happen quickly. The resident was given 1:1 to supervise and shadow C1 due to behavior and abilities. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegations of Neglect and lack of supervision. On 07/31/21, the Department received SIR reported that when staff is not looking, they call him names like "dog or puppy" and flip him off. C1 punched the window by accident due to Tourette syndrome disorder and did not mean to break the window. C1 did not disclose what resident was doing the name calling. Facility reported not allowing residents to abuse each other verbally or physically. LPA Rosas reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for the clients in placement. On August 2, 2021, the Oxnard Police Department arrived at the facility due to an anonymous to report that C1 was being bullied and threatened with knives. The Police Department interview residents in place and inspected the facility and found no suspicious activity and left the facility. On 09/08/2021, inspected facility and found all knives and sharps kept under double locks in the staff office closet. The facility always has two to three staff to supervise clients in placement. Confidential interviews indicated that restraints are conducted when clients in care pose imminent danger to self and others, staff must be SAFE trained, and two or more staff must conduct the restraint. The facility also used variety of redirecting techniques to calm clients during crisis. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with client, pertinent parties, and facility staff regarding to incident on 07/31/2021. There were no witnesses identified to corroborate the allegation. Report continues LIC-9099C Page 1 out of On 06/10/2021, Facility submitted updated reporting requirements updated policy. LPA Rosas reviewed reporting requirements with facility. Facility was able to provide Special Incident Reports and Law Enforcement Contact Reports. Special incident reports are submitted to the Community Care Licensing Department (CCLD), Social Worker and other pertinent parties related to the incident. There was not enough evidence and witnesses identified to corroborate the allegation. On 8/31/ 21, CCLD received an allegation reporting that on 08/29/21, S1 physically restrained C1 causing injuries to C1's neck area and possible rib fracture. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Regina Martin investigated the complaint allegation and based on information obtained, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, the allegation of physical abuse was substantiated. The allegation has already been investigated and completed by the Department and no further information obtained. Results from the Department's investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility. Page 3 of 3

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection 4/4/23 at 10: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 4/4/2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to , Adam Maciel, Facility Manager.

On 05/05/2023 at 9:03am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson arrived at the facility for a case management deficiency visit. At 9:42am The Facility Manager (FM) provided access to the home and LPA was able to observe the facility inside and outside. FA provided LPA Wilson with a walk through tour of facility.At 10:00am, LPA Wilson requested the Facility Manager (FM) to provide evidence of SIR reporting procedures. LPA Wilson and FM were joined by Facility Administrator (FA) and by telephone, also joined by Facility Head of Service (HS) to discuss the deficiency. A late report dated 04/01/2023 was sent to CCL on 04/27/2023. Staff shared with LPA WIlson, the current IR procedures, which have changed over "about the last month and a half." and have been undergoing audits which have impeded the ability to report incidents timely. HS stated that a plan to set timelines for reporting incident reports will be discussed (see 809D, POC). Regulatory Reference: 80061(b) Reporting Requirements Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during it's normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. Based on observation and interview, the licensee (FA) did not ensure proper Incident Reporting to CCL (Reporting Requirements) 04/01/2023 and received by CCL on 04/27/ SIR-CM-NUMBER: 04-2023-34-CM-05 , which poses a potential health and safety risk to persons in care. Type B Regulatory Reference: 80061(b). A Type B violation will be issued. An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (FA) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

narrative: On February 29, 2024 at 9:54am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an announced inspection to New Way Group Home (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection. LPA Wilson was met by (S1) and (FM) This is a short-term therapeutic residential treatment program (STRTP) that is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years, as well as non-minor dependents; ambulatory only. There is no swimming pool which meets licensing regulations. There is a Naloxone waiver on file. Facility underwent a triennial survey with the Joint Commission and has valid, accreditation status. This is a one-story facility located at Raft Lane, Oxnard CA. 93034. LPA Wilson was greeted by staff (S1) who allowed entrance into the facility and who who provided LPA with a tour of the facility. Individuals mentioned in this report are identified on the Confidential Names List [see LIC811 dated 02/29/2023.] There was one (1) client in the home (C1). Four (4) other clients (C2, C3, C4, C6) were attending school. One (1) client (C5) has absconded. There were two (2) staff in the home (S1, FM) and the Administrator (FA) arrived at approximately 10:45am LPA Wilson inspected the following: Postings: MPHA (expired 02/07/2024, Facility Sketch, Complaint Process, Administrator Certificate (FA), License, Emergency Numbers, Foster Youth Rights. Living Room: There is one large couch with seating for seven persons, Table, TV and TV stand. The Television stand is in disrepair (see photo). There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Game Room: There is one smaller couch with seating for 3 persons, TV, Fireplace that is unused, puzzles and games. Continues on 809C page 2 of Page 2 of Kitchen: The kitchen has a fire extinguisher with current inspection, There are no poisons or cleaning supplies accessible to clients, there is a (4) burner stove in working condition, toaster, microwave, air fryer and refrigerator set at 40 degrees.Inside the refrigerator, there was a plate of enchiladas, which were observed to be not stored in a covered container. Enchiladas were thrown out in the presence of the LPA. Per the (FM) facility uses paper plates, which are located in the cleaning closet. A menu was posted. Dining Area: This space has a large table with (2) bench seats for (6) persons. Group Therapy is held here. Hallway Cabinets: There are two locked cabinets which contain snacks and non-perishables. Per (FM) clients have access after school and in alignment with our daily schedule. Staff can help them get there snacks or extra food.There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Bathroom 1:This is a full bathroom with toilet, sink and shower/tub combination, which was recently renovated and in good repair. Water temperature was tested within the regulatory range. Bedroom 1: is occupied by (C2, C4). There are two beds with full linen, and drawers. There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Bedroom 2: is occupied by (C1, C5). There are two beds with full linen, and drawers. There is an on-suite full bathroom with toilet, sink and shower/tub combination, and is in good repair. Water temperature was tested within the regulatory range.There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Bedroom 3: is occupied by (C3, C6). There are two beds with full linen, and drawers. There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Laundry Room: There is a washer and dryer in good condition. There are locked cabinets, with additional bathroom towels and paper goods. Garage: This space holds a water heater, additional clothing, and refrigerator with additional frozen and perishable food items. All food items throughout the facility meet the requirements. Client caddies with toiletries were observed to be stored here. Continued on 812C Page 3 of Page 3 of At 12:00pm LPA Wilson inspected the following: Staff Office: This is a locked office for staff which has (1) large desk, computer chair, computer, printer and file cabinets. LIC500 and LIC9020 client roster was posted and a copy provided to the LPA. There are (2) locked cabinets, which contain client medications. First Aid Kit, PRN medications and sharps are kept in locked boxes inside the locked cabinet. Medications: LPA Wilson inspected the medications log and medication packs with the facility manager (FM). LPA observed that in (2) out of (3) clients, medications were not logged by night staff (NOC). LPA and (FM) counted the bubble packs contents and determined that (1) client (C2) had taken their medications, but it was not logged, and (1) client (C6) had not taken thier medication and the missed medication was not logged. The (FM) updated the logs in the presence of the LPA after confirming the missing information. Per the (FM) there was a recent CACWT medication training for staff on 02/25/24, which the (NOC) attended. LPA Wilson also spoke to the Head of Service (HOS) by phone, concerning this observation. Outdoor Area: The perimeter of the home is in good condition. During the time of the inspection, there was a painter, completing new exterior paint on the entire property. The outdoor area has a covered shaded area, grass, a shed with files and no furniture. LPA observed the gas shut off valve. Vehicles: LPA Wilson inspected (2) two facility vehicles - Toyota Sienna CE with November 2024 registration and insured by Progressive Insurance. Vehicle is in good condition with no issues- Chrysler Towne and Country with July 2024 registration and insured by Progressive Insurance. Vehicle is in good condition with no issues. LPA Wilson conducted one (1) staff interview with (FA) and one (1) client interview with (C1). LPA Wilson inspected client files (C1, C2 and C3) Court records, emergency contact information, signed personal rights, Health.medical information, Educational information, personal property safeguards and allowance log. CFT Meeting Notes and Needs and Service Plan were emailed to LPA by request to (HOS and CI). LPA Wilson was unable to review staff files and Emergency Intervention Plan. LPA Wilson will return to complete the inspection at a latter date with (HOS) A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Adam Maciel, Facility Manager.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward investigated the above allegation. LPA interviewed C1, staff and witness. C2 was not available to be interviewed. LPA reviewed needs and services plans for both clients and the police report generated from the incident. Based on the interviews and records reviews, C2 was receiving counseling in respecting the boudaries of others before the alleged incident and the facility moved quickly to address the complaints of the alleged victim C1 after the alleged incident,. C1 denied to staff, police officers and this LPA that C2 attempted to assualt him. However he and C2 did not get along and the facility quickly moved C2 to another bedroom to prevent further altercations. Although C1 denied that he was sexually propositioned by C2, there is insufficient evidence that staff developed an appropriate safety plan to protect C1 and other clients from C2 who had a known history of sexual assault and harrassment. Therefore the finding on this allegation is emended to "unsubtantiated" which means that although an allegation may be valid or true, there is not enough evidence to prove that it did occur. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: 0001231-FN On December 11, 2024 at 9:53 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding SIR dated 11/09/2024.No staff or clients were at the home. At 10:15am, Head of Services (HOS) arrived and together with LPA,went over the case management incident finding. During the course of the incident investigation, which included staff interviews and record review, it was revealed that on 11/09/24 at approximately 9:00am staff (S1) was in the home with (4) clients when the youth (C1) was not supervised, and licensee was out of ratio for client's behavioral needs. Further the licensee did not send additional staff (S2) (S3) until 10:00am. A (1) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC 809D) An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee. (FM) whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

investigation_findings: 13On 04/23/2025, at 12:35 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez made an unannounced complaint inspection to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and delivering the findings for LPA Lanice White and LPA Christine Wilson. On July 10, 2025 at 10:10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendely Moodie-Naranjo and Licensing Program Manager( LPM) Kevin Sauk conducted an unannounced inspection at the above facility. Upon arrival, LPA and LPM was greeted by Child Care Counselor, Erica Abel, who granted access to the facility. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a case management inspection to investigate a self-reported incident that occurred on June 19 ,2025, involving Client (C1) accessing pornography at the facility. During today's inspection, LPA and LPM interviewed staff (S1), client (C2) and obtained copies of that LIC 500 and client roster. On July 10th, 2025 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendely Moodie-Naranjo and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation, which was initiated on 06/02/2025, involving a self-reported incident where client (C1) was taken back into care after C1 had already been discharged. Licensing staff met with Erica Abel, who granted access to the facility. During the investigative process, LPA Moodie-Naranjo conducted confidential interviews with all relevant parties, which revealed that staff (S1) mistakenly accepted C1 back into care, because S1 was unable to reach a facility manager during the night shift. Based on interviews conducted and documents obtained, Community Care Licensing has found there to be a violation of supervision. The following deficiency was observed and cited at the time of this inspection. (See LIC809-D) Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 02/04/2021 at 1:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk made an unannounced inspection to the above-said facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection. LPA Sauk met with the Facility Manager (FM), who granted access to the facility, and who provided a tour of the entire facility, inside and out. Due to the Coronavirus pandemic, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Teams. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) male clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only (See confidential name list LIC-811 dated 02/04/2021). LPA observed the following: This is a three bedroom, two bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, garage, and staff office. All three bedrooms were observed with equipment to be in good condition, sufficient lighting, drawer and closet space, comfortable mattresses, and clean lines, blankets, and pillows. Bedroom #1: sleeps two clients (C1 and C2), equipped with two twin-size beds. Bedroom #2: sleeps two clients (C3 and C4), equipped with two twin-size beds. Bedroom #3: sleeps two clients (C5 and C6), equipped with two full-size beds. This bedroom has an attached bathroom. There is no swimming pool or any other bodies of water on the premises. The passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps, and open porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met. The outdoor space is free of debris and any hazards. Cleaning solutions, disinfectants, medication and sharp knives are inaccessible to the clients. Medication is locked and accessible only to employees supervising stored medications. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector were tested and operable at the time of inspection. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the kitchen and in multiple places around the facility that was operable at the time of inspection. (Continued on LIC809-C, page 2) The first aid kit is fully stocked. The bathrooms were inspected and found to be clean. The facility has a working telephone. FM states that there are no weapons or guns on the premises. Facility operates within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility has a current, written plan of operation. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. The facility has a Toyota Sienna passenger van and Toyota Camry to transport clients. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 3, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Manager (FM), in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

On 02/04/2021 at 2:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk conducted a Case Management - Incident inspection at the above-said facility, and met with the Facility Manager, in response to a Special Incident Report, submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 01/26/2021, in order to investigate a possible Personal Rights violation. The incident, which occurred on 01/26/2021, involved staff (S1), who took client's (C1's) blanket off of C1 in the morning, when C1 was refusing to get out of bed to get ready for school; this triggered C1 to approach S1 from behind, and wrap his arm around S1's neck. C1 later went to the kitchen and tore the fire extinguisher off of the wall and began to spray it in the living room. [See LIC Confidential Names List form (LIC811), dated 02/04/2021, for names.] LPA interviewed staff (S1), and client (C1), who both confirmed that S1 had taken C1's blanket off of C1 in the morning to help him get out of bed; this is a personal rights violation. It was reported that this method of waking-up C1 had occurred on more than one occasion, because C1 sometimes has a hard time waking up in the morning. Regardless of whether or not this method had triggered C1, other forms of waking-up the clients from bed shall be used. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 3, the following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC809-D) Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Manager (FM), in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file.

investigation_findings: 13On 02/16/2021 at 12:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kevin Sauk, made an unannounced inspection to the above-said facility, in order to inform the Licensee that a complaint investigation is being conducted regarding the above allegation. Due to the Coronavirus Outbreak, LPA met with the Facility Manager (FM). LPA Sauk Interviewed FM, the Operations Facilities Manager (OFM), and all clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6). [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 02/16/2021, for names]. Based on all of the interviews conducted, it was revealed that the sentiment, on whether punishment was inappropriate, was not common, and differed amonst the 6 clients; for this reason, the Department has concluded the above allegation of a Personal Rights violation to be Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 3.1, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to the Facility Manager, in order to obtain a signature. Signature will be on file. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: [Continued from LIC9099-A] bedrooms multiple times. There were multiple reports where C1, C4, and C6 engaged in sexual interaction in the living room, where staff (S3) reported that the clients' only opportunity may have come when S3 had left the clients alone in the living room to finish watching a movie, while S3 performed office duties, in the office. While placed in both New Way facilities, client C4 has had a history of attempting to kiss other clients, based on past incident reports. Because of C4's behavior, staff should have been aware and more vigilant in terms of supervising the clients in care to prevent such actions from taking place on facility grounds. Although C1 and C4 denied that any sexual activity had occurred, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that sexual activities have occurred in this facility between C1 and C4, due to a lack of supervision. If any additional information is received, this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. Per California Code Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), the following deficiency has been cited. narrative: On June 7, 2021 at 10:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cameo Banks. conducted an announced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection for New Way Group Home 2. During the inspection LPA spoke with Ricardo Contreras, Operations Manager, Alex Mendoza Administrator and Kendrick Mathis, Facility Manager. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted via Microsoft Office Teams and the facility was inspected inside and out. Both client and staff files and medication logs/documents were reviewed by LPA The current census is six (6) children. LPA reviewed three (3) client files on 6/4/2021. LPA reviewed three (3) staff files on 6/7/2021. LPA. conducted staff interviews with Staff #1, Staff #2 and Staff #3 on 6/7/2021. LPA. conducted three (3) client interviews with Child #1, Child #2 & Child #3 on 6/7/2021. LPA. conducted facility walk through on 3/10/2021 at 10:30am. This is a one story three bedroom, two bathroom house that has a living room, dinning room, kitchen, staff office, and outdoor space. Overall, LPA observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA observed adequate staffing at the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPA observed medication to be centrally stored, double locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. Medication was observed locked in Staff Office. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be e-mailed to the Facility Manager for signature

LPA Rosas inspected the following: This is a one (1) story (STRP) Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program, located in a residential neighborhood. This is a (3) three bedroom, (2) two bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. There is two (2) facility vehicles parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition. Outdoor Area: There was no swimming pool or bodies of water on the premises. The activity space is free of hazard materials and debris. LPA observed a staff displayed the utility shut-off valves. The facility is surrounded by wooden fence and is observed to be good condition. Report continues on LIC 809-C Page 1 of Laundry Room: The laundry room is located next to the garage. The laundry is equipped with a washer and dryer unit that was observed to be in good condition. The laundry detergent is made inaccessible to the children and is disputed according the load of the laundry. Disinfectants and chemicals are locked in cabinets made inaccessible. Garage: The attached two car garage is used as storage and is kept locked. There is two (2) vehicles available to transport youths; make and model are a Toyota Sienna, and Toyota Corolla. The vehicle has full coverage auto insurance with Farmers Insurance. Dining Area/Kitchen/Family Room (Den): There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. There is a television and working fireplace with a cover. One table with six (6) chairs is next to the Kitchen: There is a gas stove/oven with four (4) burners, all operating. There is a dishwasher, microwave, refrigerator with freezer and a toaster oven. LPA observed adequate perishable/nonperishable food supplies. Sharp knives, disinfectants/cleaning solutions made inaccessible to the children locked in the staff office. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Additional Living Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. The living room has dining table with six (6) chairs and televisions. Additional disinfectants, chemicals, and medication are locked in storage closet in the living room making inaccessible. There is a fireplace that is non-operable with a cover. Staff Office: It is equipped office furniture (i.e desk, computers, printers). The medication is triple locked inside of the staff office. The client files are kept in a locked closet. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, cleaning solutions, and medication. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. This bedroom was a bathroom. Bedroom # 2: Currently occupied by one (1) client, has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows have horizontal slide locked with curtains observed to be in good condition. Page 2 of Bedroom # 3: Currently occupied by two (2) clients. The bedroom has two (2) twin sized beds and comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows; adequate drawer and one (1) walk in closet. Bathrooms: There are two (2) bathrooms. Bathroom #1 is the common bathroom for the clients. It is a full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and tub/showers. Bathroom #2 is located inside of Bedroom#1 is full-sized bathroom with a toilet, sink, and shower. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed a key locked closet that stored hygiene supplies, and cleaning solutions. All windows were in good condition with screens and blinds. There were no security bars on the windows. LPA observed ample towels and linen closet. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. All posting requirements were met, (food menu, regulations, licenses, emergency disaster plan, Children's Personal Rights, and Ombudsman). The home has a working telephone and youths can use the telephone unless restricted by court order. The Emergency Evacuation Plan is posted. LPA Rosas was not able to review client or staff files during this visit and will return to continue with the annual inspection. On August 18, 2022 at 9:50am Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Emelyn Sanchez P. and Olivia Rosas. conducted an unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection for New Way Group Home 2. During the inspection LPA Sanchez P. and LPA Rosas met with Ricky Garcia, Facility Manager and Alex Mendoza, Facility Administrator. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas reviewed three (3) client files and three (3) staff files. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas conducted three (3) staff interviews and no client interviews due to the children being in school. Currently there are four (4) clients residing in the above facility. This is a one story house located in a residential area. The facility has three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a living room, staff office, kitchen, family room, laundry area, attached garage (used for storage space), and outdoor space. The outdoor space is free of obstructions. Overall, LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed adequate staffing at the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPAs Sanchez P. and Rosas observed medication to be centrally stored, triple locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members in the Staff Office. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be left at the facility.

On December 9, 2022, at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Olivia Rosas made an unannounced visit to New Way 2 for the purpose of conducting a Case Management - Other Inspection to address concerns regarding Cross reference referral report dated 11/22/2022. LPA Rosas and Staff#1 (S1) discussed the details SIR (See confidential name list LIC811 dated 12/09/22). The Department received cross reference referral from Client#1 (C1) County of Placement dated 11/21/2022. Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) received a CPS Hotline report from placement County reporting that C1 is currently placed at New Way Group Home 2 in Oxnard, CA. Facility reported that Child#1 (C1) is allowed to leave the facility for 30-minute walks. On 11/19/2022, C1 returned to the facility with $300 worth of merchandise including a new pair of tennis shoes and a backpack. Facility reported that C1 had the receipts for the items, and it showed that it was paid in cash. On 11/10/2011, C1 outing returned with an iPhone. On 11/21/2022, C1 was questioned about who gave him the iPhone. C1 reported a friend gave the phone. C1 did not provide further details. Facility related the information to the Department and pertinent parties. The facility is the process of scheduling a Child and Family Team (CT) meeting to discuss incidents and concerns regarding the suspicious purchases. Facility is no longer allowing C1 to have unsupervised 30-minute walks. Based on the interviews conducted and documentation gather no further information is needed. A review of Facility's Personnel Report Summary on 12/13/2022 indicates that all personnel have criminal record clearance has obtain the necessary clearances with DOJ, FBI, and Child Abuse Response. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On 06/18/20232, it was reported that Staff#2 (S2) restricted Child#1 (C1) from going fishing and fishing gear was locked up in the staff office. Interviews revealed that C1 was given the restriction of going finishing during the week and only allowed to go finished during weekends because of poor school grades. The facility limited the fishing outings to help C1 study for finals week and raise their grades. Interviews stated that facility did not threat residents or removed personal items. Facility staff denied the allegation of threatening residents in care as a form punishment. The facility uses the disciplinary style of natural and logical consequences (point system) and utilizes a group-centered treatment program. Facility reported that all discipline as a result from an incident shall be fair, respectful, equal, and consistent. Some of these approved punishments are not receiving full daily points, the temporary removal of earned privileges, restriction, the moving down of a step and in some extreme circumstances the moving down of a level. Interviews noted that some of the resident's property is kept locked in the office closet for safe keeping such as bigger electronics, skateboards, personal snacks, and allowance. The residents school laptops are locked in the office when they were enrolled in virtual learning. Based on all the interviews conducted, it was revealed that the discipline of removing the earn privilege was used as consequence and C1 did not agree with the consequence of limiting daily finish trips. There was not enough evidence and information to corroborate the allegation. Results from the Department's investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has decided that the allegations of Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility. Page 2 of 2

narrative: On Wednesday, May 18th, 2022, at approximately 5:30pm, Client#1 (C1) was walking around the house in frustration and anger as Staff#2 (S2) was asking if C1 needed to talk to his therapist or take a walk. C1 continued to dwell on the incident that happened earlier in the day and was disrespectful and rude towards S2 and Staff#3 (S3) and Staff#4 (S4). S4 offer to talk about the incident and C1 walked out of the facility and over to the office window and began kicking. C1 was able to kick the window in and started to make verbal threats towards staff. S2 used proximity control to keep C1 from getting near the broken window. C1 then walked around to the side of the house and began kicking the fence. C1 broke off a few wooden pieces that were connected to the fence. C1 was able to apprehend the broken wood pieces. In addition, C1 began to hit the electrical box from the facility and removed the lock from the electrical box. S2 was shadowing C1 to try to redirect and to de-escalate C1. C1 then turned towards the neighbor's fence door and began kicking. C1 was able to break the side neighbor's door. S2 used verbal redirection and body positioning to keep C1 from destroying more property on the neighbor's fence. The nearby neighbors came outside of their home and were viewing the incident. C1 began to say began to say some very inappropriate words and threats to the standby neighbors. S3 contacted non-emergency numbers and Oxnard Police Department. C1 then began to run towards the neighbor and crossing the street with ongoing traffic. At 6:06pm S2 conducted one-person SAFE bear hug restrain to stop C1 from harming himself and others. At 6:30pm Oxnard Police Department arrived and detained minor C1. Oxnard Police Department notified S2, S3 that C1 would be placed on a 72-hr hold/5150 at St. John's Regional Medical Center stating he was threatening the staff, children and destroying property. Based on witness, and video footage S2 conducted inappropriate restrain hold to C1 to prevent from harming himself and others. LPA Rosas ensured to thoroughly review the records of the primary active staff. The facility provided evidence of staff training transcripts stored in RELIAS Training Program digital system with a schedule to complete Hours for new hires and ongoing training for various topics including Trauma Informed, and CSEC training. LPA reviewed the Personnel Report (LIC 500) and confirmed that Direct Care Staff Ratio present for clients in placement. In addition, LPA reviewed C1 file record that include Admission Agreement, Inventory of Personal Belongings and cash resources, Dental and Medical forms, Consent Forms, Psychotropic Medication Authorization, Psychotropic Medication logs. LPA Rosas conducted interviews with clients, and facility staff that provided information on how clients in placement receive therapy sessions, provide care and supervision and facility services. Report continues on LIC9099-C Page 2 of Based on on site inspections on 05/20/2022, 06/02/022 and video footage dated 05/19/ LPA was able to obtain evidence that C1 did vandalize neighbors and break wooden gate door at time of crisis while staff was at the scene. Facility repaired broken gate door at facility and neighbors, office window and created a taller fence between the facility and neighbors' home. Based on interviews, witness statements, related records reviewed, and video footage dated 05/18/2022, S2 did not follow restraint protocol and conducted inappropriate manual restraint technique C1 which poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risks to children in care. Results from the Department's investigation, consisting of interviews with related parties, inspections, and review of records. The Department has concluded, based on the preponderance of the evidence obtained during this investigation, that the allegation of Personal Rights and Neglect and Lack of Supervision are substantiated. During the inspection investigation the LPA observed deficiencies (see attached 809D), plan of corrections was discussed and appeal rights were provided. LPA Rosas provided a copy of this licensing report to S1. Exit interview was conducted with S1 and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

narrative: On Wednesday, May 18th, 2022, at 6:30pm Oxnard Police Department arrived and detained minor C1. On May 20, 2022, LPA Rosas received a call from S4 stating that they would not picking up C1 from the hospital for the safety of C1, other clients in placement based on the incident that occurred on 5/18/22. On 5/18/22, C1 made verbal threats to neighbor. The facility does not feel safe bringing back C1 to the facility as fear of the verbal threats C1 made to the neighbor. C1 was discharged from St. John's Regional Medical Center on May 20,2022 but stayed in the Emergency Room until arrangements were made for pick up on May 23, 2022. Based on on-site inspections on 06/02/022 and video footage dated 05/19/ LPA was able to obtain evidence that C1 did vandalize neighbors wooden gate door at time of crisis while staff was at the scene.
