narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dina Camara conducted a case management inspection 4/11/23 at 11: AM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811,dated 4/11/2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments and youth case plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dina Camara observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Ricardo Contreras, Head of Service

I-32- Recommended Practices Regarding Youth Who Have Experienced Commercial Sexual Exploitation and Their Usage of Cell Phones and CSEC Power Point. narrative: On March 5, 2024 at 9:26am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an announced inspection to New Way Group Home 2 (STRTP) for the purpose of conducting an Annual Inspection. LPA Wilson was met by (FM) This is a short-term therapeutic residential treatment program (STRTP) that is licensed to provide care supervision for six (6) youths, ages 12-17 years, as well as non-minor dependents; ambulatory only. There is no swimming pool or body of water on the premises.Facility underwent a triennial survey with the Joint Commission and has valid, accreditation status.MPHA Certification is in progress per the Head of Service (HOS) and the Special mental Health Program Analyst Lisa Harvell. This is a one-story facility located at Raft Lane, Oxnard CA. 93035. The facility currently has Accreditation with Joint Commission dated 04/1/2023 and valid for 36 months. The facility has an expired Mental Health Program Approval with the Department of Health Care Services and Ventura County with an effective date of 02/07/2023 and expiration date of 02/07/2024. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The facility is current with their annual fees. LPA Wilson inspected the following: This is a (3) three bedroom, (2) two bathroom, single story family residence that includes a living room, dining area, kitchen, staff office, backyard, and an attached garage for storage. Continued on 809C page 2 of Page LPA Wilson was greeted by staff (FM) who allowed entrance into the facility and who provided LPA with a tour of the facility. Individuals mentioned in this report are identified on the Confidential Names List [see LIC811 dated 03/05/2024.] There were two (2) clients in the home (C3, C5). Three (3) other clients (C1, C2, C4,) were attending school. There were two (2) staff in the home (S1, FM) and the Administrator (FA) arrived at approximately 10:45am Postings: MPHA (expired 02/07/2024, Facility Sketch, Complaint Process, Administrator Certificate (FA), License, Emergency Numbers, Foster Youth Rights. Living Room: There are (2) couches with seating for seven persons, Table, and cabinet. There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Game Room: There is one smaller couch with seating for 3 persons, TV, Fireplace that is unused, puzzles and games. There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. Kitchen: The kitchen has a fire extinguisher with current inspection, There are cleaning supplies such as dishwashing soap and a container of Lysol wipes accessible to clients in a cabinet below the sink. These items were moved by the FM, in the presence of the LPA. There is a (4) burner stove in working condition, microwave, and refrigerator set at 40 degrees. Per the (FM) facility uses paper plates and plastic utensils, which are located in the cleaning closet. A menu was posted in the presence of the LPA. Utensils, pots, pans. Water temperature was tested within the regulatory range. (S1) returned with groceries, and there is enough perishable and non perishable foods that meet the regulation. The back door leading to the backyard area allows for free entry to the home, and has no secure bolt. Hallway: There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. There is some additional bedding in a linen closet. Hallway Bathroom : This is a full bathroom with toilet, two (2) sinks and shower/tub combination. Water temperature was tested within the regulatory range. Bedroom 1: is occupied by (C1, C3). There are two beds with full linen, and three drawers. There are window screens in good condition. Bedroom 2: is occupied by (C2, C5). There are two beds with full linen, and two drawers. There are window screens in good condition. Conrinues on 809C page 3 of Page Bedroom 3: is occupied by (C4). There are two beds with full linen, and three drawers. There is an on-suite full bathroom with toilet, sink and shower/tub combination, and is in good repair. Water temperature was tested within the regulatory range. LPA Wilson observed red and blue shoestrings were tied to the white set of drawers. LPA advised the FA to remove the strings. Laundry Room: There is a washer and dryer in good condition. There are locked cabinets, with additional bathroom towels and paper goods. A fire extinguisher with current inspection was observed. Garage: This space holds a water heater, additional clothing, and refrigerator and deep freezer with additional frozen and perishable food items . All food items throughout the facility meet the requirements. Additional clothing, bicycles and snowboard equipment were observed to be in the garage. At 10:20am LPA Wilson inspected the following: Staff Office: This is a locked office for staff which has (1) large desk, computer chair, computer, printer and file cabinets. LIC500 and LIC9020 client roster was posted and a copy provided to the LPA. There is a locked closet and locked cabinets within, which contain client medications, Medications log. First Aid Kit, and sharps are kept in locked boxes inside the locked cabinet. There is no PRN medications. The locked closet also contain snacks and non-perishables. Per (FM) clients have access after school and in alignment with our daily schedule. Staff can help them get their snacks or extra food. There is a smoke alarm/Carbon monoxide detector that was tested to be in working condition. The office has a fire extinguisher with current inspection. There is a grievance box for clients. additional bathroom towels and PPE equipment were observed. Allowance: An allowance log was observed. Per the FM, the minimum is $7 and more can be earned for additional allowance. There is also a bad tax which is a deduction from allowance anywhere from not doing your chore to incidents to being disrespectful to staff. During the intake we have the opportunity to explain the allowance rules but nothing signed that explains the tax. They also do get a monthly clothing allowance." Medications: LPA Wilson inspected the medications log and medication packs with the facility manager (FM). LPA observed that in (1) out of (5) clients, medications are prescribed, and logged. LPA and (FM) counted the bubble pack contents for (C4) and observed that one dose was outside of the bubble pack. Per the (FM), there was no explanation for the medication to be outside of the bubble pack. Per the FM, "I wont give it to him and I will write the incident report." FM used a gloved hand to dispose of the medication in a plastic bag and placed in the office trashcan. On April 28, 2022 at 0930, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Val Wilson, Jose Gonzalez, Joon Choi, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Cheraki Davis, conducted an annual inspection at Oak Grove Center Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPA was met at the facility by Administrator, Tammy Wilson. LPA's and LPM began a physical plant inspection at 10: AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are hard-wired in and are in appropriate working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced in each unit. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and appears to be following the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster in each residential unit. Medications are locked and centrally stored in Nursing station. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held in individually locked containers for 2 children. However, each child at the facility does not have their own individual lock box and key. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client's bathroom was measured in each resident unit were within F and F degrees. However, rooms B-14 96 degrees, B-13 84 degrees, and C-2 102 degrees. A work order dated 04/27/2022 was provided for the recirculating pump for the water heater. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility including Gymnasium, outside perimeters, and school hallways. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a chain link fence. The pool fencing was well over five feet tall, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. The pool is clean and well maintained. Per facility Administrator, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Next page Administrator Tammy Wilson is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. LPA's reviewed the following documents: Menu, Facility roster, Child roster, Fire Inspection, Accreditation, Mental Health Program approval, License, Shift Roster, Activity calendar, Dorm schedule, Restraint log, surety bond, Board of Directors Quarterly report for the past year, Petty cash expenses, JV223 during medication inspection, trauma informed training, and work order receipt for service. The facility is required to provide locked containers with keys, for the purpose of storing contraceptives. Based on observations and interviews, the facility is not providing the locked containers for each client. The facility is cited for violation of STRTP ILS, Section 87075(b)(1)(A) Health Related Services. The facility is required to deliver hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F and not more than 120 degrees F. Based on observation and interviews, a purchase order and work order was made on 4/27/22 for the repair. They are scheduled to arrive to make the repair on 5/02/22. The facility is issued a technical violation. Due to time constraints, LPA's will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Tammy Wilson.

narrative: During the investigation, confidential interviews stated that there were inconsistences with the information that was being reporting to staff about the incident. Confidential interviews disclosed C1 and C2 shared dorms for one day but upon learning of the incident of an alleged inappropriate behaviors staff removed C2 from C1's dorm. Other confidential interviews stated that following the incident staff set up a boundary plan for both clients that included physical distance and no communication. Another confidential interview stated that C2 had no history of sexual inappropriate behaviors. Confidential interview continued stating that C1 had a history of intrusive behaviors and further added being more acquainted with C2 and in the process of getting to know C1. Another confidential interview stated that a meeting was pending with C1 to further discuss the allegation of the complaint and was unable provide additional information. Another confidential interview stated that C1 was concerned about C2's behaviors due to information obtained from outside sources that alleged that C2 had a history of inappropriate touching. Confidential interview continued stating that there was an incident at the STRTP where C2 brushed up against the front of C1's body. Confidential interview also stated not knowing if C2's behavior toward C1 was an accident or if it was done on purpose. Another confidential interview denied that C2 touched C1 inappropriately. Confidential interview continued stating that C1 was making false allegations against C2 and that C2 was upset and confronted C1 about the allegations. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that C2 engaged in inappropriate behavior with C1 in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Oak Grove Center CEO, Tamara Wilson.

On March 18, 2024 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias and Jessica Peete conducted an annual inspection at Oak Grove Center Short Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP). LPAs were met at the facility by Clinical Director Billie Gengler. LPA Peete began a physical plant inspection at 11: AM, assisted by Program Director, Raymond Orozco, Environment Manager, Mike Howland, and Environmental Services Coordinator, Natalie Kerrigan. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facility's administration building, cafeteria, dining room, children's activity center (gymnasium), maintenance rooms. swimming pool, classrooms, multiple staff offices, nursing station, Dorm A, Dorm B, and Dorm C. Dorm A has twelve bedrooms with census of seventeen female clients. Dorm B has fourteen bedrooms with a census of 16 co-ed clients. Dorm C has 12 bedrooms with a census of 22 male clients. The clients Bedrooms are arranged so there are no more than two clients per room with a shared bathroom. All toilets, skins and showers are maintained in safe, sanitary, and operating condition. In addition, the water in each client bathroom measured between 105 and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA observed that each client bedroom room had the appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses. During the inspection LPA observed 11 bed mattresses needed to be replaced. Dorm A, bedroom one did not have blinds. Bedroom twelve had a broken dresser drawer that was repaired during inspection. Dorm B bedroom 9 had broken blinds. Per Program Directors Raymond Orozco, work orders have been placed for repair. Licensee will be cited with a violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) 87088(c)(1) Fixtures, Furniture's, Equipment and Supplies. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. The pool fencing was well over five feet tall, with a self-latching gate that swings outward. The pool is clean and well maintained with maximum depth of four and a half feet. All facility smoke detectors are hard wired in and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced in each dormitory. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods and follows the posted menu. (Continue on next page..) All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster in each dormitory, and medications are centrally stored in the nursing office for Dorms A-C. Licensee has provisions for contraceptives to be held individually for each client; LPA observed each client bedroom was equipped with a small combination safe to hold personal items or contraceptives. LPA Covarrubias assisted by Clinical Director Billie Gengler completed the review of five staff files (S1-S5), five client files (C1-C5), Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, Emergency interventions, and Core-Therapeutic Services. All required documentation was observed, and no deficiencies were found. LPA Covarrubias completed four staff interviews to go over the facilities policies and procedures. All staff were able to identify the required elements of the facility policies and procedures. LPA Covarrubias completed four client interviews and no concerns were noted. Based on observations, made during the inspection deficiencies are being cited, see LIC D. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal right, and LIC Confidential Names List, was provided to Program Director Raymond Orozco.

However, the witness was unable to provide the name of the staff member who witnessed the interaction or when the alleged incident occurred. Other confidential interviews did not provide information to support the allegation. Although it was reported that clients (C1, C2, and C3) engaged in inappropriate behaviors during placement, confidential interviews denied observing the alleged misconduct between clients (C1, C2, and C3). Multiple confidential interviews reported that C1 and C3 displayed poor boundaries, and pertinent documentation provided to LPA reported that C1 had various incidents involving exhibitionism. Furthermore, multiple confidential interviews denied a lack of supervision and reported that room visiting is not allowed, and staff conducted frequent room checks while on shift. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and documentation, the allegation that due to lack of care and supervision, minors (C1, C2, and C3) engaged in inappropriate interactions is unsubstantiated. narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Guadalupe Munoz and Joon Choi on May 9, 2024 at 10: AM. This case management inspection is conducted pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.9 (a)(2). During the inspection, LPAs Munoz and Choi met with Executive Director Tamara Wilson and LPA Choi conducted a health and safety inspection of the facility. LPAs reviewed five of child's records and three of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs reviewed five of child's psychotropic medications and medication records. LPAs interviewed three staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. During the facility visit, one child that is presribed psychotropic medication, declined LPAs request for an interview. LPAs will attempt to interview four children, currently prescribed psychotropic medications, at their respective school(s), after this facility visit. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Executive Director Tamara Wilson and provided a copy of this report.

Confidential interview revealed that C1 had to leave early at the religious service due to other clients' behavior issues, and the facility would have been out of staff ratio if C1 was to remain at the service, thus C1 had to leave religious service early. Confidential interviews also revealed that C1 later that day returned to attend another service, because C1 was able to find two other clients to attend with C1 to maintain staff/client ratio. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that the staff does not ensure C1 is allowed to attend religious service activities of their choice may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to Oak Grove Center Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP), Billie Gengler, Head of Service.

narrative: visitation to minor's family member. It was reported that C1 was bullied and had a pillow pressed into their face and staff did not intervene. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements. Some interviews indicated that C2 pressed a pillow onto C1's face and kicked their ankle. While other interviews, denied seeing any clients press a pillow onto C1's face or kick their ankle. It was reported that S10 made inappropriate comments about C1's mother and threatened to send C1 out of state. Confidential interviews denied S10 made the comments or overheard any staff make these comments. It was reported that C1's mother requested to visit C1 multiple times per week. Confidential interviews and documents reviewed indicated there were no restrictions on C1's mom visiting them at the facility and C1's mom was allowed to visit and take C1 off grounds at any time. Other confidential interviews indicated that visits for clients were set up by the therapist. Confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegations with a preponderance of evidence. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed the allegations that staff did not provide proper supervision to C1 in care, staff spoke inappropriately to C1, and staff did not allow visitation to C1's family member, which may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed with and provided to Tamara Wilson. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

narrative: Multiple confidential interviews reported the incident happened quickly after facility staff completed their morning rounds checking the client's bedrooms. Confidential interviews also denied hearing noise or loud voices from C1 and C2's bedroom. Although it was reported that staff did not prevent the physical assault of C2, the confidential statements provided to LPA consistently denied a lack of supervision. Confidential interviews reported that staff completed room checks regularly and had no indication something would occur between C1 and C2 as both were considered compatible roommates with no known issues before this incident. In addition, conditional interviews reported that the staff is proactive and would not have allowed C1 and C2 to share the same bedroom if C1 and C2 were incompatible. Furthermore, confidential interviews reported once staff became aware of the altercation; in addition to C2 receiving medical attention, C1 and C2 were assigned to different rooms, and a boundary restriction was enforced. The restriction prohibited C1 and C2 from being within ten feet of each other. Based on confidential interviews and facility documentation,the allegation that staff did not prevent a minor (C1) from attacking another minor (C2) is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to Clinical Director, Billie Gengler.
investigation_findings: 13On August 30, 2024, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Oak Gove Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. LPA Peete obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed STRTP staff (S1, S2, S3, and S4) and Client 1(C1). LPA attempted to interview C2, but C2 declined the interview. On 05/08/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that staff did not prevent a minor (C1) from attacking another minor (C2). The Special Incident Report (SIR) provided to the Department reported that C1 and C2 fought on facility grounds. The incident happened in the client's (C1 and C2) bedroom. The SIR reports that C1 used a closed fist to hit C2 multiple times on the head. C2 sustained a visible injury to the left side of the forehead. The SIR and confidential interviews did not disclose any clients or staff who witnessed the altercation. (Continued on LIC 9099-C) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
allegations: UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion: Unsubstantiated Estimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Moreover, a confidential interview reported that no other clients made allegations against S1. The Department also received allegations that staff used inappropriate restraints and staff handled an unidentified minor roughly. Specifically, there were concerns that facility staff used restraints as a form of punishment to manage client behaviors, resulting in an unidentified client's face being pushed into a door. Confidential interviews reported that all staff who initiate restraints receive Professional Assault Crisis Training (Pro-Act) and training from the Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI). Confidential interviews reported that restraints are used as a last resort to ensure the client's safety and are not used retroactively or as punishment. Additionally, before restraints are used, staff will attempt to de-escalate the situation using crisis communication and other nonphysical interventions. Multiple confidential interviews also denied witnessing facility staff misuse restraints, physically abuse, or handle clients roughly while restrained. Furthermore, confidential interviews did not disclose any knowledge of a client being deliberately injured in a restraint and sustaining an injury to the head or face. Based on confidential interviews and facility documentation, the allegations that staff (S1) was selling vapes to minors in the facility, staff uses inappropriate restraints, and staff handled minors roughly are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Clinical Director, Billie Gengler.
investigation_findings: 13On August 30, 2024, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Oak Gove Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegations listed above. LPA Peete obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed STRTP staff (S1-S6) and clients (C2-C6). LPA attempted to interview C1, but C1 did not respond to the interview request. On 05/07/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation that Staff (S1) was selling vapes to minors in the facility. Confidential documentation provided to LPA shows that the STRTP was aware of the allegation against S1 and conducted an internal investigation. The internal investigation cleared S1 of any offense, as the client who made the allegation later recanted. In addition, LPA did not obtain corroborating statements to support the allegation as confidential interviews either denied the allegation or denied seeing S1 with vapes, drugs, or alcohol on facility grounds. (Continued on LIC 9099-C) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: The investigation concluded that on 04/23/2024, C1 wrapped a jacket "loosely" around their (C1's) neck but did so in the presence of staff (S5), who was able to remove the jacket. Likewise, another agency investigated and found that Oak Grove's conduct "was not harmful." Confidential documentation provided to LPA reported that C1 did make multiple suicidal statements and wrapped items around their neck on more than one occasion. The documentation also shows that the staff was aware of these attempts and intervened accordingly. However, another confidential interview provided conflicting information and reported that staff did not supervise C1. As a result, C1 was able to make multiple suicide attempts in C1's assigned bedroom or adjoining bathroom without the staff or others knowing. LPA was unable to corroborate this statement; furthermore, other confidential interviews reported that C1 was under various safety precautions while in care. Based on confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegation due to lack of supervision, a minor (C1) attempted suicide is unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Administrator, Tammy Wilson
investigation_findings: 13On October 11, 2024 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Peete conducted an unannounced visit to Oak Gove Group Home, formerly Short Term Therapeutic Treatment Program (STRTP) to deliver the investigative findings for the allegation listed above. LPA Peete obtained documents pertinent to the investigation and interviewed facility staff (S1-S9) and Client 1 (C1). On 07/17/2024, Community Care Licensing received an allegation due to lack of supervision, a minor (C1) attempted suicide. There were concerns about two separate instances that occurred on 04/22/2024 and 04/23/2024. Based on the Special Incident Reports (SIR) provided to the Department on 04/22/2024, C1 called the "988 hotlines" and law enforcement (LE) and reported having "urges to self-harm." On 04/23/2024, they (C1) repeated the same actions and, as reported on the SIR, disclosed to LE they (C1) attempted to "choke" themselves earlier in the day. Multiple confidential interviews reported that due to C1's history of unsafe behaviors, C1 was closely monitored and never left unsupervised. A confidential interview also reported the facility conducted an internal investigation into C1's claim of self-harm. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Shoua Xiong and Nino Sanders conducted an unannounced Annual/Required Inspection at the facility on 7/15/21 beginning at 11:30AM. LPAs met with Paul Mertens, Executive Director/Administrator, and explained the purpose of the inspection. This facility is licensed for 18 clients and currently serves 6 clients. On today's date, a Health and Safety Inspection was conducted of the facility. This facility has two main houses that residents are able to stay in. Currently, only the "Main House" is utilized while the "Tea House" is unoccupied. On grounds is what is referred to as the "Staff Corridor" building which consists of an Administration Office, Classroom, and Pantry. This facility also contains a basketball/tennis court area along with a garden and chicken coop area. During the inspection of the Main House where clients stay and sleep in, LPAs observed that no more that two clients in care shared a bedroom. All clients were provided with their own beds with beddings, dressers, and closet space for personal storage. Each client also had their own individual basket of hygiene products. Each bedroom was observed with an operational smoke detector. Personal Rights poster was posted in a public area. In the kitchen area, menus were displayed on the refrigerator. The refrigerator and pantry was stocked with the required amount of both perishable and non-perishable food items. Smoke Detectors and Carbon Monoxide detectors were present in each building. Client files were observed to be locked in an office. This office also contained client medications which were locked in a glass cabinet and the Medication Administration Record binder. Throughout the facility grounds, there are areas where clients are able to participate in recreational activities, which also includes Archery. There are four storage sheds and one workshop barn on the property and they were all observed to be locked. LPAs also reviewed six client files. All required documents were present. No deficiencies were noted in client files. LPAs also interviewed three clients in care. LPAs were unable to finish the Annual Inspection and will return on another date and time. No citations were issued on today's date. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left at the facility with Paul Mertens, Executive Director/Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong and LPA Nino Sanders had conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the facility on 7/15/2021 beginning at 11: AM. LPAs met with Paul Mertens, Executive Director/Administrator and explained the purpose of the visit was to conduct an inspection of the facility for the purpose of completing their Annual/Required inspection and for the permanent Licensure of the facility. This facility is currently provisionally licensed to serve 18 clients. There were six clients placed in care at the time of the inspection. On today's date, LPAs conducted a tour of the facility, reviewed six client files, and interviewed two clients. There were no observable safety concerns or safety hazards during today's inspection. No deficiencies were cited. LPAs are recommending Permanent Licensure of this facility, pending on Management review. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Paul Mertens, Executive Director/Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On 11.04. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cecilia Warren met with Paul Mertens, Program Administrator to deliver findings for a complaint with allegations of "Minors engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior while in care" Prior to meeting, LPA reviewed Program Statement, LIC Personnel Report, Child Roster, Staff Schedule, and any Program Fees due for the month of July. LPA reviewed facility complaint history for the past year. During the investigation LPA conducted eleven confidential interviews, a facility inspection and collected Employee Work Schedule, House Rules, Strengths and Needs Plans, Social Worker Case Notes, SIRs, and Emergency Plan. All observations, confidential interviews, documentation, inspections were inconsistent with the reported allegations. The eleven confidential interviews revealed that the youth did engage in inappropriate activities, however there is no evidence to support that it was due to lack of Supervision of staff or their failure to protect the personal rights of the clients in care. The facility monitors the youth regularly and as defined in their work samples and record keeping. The youth have learned the supervision schedule and plan things between those times. The facility is aware of the youth's observations and have increased supervision and rotations of schedules to adapt to the needs of the youth, specifically during timeframes where checking on the youth is required. More staff are participating on check in's and adjusting schedules to ensure youth are healthy and safe. An exit interview was completed with Paul Mertens, Program Administrator, and a copy of this report was emailed to the facility. No Title 22 deficiencies cited. Appeal rights were provided. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

On 4/23/24 at 10: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kayla Green met with Theresa John assistant to the directors for the purpose of a case management for an incident that occurred on March 16, 2024. It was reported that a client had missed medication due to client leaving early in morning to go visit his parent and the staff forgot to give to it to him. When medications were distributed at 8:30AM, the medications was notice and the client was contacted. The client stated he felt fine and the doctor and on site supervisor was notified. The staff was given additional training and the error was logged. LPA reviewed medication logs for 11 clients and observed six clients Medication Administration Record (MAR) for March and April 2024. LPA didn't see any errors when it came to logging the medication information. LPA also spoke with Paul Mertens about their procedures for training when it comes to medications and logging it. He stated " Licensed psyc tech gives the staff training on logging the medication, any missed errors that happen by staff she retrains that staff member on the procedures. As well, we have staff meetings where we go over the procedures of logging the medications in the binders and any changes when it comes to logging the medications." Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights is left with Theresa John.

narrative: An unannounced Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman on 9/5/25 at 9:30am. LPA did not review any child's records or staff personnel files on site at the facility due to no children qualify for this inspection and no administrative staff were onsite to access staff files. LPA interviewed four staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. LPA provided a copy of this licensing report to Mary Baron, Systems & Technology Manager. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Mary Baron, Systems & Technology Manager.

facility_name: ODD-FELLOW REBEKAH CHILDREN'S HOME OF CALIFORNIA
narrative: Closure Meeting: Odd-Fellow Rebekah Children's Home of California - Location: Virtual meeting via Microsoft Teams Attendees: Rebekah: Michael Gilbert - STRTP Program Administrator/Campus Services Program Manager (Adm), and Julio Villarreal, LCSW - Chief Clinical Officer (CCO) Department Family Children Services: Cynthia Elkins - Placement Supervisor for Santa Clara County Department of Health Care Services: Gabriel Pacheco - AGPA | Children's Therapeutic Care Unit CCL: Nelson Martinez - Regional Manager (RM), Helga Wong - Licensing Program Manager (LPM), and Carolyn Flynn - Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) The purpose of this meeting is to review over the closure plan set for August 25, 2021. During the meeting we discussed the obstacles and challenges that lead to the closure, the plan for the last client in care, and plan for the future of the program. As a result of this meeting, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Michael Gilbert, Administrator with a request to sign and send back a signed copy for the files.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carolyn Flynn made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility at 9: AM on 08/25/2021. LPA met with Michael Gilbert, Administrator (Adm) to tour the facility and confirm the last client has been removed from campus. At 9: AM, Adm escorted LPA through the facility. LPA observed the six open bedrooms were empty and no clients are residing in the facility. LPA confirmed that the last client discharged on 08/24/2021. The facility is no longer operational and Adm returned the STRTP License to LPA Flynn. As a result of this visit, there were no California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Chapter 5 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Gilbert, Administrator whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents

facility_name: ODD-FELLOW REBEKAH CHILDREN'S HOME OF CALIFORNIA
narrative: Interviews conducted with County Social Worker, Probation Officer, four staff and two clients established that there was not any intent to harm youth if contact was made by the staff and the minor. All interviews except one state that the minor charged at the staff during an escalation. The photo that was sent to LPA does show a dark brownish/greyish color mark above the belly button on the stomach of a male, but there is not a face on the picture to identify who the person in the picture is nor is there a time or date stamp on the picture to show when it was taken. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation of staff caused injuries to a minor while in care is unsubstantiated. As a result of this visit, there were no title 22 deficiencies observed. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Michael Gilbert, Administrator whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these document.

LPA Flynn conducted interviews between July and August 2021. LPA Flynn reviewed and obtained copies of needs and service plans, incident reports from 05/24, 05/25, 06/04, and 07/08/2021, staff schedules and current staff phone list from Adm on 07/14/2021. narrative: On January 27, 2022, at 8:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection for Olive Crest/Hope Refuge Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at the above address, LPA met with the David Harper Facility Administrator (FA) and Tina Chang Program Director (PD) and together conducted a tour of the entire facility. Olive Crest/Hope Refuges is located in the Los Padres National Forest. The site was a previous recreational campground and currently Hope Refuge STRTP still open. There are three residential cottage, main house, dining hall, therapy building, Administration/Music building, school, bathrooms, central kitchen/staff lodging, laundry room, activity space. Currently Hope refuge Unit 1 (Olive cottage): It has four (4) bedrooms with a capacity for eight (8) clients with a sink in each bedroom. Two twin beds in each room, dresser, and adequate lighting and closet space. Four (4) bath units with a sink, shower and toilet all operable at time of inspection. There is a living room with a couch and chairs. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that must remain locked at all times and cannot be used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and tested at time of inspection. The alarms must be activated at all times. Children's Personal Rights need to be posted. Due to the layout of the facility grounds, a small refrigerator, microwave and non-perishable food supplies must be available in each cottage. Continue on LIC809-C Unit 2 (Pine Cottage): It has four (4) bedrooms with a capacity for eight (8) clients with a sink on it. Two twin beds in each room, dresser, and adequate lighting and closet space. Four (4) bath units with a sink, shower and toilet all operable at time of inspection. There is a living room with a couch and chairs. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that must remain locked at all times and cannot be used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and tested at time of inspection. The alarms must be activated at all times. Children's Personal Rights posted. Due to the layout of the facility grounds, a small refrigerator, microwave and non-perishable food supplies must be available in each cottage. Unit 3 (Oak Cottage): It has four (4) bedroom with a capacity for eight (8) clients with a sink on it. Two twin beds in each room, dresser, and adequate lighting and closet space. Four (4) bath units with a sink, shower and toilet all operable at time of inspection. There is a living room with a couch and chairs. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that must remain locked at all times and cannot be used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and tested at time of inspection. The alarms must be activated at all times. Children's Personal Rights are posted. Ensure glass windows on exit doors are covered. Due to the layout of the facility grounds, a small refrigerator, microwave and non-perishable food supplies must be available in each cottage. Stone House/Central Kitchen: The Stone House will only be accessible to staff. The house will be off limits to the youth. This is a three (3) bedroom Two and a half (2 1/2) bathroom homes with a living room, dining area and kitchen. There is a Kitchen located adjacent to the dining room, equipped with one (1) refrigerator in the kitchen and one (1) commercial size walk-in refrigerator and freezer located outside the house. The refrigerator/freezer will need to be made inaccessible to the youth, one (1) toaster ovens, one (1) range, two (2) ovens, one (1) microwaves, trash can with lid, and fire extinguisher. LPA observed 1 fire extinguishers in the unit. The bedrooms are currently empty. Once the STRTP is licensed the bedrooms can be used by Direct Care Staff if they want to stay the night at the facility instead of driving back home. Continue on LIC809-C Dining Hall: The front of the hall is equipped with three (3) couches, and dining tables LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. The Dining hall has two back rooms that are intended to be a nurse station and medication room. Applicant will need to provide a locked storage area for medications and a lock cabinet for youth and staff files. All fireplaces throughout campus need to have secured heat resist covers. Therapy Building: The unit has a group therapy area with four (4) chairs, couch, TV stand and bookshelf. The cottage also has two smaller therapy rooms with two (2) couches and a coffee table. No smoke detectors or carbon monoxide detectors available. Administration Building/Music Room: The front of the cottage is for administrator staff used only with six (6) cubicles and office materials. The back of the cottage they have a music room equipped with a piano, guitar and music stand reader. No smoke detectors or carbon monoxide detectors available. Outdoor Space: There is a gated pool on the premises with two outside accessible bathrooms, storage area and a locked room where pool pump is located. The pool is about 9 feet high with a self-closing key lock mechanism located halfway down from top of gate. School Building: Is to be used as on-site school and academic space. The front half consist of 6 desks with 5 chairs at each desk. The back half consist of 12 computer desks and chairs. No smoke detectors or carbon monoxide detectors available. Bath House: Equipped with three (3) toilets three (3) showers and two (2) sinks all operable at time of inspection. Applicant will ensure all doors are installed on bathroom stalls. Laundry Rooms: The laundry room is located in the screen room with one exterior entrance. There are three (3) washers and three (3) (dryers) sink and fire extinguisher. Additional laundry room located outside of the Stone House will not be used by the youth. Continue On LIC809-C LPA Hernandez went over the Component III agenda and discussed the forms required to be maintained at the Facility and available for inspections. LPA also went over the documents that should be available and posted in the Client's residences. LPA Hernandez went over the Child's Records documents that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. LPA Hernandez went over the forms: Preplacement appraisal information LIC603,Appraisal/Needs and Service Plan LIC625, Physician Report For Community Care Facilities LIC602, Identification and Emergency Information LIC601, Admission Agreement Guide for Residential Facilities LIC604, Personal Rights Children's Have the Rights LIC613B, Record Of Client's/Resident's Safeguarded Cash Resources LIC405, Client/ Residential Personal Property and Valuables LIC621, Consent For Emergency Medical Treatment Children's Residential Facilities LIC627B, Unusual Incident Report LIC624, Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record LIC LPA Hernandez discussed the Personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. LPA Hernandez went over the forms: Health Screening Report-Facility Personnel LIC503, Personnel Record LIC501, Criminal Record Statement LIC508, NOTICE Employee Rights LIC 9052, Statement Acknowledging Requirement To Report Child Abuse LIC9108, Child Abuse Central Index Check For State Licensed Facilities LIC198A, Designation Of Facility Responsibility LIC308, Personnel Report LIC500, Criminal Record Exemption Transfer Request LIC9188, Criminal Background Clearance Transfer Request LIC9182, Applicant/Licensee Rights LIC9058, Appeal Procedures For Applicants/Licensee LIC LPA Hernandez discussed the specific problems and issues of operating a STRTP. LPA Hernandez discussed sections A though N of the component III agenda including: Reporting Requirements, Personnel Requirements, Supervision, Intake Issues, Compatibility, Removal/Discharge, Complaint Procedures, Transportation, Health Services, Food and Hygiene, Visitation, Personal Property, Searches and Community Sensitivity. Licensure is pending final approval of Application, Plan of Operation and Program Statement. A copy of this report will be emailed to the facility administrator, due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer

On 6/21/22, at 8:50am, Licensing Program Analysts (LPSs) Nancy O'Connell and Enrique Hernandez conducted an unannounced inspection at the above listed facility, for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing inspection. LPAs were met by David Harper, Facility Administrator (FA), who granted access to the facility. LPAs conducted the file review for seven staff and client file (C1, C2, C4) [See confidential names (LIC811) dated 6/21/22, for names]. LPAs also inspect the facility vehicles. LPAs conducted confidential interviews on 6/20/22 with two staff (S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6, and S7) and two clients (C1, and C2), and one client declined to be interviewed. During the time of inspection, LPAs completed the inspection tool and were informed by the FA that the facility utilizes volunteers. Upon record review, it was determined that 2 out of 4 volunteers do no have a criminal record clearance prior to working in the facility. FA communicated that he was unaware of regulation and would take immediate action to obtain criminal clearance for all volunteers. Per California Code regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing standards (ILS), chapter 7. Version 4, a deficiency will be cited today for uncleared staff volunteers. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of appeal rights were provided to the FA.

On 7/28/2022 at 10:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell, made an unannounced inspection to the above-listed facility, and met with the Trina Garcia (S1), who granted access to the facility and provided a tour of the facility, inside and out. The purpose of this inspection is to follow-up on recent Medication Incident Reports submitted to the Department. LPA O'Connell conducted a walk-through of the facility cottage (Olive) with S1. During the time of the inspection, LPA interviewed one client (C1) and all other clients (C2, C3,and C4) refused to be interviewed [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 07/28//2022, for names]. LPA observed locked medication closet, fire extinguisher, available snacks, and the cottage to be clean and orderly. LPA O'Connell reviewed the medication log for all four (4) residents. LPA also toured the facility pool and noted that the gate was locked and the body of water was inaccessible to residents. At 11:00am, LPA O'Connell met with the FM and reviewed recent medication incident reports submitted to the Department (dated 6/26/22, 6/26/22, and 7/24/22) and asked about reason for instances of missed medication. FM reported that staff S2, responsible for passing morning medication to residents (C4 and C5), was supposed to provide medication at 7:00am, and "forgot" to pass the morning medications to residents due to focusing on getting residents ready to go on a activity outing, which was scheduled for deaprture at 8:15am. FM explained that S2 believed that another staff provided the medication. Continued on LIC809D PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), Chapter 7. Version 4, a deficiency will be cited on this day. Exit Interview conducted, and due to technical difficulties with LPA's printer, a copy of this report will be emailed to the FM along with appeal rights. .

On January 13, 2023, at 10:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk, made an unannounced inspection to the above facility for the purpose of following up on two Case Management-Incident inspections. On 12/17/23, the Department received a Serious Incident Report (SIR) communicating that a resident, C6, was hospitalized after a period of demonstrated aggression toward self and others. The SIR reports that efforts were made to de-escalate C6 over a period of several hours before the resident was transported to the emergency room for evaluation. On 11/7/22, the Department received a Serious Incident Report (SIR) communicating that resident C5 engaged in aggressive behavior, resulting in her assaulting a resident, staff, and AWOLing from the facility. During the time of inspection, LPA and LPM interviewed three staff and 1 resident at the facility in order to gather additional details related to the incident. LPA interviewed FA, FM, and HOS and C3. [See Confidential Names form (LIC811), dated 01/19/23, for names]. More information is needed to conclude the investigations related to the above incidents. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and due to technical difficulties with the LPA's printer, a copy of this report was emailed to the facility administrator

On March 7, 2023, at 11:50am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell conducted an unannounced annual inspection for Olive Crest/Hope Refuge Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at the above address, LPA met with the David Harper Facility Administrator (FA) and Roberta Strangfeld, Head of Service (HOS) and together conducted a tour of the entire facility. During the time of inspection, LPA O'Connell conducted an inspection of the following areas: Unit 1 (Olive cottage): The cottage has four (3) bedrooms, one bedroom has been converted into a office. Each bedroom has a sink in each bedroom. Two twin beds in each room, dresser, and adequate lighting and closet space. Four (4) bath units with a sink, shower and toilet all operable at time of inspection. There is a living room with a couch and chairs. LPAs observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that must remain locked at all times and cannot be used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and tested at time of inspection. The alarms must be activated at all times. Children's Personal Rights were posted. Due to the layout of the facility grounds, a small refrigerator, microwave and non-perishable food supplies are available in each cottage. Continue on LIC809-C Unit 2 (Pine Cottage): It has four (3) bedrooms with a sink installed in each bedroom along with one bedroom converted into a staff office. This unit if intended to be utilized as a privilege room and will allow a resident to have their own bedroom. At time time, this cottage is not in use. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that was locked at all times and is not used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and functional. Unit 3 (Oak Cottage): It has four (3) bedrooms with one bedroom converted into a staff office. Each bedroom has a sink and provides enough room for two residents to live in each. At time time, this cottage is not in use. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that was locked and is not used as a pass through. There is an exit door to the outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and functional. Stone House/Central Kitchen: The Stone House is only be accessible to staff. The house is off limits to the youth. This is a three (3) bedroom Two and a half (2 1/2) bathroom homes with a living room, dining area and kitchen. There is a Kitchen located adjacent to the dining room, equipped with one (1) refrigerator in the kitchen and one (1) commercial size walk-in refrigerator and freezer located outside the house. LPA observed 1 fire extinguisher in the unit. The bedrooms are currently empty but may be used by staff as needed to stay the night at the facility instead of driving back home. Dining Hall: The front of the hall is equipped with chairs, dining tables and solar panels. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. The Dining hall has two back rooms that are used as a locked storage room for cleaning supplies. During the time of inspection, LPA and HOS inspected the small kitchen connect to the dining room and upon inspection of refrigerators, LPA found multiple items that were without dates, not packages in containers, and reflecting mold. LPA inquired about reason for items not being dates, stored properly or discarded due to mold, and HOS communicated that the staff cook is responsible for ensuring proper food storage. LPA retained pictures for records. Therapy Building: The unit has a group therapy area with couches, chairs, TV stand and bookshelf. The cottage also has a smaller therapy room with couches and a coffee table. Therapy is provided individually to clients and family sessions are conducted via telehealth. Continued on Lic 809c Outdoor Space: There is a gated pool on the premises with two outside accessible bathrooms, storage area and a locked room where pool pump is located. The pool is approximately 9 feet deep with a self-closing key lock mechanism located halfway down from top of gate. The pool area has two bathrooms, with one that is not in use and has a sign posted to indicate. The pool in inaccessible to clients without supervision. Due to the weather, the pool is not in use at this time. School Building: there is a classroom space available for residents to engage in curricular activities. However, it was reported that due to connectivity issues, residents have been completing school work within their cottages. Per Title 22, there is one deficiency to be cited at this time. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this this report will be emailed to the RPD.

On March 8, 2023, at 9:20am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell conducted a unannounced annual- continuation inspection for Olive Crest/Hope Refuge Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at the above address. LPA met with the David Harper Facility Administrator (RPD), who provided access to facility records for review. LPA completed the file reviews for four staff (S1, S2, S3, and S4) and three client files (C1, C2, and C3) [See confidential names (LIC811) dated 3/8/23, for names]. LPA also conducted three staff interviews with S2, S6, and S7, and 2 client interviews with with C2 and C3. LPA inspected three facility vehicles (two in use and one not in use). LPA observed that vehicle #2 did not have a valid registration and when LPA inquired with the RPD, it was communicated that the documentation is still in process and unavailable at this time.RPD confirmed that the vehicle has been in use for the last six weeks and use to facility business and transportation of residents. During the time of inspection, LPA completed the following inspection tool sections: Emergency Intervention Plan, Core Therapeutic Services, Disaster Preparedness, Operational Requirements, and continuation of Physical Plant. Per California Code regulation, Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1, General Licensing Regulations, and Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing standards (ILS), chapter 7. Version 4, there is one deficiency to be cited today. See 809D for details. Exit Interview was conducted and a copy of this report was sent to the the RPD..

On 3/20/23, at 11:00am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O'Connell and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Kevin Sauk met with David Harper, Residential Program Director (RPD) for a teleconference office meeting. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss matters related to provision of services. During the meeting, LPM Sauk reviewed previously submitted Serious Incident Reports (SIRs), dated 12/2/22, 12/9/22, and 12/31/22. All incidents relate to missed medication and/or incorrect administration of medication. LPM Sauk clarified each instance for medication error and asked for additional information as to reason(s) for errors. RPD was able to review each incident and provide clarification for medication errors. RPD explained additional policies and efforts taken to ensure accurate medication administration, which includes new policy to only conduct medication exchanges among staff, within secured areas, and ordering a "gun safe" to be placed in the facility vehicles that can serve as a secure location for storing medications when on outings. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. A copy of this report was emailed to RPD and a signature is kept on file.

narrative: On July 17, 2023 at 10:00am, an Office Meeting was held at the Woodland Hills Regional Office. Present at the meeting were Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Kevin Sauk, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Christine Wilson, and the Facility Administrator, David Harper. The Office Meeting was called to discuss that the terms of settlement, involving a one-year probation of staff (S1), along with other terms and conditions of this settlement. S1's certification as an administrator is revoked upon the Department's adoption of the Stipulation as its Order. However, the revocation shall be stayed for a probationary period of one year subject to the following terms and conditions specified below: A. S1 meets all statutory and regulatory requirements related to the position of administrator, including but not limited to, Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) Interim Licensing Standards, version 4, Section 87064 and 87064.1. B. S1 shall work for one facility currently located at Refugio Road, Goleta, CA 93117. If S1 changes location, he will first obtain approval from the Department and give notice to the CCL Regional Office located at Ventura Blvd, Suite Woodland Hills, CA 91364. C. S1 shall be on premises located in Refugio Road, Goleta, CA 93117 for a minimum of 40 hours per week, to manage and ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations. In the absence of S1, a Program Supervisor shall receive authorization to take on S1's duties and responsibilities. D. S1 shall complete eight (8) hours of new training in STRTP administrator duties including medication management that was not previously completed and shall provide proof of said additional training to the Department. E. S1 shall obey all federal, state, and local laws; and F. S1 complies with all statutes and regulations related to S1's current employment. David Harper agreed to the above conditions as well as all of which is stated in the Stipulation and Order, which was dated and signed on 06/15/2023. S1's one-year probation shall expire on 06/15/2024. Exit interview completed, and a copy of this report was left with David Harper.

narrative: On March 18, 2024, at 9:59am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson conducted an unannounced annual inspection for Olive Crest/Hope Refuge Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at the above address, LPA met with David Harper Program Director (PD) and together conducted a tour of the entire facility. At 10:27am LPA Wilson conducted the following: LPA Wilson conducted one (1) staff interview with (ES1) and (3) client interviews with (C1, C2 and C4). At 11:16am LPA Wilson inspected the following: During the time of inspection, LPA Wilson conducted an inspection of the following areas: Unit 1 (Olive Cottage): The cottage has three (3) bedrooms, one bedroom has been converted into a office. Each bedroom has a sink in each bedroom. Two twin beds in each room, dressers, and adequate lighting and closet space. Four (4) bath units with a sink, shower and toilet all operable at time of inspection. Water temperature was within range. There is a living room with a couch and chairs for (9) persons. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit with recent inspection. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that must remain locked at all times and cannot be used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms must be activated at all times. Children's Personal Rights were posted. Due to the layout of the facility grounds, a small refrigerator, microwave and non-perishable food supplies are available in each cottage for staff use. If medications are to be refrigerated, this can be used for that purpose. School Building: There is a classroom space available for residents to engage in education curricular activities. There are (6) desks and computers. There is a water dispenser and a heating system. Continued on 812C page 2 of At 12:00pm LPA Wilson inspected the following: Vehicles: LPA Wilson inspected (4) four facility vehicles in total 1. Honda CRV with current registration that expires in October 2024. HUB International Insurance 2. Toyota Sequoia (black) with current registration that expires in September 2024. HUB International Insurance. All vehicles are in good condition with no issues. Dining Hall: The front of the hall is equipped with chairs, dining tables and solar panels. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit. The Dining hall has two back rooms that are used as a locked storage room for cleaning supplies. During the time of inspection, LPA and (PD) inspected the small kitchen connect to the dining room and upon inspection of the area for non-perishibles and snacks, LPA Wilson and PD were approached by clients, who complained about the snacks being too little. Clients were seen eating a 2oz applesauce packet. LPA inquired about reason for items Per the PD, snacks are provided to the clients, and staff choose which snacks are provided. Snacks are given to clients twice per day. PD communicated that the Facility Cook (FE) is responsible for ensuring enough snacks are purchased and that her budget has increased. LPA Wilson and (PD) reviewed CCR 80076(A) Food Services to review the regulations, Per (PD) they will meet with (FC) and review the menu and purchases to see if anything should be adjusted. At 1:40pm LPA Wilson conducted the following: Outdoor Space: There is a gated pool on the premises with two outside accessible bathrooms, storage area and a locked room where pool pump is located. The pool is approximately 9 feet deep with a self-closing key lock mechanism located halfway down from top of gate. The pool area has two bathrooms, with one that is not in use and has a sign posted to indicate. It is used for storage. The pool in inaccessible to clients without supervision. Per the (PD)Staff have water safety training each year prior to the pool availability. Due to the weather, the pool is not in use at this time. Vehicles: LPA Wilson inspected (2) additional facility vehicles - 3. Toyota Sequoia (white) with current registration that expires in October 2024. HUB International Insurance. 4. Kawasaki Mule 4x4 with current registration that expires in June 2024. Vehicle is used for on-site transportation only. Vehicles are in good condition with no issues. LPA Wilson will return to complete the inspection at a latter date with (PD) A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to David Harper Program Director (PD).

narrative: On August 2, 2024 at 10:17 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christine Wilson made an unannounced visit to the above listed facility, in order to conduct a case management incident inspection, regarding three (3) SIRs; (2) dated 07/24/24 and (1) dated 07/23/24. LPA Wilson was met by Program Director/Administrator (PD). During the course of the incident investigation, it was revealed that on dates 07/23/24 and 07/24/24 the youth (C1) was not provided proper dosage of medications as prescribed by their physician by staff (S1,S2 and S3). Per the (PD) New staff did not understand the instructions for the prescription and needed to wake up the child at 1:00am for a dosage. Staff did not pass medication at 1:00am due to medication log not documenting 1:00am dosages . (PD) spoke to the dentist who prescribed the medication and gave orders to continue to provide the client with the antibiotic. (PD) and (PM) spoke with staff who missed the medication and provided a medication training on 07/31/24 (LPA obtained copies of training sign in sheets and the post-test results). Staff (S1) did not take the training, due to preparation for her last day of employment, which was on 08/01/24. (PD) provided an update on the fire suppression line, which is on hold until an engineer assesses the landscape. NO other projects may start until fire suppression begins. Kitchen upgrade is a year-long project which will not affect services to the clients and will take place after fire suppression project ends. A (1) deficiency Type A has been determined at this time. The following deficiency has been cited. (See LIC 809D). An exit interview was conducted and Plans of Correction was developed and reviewed with the licensee. A copy of this report and appeals rights were discussed and left with licensee, whose signature on this form confirm receipt of these documents.

On 2/28/2025, at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin conducted a follow-up Case Management - Incident inspection at OLIVE CREST-HOPE REFUGE. LPA Martin met with Dominique Harrison, Program Manager to deliver investigative findings concerning Incident Report submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 9/24/2024. The incident reported in part possible neglect/lack of supervision, as a youth in care sustained injuries to the head and elbow areas, resulting from a physical altercation with another youth in care. The incident was referred to CCL Investigations Branch for investigation. CCL Investigator, Douglas Real conducted the investigation including confidential interviews with four youth, two staff members and Facility Administrator. In addition, facility file history, incident reports and related medical reports were reviewed. Confidential interviews and documentary evidence revealed on 9/22/2024, two youth residents engaged in a physical altercation. Facility staff members were present during the altercation and verbally directed the youth to stop. At some point a third youth resident intervened pulling one youth away from the other. The two youth re-engaged with the physical altercation before stopping. Statements revealed complaints of youth having a hurt elbow and headache after falling during the altercation. A review of medical records indicated the youth's x-rays revealed no fractures or broken bones. Statements obtained from involved parties and witnesses, as well as record review, revealed a lack of evidence to prove neglect/lack of supervision resulting in a physical altercation between youth with injuries. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is determined Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) at this time. A copy of this report is provided to Program Manager during this visit.

Statements obtained did not uncover or sufficiently support the allegations, therefore, the allegation that Facility staff provided drugs, alcohol, monetary assistance, and a place to stay while facility clients ran away from the facility is unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or may be valid, however, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited per California Code of Regulations or Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) concerning the above allegations, at this time. A copy of this report, and LIC811 was discussed and left with Program Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On 2/28/2025 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin made an subsequent complaint inspection at OLIVE CREST-HOPE REFUGE for the purpose of delivering findings on the above allegations. On July 29, 2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging conduct inimical by an unidentified staff member towards youth residents. It was reported that the staff member assisted youth making their unauthorized departure from the facility. It was further alleged that the staff member took the youth to the staff's home where they all reportedly smoked marijuana and drank alcohol together. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch and investigated by Investigator, Douglas Real. On August 1, 2024, LPA Regina Martin met with Facility Administrator to inform and initiate the investigation and obtain facility records. The investigation further included confidential interviews with two former residents, their assigned Probation Officers, staff (S1), and review of facility file history. Information obtained revealed denial of said allegations and or revealed a lack of corroborating proof to substantiate the alleged. (Continued on pg LIC9099-C) UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:
