narrative: On 03/20/2025, at 11:15 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nestor Gomez arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual Required Inspection on the Olive Crest-Hope Refuge (STRTP) facility. LPA Gomez met with Facility Administrator, David Harper who granted access to the facility. The annual fees are current. During the time of inspection, LPA Nestor conducted an inspection of the following areas:Unit 1 (Olive Cottage): There are currently four (4) residents residing in Olive Cottage. The cottage has three (3) bedrooms, one bedroom has been converted into an office. Each bedroom has a sink in each bedroom. Two twin beds in each room, dressers, and adequate lighting and closet space. Four (4) bath units with a sink, shower and toilet all operable at time of inspection. Water temperature was within range. There is a living room with a couch and chairs for (9) persons. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit with recent inspection on 2/19/2025. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that must remain locked at all times and cannot be used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms must be activated at all times. Children's Personal Rights and Emergency Evacuation plan were posted. Due to the layout of the facility grounds, a small refrigerator, microwave and non-perishable food supplies are available in each cottage for staff use. If medications are to be refrigerated, this can be used for that purpose. Medication is located in the restroom of the staff office and is locked. Continue on 809-C (Page 1) Unit 2 (Pine Cottage): There are no residents in this building. It has four (3) bedrooms with a sink installed in each bedroom along with one bedroom converted into a staff office. This unit if intended to be utilized as a privilege room and will allow a resident to have their own bedroom. At time, this cottage is not in use. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit with a date of 2/28/2025. All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that was locked at all times and is not used as a pass through. There is an exit door to outside in both bedrooms with an alarm to alert staff if the door is opened. The alarms are audible and functional. Unit 3 (Oak Cottage): There are four (4) residents in this building. It has four (3) bedrooms with one bedroom converted into a staff office. Each bedroom has a sink and provides enough room for two residents to live in each. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit . All smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable at time of inspection. Each bedroom was observed with a connecting door that was locked and is not used as a pass through. There is a hallway shelf unit with additional, cleaned and new bedding. Medication is locked and stored by the staff office. Therapy Building: The unit has a group therapy area with couches, chairs, TV stand and bookshelf. The cottage also has a smaller therapy room with couches and a coffee table. Therapy is provided individually to clients and family sessions are conducted via telehealth. LPA observed a fire extinguisher that was dated for 2/29/2025. Staff Office/Music Room Building: The music room contained several musical instruments, 2 couches, 11 chairs, and a fire extinguisher that was dated for 2/28/2025. Continue on 809-C (Page 2) School House Building: There is a classroom space available for residents to engage in education curricular activities. There are (9) desks and computers. There is a water dispenser and a heating system. Fire extinguisher was observed and dated for 2/28/2025. Personal rights were posted within the classroom. Dining Hall: The front of the hall is equipped with chairs, dining tables and solar panels. LPA observed a fire extinguisher in the unit that was dated for 2/28/2025. The Dining hall has two back rooms that are used as a locked storage room for cleaning supplies. During the time of inspection, LPA and (PD) inspected the small kitchen connect to the dining room. The kitchen area, nurse office, infirmary located on the other side of the building is not in use. Pool House/Outdoor Space: There is a gated pool on the premises with two outside accessible bathrooms, storage area and a locked room where pool pump is located. The pool is approximately 9 feet deep with a self-closing key lock mechanism located halfway down from top of gate. The pool area has two bathrooms, with one that is not in use and has a sign posted to indicate. It is used for storage. The pool in inaccessible to clients without supervision. Per the (FA) Staff have water safety training each year at the beginning of summer prior to the pool availability. Due to the time of the year, the pool is not in use at this time. Per FA the pool will open in May or June 2025. Vehicles: LPA Nestor inspected (4) four facility vehicles in total. 1. Toyota Sequoia (white) with current registration that expires in October 2024. Alliance of Nonprofits for Insurance, Risk Retention Group that expires 10/08/2025. 2. Kawasaki Mule 4x4 with current registration that expires in June 2025. Vehicle is used for on-site transportation only. Continue on 809-C (Page 3) Honda CRV with current registration is expired. The vehicle is currently not in use at the time of the inspection per FA. Alliance of Nonprofits for Insurance, Risk Retention Group that expires 10/08/2025. Toyota Sequoia (black) with current registration that expires in September 2025. Alliance of Nonprofits for Insurance, Risk Retention Group that expires 10/08/2025. All vehicles are in good condition with no issues. Vehicles are in good condition with no issues. Kitchen: Food was stocked with enough food for the current client census of 8. Food was stored and dated. LPA observed the area to be clean and sanitary. Staff Interview: LPA Nestor conducted four (4) interview with FA, Staff (S#) S1, S2, and S3. Client Interview: LPA Nestor conducted four (4) client interviews with Client (C#) C1, C2, C3, and C4. LPA Nestor will return to complete the inspection. There were no deficiencies observed or cited at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to David Harper Program Director (PD). End of Report (Page 4)

investigation_findings: 13On June 18, 2025 at 9:17 am, Kenrick Ellis, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an unannounced visit to Olive Crest-Hope Refuge for the purpose of concluding a complaint investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with David Harper, Administrator and discussed the complaint allegations. A health and safety assessment was conducted. During the investigation LPA conducted two client interviews and five staff interviews. During the investigation LPA also reviewed Personnel Report (LIC500), client roster, and incident reports. The interviews did not produce evidence to support the allegation. During the investigation there were no statements or evidence that indicated staff allowed minors in care to engage in inappropriate interactions. Statements indicated that staff conducted room checks every 15 minutes. Statements indicated that staff were briefed by S1 and S4 about inappropriate relationship between clients in care. Statements indicated that staff met with clients to discuss facility policies regarding relationships and inappropriate interactions. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to David Harper UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

On June 04, 2021, at 8: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jesus Cervantes conducted an unannounced annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to a STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 04, 2018. LPA was met at the facility by Residential Manager Karla Loera. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Clients medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked file cabinet in the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has one full client bathroom and one-half client bathroom. The water temperature in the bathroom one of two was tested at 9: AM and registered at 115.8 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator Amy Ahern is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. See Page Two The facility employs one Intensive Services Director, one Administrator, one Clinical Supervisor, one Residential Manager, one Care Coordinator, two Rehab Specialist, two Mental Health Clinicians, and ten direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee obtained Mental Health (MH) Certification in December 2019. Due to delays caused by COVID-19, the Department of Health Care Services is in the process of renewing the facilities Mental Health Program Approval. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA. The Accreditation is valid through October 31, 2021. Licensing fee payments are current. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. At 10: AM, LPA reviewed a sample of five clients files during the time of inspection. Two clients, and two facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. Three clients declined to be interviewed. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Facility procedures related to requesting exceptions. Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. LPA also discussed Reasonable and Prudent Parenting Standards, and resident involvement in development of planned activities. Due to time constraints and employee files being housed in their corporate office, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of staff file reviews. No deficiencies were found. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Residential Manager Karla Loera

On June 08, 2021, at 11: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jesus Cervantes, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual continuation inspection from June 01, 2021. Employee files were not located at the facility and required employee files to be reviewed at Olive Crest Headquarters located at E. Fourth Street, Santa Ana, CA 92705. LPA and LPM meet with Madison Mazzone and Denise Griffiths. Five random personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in the Human Resource office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Client and staff interviews were conducted on 06/04/2021. No deficiencies were noted during time of inspection.

Confidential interviews and record review revealed that on 11/14/2020, C1 and C2 were outside of the STRTP smoking and S2 asked the clients to give up what they were smoking. The clients refused and began walking away from the facility. At that time, S2 and S1 followed the two clients and there was a verbal altercation as staff were trying to get clients to go back to the facility. One confidential interview revealed C1 pushed S1 after S1 grabbed C1's hand, while another interview and record review revealed C1 pushed S1 when S1 stood in front of C1. Confidential interviews revealed that after C1 pushed S1, S2 told C1 if C1 put hands on staff again, S2 would push C1. S2 admitted to saying to both clients, not either one specifically, that S2 would push them if they pushed staff. S2 revealed at that time, S1 told S2, S2 could not say those things to the clients. S2 stated it was S2's first month on the job and admitted S2 made a mistake in saying that. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. The department has determined the allegation that S2 threatened C1 while in care is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Chapter 7. Version 3.1, Regulation Section 87072 (d)(11) Personal Rights, which poses a potential health, safety and personal rights risk to children in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Facility Manager Michael Cabrera.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection August 9, 2022, at 9:22 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection,10 out of Direct Care Staff and 6 out of 6 youth files were reviewed. 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 6 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated August 9, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the care plan, and Child Family Team Meeting records, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Program Supervisor Amy Ahern.

Confidential interviews reported that C1 did not admit to what substances if any, they were under the influence of. Confidential interviews reported that a vape pen was found in C1's room. Confidential interviews reported that C2 sometimes did and didn't comply with searches upon returning from being absent without permission. Confidential interviews reported that C2 never brought back marijuana upon returning from being absent without authorization and consistently adhered to search requests from staff. Confidential interviews reported that C1 never received any marijuana from C2. Confidential interviews reported that C2 denied the allegation of ever supplying C1 with marijuana or other drugs. Confidential interviews reported that it was suspected C2 was bringing drugs into the facility, but the facility never found contraband on C2 during room searches or upon C2's return from being absent without permission. Community Care Licensing also received an allegation that facility staff is not adequately supervising a minor and another resident in the home. Confidential interviews reported that on 05/24/2022, C2 was discovered in the same bed as C1. Confidential interviews reported that C1 and C2 were instructed to get out of bed, but both refused. Confidential interviews reported this was a concern as C2 was an adult and C1 was still a minor. Confidential interviews reported that C2 was placed in this facility as a minor and transitioned into adulthood during their placement. Confidential interviews reported that when C2 was a minor, they received permission from staff to visit C1's room. Confidential interviews reported that C1 and C2 never admitted to being in each other's beds. Confidential interviews reported that if C1 and C2 were discovered in each other's room, staff would redirect them to exit the bedroom. Confidential interviews reported that if C1 or C2 didn't comply, staff would directly supervise them outside the room, with the door open, until they complied. Confidential interviews reported that C1 and C2 were never permitted to be in each other's room, which was against facility rules. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that a resident (C2) in the home supplied another minor (C1) with marijuana and that facility staff are not adequately supervising a minor (C1) and other resident (C2) in the home may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and provided to Residential Coordinator Mayra Medina.

narrative: On March 6, 2023, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Olive Crest - Malena Short-Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) located at Malena Drive, Santa Ana, CA 92705. LPA was met at the facility by Amy Ahern, STRTP Program Supervisor and Mayra Medina, Residential Coordinator. A physical plant inspection and was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a locked file cabinet in the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All three bedrooms contained two twin sized beds. The facility has one full client bathroom and one-half client bathroom. The water temperature in the bathroom one of two was tested at 10: AM and registered at 118.3 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per Residential Coordinator, there are no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator Michael Cabrera is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by Personnel Report (LIC 500). Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. (Continued on lIC 809-C) LPA reviewed five out of five staff files with STRTP Program Supervisor and Residential Coordinator and no deficiency was noted. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office, LPA reviewed four out of four client files during the time of inspection. At 12: PM, during client file review, LPA observed Client #1 is missing initial health examination. Per CCR 80069 (a) - Except for licensees of ARFs, prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client, as specified in Section 80069(c), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the client. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. At 12: PM, during client file review, LPA observed Client #1, #2 and #3 are missing tuberculosis (TB) test result. Per CCR 80068(c)(1) - The medical assessment shall include the following: (1) The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. At 01: PM, during client file review, LPA observed Client #1 and #2 are missing Admission Agreement. Per CCR 80070(b)(6) - Each record must contain information including, but not limited to, the following: (6) A signed copy of the admission agreement specified in Section 80068. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the staff and client interview at a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to STRTP Program Supervisor, Amy Ahern.

allegations that C1 was physically assaulted by other clients and stated that it was C1 who instigated the fight with Child # 2 (C2) by calling C2 a racial slur and by getting in C2's face as well as throwing a rolling pin at C2. Based on confidential information obtained during the course of this investigation, the allegations that Foster Child # 1 (C1) was physically assaulted by other minors in care and that staff did not seek medical attention for Child # 1 (C1), may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. On May 14, 2025, at 3: PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu arrived at Olive Crest main office located at E. Fourth Street, Suite #200, Santa Ana, CA 92705 to conduct an annual inspection of the staff files. LPA met with Maria Orona, Human Resource Manager. Currently Olive Crest Malena is licensed to serve six clients and has a census of six clients. The facility is current with licensing fees. During the inspection LPA reviewed five staff files (S1-S5). Five out of five files contained the required documents including verification of criminal background check clearance, signed acknowledgment of mandated child abuse and neglect reporting requirements, and health screening. On June 23, 2025, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced case management inspection of the facility. LPA Mutialu met with Program Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility and deficiencies were observed. This case management has been opened while LPA conducted a case management regarding information reported to the Department on June 4, 2025, that the facility is not providing activities to the clients. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility and deficiencies were observed. LPA observed three bottles of disinfectant in client room 1 on top of the of headboard of twin bed two accessible to clients in care. LPA observed food that was uncovered, a bowl of onions and stored food in aluminum open and not fully covered and closed exposed on the third shelf of the refrigerator. LPA observed three sticks of used butter not covered, not fully wrapped, and exposed on refrigerator door storage at the top of the door. LPA observed a box of Texas toast not securely closed on freezer shelf and a unwrapped opened snack bar stored on freezer door top shelf. LPA observed two boxes of brown sugar with interior bag open and a package of bay leaves opened with bay leaves coming out. LPA observed bathroom shower, toilet, and sink had lime and dirt build up, LPA observed bathroom floor has dirt build up and reddish mold or rust near the tub behind the laundry basket. ****Continued on Page 2**** LPA observed bathroom dispenser to be overflowing with trash. LPA observed client bedrooms and found carpet stains and build up and dirt build up on twin bed frames. LPA observed marks, dirt, and stains on walls and ceilings throughout the facility. LPA observed kitchen cabinets and shelves have dirt and debris. The Short-Term Residential Therapy Program facility is being cited for violating of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Section 80087(g):Building and Grounds, 80087(a): Building and Grounds, and 80076(a)(14):Food Services. An exit interview was conducted with with Program Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez. A copy of this report and confidential names (LIC811) dated 06/23/2025 was provided to with Program Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez.

On June 23, 2025, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced case management inspection of the facility. LPA Mutialu met with Program Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility A case management has been opened regarding information reported to the Department on June 4, 2025, that the facility is not providing activities to the clients. LPA requested an updated Personnel Roster and a Client Roster. LPA conducted three (3) staff interviews and two (2) client interviews, please refer to Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated June 23, 2025. Further information and interviews are required; therefore, this case management is being extended. The outcome of the investigation will be provided to the Facility Administrator. The facility is reminded not to discuss the ongoing investigation with any interested parties. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Program Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez. A copy of this report will be placed in facility file.

Specifically, it was reported that the Staff allowed minor (C1) to visit their boyfriend's grandmother's home on April 5, 2025, and C1 missed the bus and had no means of returning to the facility due to the facility refusing to pick up C1. The facility reported C1 as an unauthorized absence on April 5, 2025, and did not report unauthorize absence to CSW and PO until April 7, 2025. In addition, facility did not report or submit report to the Department until April 17, 2025, when 10-day notice of complaint was delivered. Confidential interviews revealed consistent information. Confidential interviews entailed that C1 was denied transportation home, marked as an unauthorized absence, and was not reported to CSW, PO, and the Department per requirements. Confidential interviews entailed that C1 was denied transportation home until two days after the facility dropped off C1 at C1's boyfriend's grandmother's home. Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegations that facility staff did not ensure reporting requirements were followed, and facility staff did not ensure transportation was provided to youth in a timely manner are substantiated. The Short Term Residential Treatment Agency is being cited for violations of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), version 6, subchapter 1, section 87061 (b)(4) - Reporting Requirements: (b)The licensee shall ensure that the child's authorized representative is notified no later than the next business day if the following circumstances have occurred without the authorized representative's participation: (4) Any unusual absence or failure of a child to return or inform the facility that they are not returning for a specified period of time, and 87074 (3) - Transportation -Unless other arrangements are specified in the needs and services plan or the Transitional Independent Living Plan for a child or nonminor dependent, a licensee shall ensure transportation is provided to the following: (3)Extracurricular, personal enrichment, cultural, racial, ethnic, and social activities, in accordance with the reasonable and prudent parent standard specified in Section 87067. An exit interview was conducted with Residential Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez. A copy of this report and LIC811 dated 06/04/2025 was provided to Residential Coordinator, Leticia Rodriguez.

narrative: On July 16, 2025, at 03: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the Residential Manager, Michael Cabrera. LPA conducted a walkthrough of the facility. A case management has been opened regarding information reported to the Department that staff (S1,S2, S3) are violating client's personal rights by speaking down to and belittling clients in care. LPA requested an updated Personnel Roster and a Client Roster. LPA conducted five (5) staff interviews and four (4) client interviews, please refer to Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated July 16, 2025. Based on confidential interviews conducted, the Short-Term Residential Therapy Program facility is being cited for a type B violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), version 6, subchapter 1, section 87072(c)(15): Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed with Residential Manager, Michael Cabrera. A copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were provided to the Residential Manager, Michael Cabrera.

This is an amended report from LIC 809 completed on July 23, 2025. Licensing Program Analyst Veronica Whitaker and Latricia Rogers conducted a Joint Case Management Inspection on July 23, 2025, at 9: AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, Pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 6 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, July 23, 2025. The Plan of Operation, including policies and procedures, were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review, including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPAs Veronica Whitaker and Latricia Rogers observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to (Michael Cabrera Residential Manager/Administrator).

On August 11, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced inspection at OLIVE CREST - MALENA Short-Term Residential Therapy Program (STRTP), and met with the Residential Manager, Michael Cabrera. LPA was unable to conduct a record review to further support the statements provided, due to the facility not maintaining accurate financial records for C1. On August 18, 2025, at 10: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu returned to the OLIVE CREST - MALENA Short-Term Residential Therapy Program (STRTP), to follow-up on a Plan of Correction (POC) that has not been received by Community Care Licensing (CCL). LPA Mutialu met with the Residential Manager(RM), Michael Cabrera, and conducted a walkthrough of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. On June 04, 2025, the facility was cited for a type B violation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) standard 87061(b)(4) REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Any unusual absence or failure of a child to return or inform the facility that they are not returning for a specific period of time. When the citation was issued Olive Crest - Malena's RM, stated the POC would be submitted via email by POC due date of 7/18/2025. On 7/18/2025, RM emailed LPA Mutialu requesting a two-week extension which was granted and a new POC due date of 7/29/2025 was given. On 7/29/2025, RM once again requested an extension due to scheduling issues. LPA Mutialu granted the second extension and provided a new POC due date of 8/15/2025. RM was advised at that time that no further extensions would be granted. On 8/15/2025, RM left a voicemail for LPA Mutialu notifying LPA that RM was unable to submit the POC. As of 8/18/2025, CCL has not received the POC. ****Continued on Page 2**** ****CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1**** The facility is receiving Civil Penalties for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six regulation 80054(f.) PENALTIES If any deficiency is not corrected by the date specified in the notice of deficiency, a penalty shall be assessed for each day following that date until compliance has been demonstrated. Civil Penalties are being assessed at $100 a day beginning on 8/15/2025 and will continue to accrue at $100.00 per day until deficiency is corrected. A copy of this report along with the LIC 809D deficiency page, LIC Civil Penalty Assessment and appeal rights were provided to Residential Manager, Michael Cabrera.

narrative: On June 1, 2021, at 1:53PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Adrian Mendez, and Jesus Cervantes, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual inspection. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 4, 2018. LPA's and LPM were met at the facility by Administrator Ethan Alli. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the bathroom which is within the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has two client bathrooms, however only one is used to bathe. The water temperature in the bathroom with the sink was tested at 2:27pm and registered at 113.5 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator Ethan Alli is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Cont. on 809-C The facility employs three Clinical Support Staff, four facility managers and 9 direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee obtained Mental Health (MH) Certification in June 2019. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA. The Accreditation is valid through October 30, 2021. Licensing fee payments are currently past due. Administrator stated that the licensing fees will be paid in full by the end of this week. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Facility procedures related to requesting exceptions. Assembly Bill 388 law enforcement contacts as well as incidents involving emergency interventions. LPA discussed procedures for Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings, including an overview of required Core Services and Supports. LPA also discussed Reasonable and Prudent Parenting Standards, and resident involvement in development of planned activities. Due to time constraints and employee files being housed in their corporate office, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of staff file reviews. Two clients, and three facility staff were interviewed during the inspection. Three clients declined interviews. No deficiencies were found. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Administrator Ethan Alli.

On June 08, 2021, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jesus Cervantes, and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela conducted an unannounced annual continuation inspection from June 01, 2021. Employee files were not located at the facility and required employee files to be reviewed at Olive Crest Headquarters located at E. Fourth Street, Santa Ana, CA 92705. LPA and LPM meet with Madison Mazzone and Denise Griffiths. Five random personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel Files are maintained on-site in a locked cabinet in the Human Resource office. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Client and staff interviews were conducted on 06/01/2021. No deficiencies were noted during time of inspection.

On July 27, 2021 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Anastasia Flores and Valerie Wilson conducted an unannounced case management inspection in regard to the inspection conducted by LPA Flores on July 1, 2021. LPA's met with (STRTP) Olive Crest Treatment Center -Saylor House, Residential Manager, Brittany Bounds During the inspection on 7/01/21, LPA Flores observed the STRTP monthly menu not posted for the clients in care. LPA Flores conducted interviews with five of six clients (C1, C2, C3, C4, C5), two staff and facility Administrator. Confidential interviews disclosed that the menu had not been posted for over a week and was not easily accessible for the staff to print and replace. Based on facility records and confidential interviews, the facility is being issued a citation violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), section 87076 (b) Food Service, the STRTP's menu readily available for clients or staff to view on at least one occasion. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the youth in care. Exit interview conducted, appeal rights and a copy of this report were provided to Brittany Bounds.

Other confidential interview revealed that the staff had recently left the GH and the new staff were not fully trained in the new positions. On 07/01/21, LPA observed the snack drawer to be empty, a lack of perishable foods in the refrigerator and no posted menu. Confidential interviews disclosed that the menu had not been posted for over a week. Interviews with staff revealed that the menu was torn down sometime the week before and that the staff are in the process of creating a grocery shopping list for today. Interview with Administrator (ADM) disclosed that the staff has recently changed and the new Residential Coordinator and Residential Manager have recently been scheduled for training in the next week. ADM informed LPA that quality assurance was in the STRTP last Tuesday and that they come once a month to be sure the STRTP is running up to licensing standards. ADM informed LPA the menu for July is in the process of being created and will be posted by end of day. Based on confidential interviews, LPA observations and record review the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the department has determined the allegation that the STRTP did not have adequate food supply available for clients is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS), section 87076(c) (1) Food Service, the STRTP did not have fresh perishable foods for a minimum of two days readily available to clients in care on at least one occasion. This poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to the youth in care. An exit interview was completed and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to facility representative.

On August 26, 2021 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Cindy Hamilton conducted an unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection. During the inspection, LPA Hamilton met with Program Supervisor Amy Aherni and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed six client psychotropic records at the facility site at 10: AM. During the review of client records, LPA observed two out of six children Needs and Services Plan were not signed by the child's Social Worker and three out of six were not signed by the client. A LIC Advisory Note was issued. LPA also observed Client #5 (C5) file did not have a JV-223 authorization. LPA will return at a later date to review staff personnel files that are kept at the facility's corporate offices.. LPA began two staff interviews at 1: PM LPA interviewed one of six children currently taking psychotropic medication at 2: PM. One client was at a medical appointment and three others were not available for interviews at the time of inspection. LPA conducted exit interview with Program Supervisor Amy Ahern at 3: PM. LPA provided the Summary Report, LIC 9102TA , LIC 8099-D and Appeal Rights, to Amy Ahern upon completion.

Regarding the allegation that minor was not afforded privacy while in care; specifically that on 9/14/2021, C1 was not given privacy for religious practices and staff excessively checked on C1, confidential interviews revealed that C1's religious practices include burning candles. Confidential interviews revealed on 9/14/2021, C1 was in C1's bedroom with the door closed performing religious practices that included burning a candle and staff was informed by another client that C1 was burning a candle. One confidential interview revealed that staff were checking on C1 excessively that day, while other interviews revealed staff were checking on C1 every 15 minutes as required. Interviews revealed that once S1 learned of the candle being burned, S1 went into C1's bedroom and informed C1 that C1 was not able to burn the candle in the room. Confidential interviews revealed that clients are not allowed to have glass candles or to burn candles in the STRTP for safety reasons. Confidential interviews also revealed that C1 is afforded privacy to practice their religion and is also offered alternate places to perform their religious practices. Regarding the allegations staff did not prevent a minor from self-harming, staff behavior poses as a risk to the minor while in care, and staff did not seek timely medical services for a minor; specifically that S1 minimized C1's threats to self-harm and staff denied C1 mental health care. Confidential interviews and record review revealed that also on 9/14/2021, C1 became upset for not being able to burn a candle in the STRTP and as a result C1 wanted to leave the STRTP on respite care or wanted to be hospitalized. Interviews also revealed C1 wanted to speak with mental health staff and was making self-harming statements. Interviews revealed C1 requested to speak to a mental health staff while others revealed C1 did not. Confidential interviews further revealed that S4 who is a mental health clinician spoke to and evaluated C1 and C1 did not meet the criteria to be hospitalized, as C1 had no plan to self-harm. Interviews revealed C1 then went into C1's bedroom, broke the glass candle jar and cut C1's self with the broken glass. Interviews revealed staff then contacted the sheriff and EMT services. Confidential interviews revealed staff did not do anything until C1 actually self-harmed while other interviews revealed that staff were looking for other options for C1 and also offering C1 other coping mechanisms, however C1 refused. Interviews also revealed no staff were heard belittling or minimizing C1's feelings or threats of harm. (Continued on LIC 9099-C) Regarding the allegation staff did not provide adequate transportation for a minor and staff demonstrated an inappropriate form of discipline, confidential interviews and record review revealed that on 9/5/2021, C1 was on a self-transporting community pass and called the STRTP and requested a ride back to the STRTP. Interviews revealed C1 asked S3 for a ride and S3 denied C1 a ride and ended the call. As a result, C1 found their own ride and arrived back to the STRTP late from the community pass. This interview further revealed that as a consequence, C1 had their community passes taken away for a couple days. Other interviews revealed C1 did call the STRTP while on a community pass after the time C1 was supposed to be back and informed S3 that C1 would be returning to the STRTP, however C1 did not request a ride home. Interviews revealed that C1 was dropped off late near the STRTP by an unknown male who was not authorized to drive C1. This interview revealed C1 had their community passes taken away for 3 days as a consequence. Several interviews revealed that losing community passes is a known consequence of coming home late. Based on confidential interviews and conflicting statements, the allegations C1 was not afforded privacy while in care, staff did not prevent C1 from self-harming, staff behavior poses as a risk to C1 while in care, staff did not seek timely medical services for C1, S3 did not provide adequate transportation for C1, and staff demonstrated inappropriate form of discipline, may have occurred however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Residential Coordinator Naomi Ruiz.

narrative: Confidential interviews reported that C1 returned from being absent without permission and that C1 had left placement two days prior. Confidential interviews reported that staff conducts their room checks on a routine basis. Confidential interviews reported that the facility is not a lockdown facility and that clients can run away by sneaking out of their room windows. Confidential interviews reported that staff would hear these windows opening and attempt to redirect a minor trying to run away. Confidential interviews reported that staff are aware when a client tries to run away from placement and supervises clients regularly. Confidential interviews indicated that staff attempts to prevent clients from leaving the facility without permission by encouraging them to stay at the facility. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews and since we were unable to interview client (C1), the allegation that lack of supervision resulted in a minor (C1) AWOling, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and provided to Residential Manager Priscilla Hernandez.

investigation_findings: 13On February 2, 2023 at 11:25 am , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced inspection to the facility to deliver the findings of the above allegations. LPA met with Aisea Tongilava. LPA Jessica Rubio conducted an inspection of the facility on February 18, 2022 at 03:15 pm and no immediate deficiencies were observed. Three of three (C1, C2, C3) clients, three staff and facility administrator were interviewed. It was reported to Community Care Licensing (CCL) that C1's belongings were not safeguarded and C1 did not feel safe in the home. Confidential staff interviews reported that C1 and C2 got into a verbal argument and began insulting each other. Confidential staff interviews reported that staff separated C1 and C2 and C1 went to the staff office, while C2 was still being verbally aggressive. Confidential interviews reported that C2 and C3 then went into C1's bedroom and began destroying C1's personal belongings. Confidential staff interviews reported that staff was giving C2 and C3 verbal directives but were unsuccessful. Confidential interviews reported that law enforcement was contacted for assistance. narrative: On March 20, 2023, at 09:53 am Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Sarah Lo conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Olive Crest Treatment Centers - Saylor Short-Term Therapeutic Program (STRTP), located at Saylor Terrance, Santa Ana, CA 92705. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP on June 4, 2018. LPA was met at the facility by Residential Manager/Administrator, Priscilla Hernandez and Residential Coordinator, Elvis Radillo for a physical plant inspection. STRTP Program Supervisor, Amy Ahern arrived at 10:15 am to assist the process of inspection as well. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in locked cabinet which is within the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has two client bathrooms, however only one is used to bathe. The water temperature in the bathroom with the sink was tested at 10:24 am and registered at 107.2 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. (Continued on LIC 809-C) Residential Manager/Administrator, Priscilla Hernandez, is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one Clinical Director, one STRTP Program Supervisor, one Program Supervisor, one Residential Manager, one Residential Coordinator eight Youth Care Specialist, two Mental Health Clinician, one Clincial Director and one Rehabilitation Specialist that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee obtained Mental Health (MH) Certification in June 2019 and it is valid through May 20, 2023. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA and the Accreditation is valid through October 31, 2025. LPA reviewed five out of five staff files and below are the deficiencies cited: At 11:50 am, Staff #2 is missing a signed by medical physician the initial health screening and Tuberculosis (TB) test result. Per CCR 80066(a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (11) Tuberculosis test documents as specified in Section 80065(g) and per CCR 80065 (1) Except as specified in (3) below, good physical health shall be verified by a health screening, including a test for tuberculosis, performed by or under the supervision of a physician not more than one year prior to or seven days after employment or licensure and per CCR 80066 (a) The licensee shall ensure that personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. Each personnel record shall contain the following information: (10) A health screening as specified in Section 80065(g). LPA reviewed three out of three client files and below are the deficiencies cited: At 12:26 pm, Client #3 is missing initial medical health screening. Per CCR 80069 (a) Except for licensees of ARFs, prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client, as specified in Section 80069(c), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the client. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of staff and client interviews. A copy of this report and LIC 809-D, appeal rights was given to STRTP Program Supervisor, Amy Ahern.

Licensing Program Manager, Angela King and Licensing Program Analyst Veronica Whitaker conducted a case management inspection on 6/20/23 based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 6/20/23. The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors' meetings related to the facility's incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review, including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Veronica Whitaker and Licensing Program Manager, Angela King, observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Amy Ahern, Program Supervisor/Administrator.

Other confidential interviews reported that S6 discovered C1 was in C2's bedroom during a routine 15-minute bedroom check. Confidential interviews reported that S6 provided verbal directions for C1 to exit C2's bedroom. Confidential interviews reported that while C1 was in C2's bedroom, C1 touched C2 inappropriately on C2's chest and groin area, and then C1 tried to choke C2 by grabbing their neck. Other confidential interviews reported that C2 was the one that inappropriately touched C1's chest and groin area and that it was C2 who grabbed C1's neck. Confidential interviews reported that S6 and S5 were able to separate C1 and C2 from the bedroom successfully. Confidential interviews reported that this incident was documented in a Special Incident Report. Confidential interviews also reported that a Police Report concluded that there was not enough evidence of inappropriate touching by any client (C1-C2). Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that lack of supervision resulting in a child (C1) inappropriately touching another child (C2) in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were explained and given to Residential Manager Elvis Radillo.

narrative: C1 and C2 discharge paperwork disclosed that the removal of C1 and C2 was due to aggressive behaviors, and they no longer reside in the facility. The Department also received an allegation that staff do not prevent children (C1-C2) from bringing drugs, drug paraphernalia, and alcohol into the group home. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 and C2 would leave the facility without permission and would bring back vape pens and alcohol bottles upon return. Confidential interviews stated that staff (S1-S6) would conduct individual searches for C1 and C2 upon return of absence without permission due to a history of C1 and C2 bringing contraband into the facility. The history of substance abuse was noted on the Child and Family Team Meeting (CFT) held for C1 on 05/02/2023 and 07/14/2023 and for C2 on 05/11/2023 and 06/08/2023. Confidential interviews indicated that the individual searches consisted of searching C1 and C2's pockets, shoes, socks, and bags, conducting room searches, and perimeter checks. Confidential interviews disclosed that C1 and C2 would hide vape pens in their undergarment. In addition, confidential interviews revealed that staff (S1-S6) would request C1 and C2 to hand over contraband. If C1 and C2 refused to turn it in, staff would document it, supervise C1 and C2, and confiscate the contraband when it's safe and appropriate. The Department also received an allegation that staff (S4) were involved in a physical altercation with a youth (C2). Confidential interviews corroborated that staff did not engage in a physical altercation with any clients in care. Confidential interviews revealed that C2 was aggressive and physically assaulted S4, while S4 stepped back and S6 verbally redirected C2. Confidential interviews stated that staff use verbal crisis intervention according to their emergency intervention plan, which minimize the aggression C2 had toward S4. S4 removed self to allow C2 to calm down, and S6 continued to use emergency intervention procedures. Per the record review, the facility's early emergency intervention plan is to de-escalate the youth using verbal crisis intervention, identifying consequences, and voluntary self-isolation. Per record review, restraints are used as a last resort if needed. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegation that staff are not providing a safe environment for the child (C4) in care, staff do not prevent children (C1-C2) from bringing drugs, drug paraphernalia and alcohol into the group home, and staff (S4) were involved in a physical altercation with youth (C2) are unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. A copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Residential Manager, Elvis Radillo.

On May 14, 2025, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu made an unannounced visit for the for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Residential Coordinator, Emylee King. Residential Manager. Augustin Rojas and Program Supervisor, Brenda Solano arrived at 10: AM. The Facility is licensed to serve six (6) ambulatory children ages 12-17 years old. Facility also provides services to nonminor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1(c)(1), The current census is five (5) children. The facility is a one story three-bedroom, three-bathroom home. A physical plant inspection was completed with Residential Manager and included the following checks: three client bedrooms, two client bathrooms, one staff bathroom, kitchen, living room, dining area, family room, office, garage, laundry room, and backyard. LPA observed a bottle of Citrusafe barbeque cleaner accessible to clients in the backyard on the left side of patio door located next to a bag of charcoals. LPA observed laundry detergent in unlocked laundry room. The facility is receiving a type A citation for hazardous chemicals/cleansers accessible to clients. LPA observed items missing in the first aid kit including tweezers. Facility is receiving a type B citation. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. ****Continued on Page 2***** Facility grounds are free of debris. LPA reminded Residential Manager, Augustin Rojas facility grounds shall be clean and in good repair at all times. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. LPA observed client 1 and 3 bedroom twin beds are less than 2 feet apart and does not allow for easy passage. Facility is receiving a type B violation for bedrooms not allowing easy passage. The facility has two client bathrooms. The water temperature was tested in one bathroom and measired the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. All client files are stored and maintained on a secure internet database. LPA reviewed five client files to ensure clients had all required documents per Title 22. LPA reviewed client client medication records. LPA conducted two staff interviews and two client interviews. The Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program is accredited through Council on Accreditation valid through October 31, Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division six, regulation 80087(g): Buildings and Grounds, 80075(g)(1)(F):Healt-Related Services, and 87087(b)(2):Building and Grounds. Due to time constraints staff records located at the main office LPA will visit main office at a later time to review staff records and complete inspection. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The licensing fee payments are current. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC811 (confidential names), and appeal rights were discussed and provide to Residential Coordinator. Emylee King. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

investigation_findings: 13On October 23, 2020, at 2:45PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Ann Valenzuela conducted a tele-inspection due to COVID19, with David Owens, Administrator, to deliver and discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. On May 11, 2020, LPA initiated the above complaint investigation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed four of six Clients (C2, C4, C5, C6), please refer to confidential names list (LIC 811). LPA also interviewed four of four staff (S1, S2, S3, S4). On April 16, 2020, the Department received an allegation that S1 and S3 were informed about concerns for C1's safety at the facility and failed to inform other staff resulting in C1 being "jumped" by C2, C3, and C4. However, C1 and C3 were unable to be interviewed therefore all relevant parties were not able to be interviewed regarding the allegation. There were also no witnesses to S1 and S3 being informed of C1's safety concerns. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: revealed that staff conducted checks on all clients every 15 minutes and would document their observations. narrative: On June 29, 2021, at 3:45PM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's) Adrian Mendez and Jesus Cervantes, conducted an unannounced Required Annual inspection of the facility. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 4, 2018. LPA's were met at the facility by Youth Care Specialists Andrew Bertalan, and Aisea Tongilavea, and Program Supervisor Amy Ahern. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment/toys/books/games were observed for children's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Three bedrooms contained two twin beds. The facility has two bathrooms. The water temperature in one of the client bathrooms was tested at 4:03pm and registered at 119.3 degrees which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Cont. on 809-C The facility employs three Clinical Support Staff, four facility managers and seven direct care staff that are used in accordance with regulatory requirements. Licensee obtained Mental Health (MH) Certification in June 2019. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation through COA. The Accreditation is valid through October 30, 2021. All the client files are stored and locked in the file cabinet in the staff office. LPA's reviewed a sample of four client's files during the time of inspection. No deficiencies were found. Due to time constraints and employee files being housed in their corporate office, LPA will return to the facility to conduct a continuation of staff file reviews and staff and client interviews. No deficiencies were found. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Program Supervisor Amy Ahern.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jessica Rubio arrived at Olive Crest Treatment Center - Wheeler (STRTP) to discuss records reviewed. LPA contacted Residential Manager David Owens via telephone. Mr Owens provided verbal authorization to deliver this report to Youth Care Specialist Aisea Tongilava. LPA reviewed April 2020 and May Medication Administration Record (MAR) log for C1 and discovered there were entries of medication refusals for C1's Fluoxetine recorded on 4/16/2020, 5/10/2020, and 5/24/2020. LPA reviewed the Special Incident Reports (SIR) that STRTP submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) during that time and no SIRs were submitted to CCL documenting C1 refused medication on those dates. LPA also discovered there was a blank entry on the MAR for 4/16/2020 for Melatonin. After LPA reviewed records it was determined that C1 was absent without leave (awol) at the time medication would have been administered however, there was no mention of the missed dose of medication written in the SIR reporting the awol nor was there another SIR submitted for the missed dose. The facility is being cited for Title General Regulation Section 80061 (b) (1) (E) Reporting Requirements. Based on record review the facility did not ensure C1's medication refusals or missed dose of medication due to awol were reported to CCL which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to clients in care. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Youth Care Specialist Aisea Tongilava.

A confidential interview revealed staff did not care if C1 took C1's medication and also that S1 would not offer C1 their medication due to C1 refusing medication often. That same interview revealed that C1 asked S1 to take C1's medication however S1 did not provide it due to C1 refusing medication often. Other confidential interviews revealed there were no known issues with S1 withholding or not offering C1 medication. Record review revealed C1 was placed in the STRTP from 3/2/2020 - 5/27/2020 and was prescribed three different medications: Melatonin, Fluoxetine and Adderall. Record review indicated C1 started Melatonin and Fluoxetine on 4/8/2020 and Adderall on 5/16/2020. One confidential interview revealed it was believed there had been an issue with staff not obtaining C1's medication around April or May 2020 however, no additional details could be provided. Another confidential witness interview revealed blank entries on clients' MAR logs were often observed and appeared medication had not been provided to some clients, however, no observations were recalled regarding C1's MAR entries specifically. Other confidential interview revealed there was a lapse from when C1's Adderall was prescribed to when it was initially filled, however there were no missed doses once C1 began the medication. Additionally, a confidential interview and record review revealed that C1's Adderall was not started at the same time as the other medications due to C1 not being on any medication for several months prior. Record review corroborated and stated C1's treatment plan indicated re-initiating the medication as "staggered and gradual" to see how C1 adjusted to and was affected by the medication. Furthermore, CSW1 had no concerns of staff withholding medication from C1. At one point in April 2020, CSW2 was made aware by C1 that C1 was not yet receiving Adderall, however, CSW2 explained to C1 that it was likely due to the psychotropic medication evaluation process and C1's current assessment. Based on record review and conflicting statements, the allegation staff did not ensure minor received medications may have occurred however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC 811 and appeal rights were provided to Youth Care Specialist Aisea Tongilava.

Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios and Licensing Program Manager Angela King conducted a case management inspection July 27, 2022 at 9:05 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection 9 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 5 out of Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated July 27, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the care plan, and Child Family Team Meeting records, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Program Supervisor Amy Ahern.

On April 17, 2023, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo, conducted an unannounced annual inspection of the facility. The facility converted from a Group Home to STRTP (Short Term Therapeutic Program) on June 4, 2018. LPA was met at the facility by Residential Coordinator, Eriyan Odom and at 11: AM Administrator/Residential Manager, David Owens arrived at the facility and continued with the annual inspection. LPA began a physical plant inspection at 10: AM and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean, free of debris and hazards free. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sports equipment, books, games were observed for client's recreation time. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Medications are locked and centrally stored in the staff office inside the staff restroom. Medication records were reviewed and observed to be completed with dates and staff initials on dispensing records. Chemicals/poisons are locked in a closet in the hallway and sharp objects are locked and stored in the staff office inside the staff restroom. First Aid Kits are also stored in the staff office and are complete. Contraceptives are available in the staff office and is available to be held individually by clients. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. Three bedrooms contained two twin beds. The facility has one bathroom for the client to use. The hot water in the client's bathroom was deemed safe and measured between 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit. (Continued on LIC 809-C). Per Residential Manager, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator/Residential Manager, David Owens is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs one facility manager, five direct care staff, and two therapists. Licensee has obtained National Accreditation, The Accreditation is valid through October 31, 2025. Annual Fees are current. Licensee has mental health approval from May 20, 2022, until May 20, 2023. LPA reviewed two out of two client files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Client files are maintained in a locked cabinet inside staff office (See Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated April 17, 2023) were also completed. Per review, Client 2 is missing the initial medical assessment, per CCR 80069(a) Except for licensees of ARFs, prior to or within 30 calendar days following the acceptance of a client, the licensee shall obtain a written medical assessment of the client, as specified in Section 80069(c), which enables the licensee to determine his/her ability to provide necessary health related services to the client. The assessment shall be used in developing the Needs and Services Plan. Per review, Client 1 and Client 2 is missing the TB test result, per CCR 80069(c)(1) The medical assessment shall include the following: The results of an examination for communicable tuberculosis and other contagious/infectious diseases. LPA reviewed five personnel files to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title Regulations. Personnel files are maintained off-site in a locked cabinet in staff corporate office in Santa Ana, and the Administrator brought over the files and were available for review. CPR/First Aid Certificates were observed and were valid. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. No deficiencies were found during this inspection. LPA interviewed two staffs and one client. The client interviewed deemed that their needs were being met and they feel safe and secure in the facility. Staffs and client have no issues or concerns regarding the facility. Based upon the inspection of facility records and interviews with staff and clients, the Licensee appears to be meeting CFT and Core Services/Supports requirements. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was discussed and will be provided to Administrator/Residential Manager, David Owens.

narrative: On April 28, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu made an unannounced visit for the for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. LPA met with Residential Manager, Ruta Peterson. The Facility is licensed to serve six (6) ambulatory children ages 12-17 years old. Facility also provides services to nonminor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1(c)(1), The current census is five (5) children. The facility is a one story three-bedroom, two-bathroom home. A physical plant inspection was completed with Residential Manager and included the following checks: three client bedrooms, one client bathroom, one staff bathroom, kitchen, living room, dining area, family room, office, garage, and backyard. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Currently there a no clients in care taking medications at this time. Clients' medications are inaccessible and stored in medication room when clients in care are taking medication. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Facility carbon monoxide detectors were tested and observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced on 11/15/2024. Fire clearance inspection is to be completed today 04/28/25. ****Continued on Page 2***** Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has one client bathroom. . LPA conducted two staff interviews and one client interview. Two of the three clients home refused interview or were not available to interview. The Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program is accredited through Council on Accreditation valid through October 31, No deficiencies cited. Due to time constraints and client/staff records located at the main office LPA will visit main office on another day to review staff records and complete inspection. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. The licensing fee payments are current. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, LIC811 (confidential names), and appeal rights were discussed and provide to Ruta Peterson. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.
