On May 15,2025, at 9:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz conducted an unannounced case management inspection of the facility. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility with Youth Care Specialist, Christopher Huerta while waiting for Residential Manager to arrive. LPA observed the following deficiencies during the tour: broken kitchen cabinet, broken front door panel, rust/damage to water dispenser on fridge, and patch on bedroom wall that needs to be painted. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an Incident Report (IR) follow up visit. LPA Munoz met with Residential Manager (RM), Ruta Peterson. Community Care Licensing (CCL) became aware of an incident that occurred on 04/30/25 in which S1 noticed items from a locked storage closet were taken out of the cabinet. S1 began to ask other staff if they knew who had taken out the property. S1 then observed client (C1) take keys out of their pocket that looked like the facility keys to the locked storage cabinets in the garage. C1 refused to tell S1 how they got the key to storage room. C1 confirmed that they had taken out the property from locked cabinet earlier when C1 was alone in garage because they wanted their confiscated property. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was able to enter unlocked staff office unsupervised and gained access to facility storage keys. Interviews also confirmed that the box where the facility keys are stored was unlocked inside the staff office that C1 was able to access. The STRTP facility is being cited for violation of Title Division Chapter Article Buildings and Grounds 80087 (g), Title 22, Division Chapter 1, Article 07. Physical Environment: 80087(a) Buildings and Grounds and Interim Licensing Standards version 5, Article 7, Continuing Requirements: 87072(c)(21) Personal Rights. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was provided to RM.

On May 15, 2025, at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Stefanie Mutialu continued the unannounced annual inspection, which was started on April 28 ,2025. LPA reviewed scanned client records received by Program Supervisor, Brenda Solana. LPA reviewed five client (C1-C5) files. Five out of five client records reviewed had required documents including admission agreements, signed personal rights, medical/dental exam, immunization records, medical consent forms, an initial and updated needs and services plan on file, and met the minimum requirements per Interim Licensing Standards. During the time of inspection on April 28, 2025, LPA requested Emergency Disaster Drill Log from Resident Manager, Ruta Peterson. Per Residential Manager, they do not have access to Emergency Disaster Drill Log as it is on the secured database, and they do not have access to secure database to obtain Emergency Disaster Drill Log. LPA requested Emergency Disaster Drill Log from Program Director, Grace Coffman and Program Supervisor, Brenda Solana. LPA did not receive Emergency Disaster Drill Log. As a result, the facility is receiving a type B citation. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division six, regulation 1565(c): Other Provisions. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, Confidential Names List (LIC811), and appeal rights were discussed and emailed to Program Director, Grace Coffman. A signed copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

On July 29, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz and Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the Residential Coordinator, Roberto Elloquim. LPAs conducted a walkthrough of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a case management regarding facility's failure to correct plan of correction (POC). LPAs requested an updated Personnel Roster and a Client Roster. LPAs conducted one staff (S1) interview, please refer to Confidential Names List (LIC 811) dated July 29, 2025. On May 15, 2025, LPA Munoz conducted a case management inspection, and the facility was not in compliance. The facility received a type B violation, 87072(c)(21) Personal Rights with a POC of 06/16/2025. As of this date, the facility has not submitted POC, LPA Munoz has made several attempts to contact Residential Supervisor, Ruta Peterson, and has not received a response. Therefore, the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program failed to correct and Civil Penalties of $600 ($ X 6 days) will be assessed. An exit interview was conducted with Residential Supervisor, Ruta Peterson. A copy of this report and confidential names (LIC811) dated 7/29/2025, and appeal rights was provided to Residential Supervisor, Ruta Peterson.

On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nicole Moua conducted a pre-arranged pre-licensing tele-inspection as a result of Covid-19 related restrictions. The facility listed above submitted an application to transition the currently licensed group home facility to a Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) on 12/30/2016. The application, Plan of Operation and Program statement have been reviewed and approved. There are currently no residents living in the facility due to renovations. Completion date is approximated at two weeks. This tele-inspection was conducted with Administrator Jess Hernandez and included observation of the following: Yard Clean and free of debris or observable hazards Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials Chemicals stored in a locked cabinet First aid kit complete, including manual Adequate storage space observed Individual beds in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens in good repair. Facility has three client bedrooms, capable of double occupancy, all located on one single level. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings Adequate food storage space observed. Dining room equipped with table and chairs accommodating all clients Facility has two full restrooms in this home, all are operable All smoke detectors in proper working order Carbon monoxide detector(s) observed Fire extinguishers properly charged Adequate supply of additional bedding and linens observed Continued on 809-C Continued from Facility maintains a current fire clearance Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility The following items were reviewed by LPA LIC 500 reviewed to ensure appropriate staffing ratios, including Administrator, Social Work personnel, and Direct Care staff Administrators will be present on-site a minimum of 20 hours per week All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are retained at the corporate office and will be available to the department for review upon request. Facility procedures for 30-day updates of Needs and Services Facility is to ensure all clients considered for future placement have been assessed as meeting placement eligibility requirements. Facility has process in place to contact authorized representatives to ensure assessment for clients' continued placement Facility is to update all client admission agreements to reflect the STRTP rate Facility to obtain Mental Health Program Approval within 12 months of effective date of licensure, will keep the department updated as to MHPA status, and will provide appropriate documentation to the department upon approval On this date, Open Line is recommended for licensure on a provisional basis. License will expire one year from effective date. Facility will be licensed for a capacity of six ambulatory children, ages 13-17 years, and ambulatory non-minor dependents, ages 18-19 years.

On 11/17/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility and met with the Orion Vasilas, Administrator (Admin) regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing on November 10, 2022. The SIR was regarding the AWOL (Absence Without Official Leave) of Youths #1, #2, and #3 (see confidential name list LIC 811 dated 11/17/22) On 11/08/2022 the Youth #1 that resides at the Woodcliff Facility (lic. 455001037) reported that when he, Youth #3, and Youth #2 were AWOL from the facility, that Youth #2 was trading sexual favors to an adult for drugs, alcohol and a place to stay. Youth #1 also reported that he believes that Youth #3 may have also been involved. A Suspected Child Abuse Claim was filed, the police were notified, and SIR was submitted. Youth #2 likes to AWOL a lot. He is in a very negative stated right now in his mind. And has been for the last year. He has just been wanting to go home so he has been having behavior issues. LPA asked Admin was happened before the youth AWOL'd from the facility. Admin reported; On Oct 28, Youth #1 had a court date and thought he was going to be released to his family member, but that did not happen. The family member is not ready for Youth #1 to come home just yet. The judge also encouraged the social worker to find a lower level of care for him, but Youth #1 does not want to go anywhere except with grandma. The other two (2) youth we don't have any issues with usually. This was their first time leaving the facility without permission. On 11/05/2022 all three (3) youths left the facility. When they returned Youth #1 told me that Youth #2 was doing sexual favors for vape pens, marijuana, and a place to sleep. I asked Youth #3 what happened while they were gone and he denied anything had happened. I contacted Child Protective Service Worker (CPS) , then Law Enforcement (LE). Youth #1 should me where they were staying and I let LE know. The next day LE went to the apartment and picked up Youth #2 and Youth #3 and brought them back to the facility. They were then interviewed by LE. None of the youth has disclosed any other information to me. continued on 809-C continued form We have a Case Manager at the Facility that will be working with the youth. They are also encouraged to come to us to talk if they need to as well as their counselors. We are going to move Youth #2 to another facility to see if that alleviates him and the other two (2) youth from leaving. We thought maybe the change of environment would be good for Youth #2 to help turn things around. The other two (2) youths we have had no issues leaving without permission, so moving Youth #2 may help them not leave. Facility took appropriate actions therefore no citations will be issued. Based on the information obtained through interview, there is no evidence of any Interim Licensing Violations. There were no deficiencies cited at this time, and a copy of this report was given to the facility representative.

Three clients reported a staff member solicited nude photos from one client who was Absent Without Leave (AWOL) from the facility. The facility was informed of the alleged solicitation, and promptly terminated the staff, who was already on leave for other unprofessional conduct. In addition to soliciting nude photos, the clients reported the staff member allowed the clients to use the staff member's cell phone to access social media, which went against facility policy. The staff member also visited a client while the client was AWOL, brought the client food, and took the client to the staff member's home. Per facility administration, the staff member did not notify the facility of being in contact with the AWOL youth, nor was the probation officer contacted regarding the client's location. Based on the preponderance of evidence that was met through interviews, observation, and record review, the allegation of: Staff solicited pornographic images from client is therefore SUBSTANTIATED. Facility is issued one citation from Interim Licensing Standards, Article 06. Section 87072 (C )(11): Personal Rights: (c) The licensee shall ensure that each child... is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code Section 16001.9, as applicable. In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights: 11) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature..." A signed copy of this LIC-9099, LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D were provided to the facility. Appeal Rights were given. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: On 6/15/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) met with Tyson Poso for a post licensing inspection. As Open Line recently received their MHPA to transition from Group to an STRTP. Open Line has been licensed since 4/25/2008. Open Line currently has two houses the Oaks and Woodcliff house. Each facility is licenses for 6 youth. LPA inspected the facility inside and outside. The facility had functioning smoke and carbon monoxide detectors. Water temperature was within the required limits. The backyard was free and clear of debris and had a basketball hoop for clients to use. The bedroom were all set up with beds, dressers and LPA observed clothing for each client, personal belongings and each had their own hygiene kits locked in the office for use. All beds had clean linens, blankets and pillows. The kitchen area had the menu posted for breakfast, lunch dinner and snack times. The kitchen was clean and organized. The licenses was posted in the office area along with the persona rights. All medication were locked in the offices in a locking file cabinet by room, with each individual you having their own binder with meds which also contained the MARS report. The MAR reports were current. No deficiencies were observed. No citation given. A copy of this report was electronically sent at the time of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Misty Valencia and Mindy Pope arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a case management inspection following a record review. LPA met with Leanna Montgomery, Facility Manager. LPA McKinley conducted the record review. Three Serious Incident Reports (SIR's) dated 8/3/2023, 8/7/2023, and 8/13/2023 were completed by the facility and sent to LPA per LPA's request on 11/16/23. On review, these SIR's were not submitted to the Department previously. Law enforcement contact was indicated on the report dated 8/7/23, but the required LIC-624 law enforcement report was not completed. The law enforcement report submitted to the Department by local police has a date of 8/8/23, whereas the facility SIR has a date of 8/7/23. Facility is cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Section 80061(a,b) Reporting Requirements (a) Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department, including, but not limited to, those specified in this section. (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility...a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. A signed copy of this LIC 809 and LIC 809D were provided to the facility. Appeal rights provided.

Two Serious Incident Reports were documented by the facility, regarding two separate incidents within one week. One incident report documented an assaultive altercation between three clients. Staff attempted to de-escalate the clients using Emergency Intervention procedures. Law enforcement was called and responded. The events outlined in the law enforcement report correspond to the events in the report from the facility. The second Serious Incident Report documented verbally inappropriate behavior by one client toward another client. The staff responded to the clients by providing counsel, support, and additional supervision. Confidential interviews determined inconsistent information regarding the level of staff supervision during these two incidents. Based on LPA's observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: On this date LPA Kellie McKinley and IB investigator Drew Mitchell arrived at the Facility for an annual inspection of the physical plant.On this date LPA Kellie McKinley and IB investigator Drew Mitchell arrived at the Facility for an annual inspection of the physical plant. On 10/28/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Kim McCarty, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required, two year Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 1/18/24. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with three client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and one locked staff office. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. The backyard was free from hazards, safely fenced, with a basketball hoop accessible to clients. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility has one client bathroom and one staff bathroom. All were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was stocked with the required items.. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the garage. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked file cabinet in the locked staff office. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has 6 clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 6. Staff to client ratio is 2:6 during the day with an additional facility manager and several hours weekly from the MHRS staff as well. LPA reviewed 3 staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA interviewed 2 staff on site. LPA interviewed 1 client on site. LPA will continue the annual inspection on 10/29/24.

On 10/29/ LPA continued the annual inspection for the Oak house. LPA reviewed 3 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans, signed by clients and staff, and updated Needs and Service plans every 30 days. The facility had evidence of attempting to obtain signatures from placing agencies. Needs and Service Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. 1 of 3 clients were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current JV-220's on file. 1 of 3 take psychotropic medication with the parent maintaining the JV- 220 and has medical rights. LPA interviewed 1 clients. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809 report was provided to the Rachel Underwood. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: An incident report was submitted to the Department indicating a staff member had been horseplaying with a client. The staff member meant to tap the client on the arm with a rubber ruler, but the ruler instead made contact with the side of the client's face. The staff apologized to the client. Interviews and documentation support that the incident was accidental on staff's part. No medical treatment was necessary for the client. The facility immediately responded by suspending, then terminating, the staff. The client was provided with additional staff support after the incident. Based on LPA's interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. No citation issued due to prompt response by the facility with corrective action already completed. A signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and appeal rights were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of the Appeal right was given.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores conducted a virtual case management inspection in accordance to COVID-19 precautions to follow up on an incident that occurred on 09/07/2020 which was reported by the agency. The incident reported that foster child (FC)1 (see confidential names list titled 10/08/2020) disclosed to staff that FC2 had been touching him inappropriately at night. Agency immediately moved youth into a different room and the following day moved FC2 to a different home. Staff interviewed both children and both youth stated the "touching" was consensual. FC2 was relocated permanently to a different home for health and safety reasons. LPA interviewed FC1 and FC2 via telephone; statements were inconsistent and both youth had a different version of what had happened. LPA interviewed staff and collected documentation pertaining to the incident. Documentation included nightly bed check records, staff statements, and incident reports. From the provided documentation and interviews, staff acted appropriately. No regulations are being cited. LPA advised Administrator that incident reports should be more detailed and provide more information.

This report is continued from the attached LIC9099. On 10/30/2020, LPA Chad Cabigon contacted Bryce Inman, Facility Manager (S1) who stated that on 9/30/2020 he transported C1 home from school who was sitting in the back seat of the vehicle. S1 reported that C1 unbuckled his seatbelt and sat on the car's back window so that a good part of C1's body was out of the car while the car was moving. S1 stated he saw this out of the corner of his eye; this was on a two-lane road and "there basically was no shoulder." S1 said it was important for him to stop the car anyway especially if people behind were going to see that a youth was hanging out of a car. LPA Cabigon asked how quickly S1 stopped the car after noticing that C1 was hanging out of the window and S1 stated, "Seconds." LPA Cabigon also contacted C1 who recalled the incident and reported that S1 told him this was "unsafe transportation." C1 said he proceeded to "throw [his] body out the window" and sat on the windowsill. C1 reported that S1 told him that he would have to call the facility supervisor if C1 persisted to leave his seatbelt off, and at that point C1 complied. C1 added that he usually does not put his seatbelt on because he does not like having a strap over his chest. LPA Cabigon asked if there was anything S1 could have done to prevent C1 from taking his seatbelt off or from positioning his body out of the moving vehicle; C1 replied, "Not really because it was kind of my fault." On 2/10/2021, LPA Hillary Hall contacted C2 (see LIC Confidential Names List dated 10/30/20) and asked if he has seen clients take off their seatbelts during transport. C2 replied, "Yes, sometimes. The staff just keep going." LPA Deaton reviewed S1's write-up for C1 regarding the unsafe behavior during transportation. There is no Serious Incident Report on file with CCLD regarding this incident. The facility has no documented history of C1 displaying unsafe behaviors during transport. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. This report will be sent to the facility via email with a return/read receipt requested. An Advisory Note for Best Practices has been attached to this LIC9099 regarding ILS Section 87065.5(g) Direct Care Staff/Child Ratios.

narrative: This report is continued from the attached LIC9099. On 2/10/2021, LPA Hillary Hall contacted C2 (see LIC Confidential Names List dated 10/30/20) who said staff are not able to help him with schoolwork because they are too busy. On 2/11/2021, LPA Deaton contacted Debi Nunez, Administrator (S4) who stated the facility was "getting a lot of refusals" from C1 adding that he would tell staff he was not ready or did not want to participate when it came to distance learning. S4 said sometimes C1 would put his head down on the desk and would require a lot of prompting. S4 said the facility has no record of communications or requests to hold a Child & Family Team (CFT) Meeting to address C1's education with CSW1. LPA Deaton reviewed C1's Needs and Services Plan (NSP) dated 9/7/2020: C1 is experiencing a rating of 5 out of 10 for his schooling as shown by a history of truancy and poor grades - C1 will attend school in person, or online each school day; complete the assigned schoolwork each day; and ask for help, as needed. LPA Deaton reviewed the County Communications Log provided by CSW1 that documented on 9/8/20, CSW1 spoke with Tyson Poso, Administrator (S3) regarding concerns for C1's participation in online learning. S3 said C1 is now working in the administration building so that he can be fully supervised. LPA Deaton reviewed the School Attendance Record for C1 and found the following incidents that were not communicated to CSW1 by the facility: 9/9/20 - Distance Learning (DL) Unexcused Absence; 9/14/20 - (DL) Logged in at 9:35am; 9/15/20 - (DL) Logged in at 9am; 9/16/20 - (DL) Unexcused Absence, facility staff "...were unaware he was not logged into class;" 9/17/20 - C1 arrived to the school without his computer and other school supplies, staff was asked to return with the supplies, staff then left and circled the block and dropped C1 off again without the supplies; 9/21/20 - Logged in late, C1 told facility staff there was no school; 9/22/20 - Logged in late, staff reported that C1 was on his way to their office to get online; 9/28/20 - absent, staff "could not give us the reason for his absence;" 10/2/20 - Unexcused Absence; 10/5/20 - Unexcused Absence, facility said they were having issues with him at home [no Incident Report on file with CCLD]. LPA Deaton reviewed an SIR dated 9/14/20 that documented C1 was caught smoking marijuana; no corresponding County notification on file. Based on LPAs interviews which were conducted and record reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Title Section 80061(f) and Interim Licensing Standards (ILS Version 3.1) Section 87061(d), Section 87078(b), and Section 87078(c) are being cited on the attached LIC9099-D pages. This report will be sent to the facility via email with a return/read receipt requested. [Title Section Reporting Requirements (f) The items specified in (b)(1)(A) through (H) above shall also be reported to the client's authorized representative; ILS Section 87061(d) Reporting Requirements - The licensee shall ensure that the child's authorized representative is notified if the child is not...regularly attending school; ILS 87078(b) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision - The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's...needs and services plan; ILS 87078(c) Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision - The licensee shall ensure each child's attendance at an educational program...]

On 9/28/2021, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA's), Kellie McKinley and Stefanie Whitlow, met with Mike Hernandez for an annual inspection. LPA, McKinley toured through the facility with administrator, Mike Hernandez. LPA observed the kitchen with 5-7 days of canned and dry goods.The refrigerator had 2-4 days of fresh foods and another staff member, Helen, who allowed access to LPA when she arrived, unloaded flats of fresh fruits and veggies from her car while LPA was present. LPA observed the kitchen to be clean with no dishes in the sink. LPA observed living space to have couches, TV, and a TV cabinet, which contained movies on a shelf. LPA observed the bedroom with clothing, clean bed linens, pillows, blankets and comforters on the beds. Each bedroom had a dresser unit for each child. LPA observed the bathroom to be clean with hot running water and a functioning toilet. Water was tested to be within the temperature limits. LPA observed a locked office, which housed cleaning supplies, medications in a locked cabinet and the clients personal care bins with lids. LPA asked Mike to test the carbon monoxide and smoke alarms. LPA observed both in working order. LPA asked where chemicals and pesticide are kept. Mike stated they have a pesticide company and do not keep them at the facility. LPA observed the back yard area with a BBQ area which is used from time to time to BBQ for the clients in care. LPA observed new fence posts at various areas around the backyard area. LPA observed a covered patio area and a punching bag in good condition off to the side on a heavy duty stand. LPA observed the facility vehicle parked in the front driveway. Seat belts were in functioning order. No log was observed in the vehicle, but Mike stated the log was inside for updating information. LPA observed the fabric on the passenger side seat back was almost completely torn off. LPA advised Mike to obtain seat covers. LPA observed front yard with freshly mowed lawn. No citations were give at the time of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted with administrator, Deb Nunes, who signed LIC 809. A copy of this report was emailed to the facility administrator at the time of the inspection.

An unannounced SB Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall on 05/04/2022 at 9am. During the inspection, LPA Hall met with Tyson Poso, Administrator at the main office to review records. LPA Hall met with Mike Hernandez, Administrator, to inspect the facility inside and out. LPA Hall observed the facility to be clean and organized. The medication cabinet was locked. Appropriate staff ratio was maintained. LPA Hall conducted a medication count at the facility with Administrator Hernandez. LPA reviewed 4 clients records between 9am-11am. LPA reviewed 3 staff files between 11-12pm. Staff files had sufficient medication training. LPA interviewed 3 staff on site. LPA interviewed 3 clients who currently take psychotropic medication. No concerns were reported during the client interviews. (The fourth client was not at the facility due to a Child and Family Team Meeting). One deficiency was observed and cited from the STRTP Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87068.3: Modifications to The Needs and Services Plan (a) The needs and services plan specified in Section 87068.2 shall be updated at least every 30 days. *During the review of client records, LPA Hall observed 3 out of 4 clients did not have a current Needs and Service Plan, written in the previous 30 days. One deficiency was observed and cited from STRTP ILS Section 87070(a)(13): (a)In addition to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80070, the following shall apply: (13) The following information...shall be obtained and maintained in the child's record: Documentation of all mental health services received by a child. *During review of the client's records, LPA Hall observed 4 out of 4 clients records were missing current information regarding specific mental services provided to clients. Continued on 809C Continued from LPA conducted an exit interview with Amy Claxton, Administrator. LPA provided a signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC-809D Report to the Administrator via email. Appeal rights were provided.

The bedroom were all set up with beds, dressers and LPA observed clothing for each client, personal belongings and each had their own hygiene kits locked in the office for use. narrative: On January 18, 2024 at 9:00 a.m, LPA's Kellie McKinley and Mindy Pope arrived for an unannounced annual inspection. Fire Extinguisher was observed to be current and update, with the last inspection taking place 12/12/23. The license was posted in the office area along with the personal rights. LPA's conducted three main office staff interviews and two client interviews. LPA's reviewed five staff files and five client files and found them the be orderly and regulation compliant. LPA McKinley conducted a post licensing visit on 6/16/23 following the transition of Open Line from Group Home care to STRTP. Open LIne received their mental health license on 6/19/23. Licensing printed new facility licenses for Woodcliff and Oaks facilities. Woodcliff home has five bedrooms, one bedroom is utilized as an office and two baths residences. Oaks has a three bedrooms and two bathrooms and the den is utilized as an office. Both homes were observed to be clean, appropriately furnished and regulation compliant Medications are secured in a dual locking system, as the office is locked and the medication is locked in another separate container. Each individual client has their own separate medication binder with their MARS and they were observed to be up to date. No deficiencies were observed. TA given advising the need to change their program statement (tiers/levels) to reflect trauma informed care practice and an individualized approach. A copy of this report was electronically sent at the time of the inspection.

On 7/11/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived for an unannounced visit to conduct a case management for the purpose of obtaining additional background on an SIR received on 7/06/24. LPA requested relevant records for the two clients involved including: Needs and services, placement roster, case notes, SIR's. Based on interviews and documentation LPA determined sexualized behavior was stemming from one youth who was instigating the behaviors with other youth. There was no indication lack of supervision was the reason for the increase in the client's behaviors. The youth was removed from the program and sexualized behaviors have decreased since the client's removal. Facility inspection determined no violations were observed. A signed copy of this LIC 809 was provided to the facility. No citations were issued at this time.

On 7/16/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley met with COO for a scheduled appointment regarding a county issue. Concern's noted by COO: Shasta County is with holding funds for PT (presumptive transfer) clients placed in the Open line facilities. The county neglected to support the OL program with assistance in getting the EHR system up and running properly and claiming OL neglected their responsibility to put required documentation into the system in a timely manner. The county gave OL access to the EHR system month after the certification, with no instruction on how to document. The county is responsible for entering in the client name into the EHR system, yet neglected to do so. A full report in on file with CCLD. COO was referred to the Stephen Conn with DHCS for the Mental Health Certification for further assistance with this issue.

Based on LPA's observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. narrative: On this date LPA Kellie McKinley and IB investigator Drew Mitchell arrived at the Facility for an annual inspection of the physical plant. On 10/28/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kellie McKinley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Kim McCarty, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a required, two year Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 1/18/24. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is a home like setting, with three client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and one locked staff office. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. The backyard was free from hazards, safely fenced, with a basketball hoop accessible to clients. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility has one client bathroom and one staff bathroom. All were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was stocked with the required items.. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the garage. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked file cabinet in the locked staff office. The facility has no outstanding fees. The facility currently has 6 clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 6. Staff to client ratio is 2:6 during the day with an additional facility manager and several hours weekly from the MHRS staff as well. LPA reviewed 3 staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA attempted an interview with 1 client on site. LPA will continue on 10/29/24 to complete the annual inspection.

LPA McKinley continued the annual inspection for Woodcliff house on 10/29/24. LPA reviewed 3 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans, signed by clients and staff, and updated Needs and Service plans every 30 days. The facility had evidence of attempting to obtain signatures from placing agencies. Needs and Service Plans detailed adequate supportive services the facility offers to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. 1 of three of clients were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current JV-220's on file. LPA attempted an interview with a client but they refused to be interviewed. No citations were given on this date. A signed copy of this LIC-809, report was provided to Rachel Underwood. An exit interview was conducted.

narrative: On 11/20/20 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted a telephone call follow up case management at the above facility and spoke with Chief Compliance and Quality Improvement Officer Maria Bhattachan regarding a Special Incident Report (SIR) that was submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on 11/07/20. The SIR indicated that a prolonged restraint was applied on client C1 (reference confidential names form LIC811 dated 11/20/20). Review of SIR indicated that C1 was put on a standing restraint by two (2) staff members after C1, who was placed on red flag by therapist, attempted to run out of the dorm. While in the restraint, C1 was transitioned to the ground by four (4) staff members due to C1's self-harming behavior by attempting to bang his head on the floor. One staff used a pillow to prevent any injury to C1's head. The restraint lasted for 25 minutes. C1 was released from the restraint as soon as it was determined that C1 is no longer threat to his own safety. Officer of the Day (OD) approved the prolonged restraint due to C1's red flag status as determined by the therapist. The Psychiatrist Mobile Response Team (PMRT) and police were called and arrived at the facility to assess C1. C1 was taken to the hospital for further assessment. C1's mother, county social worker (CSW) and the therapist were immediately notified of the incident. The restraint was reported timely to CCL and C1's placement agency. LPA reviewed the facility's Program Statement on Emergency Intervention. LPA found the restraint to be in accordance with the facility's Emergency Intervention Plan. Based on the information gathered, it was determined that no follow up is needed at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided Ms. Bhattachan for signature. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: On August 20, 2021 at 9am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin and Licensing Program Manager JoAunne Griffin arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection on the home. LPA met with Theresa Nunez, Residential Director who granted access into the home. The home was toured both inside and out. Currently residing in the facility is one client. The facility is licensed to care for six male children ages 13-17 years and non-minor dependents, ambulatory only. The home is located in a residential area and was set as follows: four bedrooms; two single-occupancy and two double-occupancy, all equipped with twin beds. Bedroom doors were observed to lock from the outside, however clients are able to open from the inside. There is ample closet and adequate drawer space is available. There are three bathrooms, observed in good repair and working order, living room/dining area, kitchen, and an attached garaged which has been converted into a rec room and laundry/storage area. There is an outdoor area including basketball court that is free of obstructions. The second floor of the facility is used as a staff area and includes the therapist's office, staff bathroom, and a storage room. The home was inspected and the following was observed: Facility is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. There are no swimming pools or bodies of water on the premises. Knives, disinfectants, cleaning solutions, and poisons are inaccessible to clients. Cleaning solutions are stored in hall closet and sharp knives are stored in staff office on first floor. Clients in care are supervised and protected at all times. Four cameras were observed on the exterior of the home. Cameras view is of the front right, left, center and left rear of home. Fire escape ladder is located on second floor exterior of home. Facility has ample perishable and non-perishable food. Three refrigerators and pantry were observed in garage converting into storage area. Facility provides nutritious between meal and snacks. Menu observed posted in kitchen area. Medications are locked/accessible only to employees Continued on LIC 809C responsible for stored medications. Psychotropic medicine is tripled locked in staff office. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights. Child's rights, grievance process and emergency disaster plan observed posted at entry door. Mental Health certification effective March 23, 2021 - March 22, 2022. Accreditation effective through May 31, 2025. Clients are not restricted in telephone use except by court order. Clients accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Clients live in a safe, healthy, comfortable facility and are treated with respect. Clients can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Clients attend school, extracurricular, cultural, and personal enrichment activities. Facility reports changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Facility reports client injuries requiring medical treatment. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Current and available for review. Designation/staff assignments current. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were working properly in the home. Fire extinguisher was available and last serviced September 9, 2020. There were no bars on the windows at the time of the visit. All posting requirements were met. The facility has a Ford Transit - 150XL van and Hyundai passenger vehicle to transport clients. Current automobile insurance is with Riverport Insurance Co. LPA will return at a later date to complete Annual Inspection. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit Interview was conducted with Teresa Nunez and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On August 25, 2021 at 12pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection Continuation on the home. LPA then went to the main office at N. Figueroa St. Los Angeles, CA 90042 to inspect the staff and client files. LPA met with Maria Bhattachan, Chief Compliance Officer and began my inspection of the files. LPA inspected staff file for Maggie Williams, House Supervisor hired 5-16-2011. File contained all the necessary documents which include Criminal Record Clearances, Personnel Records, Employee Actions, Child Abuse Clearances, Training, Education and medical requirements. Maggie also has a Conditional Certificate for the STRTP Administrator Certification Program. LPA inspected Client file for Takato Fortune DOB 6/10/2002. The client file had all Medical/Immunization Records available. The client had a complete and current Needs and Services Plan as well as current Mental Health and medication documentation. Staff interview was conducted with Theresa Nunez, Residential Director. The interview went very well and all questions were answered completely. LPA was unable to interview a client at this time. There were no deficiencies to report at this time.
